[[Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]

> Fragmenty iz istorii Srednei Azii ot o epokhe Nadir-shakha i Abdully-khana F33 O1 D140

This delo consists of only a couple pages, apparently written on scrap paper.  The handwriting resembles that of Kun's mirza, Abdurrakhman (see [[index|Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]).  Also, the only other time I have seen the Persian plural on the Arabic plural of faqir () is in Abdurrakhman's [[draft Iskandarkul expedition diary|Dnevnik mirzy Abdurrakhmana, vedennyi vo vremia puteshestviia po Bukhare i ee okrestnostiam (AV F33 O1 D217)]], which makes it somewhat more likely that this information was recounted orally; also see his use of the word  on p. 4, which he also uses to refer to establishing someone in a fortress in the diary.  The three pages have no relation to one another, so there are probably missing sections to these random notes.

Page 1 is about the conquests of Abdullahkhan (     ).

Page 2-3 are marred enough that I wasn't able to follow.

Page 4 on Nadir Shah (note the mirza's misspelling) is copied (almost) in its entirety:
      ( )     .   ()      
(unable to even record a sentence due to smudging)
      .      .      .       (  )    .              
The last line does not make any sense, could be in Turkish:        

I copied from this document because it is probably a kind of oral history collected by Kun when he passed through Bukhara. It is interesting how Nadir Shah came to be remembered when [[Hakim Khan's account|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Nadir Shah]] is quite different.  Also, one can see how Abdurrakhman's status as a mirza really was something quite distinct from an alim; in that he often writes things the way they sound rather than how they are spelled (e.g.  ).

[[Library Card Catalog at the Institute of Oriental Manuscripts, St. Petersburg]]

> I 10/48 - i, .       . , 1894.
> I. Gasprinskii, Tochnyi perevod dnevnika ego svetlosti Emira Bukharskago, (Kazan': Tipo-Litografiia Imperatorskago Universiteta, 1894).

Apparently this is exactly what it sounds like - the journal of the Emir of Bukhara during his visit to St. Petersburg.  It has a Russian translation along with a lithographed version of the Persian.  Need to check up on this.
[[RGIA Index]]

1396.1.342  8  1909-20  1909, ?,        ..       .    . 

    ;  .  (121).  Subsection:  (138).
* Puts the number of madrasas in Samarkand at 19 (138b).
*  lists the entire madrasa sequence of education. All madrasas organized into three "departments" (): beginning () [], intermediate () [], and advanced (') (138b).  //The numbering of the sequence is mine.//  Note from #9 p 139 begins.
** Beginning (): 
*** 1. Introduction to Arabic grammar:     "-"       " (138b).
*** 2. [???] Arabic grammar - no more than 3 months
*** 3. ['?] Arabic grammar - 3 months.
*** 4. [??] Arabic grammar - 3 months.
*** 5. [?] [ ] - 3 months.
*** 6. ""   [?] - 2 months.
*** 7. "'" Arabic grammar - 3 months.
*** 8. "  " [ ], Arabic grammar - 5 months.
*** 9. "" [ ] - 3 years. 
*** 10. " " commentary on Kofia - 5 years.
*** 11. "" logic.  a commentary on "" - 1 year.
*** 12. " -  - " jurisprudence () - 4 years.
** Intermediate ():
*** 1. " " [? ?] - 4 years.
*** 2. " [ ?] - 2 years.
*** 3. " " jurisprudence - 2 years.
** Advanced ('):
*** 1. "--[?] -  - 2 years. [along with?] ["   --"] 
*** 2. " "  - 2 years.
*** 3. "" jurisprudence - 5 years.
** Total years for the advanced sequence, according to Goriachin's tally, is 7-8 years.
* Meetings per week:       ... (139).
** I.e. classes do not meet on Thursday, Friday, and in some madrassas Sunday (139-139b).
* Listing the 5 most prominent (   ) in Samarkand: -,-, -, , [--] (139b).
* -: Founded in 1631 by -.  70 students living in khudjras, and 20 walk-ins () (139b).
** Of those 70 students, 32 were Tajiks, the rest Uzbek (139b).  //very interesting that this is a question of import in the first place.//
** Only one mudarris:  ----[].  "[]   " (139b).
** The madrassa also has two... "...  (): --[]   ---".  Both of them received their educations in Bukhara and Samarkand and (I think, but can't quite make out the script) that they were once students in the very same school: "           ??? ...     " (140).
** Explicitly references Nalivkin's 1892/1893 report with regard to the madrassa's waqf income (140): 360 rubles to the mutawalli; 1080 split between two mudarrises; 33 rubles per khujra, of which there are 54 (140b).
*** Now, the author notes, there is only one mudarris
* -: "       -  "-" -   610 -[]" (141b-142).  80 students, one or two walk-ins. 60 khujras (142).
** One Mudarris:    , 70 years old, educated in Samarkand (142).
** Most of the students are Tajik; only 10 Uzbek students (142).



[[Repository Index]]

Notes from 6/11/2012 meeting with Sanjar Gulomov
* Article is already a published in a collection of articles coming out of Japan - in the mail.
* This article is about the Institute's lesser-known document collection that ended up in the manuscript collection erroneously.
* He is partly drawing attention to this because the //actual// document collection is essentially closed to researchers until Goliba Juraeva publishes the catalog.  Sanjar says it is nearly finished, which probably means it is a decade away.
* Sanjar does not fully understand why these collections of original documents were ever even collated - which he thinks is an interesting question in its own right.  Part of the reason may be analogous to that of the //jung// - i.e. to pass on to future generations.

>Sandzhar Gulomov, "O nekotorykh podlinnykh dokumentakh iz kollektsii rukopisnykh proizvedenii fonda Instituta Vostokovedeniia AN RUz"

* The document collection is separate from the manuscript collection.  It consists of 88 folders, 2500 specimens (1).
* A major part of the collection is //insha'//, defined as: "...         ,  ,    ,   ,   " (1).
* Unlike the insha' (which by definition are copies of official correspondence), original collections (such as [[Mubraknmajt-i Amr Muaffar biq Mu al-Dn (al-Biruni 407)]]) were included in the manuscript collection because they were collated in such a way that they //appear// to be manuscripts.  "...        (    )    ,     ...         .    ,  -         ..." (2).
** One such document collection (which he identifies by  "",  959) includes documents related to madrasas.
* Sbornik 1740: Official correspondence of Muzaffar.
** Fatwas: " -     32 ////   902-934" (3).  
* Discusses [[Mubraknmajt-i Amr Muaffar biq Mu al-Dn (al-Biruni 407)]] directly, posing the question as to why it was described in [[Semenov|Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]] since it is obviously not a manuscript (3).
* From the bottom of p. 3 the article moves to discuss documents that: "...        ,       " (3).
** Inventory number 9530: includes 70 original documents.  Of them 68 are rivayat and two are legal suits (3).  They are most likely the product of a Tashkent qazi from the Russian period (4).
** Inventory number 6102: constitutes the biggest rivayat collection at al-Biruni, including 612 original documents, 609 of which are rivayyat.  Also appears to be from Tashkent, dealing with vaqfs in Tashkent (4).
** Inventory number 9749: 445 documents, of which 442 are rivayat.  This collection is from Bukhara during Abd al-Ahad (4).  P. 5 Gulomov puts together a family tree of the mullas writing the documents (5).
** Inventory number 2588: astrological writings, divination.  Also 151 rivayat.  This collection was the personal archive of Qazi Sayyid Kamara (5).  Also has some documents appointing a mudarris and qazi (6).
*** Pages 6-7 go on to describe these appointment documents in great details.
*** My notes: [[Personal Archive of Qazi Mir Sayyid Qamar (al-Biruni 2588)]]
* Bottom line on the collection's contents: ",      1456        9530, 6102, 9749, 2588,       .    2315     1740  407,      ,    ...  ,            ,    " (8).
[[Tonk Azad Library Index]]

> Hakim Ilahi, Tarikh-i Jahan Numa (Tonk 3227)

Shaukat Ali Khan, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Persian Manuscripts, Volume 1: History, Biography, Geography, Topography, Cosmography, Travel (Tonk, Rajasthan: Arabic and Persian Research Institute, 1987).
* p. 267, Catalog no. 433, Call no. Jaipur - 3227
* Tarikh-i Jahan Numa,   , Copied 13th/19th cent. ca. from the original transcript of the author written in his own hand.
* By Hakim Ilahi, known as Hakim ul-Hind.
* Ff. 138. Size 26x17 cm. Ll. 15. Script. Nasta'liq.  Ext. Comp. Cond. Good, wormeaten.
* "A general topographical account of the world in general derived from the English geographical and Persian historical works, comprising one Muqaddimah, two Maqalahs and one Khatimah.  The Muqaddimah is sub-divided into 12 Fusul absolutely reserved for topography and geography.  First Maqalah contains for Abwab dealing with eastern continents which is also divided and sub-divided into Fusul; the second Maqalah comprises two Abwab dealing with the accounts of western continents which was also divided and sub-divided into Fusul.  At the end, begins an account of the author's other works.  It is already collated by the author.  There are also marginal notes and corrections written in hand by the author himself as confirmed by a note superscribed over the title page..." (267-268).

[[Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]

Accessed from: http://zerrspiegel.orientphil.uni-halle.de/t1186.html
See also: http://zerrspiegel.orientphil.uni-halle.de/t1186.html and http://zerrspiegel.orientphil.uni-halle.de/t21.html

>  , -    . . 33 . 1  147.           (     ). 1870 .

!!!   
* Preamble, thanks be to God, etc:                        
* Author, Abid Akhund, studied in Bukhara, then got a job from the ruler, then came to Samarqand, appointed to the Ulugh Beg Madrasa in Samarqand:                                                 
* Then in 1282 the Russians came; describing who from Bukhara went to meet them in battle:                                                                                                                                
* Russia won, Bukhara lost; Russians enter Samarqand, conquer surrounding area:                                                                                                                      
* Jura Beg of Shahrisabz summoned an army and besieged the Russians in Samarqand for a while before returning to Shahrisabz:                                    
* Peace with Bukhara, fire in Samarqand:                                          
* Around that time Abid Akhund fled Samarqand to Urgut, then to Urmatin (sp.); gives some info about a Bukharan general who was in Urmatin, takes the chaos as an opportunity to take over four formerly Bukharan provinces
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

> PNB F924 D 596.  149 .  18 .

Opis description: . .  ,    .  18th century.  //note: I am unaware how the textologs determined the 18th century designation//

This is an all-purpose volume on practical fiqh.  It is organized by section in the standard order of Islamic law, but has a massive variety of entries - Arabic excerpts of various legal manuals, Persian riwayyat rulings, explanations.  The riwayyat in this volume seem to be somewhat more exemplary than in some of the other books; could very well be that they were copied rulings of other muftis.  Strikes me as a qazi's practical go-to book.
* Possibly originates from Samarkand?  On the first page (p. 2) it the first case reads:             ... (p. 2).  Also, and less convincingly, 146b references the word , which according to  is a specifically Samarkandi word for yoghurt (p. 146b).

!!!  (p. 88b)

[[Repository Index]]
[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

> O.M. Iastrebova, ed., Persidskie i Tadzhikskie dokumenty v Otdele Rukopisei Rossiskoi Natsional'noi Biblioteki (St. Petersburg: Izd. Rossiiskoi natsional'noi biblioteki, 1999).

As it turns out, the Russian National Library has a legitimate (though not vast) document collection, including, //inter alia//, a bunch of Samarkandi waqf documents from the 18th and 19th centuries (pp. 77-80).  Lots of stuff that //might// be interesting, relatively little that is spot-on.  Based on the introduction, the documents described in this book represent a fraction of the total.

Contents of this catalog:    248  246     ,  89  (13).  Organized based on whether they orginate from Iran (//section not scanned//) or Central Asia.

Organization of the Library's Fonds
*  
** "         1817 .      . . ,  -    (7).
** "     -,      -    -" (8).
** The  of the Caucauses,     aquired a bunch of farmans from Fath Ali-Shah and donated them to the library (8-9).
*    . . 
** More than 300 manuscripts in Persian, Turkish, and Arabic drawn from the Kokand and Khiva khanates, as well as approximately 4000 documents.
** No!  It all got transfered to the black hole of Tashkent: "...  23  1962 .   07-49-376              " (11).
*     ( )
*    .  
*  

!!!Central Asia Collection

Waqf documents
* 52. Kaufman 2. (p. 78).  A madrasa waqf in some village near Khazar.  Only of possible interest because of the early date - 1759.
* 54. Pers. dok. 58. (p. 78). Might be a good example of retaining wealth between generations via waqf. Samarkand 1835, parallel Russian translation. 10 pages.

Kupchi
* 60. Kaufman 5. (p. 81). A land sale in Kish 1777 only of note because it lists a lot of witnesses, many of whom are qazis, etc.  Of possible prosopgraphic use.

Dokumenty
* 64. Kaufman 6.  The qazi al-quzat of Samarkand secures a land grant in a village nearby, 1869.  [[Link to notes|Samarqand Qazi Land Ruling 1285 / 1869 (PNB F940 D6)]]
* 65. Pers. dok. 50. (p. 85).  1872-1873 document details the Kokand khan's attempt to mediate a land dispute between a mullah and someone else.  [[Link to notes|Khoqand Land Dispute Document 1289 / 1872f (PNB F1236 D50)]]
* 67. Pers. doc. 56. (p. 86).  Little information in catalog - something to do with the collection of court duties from different people - Mulla Kasim, Rais Namangana; Russian annotation.  [[Link to notes|Az Mullah Qasim, Ra'is-i Namangan - financial document (PNB F1236 D56)]]
James, 17 December 2011 (created 16 December 2011)]]
* 69. Kaufman 60. (p. 86).  At the very least gives us another qai al-quzat; instructions on what to do with his property.

Yarlyk
* 72. Kaufman 9 (p. 87).  Appointment of a qazi in   - wherever that is.  [[Link to notes|Yarliq appointing the Qadi Matchi 1222 / 1807f (PNB F940 Kaufman 9)]]

!!!f. 111b

[[Assorted Khuda Bakhsh (Patna) Catalogs]]

> Imm usayn Chisht, usayn Shh (Khuda Bakhsh, History of Afghanistan, 1799 c.e.)

  by     (cat. vol. 6, p. 196-201, no. 530) (hand list no. 83)
* 173 folios, completed 1799.  Indexed in catalog.
* "A detailed history of the dynasty of the Durrani Afghans, comprising the account of its origin and the reigns of Ahmad Shah Durrani, Timur Shah, and Shah Zaman, to A.H. 1212 = A.D. 1798" (196).
* History of the text: "We learn from the preface that in the middle of A.H. 1211 = A.D. 1797, when Shah Zaman was holding his court in Lahore, the author went to that city, and from thence proceeded with the king's army to Peshawar, where he devoted his leisure to the composition of a history of that prince and his family.  At the end of A.H. 1212 = A.D. 1798 he went to Lucknow, where he showed what he had written to a saint Khwajah Abu Muhsin Husayn ul-Hasani ul-Maududi ul-Kumhari.  The saint was delighted and presented him with a draft of a history of Ahmad Shah Durrani and Timur Shah.  The author incorporated it into his own work, and completed the history in the middle of A.H. 1213 = A.D. 1799, calling it after the saint,  " (p. 196).
* Also includes copies of letter written by the Durrani shahs, as well as descriptions of Chishti shrines, some geographic routes around the Punjab.
* Included in Storey (vol. 2, p. 1223), but described in more detail in the catalog.

!!!                      (p. 5b-8b)
* Opening (5b):            
* (cont.) The "Ghalcha" sultans in Qandahar had become week so Nadir Shah conquered them easily (5b):            [[                                        
** Dehkhoda on "Ghalcha":         
* Subduing Herat, re-appointing and incorporating the defeated - Nadir Shah incorporates the Sadozai army and takes it with him to attack Qandahar, but leaves the governor in charge of Herat (6):                     [   ]                                                          
** Dehkhoda on "Abdali" - this is where Ahmad Shah Durrani comes from:   .                          1160                   
* After a long siege, Nadir takes Qandahar due to the defection of a Mughal courtier.  Husayn Ghaljah, who rules Qandahar, is described as having Mughal courtiers (6):               
** It was actually Husayn's sister who surrendered (6b):                      
* Nadir Shah has mercy on Husayn Ghalcha, but sends him to Mazandaran in quasi-exile (6b):                          
* (cont.)  Zulfikar Khan and Ahmad Khan from the Abdalis were captives of Husayn Ghalcha, and Nadir Shah gives them great honor (6b):                                  [] 
* Destroyed the fortress in Qandahar, built a new one called NadirAbad (6b).
* Appointed Abd al-Ghani Alkozai governor of Qandahar, orders population transfer such that the Abdalis and Ghalchas switch places (4b-5):                                           
** (cont.) From this point forward, Qandahar is the homeland of the Abdalis (7):               
* Nadir Shah took Kabul by bombing it from up high (7):                 
* Nadir Shah ends up fighting Nasr Khan of the Mughals, who has an alliance with the Yusufzai Afghans, at the Khayber pass (7):   []                          
** Despite losing the battle and getting captured, Nasr Khan is appointed  governor (?) of Peshawar and Kabul (7):                             
* From the top of p. 5b the author states that there is no need to reiterate Nadir's conquest of India, which is already well-known, and he moves on to Ahmad Shah's background.
* Ancestors are from Multan, moved to Herat (7b):       ...                            
* Legitimacy tied to proximity to Nadir Shah (57b):                                                              
* Farting and succession to Nadir's throne - Nadir foresees Ahmad Shah becoming king (7b-8):                                                                                                                       

!!!                       (p. 61b
* Opening - Shah Murad is creating chaos by raiding Khurasan and Iran (61b):                               
* (cont.) Timur Shah prepares for war in Turkestan, Shah Murad begs forgiveness (62):              
* (cont.) Because Timur Shah is busy conquering Multan, his vazir turns a blind eye to Murad's transgressions (62):                              
* (cont.) Taking advantage of the reprieve, Murad takes Marv and transfers populations between there, Bukhara, and Shahrisabz (62):                                             
* (cont.) This news reached Timur Shah right about the time he got back from Multan, and he marched on Turkestan (62):                 
* Timur shah sends a letter to Murad, which is reproduced in the chronicle pp. 62-63b.
* Murad sends another letter of apology via Yusuf Khwajah along with esteemed individuals from his court (63b):                              [ = ]           [   ]     [ = ]     [ - //  //]                          
* (cont.) Sent a letter with Yusuf Khwajah on Bukhara's past claims to the territory around Balkh (63b-64):                                                                                                                                  
* (cont.) Instead of doing battle with Turkestan, they prepared to go on Ghazat in Hindustan (64):                                         []                      
* (cont.) The eminent individuals of Afghanistan discussed long and hard the prospect of invading Bukhara, but decided to forgive since they were Sunni Muslims (64-64b):                                                                             -         -                 

!!!                              (p. 71b-75)
* Opening - Haji Karim Bamizai, veteran of the Maratha wars appointed governor of Kashmir (71b):                             
* (cont.) Known for his cruelty, luckily he died (71):                    []        
* (cont.) Haji Karim's successors continued to rule Kashmir (71b):                                     
* (cont.) The youngest brother, Azadkhan, edged his older brothers out of power (72):                                   
* (cont.) He built himself a huge army and ignored royal tax (?) requests, raised rebellion (72):                []        []               []                               [] 
* A minister sends a spy, essentially, to Kashmir to advise a course of action (72).  He advises to teach Azadkhan a lesson (72b).
(cont.)

!!!Delhi

!!!Patna
* [[Assorted Khuda Bakhsh (Patna) Catalogs]]



[[National Archives of India Index]]

> Foreign Department. S.M. 1870. Nos. 45-48

"No. 47.  Translation of Statement of a person send [sic.] from Peshawur"
* "Having started from Peshawur, I reached Bokhara in 65 days as well be seen from the accompanying list A of stages and halts, and put up in the 'Serai' of Mulla Budroodeen with Atta Mahomed, a Bokhara merchant, who was kind enough to procure for me, from Samarcand, the purchases noted in list B."
* (cont.): "A few days before my arrival, the King of Bokhara had sent his younger son to Tashkund with one lakh of Tillas (one tilla equals 6 1/2 Rupees) and the Prince did not return during my stay in Bokhara."
** [From subsequent page]: "The lack of Tillas forwarded by the king to the Russians were borrowed by him from the merchants, but he has now paid the debt."
* (cont) Trade conditions: "Since the Russians have taken possession of Tashkund and Samarcund, the import of piece goods from India has ceased, though the trade has not been forbidden by them.  If any merchandise fails to sell at Bokhra it is taken to Samarcund, but the profits realized are less than those relized before the Russians conquered the country.  The consumption of cloth goods in Bokhara has not decreased, and tea and indigo goods are also consumed in the countries conquered by the Russians.  Articles exported from Bokhara are taxed at the rate of Rs. 2-8 per cent on value.  ('Chil-o-ek') in Tashkund, and the goods exported from the latter place are exempted from taxation..."
* "The people of Bokhara generally are displeased with the king, not only on account of his conduct* [footnote: 'Explains that the King was already unpopular from seizing peoples' daughters and carrying them off to his zenana'], but also because of his having given up his country to the Russians without opposing them."
* (cont.) Geopolitics: "On my departure from Bokhara, the King was in Kurshee, and had sent his troops against Kulab.  The Meer of Shuhr-i-Subz, who was formerly on bad terms with the King, has now become his friend, the latter has therefore forwarded as a khillut ten thans of cloth together with ten horses to the former."
* (cont.) Military: "Sirbuland Khan, Afghan, who went to the King from Cabul, has entertained five Infantry Regiments for him which are called 'Surbaz.'  There are 80 guns in Bala-Hissar of Bokhara, of which 30 lie on the ground, and 50 are on carriages.  Of these 50 guns, only 15 are serviceable, gunners, ammunition, &c., are wanting for the remainder."
** "(//Volunteered//) The Bokhariots are not up to fighting, no use whatever, very inferior to the Afghans.  Their cavalry soldiers wear only a sword or knife, and the footmen flint-lock guns."


/***
|''Name:''|IntelliTaggerPlugin|
|''Version:''|1.0.2 (2007-07-25)|
|''Type:''|plugin|
|''Source:''|http://tiddlywiki.abego-software.de/#IntelliTaggerPlugin|
|''Author:''|Udo Borkowski (ub [at] abego-software [dot] de)|
|''Documentation:''|[[IntelliTaggerPlugin Documentation]]|
|''~SourceCode:''|[[IntelliTaggerPlugin SourceCode]]|
|''Licence:''|[[BSD open source license (abego Software)]]|
|''~CoreVersion:''|2.0.8|
|''Browser:''|Firefox 1.5.0.2 or better|
***/
/***
!Version History
* 1.0.2 (2007-07-25): 
** Feature: "Return" key may be used to accept first tag suggestion (beside "Alt-1")
** Bugfix: Keyboard shortcuts (Alt+3 etc.) shifted
* 1.0.1 (2007-05-18): Improvement: Speedup when using TiddlyWikis with many tags
* 1.0.0 (2006-04-26): Initial release

***/

e=createTiddlyElement(_121,"a");e.setAttribute("href","http://tiddlywiki.abego-software.de/#IntelliTaggerPlugin");e.innerHTML="<font color=\"black\" face=\"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif\">"+t+"<font>";},copyright:function(_124){var e=createTiddlyElement(_124,"a");e.setAttribute("href","http://tiddlywiki.abego-software.de");e.innerHTML="<font color=\"black\" face=\"Arial, // %/

[[Oral History Index]]

> Interview with: Abd al-Ghafur Razzakov - 10 August 2014

Interview took place in his home with Nasriddin, conducted in Persian.

Interviewee had a tattoo, suggesting he served in the army.

* Studied in Mir-i Arab until 1975.  His teachers there studied in many different places before the Revolution.
* Madrasas were still in operation up to the early 1930s; they weren't all closed in the 1920s.
* At that point many fled.
* Presented a published, full color book of calligraphy from his personal collection.
* Dahyek: After graduating the madrasa the students would go to the group (jamoa) of qazis, who would then examine the students' knowledge from the Hidaya; those who were successful would get this money.
** You could only get the dahyek in Bukhara.  For instance his teacher from Andijan did not receive the Dahyek, but his other teachers from Bukhara received it.
** It was for 120 tanga.  The tanga was silver; this was good money.
** This would also qualify you to become a mudarris.
* Hierarchy: At first after graduating you become a mudarris; a hire teaching rank is akhund (daraja-yi 'ilmi); then a'lam.  All of these ranks taught in the madrasa.
** They could not act as a mufti (or qazi) until they achieved the rank of akhund or a'lam.
** Rais was considered higher than a mufti.
* Shaykh al-Islam and Qazi al-Quzat were two separate ranks, but equal to each other.
** The Qazi al-Quzat oversaw and appointed the raises and other qazis.  This was also a more political position.
** The Syakh al-Islam was more concerned with documents.

From 13:24
* The hujras just dictated where the students would live. They moved around attending lessons in whatever madrasas they wished depending on what text they needed to learn.
** The students themselves chose which lessons to attend based on what they needed to achieve and what specialists were teaching at the time.
* Mentioned Damulla Ikromcha, who was a specialist in fiqh; Abd al-Rashid was a specialist in Aqa'id.
* Mawlavi as a rank for completing the Hidaya or Sahih-i Bukhari is not a rank in Transoxiana; it was familiar as a South Asian rank.
* Prep school: Damullaha-yi Kunjakiy performed a kind of prepping service after maktab but before madrasa. They would pay for this privately.
* Most famous ulama in Bukhara: Damulla Ikromcha; Domulla Khl'murad.
* Mufti-yi Askari was not a higher rank than other muftis, just more specialized.
* The madrasa education was entirely in Arabic.  There were a few books in Persian like the introductory Chahar Kitab; one of the authors of this book was Khwaja Atar Wali.
** The language of instruction was Persian.
* Arabic qasidas were studied alongside Persian poetry to some degree.

From 30:30
* Said that the children of Indian merchants studied in Bukhara.
* Once the Mir-i Arab reopened in 1946, students did not return from Afghanistan. The borders were still closed. Contacts between families were limited to nonexistent.
* Once it reopened many of the students were from Khoqand, Tashkent.
* If you wanted a high rank in the emirate, you had to study in an Bukharan madrasa.  Also the dahyek was really important.
* Named Samarqand as a possible second best place for Islamic education; but after Bukhara it's really in other countries.
* Wasn't sure when the Dahyek originated, but thinks from the middle ages.  It means 1/10 of the khan's property.
* Said that the students in the hujras in Chorbakr slept there and then studied in Bukhara.
* Tasawwuf was not separated from the Islamic education; they were only recently separated into separate categories.
* Emphasized that the Naqshbandiyya were much more prevalent than other brotherhoods like the Qadiriyya or Yasawiyya.

From 40:00
* Jinn - if problems became to great, the Qazis would involve Qaris to recite the Quran repeatedly to exorcize the jinn.
** Recently in Bukhara a person came to the interviewees home to ask for help because his own home had become haunted (ba khana-yi man hamin khayli muammo dosht. Shumo ba "m ch es" (minesterstvo chrezvychainiye situatia) murojat kuni, na ba man).  The interviewee went to the house to help but didn't specify what he did, just that he solved the problem.
* As far as the occult, he agreed that they were widespread before the revolution but - unlike poetry, which people continued to practice from privately held manuscripts - occult practices were widely forgotten.
** He referenced a book called Shams al-Ma'arif for information on the occult.
** His own teachers had studied the occult in their educations, but did not continue to teach them in the Soviet period.
* Modern falbinha, according to interviewee, exist for fitna.

From 1:00:00
* Reason the Kukaltash was so respected was because the salary was 250 tanga, as opposed to the usual 150.  This was why those with the rank of Akhund always wanted to teach there.
* Interviewee's silsila to the Yakka-Bagh prince-cum-calligrapher: Interviewee - Ghulamjan - Abdallah Bik "Yakkabaghi"
** See [[Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]]
** According to Ghulamjan, Abdallah Bik was very "daqiq nazar."  Sometimes he would spend two hours shaving a qalam (Abdallah Bik yak qalam ra du soat me taroshid).
** Being his student was in high demand; everyone wanted to, but not everyone was able to.  He only accepted the very best students.




[[TsGARUz Index]]

> i-126 / 2 / 6100 (May 1917)

Russian and Persian correspondence between Resident in Bukhara (conveying info from consulate in Kashgar) to Qushbegi.

f. 4-4b: "M.I.D. Rossiiskoe Rezidentstvo v Bukhare 25 Maia 1917"
* Russian consul in Kashgar informed the resident that their senior trader in Yarkend ( ) that Sa'id Khodja Mohammad Ruzybaev, a native of Bukhara, died and left behind some property (f. 4).
* Requesting that the Qushbegi order an investigation () to see if he has any living descendants in the place of his birth (4-4b).
* If there are any descendants, they should personally go to Kashgar or send a representative to collect the effects (4b).

f. 3: Persian letter - 4 June 1917
* Bukharan chancellery response to former.
* Also uses the Russian suffix to refer to the end of Sayyid Khwaja's name:     
* Sent someone to ask around amongst the merchants () from that region.
* Not true that he left behind a widow or heir:           
* Bukhara indeed ordered an investigation as requested, but could find no evidence that he was from Bukhara:                   

i-126/2/6072
* This is a very similar case, except on Igamberdy Mansur Khodjaev dies in Kashgar itself.  Qazi Kalan's office replies that they cannot find any of his heirs.




[[National Archives of India Index]]

> Foreign Department 1850, Secret, Consultation 22 March, No. 71-72

"Items of Cabul Intelligence up to 31st December, 1849" (9).
* Lamenting Afghan disunity: "The Ameer and his Brother, in Durbar, were heard to say, that when the Afghans were true to each other and of one mind they took Hindoostan; but since discussions arose, they had not only lost Hindustan, but also their own country, and that now again thier [sic.] was no unity among them, for when any of the Sirdars were ordered on any duty, they made excuses and did not obey" (9).
* Khulum: "3. Sirdar Akram Khan had written to his Father that the Meer Wullie was in great straits, an dwas about to fly from Khoolum, which he would give up if the Ameer would allow him the country of Khoorum, Hybuk, and Sirbagh. 4. Later intelligence reported Akram Khan having taken possession of Khoolum" (9-10).
* "Peshawar [DyCours?] Office, the 10th January 1850. True translation [foll. by.?] H. P. Lawrence, Dy. Commissioner.

[[Repository Index]]
[[Card Catalogue of the Firdawsi Library]]

A. Iunusov, Fehrasti Dastnavishoi Tojik-Forsii Kitobkhonai Davlatii RSS Tojikiston Ba Nomi Abdulqosim Firdavs (Dushanbe: Vazprato Madaniiati RSS Tojikiston Kitobkhonai Davlatii Respublikavii ba Nomi Firdavs, 1971).

Samariia  by     (p. 35, 8.  655)  [[Link to notes|Qr Mash Tamhd Samarqand, Samariyyah, 1957]]
* Author born in 1310/1892.  Work written in 1377 / 1957.  91 pages
* On the author:               .
* A history of Samarkand and its environs:             ,      .

Tabaqat al-Shu'ara   by     (p. 43-44, 13.  1074)
* Written in 1295 / 1878 in Arabic.
* Not totally sure if this is actually about the 19th century of if it is just a reprint.
*        ,     ...
* Acquisition:   -    ,  11  . 1962    .

Fava'id al-Asrar   by       (p. 171, 113. 1334)
* A sufi work written in 1281/1861 in Farghana.

Maqasid al-Salikin   (p. 174, 117.  745/II)
* A sufi work composed in 1140/1727, scribed in 1295/1878 - probably in Bukhara.

[[Repository Index]]

> Iu. Iusupova and R. P. Dzhalilova, Sobranie vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii nauk Respubliki Uzbekistan. Istoriia (Tashkent: Izdatel'stvo 'Fan' Akademii nauk Respubliki Uzbekistan, 1998).

Guide to the al-Biruni collections: The Collection of Oriental Manuscripts of the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Uzbekistan AKA     .       

!!!Manghit History

  Khanskii Podarok p. 176, #436, 5359/II
* Alternative title: Tarikh-i Rakhim-khani
* Author: Akhund Mulla Mukhammad Vafa b. Mukhammad Zakhir Kerminagi, Kadi Vafa (1096/1685-1183/1769).
* Scope: Covers events from 1134/1722-1182/1769, from the reign of Mukhammad Rakhim (1167/1753-1171/1758) to the beginning of the rule of Danial-bey (1171/1757-1199/1785).  Dushanbe copy (Kat. AN Tadzh., I, No. 105) covers an additional 14 years to 1196/1782.

      Pobedy Amir Ma'suma (Shah-Murad) and Amir Khaidara p. 179, #498, 40/IV
* Author: Mirza Mukhammad Sadik "munshi" (d. 1235/1819).  Secretary for Shah-Murad (1199/1785-1215/1800) and Haidar (1215/1800-1242/1826).  Author was also a poet.
* Description: This is a poetical account of the conquests of Shah-Murad and Amir Haidar

!!!Travel

        p. 375, 897; 5255/XVIII; l. 150b-155a
* Bukharan mulla does the pilgrimage to Najaf and Karbala in 1743 / 1744. Describes meeting with Shah of Iran (i.e. Nadir Shah?) and religious disputes with Iranian mullas.

     p. 377, 900; 2106, 153 l.
* This is Vazih (of the poetical anthology)'s hajnamah.  He goes via Istanbul.
* In 1904 a lithograph was produced in Kagan (i.e. Bukhara).  Copied by hand numerous times as well.

    p. 378, 904; 9379/III l. 154b-159b.
* Written by Kokandi Mulla Mirza 'Alim in 1888.  Goes through Bukhara and then Istanbul.  Chaghatai.

   p. 379, 907; 2142, 190 l. [[Sirj al-Dn Bukhr, Tufah-i Ahl-i Bukhr (al-Biruni 2142)]]
* Written by a Bukharan merchant about his travels to Russia and back in 1911.


[[Jung Literature from al-Biruni Card Catalog]]

This jung is of the fiqh genre - i.e. like [[10922|Jng-i Fatw wa Riwyt wa Masyil-i Fiqhya (al-Biruni 10992)]], for instance, it is composed almost exclusively of Arabic-language excerpts from fiqh manuals.  Because of a Turki inscription dating to 1340 on the back inside cover, Saidakbar believes it to be a Khorezmian jung.

[[Jung Literature from al-Biruni Card Catalog]]

> Jung-i Fari va Masat va Rivyt

9749      

General Observations
* A jung collection of transcriptions and many original documents both of mahzarat and rivayat.
* Poorly paginated; sometimes there are no page numbers, sometimes they are repeated.  Usually the original documents are paginated with pencil.
* The original rivayat documents themselves are arranged by topic.

* Earliest date (6): 1300
* Latest date (page after doc 15): 1323

[[Jung Literature from al-Biruni Card Catalog]]

> Jung-i Masai'l-i Fiqhiyya (al-Biruni 6029) [cited as Jung-i Muammad hir, ms. IVANUz 6029]

General remarks: This jung is almost exclusively Arabic fiqh excerpts and Persian masa'il, with a few actual riwayat tucked in.  If a general issue is clear from the Arabic fiqh, some sections are entirely left at that; the Persian masa'il contextualize the Arabic fiqh for Central Asia.  Unlike other jungs, there is very little extracurricular material, such as poetry, medicine, or occult (though there is some Sufi material).  The issues (masa'il) are well labeled to the extent that this would be a good source for getting a holistic sense of legal thinking of the period.

Colophon (523b)
* (1)     [] 
* (2)      [
* (3)     
* (4)    
* (5)  
* (6)      
* (7)     
* (8)     
* //note: preceded (ff. 521b-523b) by a narrative of a shaykh of some kind; damaged and difficult to read; seems to conclude in 899 h.//

__             __ (p. 475)

> Jung-i Rivyt (al-Biruni 4798)

4798  
* Date listed in card catalog: 1183 h.

General Observations:
* This book of rivayats is carefully organized into chapters per the standard organization of fiqh manuals, not unlike [[Sbornik vypisok iz sochinenii po fikkhu i iuridicheskikh kazusov (PNB F924 D558)]], which also dates to the 18th century.
* In comparison with other fatwa collections, this jung is very heavy on explanation.  In many sections a few exemplary rivayat will be offered, and then the bulk of the chapter actually consists of extensive excerpts from fiqh, etc.  The citations are also much more thorough, often specifying specific page and chapter numbers.


!!!          

Note: All of the cases and excerpts from p. 432-440 are about vocal zikr and rule in favor of it.

Encouraging the vocal zikr in the Kubrawiyya order (432)

[[Jung Literature from al-Biruni Card Catalog]]

> Jng-i Fatw wa Riwyt wa Masyil-i Fiqhya

10992       
* Massive book > 800 folios.

!!!

Jung almost entirely composed of Arabic excerpts from fiqh.  It is a "jung" in the sense that there are fatwas / riwayats inserted into different pages of the text and it has shorthand notes scribbled in various places; it clearly seems to be a practical aid.

!!!Notes on inside cover and first few pages:
* Combined with note from backside cover, seems that this jung belonged to rais of Kulab (2b):                  

!!!Notes on the back cover:

Large seal:              

A valid loan
* (1)           
* (2)           
* (3)       
* (4)         
* (5)        
* (6)  some kind of forumla

Noting the death of Badr al-Din and his replacement Muhammad Baqa Khwaja, at which time the author was ra'is of Kulab
* (1)             
* (2)              
* (3)           
* (4)       
* (5)

[[Jung Literature from al-Biruni Card Catalog]]

> Jng-i Masil wa Wqit (al-Biruni 8887) 

General remarks:
* Card catalog has the author as         //but I don't see that reference yet//
* A much tidier work than many of the other jungs.  Also wider pages.
* Organized by fiqh topic, composed of issues / questions (masala), a short Persian sentence or two, and Arabic references.

[[National Archives of India Index]]

> 1884 Foreign Department.  Secret - E. Pros. April 1884, Nos. 258-266. News-letters from the British Agent at Kabul, Nos. 16 to 23 of 1884.

"Translation of a letter from Lieutenant-Colonel Sardar Muhammad Afzal Khan, C.S.I. British Agent at Kabul, to the Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department, No. 18, dated Kabul, the 4th March 1884." (1).
* Bukharan Haj pilgrim: "On the same date I learnt that Haji Sayyiad Masum, a native of Bokhara, who travelled from Peshawar to Kabul, remained there for a few days; that the Amir exempted him from paying any duty on the goods he had brought; and that at the time of his departure His Highness presented him with a khilat consisting of a Khalil Khani shawl and a chogha of kinkhab, and his nine servants with an embroidered lungi and a chogha made of broadcloth each, and asking him to bring Russian goods for sale to Kabul, as, His Highness said, he would thereby save the duty" (2).

"Translation of a letter from Lieutenant-Colonel Sardar Muhammad Afzal Khan, C.S.I. British Agent at Kabul, to the Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department, No. 20, dated Kabul, the 11th March 1884." (1).
* "On the same date I learnt that a certain man, known as Haji, a native of Samarkand, who arrived at Kabul last year and stated before the Amir that he was a prisoner in Samarkand, and that having effected his escape from there was proceeding to India, and to whom the Amir presented Rs. 100 for road expenses, has just returned to Kabul from India and intimated his intention to His Highness to go back to Samarkand. The Amir thinking that he has told lies and imprisoned him with his two servants" (1).

"Translation of a letter from Lieutenant-Colonel Sardar Muhammad Afzal Khan, C.S.I. British Agent at Kabul, to the Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department, No. 22, dated Kabul, the 18th March 1884." (1).
* "On the 18th instant I learnt that a certain @@astrologer@@ had written to the Amir from Turkistan to the effect: - 'Nauroz is drawing near.  According to the Muhammadan system of astrological calculations there will be wars amongst great kings in the ensuing year, but that the Muhammadans will come out victorious, and that the party, whom the Amir will assist, will triumph.  White dress should be worn by all on the day of the Nauroz." (2).

"Translation of a letter from Lieutenant-Colonel Sardar Muhammad Afzal Khan, C.S.I. British Agent at Kabul, to the Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department, No. 23, dated Kabul, the 21st March 1884." (1).
* "On Thursday, the 20th instant, the festival of Nauroz was observed, and I was invited by the Amir to take part in the festivities held in the garden of King Babar.  All the Sardars, the Khans and the officials were present there.  Only the Amir was attired in a white robe*.  [Sidenote: 'It seems that the Amir acted up to the advice of the astrologer.  //Vide// Sardar's letter No. 22, dated 18th March 1884.  2-4-84. (Sd.) K.S.A.]  First, sweetmeats and fruits of different kinds were brought and distributed and then the repast was served up." (2).




[[Master Index]]

* (Anonymous) //Baharistan-i Shahi// (Tonk no. 1146)
** to 1023/1614.
* Hasan b. Ali Kashmiri, //Tarikh-i Kashmir// (Tonk no. 1148)
** to 1024/1615.
* [[Muhammad Azam Dyadmari, Waqiat-i Kashmir|Muhammad Azam, Waqiat-i Kashmir (Indian National Archive no. 319)]]
** Author died in 1721, covers events from pre-history to that point.
** Initial notes from copy at the [[Indian National Archives|Indian Archives and Libraries Index]]; full scan from Vostfak Library.
*** Urdu translation (Khuda Bakhsh) by Munshi Ashraf Ali; used in Zutshi, Past as Tradition, Past as History."
** Badi al-Din Abul Qasim M. Aslam Mun'imi b. Maulawi  M. A'zam Kul Mustaghni, //Gauhar-i 'Alam Tuhfatan lil-Shah// or //Gauhar Namah-i 'Alam// (Tonk no. 1157): "A history of Kashmir based on the Waqi'at-i Kashmir of Khwajah M. A'zam. Composed in 1190/1776."
** Another title: //Lub al-Tawarikh//, also by Dyadmari, almost certainly the same history (Tonk no. 1156)
* Abd al-Qadir Khan (Ghulam Qadir Khan b. Wasil Ali Khan Ja'isi), //Hashmat-i Kashmir// (Tonk no. 1158)
** composed in 1245 / 1830.
** Tonk catalog suggests this has been published, but does not say where.
*  Birbal Kachar (Kacheroo), //Majmu-'al Tawarikh// (Tonk no. 1159)
** 1262 / 1846
** Covers earliest times to the "last rule of the Punjab Sikhs in Kashmir. Various MSS. of the work are preserved in the Research and Publication Department, Srinagar, Kashmir. Besides the political history of Kashmir, it is an ample record of Kashmir springs sacred to the Brahmins of this country" (Ibrahim, 24).
* Mirza Saif-ud-Din, //Khusalat-al-Tawarikh//, 1862. (Tonk no. 1161).
** "One copy of the work is preserved in the Research and Publication Department, Srinagar" (Ibrahim 24).
* Mulla Abdul Nabi, //Wajiz-al-Tawarikh//
** 1274 / 1857
**  "great source for later Mughal period in Kashmir" (Ibrahim, 24).
* Mulla Khalil Mirjanpuri, //Tarikh-i-Kashmir//
** close of 19th century
* G.H. Khuihami, //Tarikh-i-Hasan//
** Urdu trans. Shamsuddin Ahmed, Shams-u-Tawarikh: Farsi Tarikh-i Hassan Jild Awwal ka Urdu Tarjamah, Srinagar, 2003; used in Zutshi, Past as Tradition, Past as History."
* //Tarikh-i-Kabir//
* Muhammad al-Din [[Fawq, Hikayat-i Kashmir]]
** 1928
** Edited edition published by Khuda Bakhsh
* H.M. Chadurah, //Tarikh-i Haider Malik Chadurah//
** Haidar Malik, //Tarikh-i Kashmir// (probably the same) available Tonk no. 1149.
** Urdu trans. Razia Bano, History of Kashmir, Delhi, 1991;  used in Zutshi, Past as Tradition, Past as History."

Biographical dictionaries: "Besides these historical works, there are other sources of Kashmir's history in the Mughal period. These are Tubfat-ul-Fukra by Mulla Mohd. Murad Teng, Khawariq-al-Salikeen, Tazkirah of Mulla 'Ali Raina, Fathal-i-Kubrawiyyab, Khamsa of Mulla Baba-ul-Din Matto, and Tazkerab Hadrat-i-Qadiriyya.

!!!Kazan Catalogs
* A.A. Arslanova, Opisanie rukopisei na persidskom iazyke Nauchnoi biblioteki im. N.I. Lobachevskogo Kazanskogo gosudarstvennogo universiteta, Vypusk 1(Moscow-Kazan: Kazanskii rosudarstvennyi universitet, 2005).
* C.M. Giliazutdinov, Opisanie rukopisei na persidskom iazyke iz khranilishcha Instituta Iazyka, Literatury i Iskusstva, 3 vols. (Kazan: Fiker, 2002).

!!!Sources

* [[Ramz, Talfq al-Akhbr wa Talq al-Athr fi Waqi Qazn wa Bulghr wa Mulk al-Tatr (1908)]]
* [[Tarikh-i Mu'aziya (Orenburg,1908)]]
* [[Qursavi - Ule'ge khekem itelue, Bukhara 1823 (KUL F520)]]
[[Imperial Russian Sources]]

> O. Kerenskii, Nashi uchebnyia zavedeniia: Medrese Turkestanskago kraia, in Zhurnal" ministerstva narodnago prosveshcheniia No. 11, Turkestanskii Sbornik: Stati i zametki iz russkikh i inostrannykh razet" 418 (Tashkent, 1892).

For backstory on Kerenskii, see [[Argutinskii (1909) l polozhenii narodnoro obrazovaniia v Turkestanom krae i o deiatel'nosti F. Kerenskoro (RGIA F1396 O1 D337)]].

//Note: first page number is from the Turkestanskii Sbornik, the second is from the article iteslf//
* Article based on two sources of data: Government data and the observations of private observers (1/18).
* Traces the foundatin of the majority of madrasas in Samarkand, Kokand, and Tashkent to the 15th century (1/18).
* Physical features of the madrasa: "... ,     (),      (), -, -,  ,   , , , " (1/18).
* Average size of the sells was "3  6 . " (arshin = 0.71 m) which held 3-4 mullas (1/18).
* Kerenskii's description of life in the cells is one of gloom and cold: "      ,     " (2/19).
* Every madrassa has a mosque between the cells and classrooms (2/19).
* The outward appearance of madrassas in Bukhara and Khiva are the same as those in Turkestan.
* Author notes that small madrassas are of a different type than those he described; i.e. small wooden ones with external mosques, etc (2/19).
* Most madrassas are to be found in large cities and bazaar towns ( i).  They are usually located at the center of the town near the bazaar (2/19).
* At this point Kerensky gets into a discussion of __waqf__.  He notes that all waqfs are establihsed by private indviduals.  While many were founded by the emirs, they acted in the capacity of private individuals, not as from the state "     ,    " (3/20).
* According to Kerensky, Kokand enjoys pride of place in terms of quality of madrassas and waqf revenue (though he is probably talking about Turkestan):          . .   34      64  (3/20).
* Kerensky notes the presence in many madrassas of "holy hair" from the Prophet's beard, i.e. mui-mubarak.  In Tashkent he notes that in 1857 the Hakim Mirza-Akhmat built a madrassa that is known known as the Medrese-i Mu-yi Mubarak (3/20).
* Has some discussion of the legal procedure for when a waqf falls into disrepair or becomes unprofitable and needs to be entrusted to someone else (4/21).
* Kerensky notes the various sorts of trusts that can be set up (including cash and slaves, which he notes are rare), as well as the possibility of books:  ,      ,     ,     ;   .   ,  ,    ,  ,    ,        (4/21).
[[Repository Index]]

> A. B. Khalidov, Arabskie rukopisi Instituta vostokovedeniia: Kratkii Katalog, (Moscow: Izd. "Nauka" Glavnaia redaktsiia vostochnoi literatury, 1986).

"In 1915-1916 V. A. Ivanov bought in Bukhara and delivered to the Asiatic Museum 1057 volumes (the Bukhara Collections)" (523).

* 1842: [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]] //Persian//
** [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh: Khoqand through Alim Khan]]
* 1869: [[Mull Ava Muammad, Tufat al-Tawrkh Khn (IVRSP C 440)]] //Persian//

* [[Materialy po istorii Ura-Tiube (trans Mukhtarov)]]

[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]
[[Iastrebova, Persidskie i Tadzhikskie dokumenty v Otdele Rukopisei Rossiskoi Natsional'noi Biblioteki]]

The text of this very short document is clearer than some others ([[for instance|Yarliq appointing the Qadi Matchi 1222 / 1807f (F940 Kaufman 9)]]) so I have transcribed it entirely.

* Note how polite the language of this request from the Khoqand khan is.

* (10)         [ ] 1289
[[National Archives of India Index]]

> 1893 Foreign Department. Secret F. Pros. September 1893, Nos. 368-382. Khorassan Agency news-letters for the period from the 8th July to the 4th August 1893. G.C. Press, Calcutta - 8.

//Note: further notes about this file in the [[Russian Khorasan tiddly|file:///C:/Users/James/Documents/Academics/Academic%20Notes%20%28TiddlyWiki%29/Russia%20and%20Iran%20research%20project.html]]//

"Dated Chahil Dukhteran, Herat, the 12th August 1893"
"Translation of a news-report sent by Colonel Yate, dated Camp Chahil Dukhteran, the 9th of August 1893" (1).
* Premise: "Kewal, Hindu, an inhabitant of Shikarpur, together with four other Hindus, arrived here last night.  He went to Bokhara 23 years ago for the purpose of carrying on mercantile transactions.  He has now come here from Bukhara via Merv and Sheikh Junaid; and he reports as follows -" (1).
* "Formerly the Russians used to carry on their mercantile transactions through the medium of the servants of the Amir of Bokhara.  But now they transact direct such business of sale and purchase with the town people without any medium whatever; and the Russians are also building new houses in the 'serais' for their mercantile transactions" (1).
* (cont.) "Formerly the Bokhara 'Tungas' were much in use in Bokhara, and the Russian 'Tungas' were not in much use; and at that time 60 Bokhara Tungas were equivalent in value to 100 Russian Tungas.  But now, although the Russian Tungas contains a good deal of copper, they are much in use and circulation" (2).
* "At present the Amir of Bokhara exercises sole authority in Bokhara; and the Russians have not as yet interfered in any way in its Government by the Amir of Bokhara.  But the Russians exercise their own authority in their own cantonments" (2).
* (cont.) "At present there are about 300 Hindus and 300 Mussulmans, British Indian subjects, in Bokhara itself.  The Russians have expelled all Hindu British Indian subjects from Samarkand on the plea of their charging heavy interest on their money lent" (2).




[[National Archives of India Index]]

> 1893 Foreign Department. Secret F. Pros. May 1893, Nos. 363-368. Khorassan Agency news-letters for the three weeks ending the 9th April 1893.  G.C. Press, Calcutta - 8.


(For more notes from this file, see the "Russian Khorasan" tiddly)

"No 88-A., dated Meshed, the 8th April 1893.  From - E.C. Ringler Thomson, Esq., Her Britannic Majesty's Acting Consul General for Khorasan and Sistan, and in charge of the Khorasan Agency, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department." (1).
* "Daragez. L. News-letter dated 22nd march 1893. Received Meshed 3rd April 1893" (5).
** Direct comparison of Bukhara with the Princely states: "23rd march 1893 - A traveller from Bokhara states that during recent visits to St. Petersburg the Amir of Bokhara agreed to maintain a force of two thousand cavalry and to place it at the disposal of the Russian Government in case of necessity" (5-6).
*** "Remarks: "This is probably true.  The Russian took a leaf out of our book in making Bokhara appear on the same footing as one of our Native Indian States. Now they are going to have Imperial Service Troops. (Sd.) E.R.T" (6).

[[Imperial Russian Sources]]

> Aleksandr Pavlovich Khoroshkhin, Uzbeki Kenegez: Etnograficheskii ocherk, Turkestanskii Sbornik vol. 116 (St. Petersburg, 1876): 516-519.

Introduction by P. Maev
* Author, Khoroshxin was a an officer who participated in the Bukharan, Khivan, and Khoqand campaigns; he was killed in the Khoqand one in 1875 (

 :  
* Shahrisabz pronounced "" in local parlance (516).
* Remarks that the Russian forces there in 1870 did not collect detailed data in the general chaos (516).
* Population divided between cities of Shar and Kitab (516).
* Citadel of Shar: " ,      .    -         ,     ,    " (516-517).
** Walls of the citadel were once 100 arshins high, but have since crumbled (517).
** Recounts a local legend about how Timur ordered his retinue to jump off the top to catch a letter he tossed off the side bearing ill news (517).
* Explanation of their consistent independence from Bukhara - combination of mountainous reaches and water barriers of the province (which was never fully subdued by the Bukharans): "     () ,    ,  ,             ,   ,             ,     " (517).
* Nasrallah's attempts to conquer Shahrisabz lasted over ten years.  He resorted to sieges cutting off resources, which led to scurvy in the population: "...   , ,         ,      ..,         -     " (517).
** Author claims that Nasrallah ended up paying for the victory with his life; as the Kenagis women are renowned for their beauty.  Specifically, Nasrallah took away 's bride, who was famous for her beauty, the sister of the ruling Bek Iskandar (517).
** But she loved her husband, and - according to legend - she slipped quicksilver into Nasrallah's ear while he was sleeping: "     ,  ,          ,  , ,  " (518).
** When she was discovered, her [throat - ] was slit over the death bed of Nasrallah along with her two children.  She was called - ( : ,  ) (518).
*** In another version of the tale, Nasrallah killed her simply out of jealousy, afraid she would consort with other men after his death (518).
* In Vambery's telling, Nasrallah died from apoplectic anger when Shahrisabz resisted him through thirty battles and a six-month siege.  In a third version he died in a state council after suffering from a serious headache for a full year (518).
* The current amir (i.e. Muzaffar) was also unsuccessful in subduing Shahrisabz, though he made it to the gates once; the city was never subdued until 1870: " ,       , , ,  :          ,  1870 ,        . ,  , ,   " (518).
* Kenagis are renowned for taking in political prisoners.  For instance in 1868 they protected Sayyid Abd al-Malik Khan, the oldest son of the amir; rumor has it he is now hiding in Kashgar waiting for his father's eventual death (518).
* Mentions how the Kenagis helped the defenders during the Russian siege of Samarqand in Urgut (518).
** The Kenagis treated the Russians with the same animosity with which they treated the Bukharans (519).
* Aftermath of the Russian conquest - Shahrisabz returned to "ancestral" vassal status, beks exiled to Tashkent with pension: "     1870    ,      ,        ,      .  :      .        ,   - ,      ,        .  -   35,  ,      ; - -    40,      ,          ,   -       " (519).
* Kenagis crafts and trade gravitates toward Samarkand (519).
* Kenagis also known for being good shots (519).
[[TsGART Index]]

General observations: 
* The Russians handed out qazi ledgers to the village qazis to keep track of their cases. The cover page of F60 O1 D3 (1873) reads: "     ," despite being no such thing; the cover of D1 (1870) is correctly labeled "   ." 
** The notebooks are equipped with column headings, such as "    ,        " on the left side and "   " on the right, but the qazis ignored these columns and divided page into small boxes for each ruling.  
* Most rulings are about either petty transactions or marriages / divorces.  
* These documents more or less follow the format of the exemplars (for instance [[Notebook of Qazi "Abu Nurchashmi" - 19th Century (PNB F924 D561)]]) but are generally even shorter.
* Despite the fact that (according to Morrison) madrasa training was no longer required after the Russian conquest to become a qazi, the extensive Arabic usage suggests that the qazi did indeed have such an education.
* The material culture of the qazi changes substantially; no longer do we have introductions praising God, but rather a standardized, columned notebook.

!!!F60 O1 D3    , 1873
* Note that despite the designation in the opis, the cases go through 1294 / 1877.
* Case 1b.1: Property transfer
** (1)       1290              
** (2)               []    
* Case 1b.6: Example of a divorce
**                      

!!!F79 O1 D1 Kniga zapisi reshenii narodnoi sud'i Matchinskoi volosti 1895 
* What is particularly interesting about this ledger is that there are printed instructions for the Qazi in Turki, notable since madrasa education was entirely Arabic-Persian; possibly reflects the fact that madrasa education was no longer necessary under Russian rule.
* Transcription of cover page:
**       [then in handwritten:]     [back to printed:] 
**         
* This cover page is followed by   
** First line of instructions (@@scan@@):                1896      
* Nevertheless, I think this qazi is writing in Persian, but it is hard to tell because of the handwriting and because so many of the legal terms would be the same anyway.

!!!F42 O1 D1 Kniga dlia zapisi reshenii c"ezda kaziev Khodzhentskogo uezda 1870
* This delo is water damaged and difficult to read; many of the cases seem to be about large-scale inheritances.

[[Imperial Russian Sources]]
[[TsGARUz Index]]

> TsGARUz F i1 O 69 D 15, serial 116

Same delo (and pdf file) contains report by Kun on archeological survey of Khujand (ff. 110a-112b) Dokladnaia Zapiska, No. 3, 11 ianvaria 1871 goda, Tashkent

     (ff. 68a-69a)
* Majma al-Gharib, tanf-i Suln Muammad (68a):     
** A geographical work by Sultan Muhammad ibn Darwish Muhammad al-Balkhi. See Storey 1927-84, 2(1): 135-137.
*** Commissioned by Pir Muhammad (d. 1567), ruler of Balkh, and uncle of Abdallah (McChesney, Waqf, 70).
* Trkh-i Mawln Wsif (68a):   
** Possibly Zayn al-Din Wasifi's Bada'i al-Waqa'i
* Trkh-i Sharafnma-i Shh (68a):    
** 1584-9 Hafiz-i Tanish: Sharaf-nama-i shahi
* afat al-Akm (68a):   
** Note: written   but transliterated as   and translated as  .
* Dwn-i Mrz Shawkat (68a):   
** Khwaja Shawkat of Bukhara went to Herat in 1088 hijri. Then he went to Mashhad, and ultimately settled in Isfahan, where he died (d. 1695/99). He was a poet of Sabk-i Hindi.
* Takira-i Dawlatshh wa Murshd Sharf Rqim dar yak mujallad (68a):           
** Author: Dawlat Shh bin Al al-Dawla al-Bakhtshh al-Ghz al-Samarqand. One of the few authors before the 16th century to have devoted a work entirely to poets, arranged more or less chronologically.
* Khula al-Akhbr dar Trkh Chingiz wa Awld-i way (68a):        
** Translation:      
** Author (?): Muhammad Khwandamir
*  Jild-i Akhr-i Trkh-i Rawat al-Saf Khwndshh (68a):       
** The Gardens of purity in the biography of the prophets and kings and caliphs is a Persian history of the origins of Islam, early Islamic civilisation, and Persian history by Mr-Khvnd, a Fifteenth-Century historian. The text was originally completed in seven volumes in 1497 (836 AH). The work is very scholarly, Mr-Khvnd used nineteen major Arabic histories and twenty-two major Persian ones as well as others which he occasionally quotes. His work was the basis for many subsequent histories including the works of Hajj Khalfah.
** Author: Mir-Khwnd (Mohammad ibn Khwndshh ibn Mahmud), born in Bukhara in 1433; spent much of career in Herat, died in Balkh.
* Fatw-yi Ibrhm Shh (68b):   
** Author: Shahab al-Din Dawlatabadi (d. 849.1445)
** Ibrahim Shah ruled the Jaunpur sultanate from 1402-1440. A large number of scholarly works on Islamic theology and law was produced during his reign, which include the Hashiah-i-Hindi, the Bahar-ul-Mawwaj and the Fatwa-i-Ibrahim Shahi.
* Natij al-Afkr, shar-i Hidya (two copies - see below).
* Natij al-Afkr, shar-i Hidya bi-jild-i dgar (68b):      
** Seems to be a commentary on the Hidaya by Ahmad ibn Mahmud Qadizada
* ??     
** Mispelling of Quduri, section on waqf?
* Mab-i Sarakhs Waqf (68b):   
** Note Russian gloss.
** Probably section specific to waqf (?)
* ibb-i Mawln Ysif, nam  nasr (68b):      
* Aqid-i Mulla Jall (68b):    
** Probably the Sharh-i Aqa'id-i Uzudiyya, but could also be confused with his Akhlaq.
* Dwn-i Ghazaliyyt-i Umar Khn mutakhalla bi-Amr (68b):      
** Probably referring to Umar Khan of Khoqand's divan.
* Trkh-i Mr Sayyid Sharf Rqim (68b):     
** Late 17th century history of Central Asai.
* Khamsa-i Amr Nawy (68b):   
* Daftar-i Awwal-i Hidya-i Sharf (69a):    
* Muawwal-i Shar-i Talkh al-Mift (69a).
** A famous work on rhetoric by Taftazani.
* Unknown work on medicine (69a):        
* Majma-i Naqliyyt  Wqia-i Mrz Hamdam (69a):      
* Kitb-i Ghayb-yi Frs (69a)
* Unknown (69a):           

[[Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]

> A.L. Kun, "Musul'manskaia shkola" (handwritten) F33 O1 D28

In this draft Kun describe the play-by-play of maktab primary schooling

* Here Kun is writing only about those places he has personally visited:    ,     ,    (1).
* Just about everywhere Kun has visited in Turkestan has a school in every neighborhood (guzar, mahal) (1-1b).
* There are no special requirements for the right to become a maktab teacher; they are simply chosen from amongst the prominent locals who have gotten such an education themselves :           ...  ,          (2b).
** //This is probably why [[Khamuli|Tarjuma-i l-i Q Juma-Qul Khaml]] had so many complaints//...
* All students come daily and are not live-in (verify translation):       (3).
* The insides of the school are extremely modest and plain (3).
* Wealth disparity:  ,     ,     ,   ..." (6b-7).



Temp: check out 6b - discusses wealth disparity.
[[Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]
See also notes from [[Abdurrakhman's Tajik-language diaries|Dnevnik mirzy Abdurrakhmana, vedennyi vo vremia puteshestviia po Bukhare i ee okrestnostiam (AV F33 O1 D217)]].

> A. L. Kun, "Predislovia" / coobshcheniia o Iskanderkul'skoi eksp., mirzi Abdurrakhmane, tseli i khode issledovaniia F33 O1 D218.

* Sent on a reconoitering expedition ( ) General   (1).
* Primary goal of expedition was to collect               (1).
* Looking for traces of the ancient:    (?)                 (1).
* Goal 1 for the diary: Studying the Tajik language.             ()                ,  (sic.)        (1).
* Goal 2: Geographic information.             (1b).
* Kun also kept his own records, which he synchronized with those of the Mirza (1b).
* Kun used his conversations with the Mirza to try to pick out the peculiarities of Tajiki:       ,     (sic.)    ,        " (1b).  He would record these words in his own diary.
* He sought to collect  , ,    as well as inscriptions () of the mountain natives, but he was not successful in this everywhere (1b).
* There were plenty of literate Tajiks up the Zarafshan Valley (1b); the problem was that they did not know the cause () of the armed education and so would take to the mountains: ....     .                        " (2).
**                  ,                (2).
** Ultimately, he could only find people to personally record () folklore for him (2).
*** //Here he is essentially creating a written dialect.//
** Even in the recording of these tails there was an emphasis on discovering " " (2).
* Mentions that one of the highlights of his trip was encountering two poets who composed original poetry for him:         ,  .      " (2b).
** //Point illustrates the extent of the Persianate world; even small villages had a few//
* (roughly) - he took a lot of etchings of various ancient writing on stones, etc., but is not really impressed with the historical value of any of it.
* In his journal he refers to the @@full name@@ of his agent as         (4).
** Kun adds that he is a Samarkand native and pure Tajik: ...    " (4-4b)
*** //though one notes that some of the diaries Abdurakhman wrote were in Uzbek, such as// F33 O1 D221:   ,     .
** Abdurakhman's education:        /          .    (sic.)            .           -.            .  (//marred, incomplete sentence//)           ,       " (4b).
*** __Note__ one of Dehkhoda's definitions of ; the primary definition is , i.e. prince, but an auxiliary one is:     
*** Encyclopedia Islamica, "Mrz", R. Levy: "The title, in addition to bearing its original significance, was also given to noblement and others of good birth, thus corresponding to the Turkish Agha.  Since the time of Nadir Shah's conquest of India, it has been further applied to __educated men outside of the class of //mullas// or //ulama//__.  
*** //This is a very intriguing sentence; note that Kun separates between Persian and Tajik starkly, valuing the latter. He was also a huge proponent of Russian schooling, and seems to be deriding the ulema in this sentence.//





[[Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]

> .. ,         (33 1 16)

Note:  This is an //extremely// rough draft, clearly repeatedly edited with lines crossed out, words added in in the margin, etc.  Original written in pre-reform Russian, transcription not.  Also, [[Zhukovskii's piece on the history of Iranian dialects|Zhukovskii, Kratkii ocherk istorii persidskogo iazykf i obzor iranskikh dialektov polosy goroda Isfagana (F17 O1 D11)]] makes a good companion piece.  I could make out so little of it that it is mostly useful just for indicating what debates Kun was participating in.

* Opens by noting that Iranian peoples have inhabited the Syr-Darya, Zaravshan, and Amu-Darya areas since the most ancient times ( ) (1).
* Like [[Zhukovskii|Zhukovskii, Kratkii ocherk istorii persidskogo iazykf i obzor iranskikh dialektov polosy goroda Isfagana (F17 O1 D11)]], he also references Dorn's work on Mazandaran; also work on the Kurds, Ossetians (1b).
* Kun engaged in his study of Iranian dialects in Turkestan during his service there (      ) (1b).
* He is interested in finding traces of words from ancient Sogd, Khorezm (4).
