[[Source Guide Index]]

> Golib Negmatovich Kurbanov, Pechati Bukharskogo khanstva XIX - nachala XX vekov (Moscow: Akademiia Nauk SSSR, Institut Vostokovedeniia, 1990).

This 389 page dissertation is about chancellery seals on official documents and how to deal with them.  The author examines the stamps themselves as well as their imprint on various documents (18-19).

References
* M. Talibova, Kh. Turaev.  Iz opyta registratsii kollektsii dokumentov Bukharskogo muzeia.  Bartol'dskie chteniia.  1984.

Background on archives:
* The formation of the archive of the Qushbegi (-126 at ) began under Shah Murad (1785-1800) and went through Alim Khan (1910-1920) (19).
* All materials were transferred from the Bukharan Museum to Tashkent in 1937-38 (20).
* The designation of the Waqf fond at  is -323.  " ,      " (20) - i.e. 19th - beginning 20th century.

Document Descriptions
* Example of Yarliq dealing directly with madrasa cells: ... . . 350/273.  1917.
* There are loads of "kupchaia" in the Bukharan museum, i.e. deeds of sale.
* There are also marriage documents.  //Possible to track new residents to Bukhara this way?//
* "Letters" genre:
** ... . . 509/424: A mulla / mudarris writes the following - "...         " (367).
** ... . . 9759/12: "  -    , ,  " (368).  (Katolog 1, No. 119, 269).


[[Chronicles Index]]

> Muammad Kim, lam r-yi Ndir (Tehran: Kitbfursh-i Zavvr, 1985).

107:                       
* Riza Quli was ordered to conquer Balkh (571).
* Author reports that two thousand troops were mustered for the conquest of Balkh (572).
* On the way to Balkh they subjugated the town of  between Marv and Balkh (572).
* With the aid of the 12 imams they take the fortress of  by force:                   (p. 573).
* A messenger was sent to Qandahar to inform Nadir Shah (I think  - if   refers to him) (575).
** According to Nadir's orders, Ali Mardan - former ruler of Andakhud - was then sent to serve in Nadir's court personally:                      (p. 575).
** But then he died a "natural death"?:               .                                       (p. 575).
* Other nearby provinces went peacefully:                               (p. 575).

108:                  
* Riza Quli's army ran into an Uzbek army on their way to take the fortress , but the army withdrew:                                                         (p. 575-576).
** As a result the Uzbek ruler of the fortress (one ) had no choice to acquiese and pay tribute (576).
* Riza Quli spent several days in fortress Aghcha hoping to convince Balkh to surrender with out a fight (576).
* Ruler of Balkh at the time:    (p. 576).  
** He was a descendant of Ghengis Khan:       , but he was nevertheless a weak man:       (p. 576).
** Since Abu al-Hasan was weak, the real power in Balkh was Sayyid Khan for the Manghit:                                                    (p. 576).
*** @@interesting@@: So in Balkh we have the exact same situation that Rahim Khan would later replicate up in Bukhara - keeping a weak Chinigissid on the throne while a Manghit keeps the actual power and rules from behind the throne under the title "Ataliq."
* Abu al-Hasan's advisers counseled him that Riza Quli  would be merciful and that he should pay tribute:                                  (p. 576).
** Such was the council to the "oppressed" khan:            (p. 576).
* However, Sayyid Khan controlled the military and had other ideas; he would fight Riza Quli with his troops:                               ...                            (p. 576).
* Sayyid Khan reprimands Abu al-Hasan for his cowardice, especially when the Balkhis have the barakat of Chingis behind them:          (p. 576).
** He also notes that most of the Qizilbash troops are infantry, while he has cavalry:       (p. 576).
* Riza Qoli sends some scouts up in the middle of the night that manage to capture some of Sayyid Khan's troops and interrogate them (576).
* Sayyid Khan was ultimately defeated and driven into a fortress, which Riza Quli's forces siezed and stormd:                   (p. 578).
** After that point the local leaders supplicated to Riza Quli:                (p. 578).
* At some point Abu al-Hasan comes out of the fortress, submits, and denounces Sayyid Khan (579).
** Abu al-Hasan Chingissid heritage was potent, even before the victorious army:                              (p. 579).
** They send Abu al-Hasan to pay his respects to Nadir Shah in Qandahar then on the Hajj, where he died:                  .                                            (p. 579).
* The local power holders of Balkh went to pay tribute to Nadir and were then allowed to return:                             (p. 579).

108:        

109:        

110:           

111:          

112:          


137:              
* Sending tax collectors to Kashmir (730):                                                              .

140:                          
* Subjugation of Kashmir around the same time as the Shahjahanabad massacre (747):                                                          
** Briefly mentions that he appointed governors to Indian provinces, including Kashmir, on p. 749.


149:          
* As Nadir assembles his forces in Balkh, Kazim (the author) is an eyewitness (785):               

150:                    
* Nadir learned that there were some Turkmen and Uzbeks near Chaharjub where he wanted to cross, but they fled at his approach (787):                            ...                                
* After building boats to cross the Amu, Nadir builds fortresses on both sides (788):                                     -               
* As he advanced he sent messengers for an audience with Abu al-Fayz.  Bukhara realizes just how outmatched they are (788).
** Abu al-Fayz's response - delivered by Hakim Ataliq (788):                                                           
** Nadir Shah is pleased by the submission and charmed by Hakim Ataliq, makes an Afrosiab analogy (788): :   .                                  .                    
* Messenger alerts that a group of warriors from the direction of Farghana are approaching to avenge the death of Adina Quli Dadkhah, who was killed during Rizaquli's previous invasion (789):           :                                                                          
** On Nadir's incursion from the Khoqandi perspective see: [[Sayyid Umar Beg, Anjum al-Tawrkh (IVANUz 11366)]]
** Some of this group sought audience with Abu al-Fayz (789):             
* Amirs of Turkestan objected to Abu al-Fayz submitting to Nadir (789):           :            
** Their words (referencing Afrasiab, again) convince Abu al-Fayz (789):              .         
** Only Hakim Ataliq thought this notion was crazy (789):                               
** Seems that Nadir's troops got in a skirmish with these forces and killed most of them and captured a few (789).
** Then another more decisive battle, which the Qizilbash also won (790).
* Another battle with Nadir - involving Rahim Khan (790-791):                        .                     ...                               
* Crucial - the Uzbeks are vastly outclassed in terms of military tech (791):                     
** Vivid description of rivers of blood thick with bodies (791).
** Poetry as well is really harkening to Shahnama imagery - Turanians vs. Iranians (791).
* Some of the troops ( ) fled to Ghijuvan and Miankal; Abu al-Fayz fled to the Bukharan fortress (792).
* Following his victory, Nadir camps about a mile outside Bukhara at a Charbagh (793):                   

!!!151:                        
* In which a broken Abu al-Fayz repents for his bad behavior (793).
* Nadir Shah accepts Abu al-Fayz's apology (794):                                                      
** Abu al-Fayz gifts Nadir relics from Amir Timur and Chingiz Khan:                        
* After exchanging gifts and honors, they get to the matter of the treasury; after which Nadir orders his troops not to molest the local population (796):                            .          :                                               
** (cont.) Punishing anyone who defied the orders not to pillage upon punishment of death (796):                                               .                     
* (cont.) Khutba and coins, Qarshi, Samarqand, Shahrisabz, Hisar incorporated (796):                                            
* Concludes by reminding that Nadir restored Abu al-Fayz to king () of Turkestan (796).

!!!152:                   
[read and fill in interim]
* (@@important@@) Abu al-Fayz //asks// Nadir to take the other amirs with him because they are giving him so much trouble (802):      :                             .                   .              

!!!212:  
* Premise - Badakhshan stops sending taxes to Balkh (1093):                                        
* Niyaz Khan, wali of Balkh, sends men to compel them to do so, but they come back empty-handed (1093).
* Requisitioning taxes from Charjuy in Turkestan (1093):                                                   
* Niyaz was short and late on taxes, conducting himself like a king (1094):                  
* Nadir Shah heard of this, god mad, appointed someone else in charge of Balkh.  Niyaz apologizes, but dies shortly thereafter of illness (1094).
* The rebellions in the Kuhistan cont. (1094):                              ... 
* Following the deposition of Niyaz Khan, Behbud Khan comes to Balkh with an army intended to punish China (1095):                                                         .                                             ...
* The connection between the Kuhistan and China (Chin) lies in the fact that the rulers are blaming their rebellion on them (1095):                         :                                           
* They basically bought the explanation and resolved to punish Sarmaq (1096):                              .                    
* (cont.) They were greeted with open arms upon reaching Hisar (1096):                  
* Sarmaq indeed realized that resistance was futile and sent tribute (1096).
* From there Mehdi Khan and Kadai Vali set out for Kulab to punish the rebels there (1096):                                                  
** Mirza Qul Arali took his forces up to a mountain redoubt in Kulab, several pages describing this (1096).
** Several Khurasani prisoners escaped and told Nadir's forces about the hidden fortress in the mountains (1097):                               
** Arali's forces used the higher ground to rain hell down on the Afsharid forces (1098):                            
** Mehdi and Kadai limped back to Qunduz and Balkh (1098).
* In Kunduz (1098):                              
* This show of force prompted regional rulers to pay back taxes (1099).
* Badakhshan sends rubies after several years of thinking it could get away with not doing so (1099):    (    )                                                                                             
** The Padishah of Badakhshan and the Sardar / Vali (of Kunduz?) and brought the rubies (specific amount detailed) (1099):                                                       

!!!213:                      
* Note: This episode is also described in less detail in [[Risla-i Muammad Yaqb Bukhr]] and [[adr , Trkh-i Saln Uthmn va Nasab-i Ishn (al-Biruni 1304-II)]]
* Opening and premise - Abu al-Fayz loses control of things in Turkestan (1101):                                                         
* Nadir Shah dispatches Qizilbash to solve the problem (1101).
* Enter Ibadallah Khitayi; one of Abu al-Fayz's courtiers, based in Samarqand, falsely claimed Chingissid lineage (1101):                                                       .                                   
* Bukhara sends a force to put down Khitayi, but it fails (1101).  Eventually Abu al-Fayz is forced to send word to Nadir's court, since even the outskirts of Bukhara are being ravaged (1102):                  
* This was actually good news from Nadir Shah's perspective, since he had been planning to invade China once he was finished subduing the Ottomans; so he sends Shahquli Qajar with 4000 men to deal with the uprising (1102):                                                                              
* (cont.) And Rahim was sent along with Shahquli at the head of one thousand Uzbek warriors (out of 40000 total Uzbek warriors at Nadir's court) (1102):                                                                    .                                                  
* When Khitayi learned of the approach of Nadir's forces, he fled to Samarqand (1102).
* There was another rebel as well named Murad (but he was quickly brought into line) (1102):                            
* Shahquli ordered to hold off punishing Khitayi, even though Abu al-Fayz was impatient (1103).
* Specifics on this page about the quantity and quality of forces dispatched to Bukhara (1103).
* Behbud Khan was appointed Sardar of Turkestan (1103):                     
** (cont.) Behbud Khan was the guy who brought Qipchaq and Georgia into line (1103):                                         ...
** Following the appointment, Behbud set out with an army to punish the usurper in Turkestan (1104):              ...                     
* Date - 1159/1746 (1104):   ...                  

!!!214:          
* At the appearance of Nadir's forces, the aforementioned Murad, governor of Kuh-i Nur, as well as another Ibadallah unrelated to Khitayi, came into line (1104).
* Khitayi, however, hightailed it for Uratepa (1104):                                                
* (cont.) Details on the Ming ruler of Uratepa at the time; Khitayi wanted to join him, but Farakh Khwaja realized Khitayi was no good (1104-1105):                                                              
** (cont.) When Farakh comes out of the fortress for his childrens' wedding, Khitayi kills him and takes his treasury (1105):           .                                              
* At this point Shahrisabz also seizes independence.  Ruled since the end of the Qalmyq invasion in 1135/1722. (1105):                                 .                                    .                                                                                                 
** (cont.) All of Bukhara was ruined by the Qalmyq invasion, including Shahrisabz, and many fled (1105):                                 .                                                     
* Details of an inter-Amir dispute between Alim Beg Kenagis and some other rulers (Qabil Beg in Yakkabagh - who per p. 1107 is also Kenagis) (1105-1106).
* Once Alim Beg hears of Nadir's forces, he submits (1106):                                      
** Convinces Nadir's forces to go after Qabil Beg on his behalf.  Qabil puts up a fight, but is defeated. When the Qizilbash take his fortress, they decided to go after the treasure instead of following Qabil, which enrages Behbud (1106).
** Marvels at the incredible fortress in Siqnaq-i Timur, relates his Tamerlane history (1107-1108).
* Qabil tries to flee up to the impenetrable Siqnaq-i Timur fortress, but the pass is closed from snow (1108).
* The other sardars (i.e. Shahquli and Hasan Khan) turn back due to the weather conditions which forced them to leave their horses behind, but Behbud presses on and forces Qabil to submit (1108).
* Turning Shahrisabz over to Alim Beg (1108):                                       
* (cont.) Messengers arrive in Shahrisabz instructing the chronicler to take an accounting of the army and return to Nadir's court, and so he parts ways (1108):                                         .                                                 
** //passage describes the author's role in all this and indicates his presence at the events//
* Learning of Khitayi's plans to wed Farakh Khwaja's (?) daughter (1108):                                                 

!!!215:          
* Opening - Khitayi forcefully weds Farakh Khwajas (wife?) (1109):                                      .            
* Relays a story about how one of Khitayis men is out hunting and chances upon Behbuds army, which is trying to take them by surprise (1109).
* However, Khitayi is still in the middle of his wedding, not having consummated the marriage (1109):                                                                      
* Behbud lay siege to the fortress of Farakh and then chased down Behbud at the Syr Darya (1110).
* The elders of Khitayis group submit and ask for mercy (1110):                    .                 
* (cont.) Justice and retribution for Umar Khwaja (1110):                     .                                     
* (cont.) Behbud decides to wed himself Farakhs girl, who Khitayi had sought but failed to wed that night (110):                                 
* (cont.) Behbud takes Khitayis people with him back to Samarqand; note about that fortress being Afrasiyabs prison, which Behbud razed (110):          .                 .              
* As Khitayi escaped across the Syr Darya, once Behbud hears of the extent of his transgression he prepares to invade China et al (1111):                                                    
* (cont.) In Samarqand reps from all over the Farghana valley (but not Khoqand itself, apparently) come to submit tribute and indicate their readiness to serve Behbud (1111):                                                                                  
* (cont.) Heading out to subdue Kashgar (1111):                                                                   
* (cont.) Behbud sends most leaders of Turkestan back to rule their home provinces, but keeps some with him as collateral (1111):                                      .                  .                               

Tale of the well of Samarqand (subsection):    
* Premise: The author noticed one tomb complex (definitely Shah Zinda) to the north side of the city, the resting place of the great Timurid sultans (1111):                        .                                    
* Author copied the inscription on the tomb (1111):                   
* Mystical well so deep the flames of hell are visible; legend about how Timur tried to divine its secrets (1112):                                                          .                     .                            
* So Timur's wazirs got together to discuss the problem, and realized that one Khwaja Halal, was especially learned in such matters (note from previous para that there is a village near Samarqand named after him. So Khwaja Halal was summoned, and he set up a tent at the base of the well (1112).
* After three days of praying, he received permission to go to the spirit world, and tied a rope around each foot; then he went headfirst into the well.

!!!216:      
* Opening - bringing us back up to speed on Khitayi, who found shelter and support in Tashkent (1114):                                                      
* (cont.) Those in Tashkent, fearing the march of Qizilbash armies, tricked Khitayi, shot him, and sent his head to Nadir's rep's camp (1114):                                                            .                                                         
* Rumors start circulating about uprisings against Nadir in Iran; Behbud receives word that Rahim Khan and Shahquli have started a rebellion in Marv (1115):                                                                                       
** (cont.) Describing the contents of the Marv treasury - which was looted by Shahquli and Rahim (1115):                                       .                                                           
* (cont.) Another messenger arrives suggesting that Nadir Shah vanquished the many foes that tried to murder him (1116):                                         
** (cont.) This news spooks Shahquli and Rahim, and Rahim murders Qabil Beg (1116):                                                                   
* Shahquli and Rahim decided that the safest thing to do was to take armies from Marv and flee to Shahrisabz and Bukhara respectively; plot to join forces to oppose Nadir if necessary; they planned to take the Marv garrison with them (1116):                                   .                                      .                   
** At the time the Marv garrison was three thousand strong (1116).
* Bayramali Mingbashi sent word of the impending treachery to Nadir's matrilineal uncle Fathali Khan who conquered the Hazarajat (1116).
* Though Shahquli went to reassure them, some of the forces of Marv panicked for fear of Nadir and began to resist him (1117).
* Rahim Khan learns of incoming Nadir forces and repents; Shahquli tells him to hold on and see if they can take the fortress at Marv (1117):                  .               :                             
* Shahquli slips into Marv, takes the fortress and sends word to Rahim.  However, the Uzbeks under Muhammad Amin Khan Hisari (the same one who rebelled only recently - see p. 1095) and Muhammad Amin Khwaja Naqib oppose them as traitors (1117):                             :        .                       
** (cont.) This convinces Rahim Khan to return to Nadir's court (1117):                       
* Realizing the game was up, Shahquli fled into the desert with 300-400 men (1117).
* Shahquli wanders around in the desert for a while, there is some drunkedness and murder of women and children, then he slips back into his residence in Marv under the cover of night and hid in a vineyard (takistan) and reunited with his women and children (1118).
* About this time Nadr Ali Beg, who was under the command of Fathali Khan, comes into town with Qizilbash troops (1118).
* One of Shahquli's men ends up betraying him to Nadr Ali Beg; Nadr Ali immediately arrests Shahquli (1119).
** Orders arrive to blind Shahquli and send him back to court (1119):                                    
* (cont.) Rahim Khan blames it all on Shahquli, is rewarded for it (1119):                                      .          

!!!217:           
* Behbud accuses the author and a number of others of treason (1120):                                           . <                                                           .           
* (cont.) May 1 - 1747: Nadir orders Rahim to go to Bukhara to ensure the peace and then return to the royal encampment (1120):                                                         
* Rahim Khan greets Bihbud Khan in Bukhara (1120).
* Nadir is the one who orders the deposition of Abu al-Fayz, but because of a letter Rahim Khan sent; appoints Abd al-Mumin in his place (1120):       :                                             .                 
** Interesting - coins and khutba were done in Abd al-Mumin's name (1120):                   
* Bihbud Khan puts Abu al-Fayz under arrest and twelve-year-old son on the throne on July 7, 1747 / 2 Rajab 1160 [note Nadir Shah assassinated June 20] (1120):                                                                                            
** Note that there are still Qizilbash fortified at this point (1120):               
* Muhammad Kazim's conversation with Rahim (1120-1121):
* Premise - Bihbud Khan sent Kazim to work out provisions for the Qizilbash troops (1120):                                 
** (cont.) Rahim tells Kazim that it was decided that the Qizilbash should disperse for the winter and find their own provisions - anywhere they like aside from Bukhara itself (1120-1121):    :                   .                                   .                      
** (cont.) Rahim takes Kazim aside and lets him on a "secret," that by high order the munitions were entrusted to Rahim, and he orders Kazim to calm them when the unrest begins and make sure they are loyal to him; subtly threatens Kazim; tells him to only reveal the secret to the heads of the munitions (1121):                      :                                 .                      .                                                                 .      :              .        
* Author realizes Rahim is up to treachery, alerts the heads of the munitions, and they all inform Behbud, but Behbud doesn't believe him out of fear of Nadir (1121).
* More rumors start circulating among the Qizilbash about unrest in Iran; Behbud's men form ranks in solidarity (1121).
* There is a dispute over a sheep in Bukhara proper between a Bakhtiyari and a Bukharan shepherd; everyone starts taking sides in the dispute, leading to general chaos.  Both Behbud and Rahim try to figure out what is going on, but without avail (1122).
* Abu al-Fayz learns of Nadir's death, warns author that Rahim Khan intends to kill him, begs to be put under Behbud's direct supervision (1122):                                                .       :                   .                                            
* But Behbud does not comply, saying that Rahim Khan doesn't have the guts (1122).
* Rahim kills Abu al-Fayz on 3 Rajab 1160 / 10 July 1747 (1122).
* Behbud realizes Rahim's treachery, prepares for battle, fighting ensues (1123)

Expert Afghan artillerymen defect to Rahim's side (1124-1125)

Messenger comes telling Behbud to leave Turkestan to Rahim and rush to Kalat as reinforcement - which they recognize as a lie from Rahim (1126)

Rahim demands return of prisoners (1126)

Behbud trying to cross a flooded river to escape (1127)

Behbud destroys munitions as he flees (1127)

Behbud flees to Balkh (1128)

Balkh politics, uprising following news of Nadir's death (1128)

Kulab (1129)

Behbud (?) takes control of the Kulab garrison (1131)

Behbud's ultimate fate - going into the service of Muhammad Ali Khan (1146).







[[Travel Literature Index]]

> Mohan Lal, Travels in the Panjab, Afghanistan, & Turkistan, to Balk, Bokhara, and Herat; A Visit to Great Britain and Germany (London: William H. Allen & Co., 1846).

Kabul
* In Kabul: "May 8 to 17. - I had the pleasure of talking with Mr. Wolff, who came into my room, and told me to listen to the Bible, and be converted to Christianity, whih is the best religion in the world.  My answer pleased the reverend gentleman very much.  He added the following most singular seech: - That in the City of Bokhara he had an interview with Jesus Christ, who informed him that the pleasant valley of Kashmir will be the New Jerusalem after a few years" (72-73).
* Language in Kabul: "The people and the merchants of the city generally speak Persian; but in the country, a very harsh Pashto continues to be spoken" (73).
* Hindus: "The Hindus are nearly two thousand in number, and many of them are the first inhabitants of Kabul... Their shops are spread over all the streets and bazars, while their Mohammedan neighbors, though they are prejudiced against them, treat them very tolerantly" (74).
* Trade w/ Bukhara: "The caravan of Lohanis, which consists of between six hundred and seven hundred camels, furnishes it once a year with English and Indian goods.  They come through Multan and Ghaznin, where they are not ill-treated.  Great part of their merchandize is conveyed to Bokhara, which furnishes the merchants in return with fine silk, and also with a good breed of beautiful horses.  These fine animals, purchased in Kabul, are sold in India at a price, quadruple their original cost, surpassing the expectations of their first Uzbeg masters" (76-77).

The road from Kabul to Bukhara
* @@important@@ - Lal places the border between Afghanistan and Turkestan just after Bamian: "May 24. - As soon as the sun shone, we commenced our journey, escorted by Haji Khan's people, who were all well armed and mounted.  Our route conducted us betwixt the lofty branches of the Hindu Kush, ascending over large ranges and descending into deep defiles, all without verdure, and of dreadful aspect - not a single tree appeared in sight.  Having crossed the pass of Akrabad, the height of which is 10,500 feet, we quitted the boundary of Afghanistan and entered Turkistan" (90-91).
** (cont.) The first town in Turkestan: "Our march, which was not more than thirty miles, brought us to the beautiful town of Saighan, ruled by Mohammad Ali Beg.  His object is to attack, or chapao, the villages of Hazara, and reduce the inhabitants to slavery" (91).
* At the caravan stop of Haibak: "The caravans of Bokhara and Kabul, which pass here on their route, are obliged to pay very heavy duties.  A market is held on Mondays at Haibak.  The Hindus are also shopkeepers; the language they speak is Persian, and they look very like the Muhammedans" (95-96).
* "This country is called Turkistan, but the Qizal Bashis of Kabul have named it Kafristan, or Country of Infidels, on account of the slave-trade.  The inhabitants are Turks, or Uzbegs" (98).

Qunduz and Khulum
* Mir Murad Beg ruled Khulum from Qunduz: "Mir Murad Beg, the ruler of the country, is in person short and thin; he has very small and gloomy eyes, and no regular beard, only a few hairs on his chin.  He is an Uzbeg, which signifies, in Turki, an independent, and also the king of his own house.  He is said to be unacquainted with justice and mercy, those ornaments of human nature" (99).
** "His standing army is a few hundred men, but in time of war he can collect nearly twenty thousand, both horse and foot, each selected from separate families" (99).
** Boundaries: "Towards Kabul he rules as far as Kamard, and towards Bokhara, to the kotal named Abdu.  His residence is at Qunduz, and in that direction he commands a large territory in Badakhshan, and also the base of the Hindu Kush" (99).
** Relationship with Bukhara: "he is a more enterprising man than his father, who was dependant on Bokhara; but his death made the name of Murad Beg so famous in the country, and his power so much respected by the people, that in a short period he was recognized as independent chief of Qunduz, and almost of the whole of the rich valley of the Oxus.  He possessed himself of more countries than any of his predecessors had" (99-100).
** "Atma Ram, a Hindu inhabitant of Peshawar, who stands very high in Mir Murad Beg's favour, possesses a great influence over him.  He bears the title of Diwan Begi, or the prime minister.  The whole business of the country is managed through his intervention.  Notwithstanding he adheres to all the customs of the Hindu religion, and is partial to his countrymen, yet he is respected by all Mohamedans, and none venture to throw a slander on his character.  Being a man of distinction, he keeps a great number of Mohammedan slave-girls and boys, which privilege is not allowed to any other Hindu in Turkistan" (101).
* Characterization of religion in Khulum: "Disputes respecting religion are a frequent cause of tumult among them; but although they are not acquainted with one word of its tenets, they are so bigoted, as to pretend to be strict observers of the Mohamedan faith" (105).

Bukhara and environs
* "Qarshi is larger than Khulum. The buildings are much better than those at Balk... The place is celebrated for god tobacco and sweetmeats.  The great bazar is not neatly roofed, and canals run through every place; but few of them contain water. Numerous gardens filled with trees form a boundary to the town within which all wealthy classes reside; mechanics and tradesmen live in huts under the trees" (121-122).
** "The people are Uzbegs, and are computed to be nearly 13,000.  They are all of the Sunni sect, but do not attend strictly to the laws of religion... The men who are affected with leprosy are not allowed to touch anybody, and are generally exiled" (122).
* In Bukhara: "June 29 - An early walk led me through the bazar called Sarafan, where I observed two Mohammedans mounted on camels, guarded by four sepoys, who had only whips in their hands. They were ordered to be scourged by the Qazi for not saying their morning prayers and for sleeping after the sun was up. This sort of occurrence happens every day at Bokhara, and the punishment is publicly inflicted.  Some are chastised for smoking, some for drinking, and others for snuffing: these practices being prohibited by the law of Mohammed.  The guilty person, mounted on a camel, calls out in the following manner: 'This is th epunishment for a person who does not recite his prayers.  He who will smoke shall suffer like him; snuffing is the cause of the distress which he endures now patiently.' The Qazi, who is said to be guilty of some misdemeanors himself, has no power to seize the criminal in his own house, because the Qazi uses his authority according to the following proverb: 'the Qazi is of no use in the house.' The Hindus smoke in the caravansarae, which privilege is not allowed to Musalmans.  I was surprised at the foolish prejudices of the bigoted Mohammedans of this country, who prohibit smoking tobacco, but allow it to be sold publicly" (126-127).
* Ablutions in Bukhara: "They never wash themselves with water, but clean themselves with a piece of clay.  If any man dares take water, either according to the custom of his own country, or from a regard to cleanliness, he is consdiered by the Sunnis to be an infidel, or Kafar Qizal Bash" (128).
* Veiling: "They are covered with a gown from head to foot, and have a black thin veil, which sometimes they lift up in the streets, and pretend that none have seen them.  They bind a white turban upon a handkerchief, which conceals their head, and hangs as far as their waist.  The bad women are called jahab or qatah.  The present king enforces more strictly than his predecessors the outward observance of morality" (128).
* Bukhara population: "The population of the city is 170,000 souls" (129).
* Kingly power: "Notwithstanding his authority is limited by the law of Mohammad called Shariat, yet he rules sometimes according to his own will.  It is very odd that his arbitrary power is praised by every person, with numerous good wishes for his life" (130).
* Illness: "The climate of Bokhara is healthy.  The people are not subject to any disorder, except the guineaworm, or rishtah, which molests them much.  It is like a thread, and springs up from every limb of the body; sometimes it breaks into pieces, and obliges the sufferer to linger in bed for four or five months, during which time he undergoes the most terrible pain" (131).
* Drug production: "Tobacco and rice, though cultivated at Bokhara, are not so good as in Qarshi.  Opium is planted here abundantly, and also mulberry trees" (132).
* Visiting a madrasa: "July 13 - I paid a visit to the college at noon, and had a long altercation with the Maulavis in Persian. They were of course in possession of knowledge, but had not a good pronunciation.  Every person at Bokhara had a greater desire to write well than to acquire learning. They examined me, and then said, 'Allaho Akbar! how is it possible that a Kashmerian at such an early age should be versed in a science of which the Mohammedans at Bokhara are destitute!' One of them, who was older than the others, spoke civilly to me, and said, if I would be an Uzbeg, I should indeed be the Plato of the time" (133).
* Sovereignty of Nasrallah: "... the king has now obtained a degree of glory which was never enjoyed by his predecessors.  The chiefs of Sabzshaihar, Samarqand, Balk, and Qarshi, do him homage for their possessions" (134).
* "Bokhara is the largest and most populous and wealthy city in the whole region of Tartary.  The splendid mosques and magnificent colleges, which are 360 in number, contain students who are unqualfied both in the Persian and Arabic languages, but they write a very good hand" (136).
* Power of poetry: "July 17. - Maulavi Babajan, who became my great friend, desired me to call at his house, where he had prepared a rich dinner fo me.  When the entertainment was over, we began to read poetry, which my host liked very much.  Before I left him, he presented me with a Koran, and his wife with a cap made of silk" (137-138).
* Army: "It is said that the king of Bokhara has 20,000 troops, which are mounted on swift horses... It is alleged that the king may collect 100,000 soldiers from the villages, in a time of great danger; bu tthey might be routed by 10,000 regular troops" (138-139).
* Treatment: "We have been respectably received and civilly treated, though we can scarcely call it kindness... for we were all looked on as Kafars, and were not permitted to ride in the city.  Like other infidels, we were obliged to submit to be distinguished by a peculiar dress: this is a black cap, and a rope round the waist" (143).
[[National Archives of India Index]]

> Foreign Department 1851, Political, Consultation 28 November, No. 14.  National Archive of India

(p. 1)

No 2138 of 1857
Political Department
From  The Commissioner in Scind
To The Right Honorable Lord Viscount [Falkland]
Governor and President in Council Bombay
Dated 13 October 1857

My Lord,

I have the honor to forward for submission to your Lordship in Council an Extract para: 5 of a letter from the Collector of Shikarpoor no. 699 dated the [4 Instant]/

2. The Kandahar and Khelat traders write to their Agents here as though the disturbed state of Afghanistan generally were likely to interfere with trade, but the latest accounts from Khelat state that the differences between the Khan and the Kandahar Sirdars were likely to be accommodated and that some Kalifas which had been delayed in consequence were en route to Kurrachee.

I have the honor to be /signed/ [H. B. E. Frere], Commissioner in Scind
Kurrachee, 13th October 1857

Extract from a letter from the Collector of Shikarpoor no. 699 dated 4th October 1857 to the Commissioner in Scind - 

Para: 5. Information has reached the [sowkars] here, of several Kalifahs having been stopped, and detained on the road from Bokhara at a place called [Punchvao?], about 50 miles from Herat by some petty Patan Chief.  That the Sirdar of Herat [Synd]

(p. 2)

(cont.) Mahomed has sent out a party for their release, and it was believed that after paying a reasonable [donceur] to the latter, they had proceeded on their journey.]

//end of file//



[[Translated Sources Index]]

> Scott Levi and Ron Sela, eds., Islamic Central Asia: An Anthology of Historical Sources (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2010).

Majma' al-arqam: An Administrative Manual from Bukhara
Mirza Badi' Divan, written: 1798
* Editors' notes:
** Written 1798, appendix added 1800-1801; author was one of the highest ranking administrators after the appointment of Amir Haydar (270).
** "The list of ranks in the Bukharan Administration that is presented in the Majma' al-arqam should be treated with some caution, as it tends to present the different positions in an overly formulaic manner, disregarding contradictory information from other sources" (270).
** Administration divided by four because of auspiciousness of the number: "In the words of the manual, there are four established forms of physical geography; the first rightly guided caliphs were four in number; there are four elements (earth, water, wind, and fire), four human tempers (phlegm, yellow bile, black bile, and blood), four seasons of the year, four cardinal directions, four types of precipitation (snow, rain, dew, and hail), and so forth" (270).
* Four high positions: 
** 1 - Shaykh al-Islam; under him the Supreme Judge (qazi al-quzzat); under him the Military judge (qazi askar) (270).
** 2 - The Muftis, the highest among them being a'lam; there is also a mufti askar to issue fatwas for the military (270-271).
** 3 - Mukhtasibs.  "If there is no mukhtasib from among the sayyids, they allow someone from among the non-sayyids to supervise the people's observance of the shar'ia" (271).
** 4 - The teachers (271).
* Four positions in the the amir's court:
** 1 - "The first - the highest position - is entrusted to special representatives of the Juybari administration from inside and outside the city walls.  Sometimes sayyids are appointed to the position" (271).
** 2 - Naqib - conditions, equipment, and allocation for military during war (271).
** 3 - Uraq - has the duties of the mukhtasib in the military (271).
** 4 - The Naqshbandi, in charge of administration, irrigation, and grounds for the [Baha' al-Din Naqshband] shrine (271).
* Four other positions: faizi, mir-i asad, sadr, sudur; former two in charge of mukhtasib duties outside of Bukhara; latter two in charge of waqf administration outside the city (271).
** Sadr vs. Sudur: "The sadr manages registration of waqf inside Bukhara, and the sudur handles waqf registration outside the city" (271).
* Four bureaucratic positions: Divan-i Kalan - manages documentation; Mushrif - in charge of recording government inventory; Daftardar; Divan Tanabana handles land tax (271).
* Mentions someone in charge of "the affairs of the Arabs" (271).
* Other minor positions: "There are four other positions: First among them is the secretary (munshi), who writes the yarliqs and official documents.  The second is the arbab, who looks after the cleaning of canals... the third is the divan for the affairs of Arabs... and the fourth consists of different divans, handing bookkeeping and accounts.  There are four other, more minor positions: The librarian keeps treaties and looks after books.  The second is the bakhshi, who is in charge of expenditures of building activities; the third is the divan sayis khana, who is in charge of horses and stables; and the fourth, the divan tushak-khana, manages the store room and supplies" (271).
* Positions directly supporting the amir: "The next four positions are those who support the amir: First among them is the ataliq, which means 'fatherhood' and so they call the [amir's] guardian.  The ataliq has to have the kind of relations with the sovereign as a father has with his son, and also has to treat the rest of the subjects in a similar manner.  He also handles water management of the rivers of Bukhara and sees that water is distributed as fairly as far as Samarqand and Qaraqul...  The second is the divanbegi, who manages the kharaj lands mu'azaf, and is in charge of revenues from all types of lands, and is also in charge of the officials of the chancellery. The third is the parvanachi, who issues the yarliqs for people of significance.  The fourth is the dadkhah, who receives all complaints and petitions, and the government's response to said petitions.  he is also in charge of corresondence with foreign rulers" (271-272).

[[National Archives of India Index]]

> B.B. Lord's Report on Kunduz (NAI FD 6 March 1839, Nos. 23-25)

* No. 23, marked 6 March 1839 (in a separate folder), is Macnaghten forwarding the report to Fort William on 9 August 1838.

!!No. 24 (main report)

!!!Introductory letter by A. Burnes

__F. 1__

"To [W. H.] Macnaghten, Esquire, Secretary to the Governement of India, Simla"

"Sir, I do myself the honor to transmit, for information of the Right Honorable the Governor General of India "Memoir on the Uzbek State of Koondooz and the power of its presents ruler Meer Moorad Beg" by P.B. Lord Esq. the result of that gentleman's visit to Toorkistan."

"2- On this document, which gives proof of each research and contains so much valuable information, it is unnecessary to say more than that the historical portion, at the commencement, will..."

__F. 1b__

"... be found to contain much novel matter while the political and military portion with W. Lords views as set forth, towards the conclusion, will, I believe, enable the Governor General to bring countries so important at this time, with great confidence into his Lordship's calculations."

"3 I take this opportunity also of note that when it appears advisable still further conciliate the chief of Koondooz, it can be ready by sending a reply to the letter he addressed to the Governor General by W. Lord, and which remains unanswered."

"I have the honor, Sir, your most obed. humble, Signed A. Burnes on special duty."

"Simla, the 31st July 1838"

!!!"A Memoir on the Uzbek State of Kundooz and the power of its present ruler Mahomed Murad Beg" (f. 5)

__"Introduction" (f. 5)__
* On Kunduz's strategic position: "The geographical position of the State of Kundooz gives it an importance which it would not otherwise possess.  The passes of Hindoo Kosh, the direct roads commercial, as well as military from Toorkistan to Hindustan all lie within its limits, and its ruler has therefore equal power to assist or extinguish arising commerce, to expedite or retard an advancing enemy.  This renders it an object of interest to us to inquire into the origin, nature, and extent of the power of Mahomed Murad Beg the present Chief of Kundooz, to investigate the resources at his command, and, which should always be considered in speaking of Asiatic states, the probabilities of his transmitting them undivided to his successors" (5).


!!No. 25 (acknowledgement and reception)

__F. 1__

"To Captain A. Burnes, Simla, Pol. Dept."

"Sir, I am desired by the Right Honble. the Governor General of India to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated to the 31st. ultimo, forwarding copy of Mr. Lord's Memoir on Koondooz, with your report on its value, and mentioning that the unanswered letter from the Chief of Koondooz affords an opening to address him, when deemed advisable."

"2. In reply, I am desired to acquaint you, that the Governor General has perused this very able and useful memoir with the greatest gratification.  You are requested to apprize [Dr.] Lord that this document has given his Lordship an exceedingly high opinion of the zeal, ability, and industry of that Gentleman."

"3. As suggested by you, a reply to the letter from the Ruler of Koondooz will immediately be prepared, on the part of the Governor General."

"Simla, the 9th August 1838"

[... Macnaghten]



[[Imperial Russian Sources]]
[[Card Catologue - Alisher Navoi Rare Books Collection]]

> , . .   . , 1875:  1984.  82 pages.

//note// in transcriptions and transliterations I have ignored the old Russian characters.

   1:    
* Opening line attests to the former independence of Shahrisabz: " 8  (64 )  ,     ,    ,    ,  ,  ,  ,   ,    " (1).
* Travel companions: "      .. ,         ,  .. " (1).
* Rotation of official posts in the Bukharan emirate: "   ,            , ,  ,       ,   " (2).
* Strange note about a legendary Russian qishlaq: "    ,    -.   ,  -,  ,    ,         .  -   -,  .  ,             - " (11).
* Waiting for the amir's response, Maev and his companions are forced to spend several days in the Bek of Kitab's residence, conversing over the dastarkhan and watching dancing boys: "   ,     .    ,         ,  .        ,    ,          ,       (   )   .            ;   ,      ,       " (16-17).
* Kitab has a reputation of deadly fevers emerging from puddles of standing water: "   ,      ,          .          " (17).
* Reaction of the locals to their presence in Shaar, impressions of women: "    ,            .    ,         . - ,   ,  ,      -.        -  ,  ,     .           -,    ,   , ,      , -    " (24).
* (cont.) Resident Jews: "       .  ,     ,      ,     ... ,         .       100.   ,   ,       ,      ,         .   ,  :     ,  ,      ,      ,   ,       ;    ,     " (24-25).
** Though the restriction on riding mounted in cities is general to all non-Muslims in Bukhara, not just Jews: "   ,      ,  ,      ... ,   ,      ,    ,           ,  ,      " (25-26).
*** Stoddart was killed in part for daring to ride through the streets of Bukhara mounted (25).
* More insinuations of homosexuality, this time in glances at the Jewish aqsaqol's son (25-26): "   -,  14,       ;    //// ()  .   ,          .    ,   ,      :           ,          " (26-27)
* Beks do not have the power to execute offenders: "    , :      ? "    ?"  . ",   ;   .   ." "      ?" ",  ;         ,  ////,    .  ,        ,  ,     ,        ,    " (30).
* They were very closely monitored by spies throughout their time in the khanate: "    ,         ,     . ,    ,   ,   ,      .    ,  ,    ,      .     ,   " (33-34).
** (cont.) Anecdote about a conversation with a paranoid Bukharan: ",   ,    - ,  ,  ,      .          ,      ,  ,   ,  .    ,         .      : "  ",    .   ,    ,      ,     ,       " (34).
* Speaks very positively about the populace at large, which he contrasts unfavorably with the scheming of the amir's court: "   ,      .        ,   .    ,               .   ,  " (35).
* While the amir was staying in Shahrisabz he put on all kinds of shows and features in the public square so that the populace would associate him with grandeur and happiness: "    ,             ;        , ,    .  ,   ,    " (38).
* The bek of Hissar at this time was Muzaffar's son: "  , 15-       ,   - ,   ...   -,      ,  -,    ,  .  ,         . x-        , -, ,  ,     (  1868 )    ,     ,  ,  " (43).
** Assuming that his past sin of helping the amir's son attempt to seize power, Rakhmatallah came to Shahrisabz, but the amir had him executed and beat his son within an inch of his life (44).
** Per the tradition, the corpse was left at the place of execution until the second afternoon prayer (?): "   ,  ,      //// ( ), ..  4  " (44).
** All of this, of course, made quite an impression on the author (44).

II.    
* Role of Qarshi as a link between Bukhara, Shahrisabz, and Hisar: "       ,   ,        " (51).
** Also a major trade stop: ",        -,   " (51).
* Note that Maev frequently references Khanykov's account of Bukhara; evidently the number of mosques grew substantially since his visit: ",    , ,    6 ;     " (52).
* New madrasa in Qarshi, aesthetic comparison between Qarshi and Bukharan / Samarqand madrasas: "      --;       ??...?? ;      , (      ),     .           ,     " .      ,    . ,   , :    -,      ..."" (52-53).
** Two other madrasas: "...    :  -    -...  ,  ,   ,   ,    ,   " ( 53).
* Traversing the steppe from Qarshi to Bukhara, they run into infrastructure built under Abdallah Khan: "        -   -      " (59).
* First sighting of Bukhara itself: "   ,  ,     ,   - ,  , ,  , - ...   -  ,   , " !"" (63).
* The Qushbigi: " -,          ,             . -          ... -,       ,      " (64-65).
* The whip of Rustam kept as a trophy in the Bukharan museum?: "      : ,    ,  1  ,   ;      ,             ,  ,       " (65-66).
* Mentions the Ir Nazar madrasa endowed by Catherine the Great (69).
* Maev's madrasa data, characterization of the city as a timeless center of Islam: "     103,   - 360,   ;    ,               :           1840 ! " (70-71).
* Local Bukharan humor about a saint shrine: "...         ;  ,    ,   : "  ,        "  : " ,       ;     ,   ,  ,   ..." (71-72).

[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

> Ab al-Barakt al-Mulaqqab bi Pdshh Azz Khwja Mrgn Razaw,  Manqib wa Maqmt-i Sayyid Muammad Aallah Shaykh al-Islm

See also in particular: [[Biography of Ata Allah bin Abd al-Hadi (al-Biruni 79/XII)]]

Same genre (Manaqib): [[Sadatallah, Luf-i Buzrg (IVRSP B 1932)]]

[[Kostygova, Persidskie i Tadzhikskie Rukopisi Gosudarstvennoi Publichnoi Biblioteki]] (p. 225, 1257; ... 200)
*          -          
* Copied in 1258/1842f (noted on f. 77a), authored in 1231/1815f.
* Biography of Atallah.
* Note: almost entirely unpaginated.
* Work ends abruptly, mid-story, and without even getting to one of the sections it purported to cover.

Text on the inside cover in orange ink (1):                                         1257    

!!!Introduction
* Amo Bad - author introducing self (1b):                                            
* (cont.) Became Ata Allah's disciple in 1183 during the age of Danial (1b):              [=1183]               []               []                                               
* (cont.) Describing the benefits and grace of attending Ata Allah's circles (1b-2):     [ ]                                                  
* (cont.) (2a):           []                                       
* (cont.) Reason for writing this had to do with Ataallah attracting the attention of Amir Haydar (2a):             [ = ]                       
* (cont.) (2a-2b):                   []           []            [ ]                          
* (cont.) Bayt (2b):  -        -        
* (cont.) Delayed writing down what he had learned from Ata Allah and the other sufis until 1231, when he hurried to put pen to paper (2b):                                       [1231]                                      
* (cont.) Contents (2b):             []                            [  

Contents:
# Travel and meeting other shaykhs of the age (2b):      [  =    ]         [  ]  
# Pearls of wisdom overheard (2b):                    
# Miracles (3):                      
# Naqshbandi shaykhs (3):                  
** //this last section does not appear to be included in this volume//

!!!Maqala (3a):                  
* (cont.) Ata Allah was inducted into the Naqshbandi by (I) Pari Bukhara, who was the student of (II) Ishan Imla, who was from Sangcharik and whose real name was Mavlavi Muhammadi (3a):                                                                     
* (cont.) Imla traces his spiritual lineage through two sides - but text only mentions (III) Mirza Bahadur Hisari (3a):                     
* (cont.) Mulana Mirza (presumably the same as Mirza Bahadur Hisari) was trained by (IV) Muhidallah ibn Atallah Saktarki (3a):                    
* (cont.) Who was trained by his father (grandfather?) (V) Amir Alima Akbar (3a):            
* (cont.) Who was trained by his father (VI) Shahab al-Din (3a):              
* (cont.) Who was trained by his father (VII) Amir Husayn Payanda (3a):             
* (cont.) Who was trained by (VIII) Qutb-i Samarqandi Khwarazmi (3a-3b):      [  ]  [=]  
* (cont.) Who was trained by his father (IX) Mir Abu al-Husayn (3b):                
* (cont.) Who was trained by (X) Abu Tahir Khamushani (3b):          []      
** (cont.) Interesting note about how in those days Quchan (where Khamushani is located) was Sunni and free of innovation (3b):                          
*** //so  must be in Iran then?//
* (cont.) Abu Tahir was trained by (XI) Shaykh Muhammad Shah (3b):          
* (cont.) Who was trained by (XII) Rashid al-Din Sarwari, who was trained by (XIII) Abdallah Bazrishabadi (?), who was trained by (XIV) Ishaq Khatlani (3b):        []         [ ]         
* (cont.) Who was trained by (XV) Sayyid Ali Hamadani, who was trained by (XVI) Mahmud Marzakhani (3b):                      []
* (cont.) (3b):                                                                                []      
* Tracing the lineage through both Ali and Abu Bakr (4a-4b).

!!!Maqsad-i Avval (6-11)                        
* Opening - anecdote about how he was entrusted to Imla by his father (6):                                                                                       
** (cont.) (6-6b):                                                                                      
* (cont.) Encounter with Ibrahim Sukhargi (6b):                                    
* Recollection of Ishan Sufi's prophecy of his Qazi Kalan-ship (with Turki quotes) (7b):                                                                                            
** (cont.) Also predicts Tursun Baqi's qaziship; later, Tursun reminds Shah Murad of his promise in Qarshi to make him a qazi (7b):     []                                                                                  
** (cont.) Concluding bayt (7b-8):  -       -       
* Another recollection about Ishan Sufi (8):
* Recollection about Ishaq Khwaja "Ishan Pir", who attended the death of Hadi Khwajah, after which Ata Allah went into his tutelage (8-8b):
* Recollection about an ecstatic state at a cave above a river in Saktara (8b-10).
* Recollection of meeting Mula Husayn Ghijduvani while making a pilgrimage to the shrine there (10):                                        
** Weird comment about seeing heaven and hell in his eyes (10-10b):                          
** Author's own experience visiting Mula Husayn, who he reports attracted disciples from as far afield as Kashgar and devoted all the alms he received to students in the Ghijduvan madrasa (10b):              []            [   =]                                                      
* Recollection involving father-in-law Ibadallah (10b-11)

!!!Maqsad-i Thani - wise stuff Ata Allah said (p. 11-20)
* Vocal zikr (13b):                              []                                                                                                      
* Another anecdote about zikr-i jahr (15b):                                                                                
* Shrine visitation (16):                   [=]                                             [ \ ]    
** (cont.) Cites hadith to make his point (16):                             
** (//continues//)


!!!Maqsad-i Thalif - miracles                  (p. 20-
* Story of how author came to seek Ata Allah's tutelage (20-21b):                                                                              [ /  / ]                                              
** (cont.) It was Amir Kulal's shrine that the author was at (21b):                                                                             
* (cont.) Ata Allah soothing the author out of an ecstatic states (21b-22):                                    [ / ]              []                                                      
* Miracle of magical water melons (22-22b).
* On the death of Ashiq Khwajah (22b): 
** Mentions author's madrasa as Nadir Divanbigi (22b):            
** Mavlavi Ashiq, one of Imla's khalifas, one of Ata Allah's teachers (22b):                                                           
** Ata Allah's "court" is inside Kukaltash (23):              
** Danial Bey himself attended the funeral in the Registan (23b):                             
* Miracle story (24-24b)
** Abd al-Aziz, student of Ata Allah and son in law of Shah Murad (24):                              
* Miracle story (24b-25)
** Salah al-Din Khwajah is Ata Allah's nephew and son in law (24b):                          []           
* Story involving the footprint of Imla - //he had a footprint shrine already?// (25):                               
* Another story involving watermelons (25b)
** Pilgrimages to relics of the Prophet (26-26b):                                                             []   []                                                                                      
*** //tomb location description continues//
* Story involving Chuqmaqi (27):                                     
* Ata Allah spending Ramadan in Fatahbad (27b-28):                                                  
** (cont.) The act of eating together during Ramadan effectively led to a majlis (28):                                                                                         
* Memory of Muhammad Amin (28):                             
** //note I am not certain if this is the same as the Muhammad Amin who was Musa Khan's disciple; this text does not identify him as Ishan-i Pir nor has it mentioned Musa Khan yet//
** Comparing the inglorious present to the resplendent past (28-28b):                                                     [=]                                                        
** Some more background on Muhammad Amin's pedigree from Shah Mansur (who is described by [[Muhammad Tahir|Takirah-i hir shn (aka Silsilah-i Khwjagn-i Naqshbandiyyah) (al-Biruni 855/I)]] and Imla (28b):                                       
* Tale of Khwarazmian vali dispossessed of his country by Yamut tribesmen, goes to Danial Bey of Bukhara for help (29):                     []                                                                                             
** //notice the term sart juxtaposed with Turk here//
** //note that Bregel's Firdaws al-Iqbal translation explains the broader context here//
** (cont.) Great ones of the realm advise Danial not to Aid Muhammad Amin (i.e. the ruler of Khiva) because if they do Khiva will never submit to Bukhara; Danial agrees and instructs his people not to help the Muhammad Amin (29b):      []                               
** (cont.)  However, Muhammad Amin was spending much of his time with Ata Allah and had been a follower of this family for a long time (29b):                                            
** (cont.) //difficult to understand passage with lots of Turki// (29b):              []           []       [   ]            []  []                 []                                                      
** (cont.) Ata Allah blesses Muhammad Amin and ensures him victory, but demands that it must be in the name of the true shah (i.e. Danial?) (30):                                                                                                                                                    []                                                                 [ /  = ]      
** (cont.) Muhammad goes on to win a great, improbable victory, retaking Khiva.  Ata Allah was in an ecstatic state the entire time of the battle helping him out (31b):                                                      []                                                                                                                                []                    
* Tale of Ata Allah's miraculous appearance at the Prophet's grave in Mecca (32-32b).

Then Shahmurad issued a yarliq appointing him military qazi (76-76b):                                                 []                                                                                           [  ]

[[Kazan Index]]
[[Arabic Sources]]

> Shihb al-Dn Marjn, Wafiyyat al-Aslf wa Taiyyt al-Akhlf

     
  
Nauchnoi biblioteki im. N.I. Lobachevskogo Kazanskogo gosudarstvennogo universiteta, Otdel' rukopisei i redkikh knig
Call number for tom 6: 615a. (ar)
6 volumes, 2 copies of the text

General Notes
* chronological biographies (ordered by year of death) of ulama - as well as kings, notable governors - from the time of the Prophet through 1307 / 1889f from all over the world 
** not just from Tatarstan.  Marjani includes biographies of Mughal, Central Asian, and especially Ottoman rulers.  Many - perhaps even a majority - of the ulama entries are Ottoman.  There seem to be almost as many ulama from the Maghrib as there are listed from Transoxiana.  Also worth noting that he covers all of the Madhabs, not just the Hanafis (particularly Shafi and to a lesser extent Maliki).  Even Wahabi
** //Note//: There might be a bit of a "chicken or the egg" thing going on here; the preponderance of Ottoman scholars vis-a-vis Bukharan ones might have something to do with the lack of biographical dictionaries for Marjani to work from (he is going on word of mouth), not a lack of interest in Bukhara
** Also, the geographical spread is not even over time; in the 18th century and earlier there is a preponderance of Ottoman scholars, but then in the 19th there are far more Tatar and Central Asian scholars, suggesting that Marjani was working from another work earlier on and then from oral sources once the time period got closer to his own time.
* Note that the "entry #" designation is written in pencil by the editor, not the original author.
* The dots for  is never marked; I used  when I was certain, but generally left it as , which could mean either  or  (but probably almost always the former).

!!!Volume 6

* Ataallah al-Bukhari Shaykh al-Islam               (d. 1210; #571 p. 127b)
** (2)             
** (3)                
*** Writer of fatwas, teacher; revered among the ulama

** (8)               
** (9)               
*** Shah Murad sent Shams al-Din al-Balkhi to meet Shah Timur in Balkh
** (10)                 
*** He was supposed to send Ataallah, but changed his mind and sent al-Balkhi instead
** (11)               [
** (12)  [ ]  @@    @@        
*** Murad should have sent Ataalah because the ulama of Kabul are weak in Islam and he would have schooled them.
** (13)               
** (14)                
*** al-Balkhi, in contrast, was not among the great ones of Islam, yet in that meeting the Afghans mistook him as such.
** (15)                  
*** Elias: He [also] composed a shar'(?) to the Supplement to Farabaghi* which he named "al-Ikhah wa-l-fulul"
**** Farabaghi is probaly the auther of an important (legal?) work. Someone then wrote tatimmat kitab al-farabaghi, which is like a supplement or continuation of Farabaghi's work. I think 'Ata Allah wrote a shar' to this. I would GUESS that shar' here means another supplement, maybe an introduction (shara'a can mean to begin), or it is some kind of commentary. It's all guesswork for me as to what it means
** (16)      []   [   
*** //page 128//
** (17)      [ / ]            
*** Elias: huduth al-'alam is a theological term for the world's being created and NOT eternal ('alam is always translated as world, but actually means Cosmos/the universe). Most sunni theologians believe(d) that the world was created by God at some beginning point. Most philosophers, on the other hand, and some theologians believed that the world was eternal and was never created (the word for this is qidam ). This argument essentially rests on the idea of conversation of matter. Matter cannot be created or destroyed. Matter exists. Therefore, it must have always existed. I thought this was settled by the 12th century that the world was created, so this seems kind of strange that he would still be talking about it. (I am assuming his death date is hijri).
** (18)            
** (19)                  
** (20)              
** (21)

* Abu Muhammad Shir Muhammad al-Khoqandi (d. 1241; #695 p. 160b-161) @@scanned@@
** Originally from Farghana, studied in Bukhara, where he gained renown and taught at madrasas (160b).
** Taught at two prominent madrasas (160b):                                                           []                    
** Note that neither of these madrasas are mentioned by Sadr Zia despite Marjani insisting that they are among the most famous; perhaps they are not in Bukhara proper?
** Marjani's father studied under this scholar (160b).
** Slander - this guy was a harsh master, swearing a lot and hitting those who interrupted him; there is also insight here on the prominent works that were taught and how his method differed from that norm (160b):                                                
** (cont.) More complaints (160b):                                         []
*** (cont.) A test by Amir Haydar (160b-161):                  []

** Studied under Atallah bin Hadi Khwajah (161).
** Students who studied under Shir Muhammad himself (161):

* Abu al-Nizam al-Bukhari             (d. 1263; #809, p. 204)
** (2) ...           
** (3)      []        
*** Elias:  Madrasas don't have qadis. I mean a qadi can work as one as a teacher or whatever, but you really wouldn't be called like "qadi of XX madrasa." I think it means he was the head lecturer at several madrasas and was a promoter of jusitce or something.  with a fatha on the nun and Sad means justice,  can mean to rule or judge, right, also to carry out. (You might find it helpful to look at the ToC of Geroge Makdisi's Rise of Colleges book. It's very detailed and he focuses on like every technicality.
** (4)                
** (5)              
*** Elias: I think this might actually mean that Bukhari followed/learned theology from Qursawi. Aqida means like doctrine/statements of belief and is used to refer to theological doctrine regularly. If I am right, then Bukhari described Qursawi.
** (6)             [ \ ]    
** (7)                
*** Elias: 6-7) ~= "He used to say that there was no one from Bukhara like him [Qursawi?]. His theological doctrine [kalm] was above the comprehension of the commoners and outside of normal (marsm) behavior. Because of this, they rejected/reprimanded him. Our friend Nim al-Dn would praise him ( ) by saying that he was more knowledgeable than the masses)
** (8)                
** (9)

Qazanis who went to Bukhara:
* 793, 801, 805, 823, 828, 881, 883, 901 (traveled to Bukhara then Baghdad and Damascus), 908, 913?, 914, 915, 944, 951, 979, 982 (went to Istanbul too), 1003
* Also check out: 799 (Qazani goes to Tiflis); 806 (Shah Shujah buried in Balkh); 865 (looks like Marjani's father); 875 Bulghar died in Bukhara; 889 Indian with some northern connections; 890 Nasrullah's bio; 895 Khoqandi prince; 905 the Afghan amir that ends up in Bukhara; 928 super long bio; 947 emigrated to Ethiopia; 977 ruler of Kashgar (?); 981 Afghan amir
