[[Khoqand Chronicles Index]]

> A.A> Semenov and O.D. Chekhovich, eds., Materialy po istorii Ura-Tiube: Sbornik aktov XVII-XIX vv., trans. A. Mukhtarov (Moscow: Izdatelstvo Vostochnoi Literatury, 1963).

Intro (Predislovie by A. Mukhtarov)
* An incredible amount of medieval documents remain unexamined in the Ferdosi library, Dushanbe (3).
* This particular collection obtained from an ishan-zada from Uratepa (3).
* Uratepa was generally subject to Samarqand or Bukhara, but in the mid 18th century it gained independence.  It also controlled Penjikent, Khujand, and Jizakh; even part of Tashkent paid tribute at times (4).
** "         ,             " (4).
* Apparently the ruler of Uratepa had diplomatic relations with Afghanistan and pushed (tolknul) Timurshah to go to war with Bukhara; though that campaign ended in defeat for Afghanistan (4).
** //not the case re defeat Afghanistan//
** Here citing Dushanbe copy of [[Muhammad Vif- Karmnag, Tuhfat al-Khn (al-Biruni, 2721)]], l. 62.
* Some basic facts on the dynasty: "    XIX .       1866 .  -  17 .    --     12  (1816-1828).    :      " (3).
** (no source cited)
* Constant warfare devastated the local population: "    XIX . -        " (4).
** (no source cited)
* Kokand essentially controlled Uratepa during the reign of Umar: " 1813-1814 .    -  ;       -,      .    ,      - -,      ,      ---,     . - -,    - -" (11).
** Citing Mu'ini, Tarikh-i Bukhara, IVTadj 1229 f. 123.

Doc. 18: 1702-1711 appointment of Uratepa governorship from Ubaydalla Khan (p. 35)
* Document in fact informing Ishan Musa Khwaja of this development.
* Appointment of Akbute Qushbegi to Uratepa, Khujand, and Andijan (35):               
* See also similar doc. 20 (1714).

Doc. 22: 1750 order from Muhammad Fazil Bey in the name of the "khan" granting water rights to an ishan (p. 40).
* Opening:      -   
* //so in 1750 Uratepa governor is still enacting orders in the name of the khan, though it does not mention which khan//

Doc. 23: 1773 order appointing Mir Hasan mudarris of the Friday mosque (p. 42)
* Wording clear that it is the ulama who are doing the appointing:                                                   ...

Doc. 25: Late 18th century  order from Muhammad Khudayar Divanbegi (p. 45)
* Includes language   

Doc. 26: 1804 Yarlik from Amir Haydar appointing a mudarris in the Khudayar Divanbegi madrasa in Uratepa (p. 47)
* Opening:          

Doc. 27: 1805 order from Haydar to keep saying the Friday prayer in Ubaydallah's name in a local mosque (p. 48)
* Opening:          
* (cont.) Premise - Muhammad Salih was ordered by Ubaydallah Khan to do the Friday prayer:                              
* (cont.) Haydar reaffirms that appointment:                       
* (cont.) Though apparently there were some muhtasibs stopping him from doing so:                   1220
* (related) Doc. 28 is Haydar offering Salih various economic benefits.

Doc. 31: 1814 yarlik from Umar Khan appointing a sadr of Uratepa (p. 52)
* Opening:              

Doc. 32: 1817 yarlik from Umar Khan appointing a Mir-i Asad (p. 54)

Doc. 35: 1825 yarlik from Muhammad Ali Khan appointing Muhammad Salih Khwaja khwaja kalan in Uratepa (p. 58)

Doc. 38: 1832 yarlik from Muhammad Ali similar to doc. 35, i.e. also appointing Muhamamd Salih Khwaja Kalan
* Makes it rather clear that local notables are driving this appointment.
[[Library Card Catalog at the Institute of Oriental Manuscripts, St. Petersburg]]
[[Travel Literature Index]]

> B XCIII/29 - .   i  i,   ,  1820  1821 .

> Meiendorf (Polkovnik, Baron).  Otryvok" iz" puteshestviia v" Bukhariiu, Polkovnika Barona Meiendorfa, v" 1820 i 1821 godakh"

This is an early Russian edition, but the Brits had this translated at least as early as 1870 (Calcutta edition).

* Relays the narrative of Bukhara prospering under the early centuries of Arab rule until the Mongols sacked it.  Then the city prospered under Timor despite the fact that he made Samarkand the capital (32).
* Author relays a local tale of Bukhara's founding: ",     i.      i   .       ,  ;     .      : i    ;  i ,     ,      " (33).
** Translation: "It is well known that Eastern people love storytelling.  The Bukharans tell the following about the formation of their city.  In the surrounding areas there were a large number of lakes with an abundance of fish, and there appeared there a large number of craftsmen.  There were insufficient [resources] in the water, so the fishermen turned to agriculture.  Soon the population multiplied, residents built vast houses, and in this manner the city of Bukhara came to be" (33).
* Bukhara became a center of learning: "...      i..." (33).
* Author contends that the name "Bukhara" comes from "Bukh" - Mongol for learning, and "ara" - meaning riches.  The Mongols allegedly named the city such because there were so many scholars there (33).
** Obviously not the case since the name was used long before the Mongols, perhaps even the Arabs (Narshakhi).
** //it is possible that these stories tying the city's origin to Chingis Khan is indicative of popular perceptions of legitimacy//
* Portrays Bukhara as an austere, humorless place: "       ;    , ,     ;       ,   i  :   ..." (35).
* Some stats: about 7-8 thousand houses, 70-80 thousand residents (82).
** 1/4 the residents "Tajik" engaged mostly in tradecraft (83).
* Jews: Apparently a Jew that immigrated from Algeria () had a great influence on improving the state of Jewish education there - "   ,     i,    ,    ,          ,   " (86).
* Tatars: Reports that a great number of runaway soldiers and criminal Tatars have settled in Bukhara (87).
* Afghans: About 2000 in Bukhara, having fled the chaos reigning in their home country (87).
** Most of them were from cities to the east of the the Kabul Khanate (88).
** Some of them were slaves in Bukhara, which the author notes is forbidden for a Sunni to enslave another Sunni (89).
* Slavery - very common in Bukhara, especially from Persia: " ,  ,   ,    i" (90).
** No more than 10 Russian slaves; many more Russian slaves were freed and still lived in Bukhara, though under suspicion as infidels: "          10; i i      i  ,   i,   ,     " (90).
** Estimates a total of 600-700 slaves in Bukhara (90).
* Writes that adulterers are sometimes thrown off the "Mirgarab" tower and dashed upon the rocks: "      ;    " (154).
* Mosques and Madrasses: "  360 ,     ,  60,   " (154).
** Dates the Mir-i Arab madrassa to 1650 under Abdul-Gazi-Khan or Abdul-Muminom (155).
** Catherine the Great revered in Bukhara for donating money for a madrassa (??): "      .      ,       .     ,     i ,  i   4000  ,        .         i..." (155-156). 'Emperor Catherine' bolded and in larger font.
* Punishment: Describes criminals being hanged and decapitated heads in the Registan, and remarks how the populace merely goes about its business (160).
* Author counts 14 bathhouses in the city (161).
* Decline narrative: "  ,        i,    .       i.         ,      i,   ,    i    i    i  .   12      ,      ; , i   , ,   " (162).  (Goes on...)

  1826 No. XIX.  XX.   -  : i  i,    (The bound copy at the Institut Vostochnykh Rukopisei, StP, seems to a be a collection of numerous pieces by Meiendorf)
* Has some information on hierarchy and ranks (161-164).
* Comments on race: "i i     i: , i ,  , i " (165).



[[Repository Index]]
[[Source Guide Index]]

See also: [[Miklukho-Maklai, Persidskie i Tadzhikskie Rukopisi Instituta Vostokovedeniia]]

> N. D. Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia, 3rd ed. (Moscow: Izdatel'stvo "Nauka", 1975).

p. 334, #462: Tarikh-i Badakhshan
Mirza / Mulla Sang Muhammad Badakhsi "Mirza"; 2nd author - Mirza Fazl 'Ali bek Surkhafsar
B 2311
* Author Sang served the Badakhshani amir Muhammad-Shah 1792/3-1821/2; work finished in 1809/9.
* Author Fazl lived in Osh and spent time in Badakhshan.  He extended and finished the work of the first author in 1907.
** It is unknown what changes the second author made to the work of the first; it is also not clear where his work picks up and the previous author's left off.
* Miklukho notes that in addition to being an excellent political history it is very useful for exposing social relations.

p. 313, # 449: Gulshan al-Muluk
  " "
C 1141 (Nov. 182)
* Author: Muhammad Ya'kub Bukhari.
** 12th son of Muhammad Danial (1759-1785); probably died in the 1830s.
* Probably written around 1824-1825; goes through 1830-31.
** A copy of this manuscript is also in the [[first section of V 681|Muhammad Yusuf Munshi, Tarikh-i Muqim Khan and Gulshan al-Muluk (V 681)]]


[[Mr Salmn Samarqand, Tafsl wa Bayn-i Dawlat-i Jamat-i Manghit (IVRSP C 667)]]
*           -     (p. 319, 453; C 667)
* Chronicle runs from p. 161a-178b and is one part of a longer manuscript.
* Written no earlier than 1860 and no later than 1868.
* Pages 177b-178b cover the life of the author himself: "...         ;   -  -  -              ...       -       ;           ,    .      ...         ;   ...       ,         ;              " (319).
* Miklukho-Maklai believes this to be an autograph copy (320).
* Description and value of the work: "      ,   1160/1747 .       , .. 1277/1860 .          ;       ,   ,   XIX .       " (319-320).
* Origin of the manuscript: ". . , 1890 ." (320).

[[Risla-i Muammad Yaqb Bukhr]]
*  -    (p. 318, 452; C 1934)
* 30 pages.  Work begun in 1828 and finished no earlier than 1830.
* Author wrote another work,  , which is similar in content but more detailed. (In fact, there are various versions of that work as well.)  There are many copies of the Gulshan al-Muluk, [[including this one|Muhammad Yusuf Munshi, Tarikh-i Muqim Khan and Gulshan al-Muluk (V 681)]] but only one copy of the Risala.
* Author was the twelfth son of Danial Bey.
* From page 25b is a description of  the various vazirs that served the Manghits.
* For the most complete description of the work, see: Anke von Kugelgen, Legitimatsiia sredneaziatskoi dinastii mangitov d proizvedeniiakh ikh istorikov, XVIII-XIX vv. (Almaty: Daik-Press, 2004), p. 152-
** Kugelgen used the Risala as her main work, turning to the Gulshan al-Muluk when she wanted more detail (154).

[[Dhikr-i Trkh-i Ab al-Fay Khn (Anonymous) (IVRSP C 667)]]
* p. 320, 454; no. C 667
*     
* Anonymous author, written in 1288/1871-1872.
* Very short, unofficial history events from Abu al-Fayz to the enthronement of Muzaffar: 264b-270a.
* In the same volume as [[Mr Salmn Samarqand, Tafsl wa Bayn-i Dawlat-i Jamat-i Manghit (IVRSP C 667)]]
* "...     ,    , - ,   XVX ."


[[Mull Ava Muammad, Tufat al-Tawrkh Khn (IVRSP C 440)]] p. 329, 458; C 440 (572d)
* Title:    
* Author:         
* Written 1286/1869-1870.
* Contents: "     .    :  (. 1).     -   (. 15-16).         1283/1866-67 . (. 98)" (p. 330).

See also: [[Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia]]

> N.D. Miklukho-Maklai, Persidskie i Tadzhikskie Rukopisi Instituta Vostokovedeniia Rossiiskoi Akademii Nauk: Kratkii Alfavitnyi Katalok, 2 vols. (Moscow: Nauka, 1964).

       -   (p. 540, 4002; C 1943)
* Link: [[Abd al-Am Muammad Sm, Mirt al-Khayl (IVRSP C 1943)]]
* Written in 1322 in honor of Abd al-Ahad.  Described in in Miklukho-Maklai's Opisanie, vol. 2, No. 123, and Khadizade p. 127.

         -   (p. 543, 4031; C 1611-1a / Nov. 1302)
* Also in [[SVR|Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]] II, no. 1736.
* Written in 1850, covers 25 poets.
* This is a rough draft and difficult to read; //probably better to use the Uzbekistan copy, if possible, which is far more complete//.

[[Tazkirat Index]]

> Mr Musayyab Bukhr, Kitb-i Maqmt-i Mashikh

A.T. Tagirdzhanov, Opisanie tadzhikskikh i persidskikh rukopisei, Vostochnogo otdela Biblioteki LGU (Leningrad: Izdatelstvo Leningradskogo Universiteta, 1962).
* 150 / p. 362, # 854
* 892 folios
* Author:         
** "...   1217/1802-1803 .,  1232/1816-1817 .,  15- ,         ,         1261/1845 .       1280/1863-1864 ."
* Russian translation of title:      
* Mentioned in Story (v. 2, part 2, p. 1064).
* "...       ,   ,     "
* Much of the work, esp. the part about Ataallah, was written by Muhammad Sharif Khwajah ibn Ataallah (                ).

//DeWeese on Mir Musayyab Bukhari, Kitab-i Maqamat-i Mashayikh 10/2012//: The "title" was just Tagirdzhanov's generic suggestion, as I recall (in one recent citation of the work, I mentioned a Zhukovskii reference in which he suggests another possible title).  I don't have scans, but a partial microfilm; I've tried without success to get copies of the rest, and if you go there again, it just might be helpful in getting copies to ask only for the parts I don't have (extensive as they will be), so let's coordinate folio numbers at some point.  I don't know of anyone who has worked on it; as you know, there are still just the two articles on late Naqshbandi/Mujaddidi history, and neither Babajanov nor von Kugelgen made use of this text.  If someone in St. Petersburg is working on it, I haven't heard of it; and given the tendency for scholars to keep close to materials at their own institutions, and this work's preservation at the University library, I doubt if anyone is working on it.

Contents:
* Lineage of Ataallah: 6a-8b.
* Transmission of  from the Prophet to Ataallah; in practice details numerous shaykhs and scholars, from long ago to more recent times (major section): 9b-165b.
* Short section entitled  about Muhammad Sharif's connections to the Naqshbandiyya, the Yasaviyya / Sultaniyya, and the Kubraviyya: 166a-167a.
* Biographies of __Naqshbandi__ shaykhs, starting with Baha al-Din Naqshband himself (d. 1389) and going up to Niaz Muhammad Chuqmaki (d. 1779): 166a-434a.
* Biographies of the __Yasavi__ shaykhs, beginning with Ahmad Yasavi (d. 1167) and going through Azizana Mavlana Usman at the end of the 18th century. No heading.: 438b-546b.
* Biographies of the __Kubravi__ shaykhs, starting with Najm al-Din Kubra (d. 1221) and going through Akmal al-Din Muhammad Kamila al-Badakhshi (d. 1719).  Unfinished, no heading: 548a-584b.
* Biographies of the __Suhravardi__ shaykhs, starting with Shihab al-Din Suhravardi (d. 1234) and ending with Akhund Muhammad Tayyib (d. 1638).  No heading.: 585a-598a.
* Biographies of the __Chisti__ saints, beginning with Khwadjah Mu'in al-Din Chishti (d. 1235) and ending with Muhammad Murad (d. 1719).  No heading.: 602a-618a.
* Biographies of the __Ishqiyya Shatariyya__ (       ) beginning with Abdallah Shattar (d. 1485) and ending with Burhan al-Din Burhanpuri (d. 1673): 623b-628b.
* Biographies of the __Dahbidi__ shaykhs, beginning with Musa Khwadjah Dahbidi and ending with Abd al-Sattar Makhdum (d. 1860): 629a-676a.
* Biographies of Hadi Khwajah's descendants:
** Detailed biography of Ataallah: 676b-718b.
** Biography of Rahmatallah: 724b-762a.
** Biography of Muhammad Sharif Khwajah: 763b-893a.

!!!Introductions

Amo Bad (1b):
* First substantive line - At 15 years of age enters the tutelage of Rahmatallah and Muhammad Sharif Khwajah (1b-2):                     [ ]           [ ]      []    [ ]    [ ]                                      []      []                     []     []   
* Note: The Tagirdzhanov transcribes much of the table of contents starting on p. 2.

!!!Biographies of Naqshbandi shaykhs, starting with Baha al-Din Naqshband himself (d. 1389) and going up to Niaz Muhammad Chuqmaki (d. 1779): 166a-434a.

Niaz Muhammad Chuqmaki        (d. 1779): 428b-434a.
* Disciple of Imla (428b):      
* (cont.) Native of a village outside of Bukhara, came from modest origins (428b):                                         []                    [ ]    []  
* Naturally, he came to Bukhara to study (428b):                       
* (cont.) In Bukhara he realized that studying without a sufi master was basically impossible, which brought him to Imla (428b):

[[Repository Index]]

> A. M. Mirzoev and A. M. Boldyrev, eds., Katalog vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii Nauk Tadzhikskoi SSR (Stalinabad (Dushanbe): Akademiia Nauk Tadzhikskoi SSR, 1960).


!!!Tom 1

  p.180; 172, 2012
     -  
* This is Ahmad Donish's sufi metaphysical work published in the second half of the 19th century.
* For instance, the section entitled        discuses: "       ,  ,    " (p. 181).
* This work also discusses Russia and European countries.
* ch. 15 -       : "        ,   .." (183).
* ch. 20 -          : "...                    " (183).

      p. 188; 177, 294
        
* This is the biography of a qazi that lived outside of Samarkand in the second half of the 18th century.  It was composed in 1836-1837.

 p. 188; 178, 1428/1  [[Link to Notes|Muhammad isari, Yddshth, 1268-1296]]
      
* @@money@@: "  ,  ,   28     1268/1851-1852 .  1296/1878-1879 .   ,            ,   ,   ,              .    ,      10      .   ,      -   - ()   " (p.188-189).
* (From inspecting the book itself): This manuscript is very much situated in the Persian poetical tradition.  Just like Sadi & co., it is divided into sections - verse, hikayat, verse.  Also, there seem to be two separate books here...

 p. 189; 179, 1917/I
Anonymous author
* Work covers all sorts of topics (including a bunch of stuff on earthquakes - Northrop might be interested?).
* "...      1377/1919 .   ... (. 172)" (190).

         p. 190; 180, 230/III
        
* This is one of the Sadr Zia compositions.  According to the catalog, it includes interesting information about the poets and literary life in Bukhara.

      p. 191; 181, 230/V
* Another Sadr Zia work, this one ridiculing the Bukharan Ulama.

  p. 239; 250, 2025
      
* Compiled in 1832 and documents experiences earlier in the century.
* This guy was stationed as an ambassador all over the place.  A lot of it is about his experiences in Turkey, but also: "...     ,   ,        ,   - ...     ,      XVIII ..." (p. 239-240).
* This work also has tons of general history about Afghanistan and the khanates.
* Perfect: "...       , , ,    XVIII   XIX " (p. 240-241).

     p. 119; 122, 1243/X
* Interesting - the 1910 Bukharan riots in poetic verse.

  p. 129; 130, 204
  
* This is a eclectic history in verse; of possible interest just because of the colorful history of the author, who originated from Kunduz.
* Also worth noting that Mirzoev has a really detailed, list-by-list description of the text, so it would not be necessary to read the whole thing.

!!!Tom 6
This tom describes letters and documents (inter alia) but there is less information about the contents of those materials.

    p. 155; 2165, 1031/I
  
* A collection of letters from a servant of the Mughals who lived in Peshawar, Kashmir, and Lahore.
* Has information on Nadir Shah's assault on India and the general situation in Peshawar.





[[Repository Index]]
Related: [[Mirzoev and A. M. Boldyrev, eds., Katalog vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii Nauk Tadzhikskoi SSR]]

> Said Ali Mujani and Amr Yazdan Ali Mardan, eds., Fihrist-i nusakh-i khatti-i Farsi-i Anstitu-yi Asar-i Khatti-i Tajikistan, 4 vols. (Tehran: Vizarat-i Umur-i Kharijah, 1997).

!!!Volume 1

     p. 112; 483 [[Link to Notes|Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]
         
* Author lived 1817 - 1893.  Book written 1864-1870.
* This is a poetical biography / excerpts type text.  Interesting because it includes Iranian and Central Asian authors.  It also includes information on a circle of Khoqandi poets.
* From this page forward there are lots of other poetical biographies as well - tons of em.
* About Tajik poets in the late 18th and 19th century.

 p. 112; 952
   
* 1860.
*          @@  @@ - so this also includes non-poets.
* Has a brief history of some of the amirs of Bukhara and the end of the work.

  p. 113; 394
         
* Author died 1920; finished in 1910.
* Includes 125 poets; not completed - only includes poets alif - qaf.

     p. 115; 3220
      
* Died 1922; completed 1904
* Entries on 118 poets from the second half of the 19th century and beginning of the 20th.
* The original is at al-Biruni - number 64 there.

  p. 115; 230/1
        
* So this is one of Sadr Zia's literary productions, finished in 1910.
* Focuses on 45 poets and literateurs in the second half of the 19th century and beginning of the 20th.

  p. 116; 1265
 
* Author died 1822; written 1812.
* Very brief summary of the lives of Kokandi poets in both Tajik and Uzbek.

!!!Volume 3
    p. 334; 1224/21
* Written in 1900; describes the various shrines of Bukhara.  Author unknown, though in the book it says he was the  .
* Contents: ...   149        22    

[[Manuscripts Index]]
[[Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]]

> Mubraknmijt-i Amr Muaffar biq Mu al-Dn

       Semenov vol. 1 p. 163; 386, 407
Date range: 1290-(1294)
*   ()     .            ,  ,         .
** [[Sadr Zia's Tazkirat|adr , Takr-i Ashr]] has information on Badr al-Din.
* Question here then is: What sorts of things could the Amir presume to command a local qazi?

General observations:
* Language with which the amir addresses a regional qazi is very respectful:    
** You have the esteem of everyone:                  
* Oftentimes the responses are simple acknowledgements that whatever correspondence Muhiaddin was sending were received:            (e.g. p. 3).  //Note that in specific examples below I have assumed this introduction.//
** Sometimes the letter addresses may qazis at once, saying that all of their letters have been noted.  (17.)
* Not all the letters are addressed to Muhi al-Din; for instance, letter 8 is addressed to the ra'is   
** Another is to Mirakhur Shaisaid.  (Mirakhur was a position kind of like police for arresting people.)
** Another to     (p. 32).
* Interesting that even a regional qazi was in close personal touch with the amir.
* Most of the action seems to be taking place in the tuman of Vbkand, which is the same thing as Kmn, a suburb of Bukhara.  See [[Trkh-i Humyn-i Gulshan, 1328]].

[[Perti, Catalogue of Acquired Manuscripts]]
[[Kashmir Chronicles Index]]


[[Perti|Perti, Catalogue of Acquired Manuscripts]]: 81 - Waqiat-i Kashmir, Muhammad Azam bin Khair al-Zaman Khan: Acc. no. 319 (p. 47)
* "... a history of Kashmir from the earliest times down to 1160 A.H. (1747 A.D.). The author commenced this work in 1848 A.H. (1735-36 A.D.) and dedicated it to Muhammad Shah. It includes biographical notices and extracts from the writings of the principal Shaikh, Savants and poets of Kashmir."
* From Catalogue of the Arabic and Persian Manuscripts in the Khuda Bakhsh  Oriental Public Library, vol. 7, p. 126-128: "The work forms the chief authority for Newail's "Sketch of the Mahomedan history of Cashmere," Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, vol. xv., pp. 409, 441.  See also Wilson, Asiatic Researches, vol. xv., pp. 2, 5... An Urdu translation, by Munshi Ashraf Ali, has been lithographed in Dhili, 1846..." (127).

This history is nearly a tazkirat, with a plentitude of entries detailing individuals.

Introduction
* Cold open (1):          [  ]        []                       []                   
* Amo bad...: a marvelous country without parallel (4):          []                               [ ]        
* (cont.) Many Hindus have written about this country in centuries prior (4):                        
* Table of Contents (6):                                                                []                
** 16: Qism-i Avval - Pre-Islamic Period
** 60: Qism-i Davvom - Islamic Sultans
[[Travel Literature Index]]

> Hafiz Muhammad Fazil Khan, The Uzbek Emirates of Bukhara & Khulum in the Early 19th Century as described in an Indian Travelogue: Tarikh-i-Manazil-i-Bukhara, trans. Iqtidar Husain Siddiqui (Patna: Khuda Bakhsh Oriental Public Library, 1812).

Translator's Introduction (i.e. by Siddiqui)
* Khulum: "The three kingdoms that an European invader might face on his way to India were (i) the kingdom of Bukhara, (ii) the Principality of __Khulum__ (sandwitched between Afghanistan and the kingdom of Bukhara, comprising the parts of Balkh and Badakhshan territories), and (iii) the kingdom of Afghanistan" (4).
** The ruler of Khulum was Mir Qulij Ali Beg (6).
* The expedition party of 1812: "Saiyid 'Izzatul1ah was accompanied by two other persons, Hafiz Muhammad Fazil Khan, an India Pathan of Bareilly town (Western Uttar Pradesh) and Sarfaraz Khan, son of Mulla Abdul Samad, the Mufti (Jurist) of Bukhara. On their entry in Afghanistan the envoy, Saiyid Izzatullah was detained by Bahadur Khan (the governor) in the fort of Attack. Thereupon, his companions had to proceed on their journey without him" (5).
* Characterization of Bukhara: "Unlike Alexander Burnes and Mohan Lal, Fazil Khan appears to have been highly impressed by the socio-political system that he witnessed in the Muslim states of Khulum and Bukhara. The Bukhara society uuder Mir Hyder Ali is protrayed by him as an ideal society" (7).
** "The author glows with joy and pride wlien lie describes the judicial system based on the Islamic Sharia' which treated every person equal irrespective of birth or creed... Religious divines (ulama) commanded great respect in the society and students were looked after properly. The state and rich people endowed property to the madrassas (col1eges) for their upkeep" (7).
* Author of the source portrays the Bukharan army as a formidable force, despite the fact that "It makes it clear that the anny organization did not undergo any change since the 16th century" (8).
* Health systems: "The only important thing that our author found wanting in Bukhara was the hospit11s maintained by the state as well as the availability of expert physicians" (9).

!!!The Travelogue

Chapter 1
* Balkh is subservient to Kabul: "The 26th stage is from the city of Balkh, lying in the western direction, inhabited by Uzbeks and Tajiks and held by the governor, Najib Ullah Khan, posted by Muhmud Shah, the King of Kabul" (13).
** But Khulum is definitely not: "Inside the border of Kbulum under the government of Mir Qulij Ali Beg there is neither the fear of the robbers and highwaymen nor Sa'ir taxes (numerous taxes on animals) are collected. In Balkh which is governed by Najib Ullah Khan, appointed by his Majesty, Mahmud Shah, the King of Kabul, tax cannot be collected owing to the interference and objection from Mir Qulj Ali Beg" (17).
* A desert separates Khulum and Bukhara; apparently, Bukhara controls the Oxus itself: "The entire track is a waterless desert, forming the boundary between the territories Qulij Ali Beg and Mir Haidar, the king of Bukhara. Both of the banks of the river Oxus and the boats availble there are under the charge of Mir Rahim Ali, the son of the uncle of Mir Haidar, the King of Bukhara" (16).
** "There are no hillocks and fortresses between Khulum and Bukhara" (18).
* Territory between Khulum and Bukhara is very dangerous: "People may, however, travel through that track when they are in caravan and sufficiently laced with weapons. If the party of the travellers is small and without weapons, they can pass through safely in two ways; first, (by chance) they do not meet the highwaymen on their way, (2) they employ people of the Ghilja clan on wages to be their guides" (16).

Chapter 2: Account of the boundaries of the Country of Mir Qulij Ali Beg, the ruler of Khulum
* Description of the ruler of Khulum: "Mir Qulij Ali Beg is sixty years old but vigorous, fair-complexioned, having a reddish face. He has only a few hairs of his beard on the chin and they are all white. He has short eyes and wide forehead. He wears Uzbek dress" (20).
* The Amir would go to the bazaar personally to inspect weights, look for fraud, etc. (20).
* Khulum has a Hazara population: "There is the village Zubki in the south of Khulum, inhabited by Hazara people who profess Shi'i fai'h. Most of the road upto the vicinity of the village, Iqrabad, the dependency of Butbamiyan (Bamiyan) in the Kabul Kingdom is infested with the Hazaras (robbers) who attack and pillage the caravans proceeding to Kabul or Kbulum" (21).
** The Amir captured and enslaved many of these Hazaras (21).
* Interesting - the Mir's son governed Balkh for the King of Kabul: "The Mir has got thirteen sons. One of them Ahmad Beg, aged 20 years was his eldest son. He was the governor of Abik on behalf of His Majesty Mabmud Shah, the king of Kabul. His title was vali of Balkh. The annual income accruing from the BaUch canal that amounts to 70 thousand rupees was granted to him by Mahmud Shah, the King of KabuI. He passed away all of a sudden towards the close of the year 1802 A.D. As half of his body became blue after his death, he was supposed to have been poisoned by some enemy" (22).
** After the son died the King of Kabul "However, the government and administration is carried on by Mir Qulij Ali Beg in the territories of Balkh and Khulum. The hakim of Balkh does not enjoy any power" (23).
** "The revenue of Balkh is not sent to the king of Kabul. But the hakim 'of Balkh sends present, consisting of horses, etc., every year. Sometimes, Mir Qulij Beg sends cows and Turki horses as gifts from a friend to Fath Khan, the Wazir (prime Minister) of Mohammad Shah, the king of Kabul, for Painda Khan, the father ofFath Khan Wazir had don~ Mir Qulij Khan some favour in the past" (23-24).
* Governance: "The army men are not paid their allowances in cash but land has been reserved for them" (22).

Chapter 3: The Boundaries, Divisions and Officers in the Emirate of Bukhara
* Haydar appoints his sons as governors to various cities, but he also appoints slaves (25).
* The significance of mir vs. bey: "The title of Be or Mir is conferred upon the chiefs (officers). Be is higher in importance than Mir. Therefore, the Wazir ofMir Haider Padshah is (called) Hakim Be. Even the name of the father of Mir Haider Padshah is known in that country as Shah Murad Be. Mir Haider Padshah is called Mir on account of his noble origin. The noblemen and officers, great as well as small in the personal service of Mir Haider Padshah are known as Mir Koh" (26).
* Has a list of the goods that are traded back and forth between Kabul and Bukhara, as well as Herat and Kashgar (27).
* Minorities - Hindus and Jews: "The Shikarpuri Hindus go to Bukhara in connection with trade alld some stay there for six months while others spend the whole year and rom back to Kabul and Shikarpur after they had done their business. No Hindu owns a house in Bukhara. All the Jews (of Bukhara) own one thousand houses in a settlement near th~ gate of Salah Khana (magazine), in the city of Bukhara. They are engaged in the trade of silk, the work of dyer, carpentry, slaughtering and selling meat" (28).
* Description of Haydar: "The title held by Mir Haider, the Padshah of Bukhara, is Bahadur Khan. He is thirty-five years old, tall and a good looking young man of red and white complexion. His face has turned yellowish on account of his religiosity and piety; he observes fast on alternate days throughout thc twelve months of the year, and spends night in vigil, and administers justice daily. He has a beard. He wears an Uzbeki cap on which. he wraps (First) the Uzbeki turban resembling the Arabs' head-dress and then a strap of (another) cloth" (29).
** Maternal sayyid descent: "The mother of Haider Padshah of Bukhara is of Saiyid origin" (29).
** Haydar's piety: "This (present) King gets up at midnight and offers namaz-i tahajud (mid-night prayer), and then remains busy with reciting the names of God till moming. Having offered his early morning prayers he imparts lessons to forty-five students on the hadith (tr:Jditions uf the Prophet). Thereafter he sits in the hall on a throne covered with green velvet. He always remains on his knees (in siting posture)" (29).
* Courtly ulama: "In the royal assembly the Saiyids and the ulamas (scholars) sit on the right hand of the king. The saiyids sit near the king and then ulamas sit on their left..." (29).
* Court Shariah law: "All the petitioners sit before the king without much distance between them. Everyone of them submits his petition to the king, the latter having enquired into the matter dictates the order according to the book (Islamic law). There are a few bound books on fiqh (Islamic Jurisprudence) placed on the throne. In the afternoon, five or six distingushed scholars join the king and then discussion is held about matters relating to science and knowledge. The king not only listens to them, but also takes part in the discussion" (30).
* Royalty and shrine visitation: "The king stays with his mother in the house at night on Tuesday. In the morning, on Wednesday he goes on foot to the shrine of his holiness Baha-ud-Din Naqshband, and having offered prayers [on his grave] comes back on a horse and enters Bukhara distributing articlcs [moncy, etc.] in charity" (31).
* "The second brother, whose mother is one of the descendants of Khwaja Ahrar, resides in Shahr-I Sabz and the hakim of [the place is] Niaz Ali Be. Mir Haider, the king, sends him his maintenance allowance from his own pocket. The said hakim is in rebellion against the king of Bukhara" (31).
** //huh? so the king's brother fled to Shahrisabz but the king sends him money anyway?//
** "The cause of the arrival of Husain Khan in Shahr~i-Sabz, is that he was the hakim of Samarkand at the time of Mir Haider's accession to the throne. As he refused to pay allegiance to Mir Haider, the king having been informed about his conduct, deputed an army for setting him right" (32).
* Note that the author also describes Kokand as temporarily in rebellion: "He was in rebellion against the king of Bukhara. He was unjust, oppressive and a tyrant" (31).
* What does "rebellion" mean?  "Likewise Niaz Ali Be, the hakim of Shahr-i-Sabz and Saiyid Be the hakim of Hisarll are in rebel1ion against the king of Bukhara. But both of them always send their envoys with gifts and letters of submission to tbe King of Bukhara. Haji Firoz-ud-Din, the vali of Herat, also sends his envoy to the court of Bukhara" (33-34).
* Shifting symbols of royal legitimacy: "Since Mir Haider, the king is of gentle nature, Hafiz of the Quran (one who has committed the Quran to memory), and a just ruler known for his piety, religiosity and sound scholarship, he __had the word Padshah (king) removed__ from his coins. In all nobility and high minded ness, he had Amir-ul-Mominin (for him) struck on the coin instead" (34).
* Everyone is armed: "In the whole of the country of Turkestan every man, smaIl as well as high, ties a scimitar to his waist. Some persons have one dagger while other carry two daggers. In short nobody is found without a dagger" (34).
* Womens' clothing: "The ladies wear a short coloured silken head cover made in Bukhara which does not come upto their breast. Their garments are like those of men. They wear shoes and slippers made of dressed sheep skin which is covered with banat of black colour [woollen cloth] with embroidery work. Some [ladies] wear [shoes] simply made of dressed sheep skin with no banat at all. They put on tight trousers and come out from their houses with a black sheet of cloth covering them" (35).
* Author is very impressed by the number and size of the __madrassas__, reporting that some even have up to three hundred hujras (38).
** "There is (at least) one teacher for every branch (of learning) in the madrassa, and two students live in one room. The founder of the madrassa having purchased several bighas (acres) of cultivable land and few shops, endowed them for the maintenance of the teachers and the students" (38).
** Non-waqf salaries: "In addition to (this income) the King also gives an annual cash grant to every madrassa. The King rather pays the prominent teachers every month (at different rates) five tilas to fifteen til as" (38).
* Has some interesting information on physicians in Bukhara, how most of them are of poor quality, and on the legal proceedings for indicting quacks (39).
* Author's note: "In the month of April, 1812, Saiyid 'Izatullah Khan, the servant of the government of the Company of Angrez Bahadur (the English East India Company) proceeded to Bukhara on the persuasion of Nawab Muntazim-ul Daula, Mukhtar-ul Mulk; Charles Hafles, (Mr) Metcalfe Sahib Bahadur and Sahib-i Wala-Manaqib (Mr.) William Moore Kraft Sahib Bahadur" (40).
[[Chronicles Index]]
[[Timeline of Chronicles]]

> Muammad Vaf- Karmnag, Tufat al-Khn (al-Biruni, 2721)

1745-68/9 M. Vafa Karminagi: Tuhfat al-khani [P., Bukh.] *
* Excerpt translated into Russian (Storey Bregel p. 1150, 1007).
* Four copies at al-Biruni: Semenov 1 p. 77, 195-199; 16, 2721, 2726/III, 1508, 615/III ; best quality is probably 2721
* Mirzoev 1, p. 101; 105, 1426/1.

!!!                                     (p. 18)
* Introducing Nadir Shah (18b):   []                                                                                    ...
* Quickly covers Nadir's conquest of Iran, Iraq, Khorasan, and India; Nadir had a bit more trouble with Afghanistan though (19-19b):                                                                                  
* Incorporating the Qandahar army (19b):                             
*                         []                                    
* Nadir conquers India and takes the Peacock throne (20-20b).
* Proclaiming himself Shah, Caesar, Alexander (20b):                                                        
* Moved on to Balkh from India in 1151 (20b).
* Persianate language in poetry about Nadir's march on Turan (20b):      -      -     -       -     ...
**     -       -       -        -     [ ] -       
* Difficult language about Nadir Shah's titles, critical of his arrogance in taking the title Shahinshah (20b):                            
** verse (20b-21):  -      -       -       -         -      -      
** (cont.) Criticizing the arrogance of him taking the title Shahinshah (21):                 [ / ]                                                                              

Riza Quli goes to Qarshi:                  [ 
* Negative portrayal of Riza Quli's army on its way to Turkestan (21):                                      
* The battle raged long and hard until Riza Quli was routed by the "army of Islam" (not what happens in [[other accounts|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Nadir Shah]]) (22):                                                 
* Rahim Khan (?) resisting the invaders (22b):                                                    
* Abu al-Fayz could not defend his kingdom; Rahim Khan advises go to war (22b).

               (p. 22b)
* Abu al-Fayz wages jihad (23):                         
** (cont.) Bahadur Qul of Samarkand comes as well:                     
* Bravery of the "armies of Islam" against the "enemies of religion" (23b):                             
* Size of the Qizilbash army (24):                       


23b

!!!                       
* Pushing the conflict back to the Shibanid period (26b):                                                                                                           
* The author is really portraying this as a holy war against the infidels; even busts out a Quranic jihad citation (27):      -                            
* Nadir Shah's reign of terror (27):                                               
* Qizilbash designs on Bukhara and the house of Islam (27b):                                           
* No one in Bukhara was happy about the approach of Nadir Shah (28):                                
* From Balkh Nadir moved to Charjuy (28).
* Portrays Abu al-Fayz as terrified at the approach of Nadir (28b):             []          [ / ]         
** On hearing of the invasion, Abu al-Fayz sends for help from Qarshi (i.e. almost certainly Rahim Khan) (28b):

[[Rukopisnyi Fond Index (Institut Vostochnykh Rukopisei)]]
[[Manuscripts Index]]


Rukopisnyi Otdel Index #:  (V) 681
Catalog designation:  482. Tarikh.  Short history of the Bukharan emirate from 1022/1613 - 1246/1830. "...     ,     6 ,   , , ,   ."

//Note//: Because this work is not properly identified, I initially thought it might be an unknown work, but it is in fact Muhammad Yusuf Munshi's history, which has been translated: Moammad-Yusof Moni b. Kja Baq Bali, Tri-e Moqim-ni, tr. A. A. Semenov, Tashkent, 1956, in Russian.  

Moammad-Yusof Moni b. Kja Baq Bali, Tri-e Moqim-ni, tr. A. A. Semenov, Tashkent, 1956.
* Very popular work, but most copies were made in the 19th century.  " ,     -     ,    " (5).
* Possible origin of the Petersburg copy?: "   .. ,    1820-1821 .,       '- '     " (6).
** //Though this would be impossible since on p. 174 the date 1272 (1855) is listed.//
* Note that Semenov's translation only has the second book; both the six page first book and the Manghit section are not present.

N. D. [[Miklukho-Makla, Istoricheskie sochineniya (Historical works)|Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia]], Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopise Instituta vostokovedeniya (Description of Persian and Tajik manuscripts of the Institute of Oriental Studies) 3, Moscow, 1975; the catalogs 8 vols. were first published 1955-68, and the main title varies. Volume 3.
* The second book is in fact Gulshan al-Muluk ( ) by Muhammad Yakub, the twelfth son of Muhammad Danial, the second Manghit Amir (313).
* Miklukho-Maklai's entry for the first part of this manuscript (i.e. Tarikh-i Muqim-Khani) is entry 430; his entry for the second half (i.e. Gulshan al-Muluk) is entry 451.
* There are many different editions of the Gulshan al-Muluk; this one clips off the beginning, but contains the most valuable part that goes up to 1830 (316).
* The author mentions his name on p.147a (316).
* Miklukho-Maklai notes that the very end section of the book about Nasrullah starting on p174a  was probably written after the completion of the rest of it, very close to the events themselves (317).
* p. 175a lists rulers of Balkh, Kunduz, Tash-Kurgan, Hisar, and Ura-Tyube (317).

From [[Story|Stori and Iu. E. Bregel, Persidskaia literatura: Bio-bibliograficheskii obzor]]
* Translated: ,     "--",  ' ", , 1949.

Initial Notes
* There is a Russian notation on the inside cover "1910  5."
* Date at the end of the second "sub-book" is 1225 (1810) (p. 132).

!!!Perusal Index
* Fairly certain that pages 1-6 is just preamble, i.e. praise to God, Muhammad & co., etc.  These pages also make up "sub-book" 1.
* 12b: Tale of the rise of Chingiz Khan
** 15: Chingiz and Khwarazmshah
** 15b: Chingiz and Balkh; 16b: the plunder of Balkh and Tirmiz
* 19b: Maqala 1 on Shibani Khan
** 27: A Shibani conquest of Balkh - during reign of   ; he sents    to Balkh.
** 32: Abdallah Khan
* 33b: Maqala 2 on the Astrakhanids
** 36b: Revenge in Kunduz
** 39: Enthronement of a new khan     and sending his brother    to Balkh
** 46: Date - 1084 / 1673
** 46b: Someone sent by Jahangir from Hindustan
** 54: The battle with Hindustan for Balkh (I think).
** 58b: Someone from Urgenj (judging by the name briefly takes the thrown of Mavrannahr and is killed quickly thereafter.
** 67: Sending someone to Balkh
** 68->: numerous enthronements in Balkh; 75: attack by a sultan of Balkh on Bukhara.
** 80b: Aurangzeb of Hindustan sends on embassy in 1096/1684.
** 88b: Something to do with the Kaisars of Rome i.e. Ottomans and Bukhara.
* 109: Maqala 3 on the enthronement of        in Balkh
** 115: year of 1115/1703
** 126: Rahim Ataliq attacks Hisar
** 130: something about Kunduz
** 132: date listed at end of second book is 1225 (1810).
* 133b: Beginning of "sub-book" 3.
** 134: Mentions Nadir's conquest of Bukhara in 1152/1739.
** 136: Lists governors of all the different provinces
** 150: Amir Mausum
** 161: Haydar
** 174: Date 1272 (1855) is mentioned.

* Now we introduce the khan
