[[Manuscripts Index]]
Catalog: [[Mirzoev and A. M. Boldyrev, eds., Katalog vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii Nauk Tadzhikskoi SSR]], p. 188; 178, 1428/1

 
      
Mrz Bb bin Dmal afar Muammad ir

!!!Basic Data from Catalog Description
Memoir covers the 28-year period 1268/1851-1852 to 1296/1878-1879, which includes the Russian invasion, from which the author fled in 1866.  A potentially invaluable source as the author received his education in Bukhara and traveled around the region serving in a variety of positions.  Mirzoev notes that the style is interesting and characteristic of epistelography in the period; as such the author switches back and forth between narrative and prose.  There are poems between all the different  that take up a few pages.  Every section heading (after the first few) denotes a new  even when I do not title them as such in my notes.

Some general thoughts: The Russians are barely mentioned in this text, only in a poem at the beginning, and then in the strange story of the mutant calf portent.  Yet perhaps the consequences of the invasion can be seen; Hisari's Bukhara is a more coherent state under the Russian largesse than it had been before, which comes through in the clockwork pilgrimages by the hakims to pay homage to the emir.

!!!Introduction: God, the Prophet, Judgment Day, and the Four Rightly Guided Caliphs
Book opens with Persian poetry about the aforementioned topics.

!!!On the Qualities of Nasrullah Khan:        
4b
* As the author leads in to his description of Nasrullah's qualities, he links the khan directly to the Islamic notables of the introduction (Muhammad & co.), whom he refers to as the first kings of Bukhara:         
* Nasrullah's Islamic credentials are referenced quite explicitly (as are his justice, greatness, hunting and battle prowess, etc.);    
* Persianate reference: Nasrullah taking power is described as ____      in the year 1261.
5
* Nasrullah is praised for expanding the ranks of the ulama:   ; he is also praised for expanding the military, etc.
5b
* Nasrullah dies and the author begins lavishing praise on his son, Muzaffar al-Din.

!!!Poems to the Ark, Sufis, Ulama, Army
* Note that the author distinguishes     and   from one another in separate poems.

! 
This section begins the autobiographical section of the author's account with him traveling from Hisar to Bukhara.

11b
* Author's full name:      
* In the year 1268 (1851-1852) the author set out from Hisar in search of:       
* Author leaves the comfort of his home-city friends and trades his clothes for tattered ones (or they become tattered on the journey).
12
* Nevertheless, he commits himself to the road heart and soul (    ), and overcomes the pain ( ) through his commitment to learning.
* For the journey he takes three companions: one was a scholar (     ); one was a practical sort (     ); one was simply a friend who agreed to travel the world (         ).
* About the journey itself the author only mentions that they spend several () days and stay in houses along the way ().
12b
* Hisari spends six months traveling in want of learning but lacking the necessary funds:            
* "Ghudjuwan [EI, Frye] (today Gizduvan), a large village in the northeastern part of the oasis of Bukhara, on the tributary of the Zarafshan River at present called Pirmast, formerly the Kharqan Rud... At present the village is sixteen kilometres / 10 miles from the railroad station of Kyzyl-Tepe and ca. 50 km / 30 m. from Bukhara."
* Ghudjuwani (EI, Naficy): Died 575 / 1179. Studied in Bukhara under Abu Ya'kub Yusuf Hamadani.
* Eventually he ends up in   where he absconds to a mosque for .
13
* Author inserts a poem depicting his diligence and love of learning; the second line equates his inkwell ( - check this word) to the cup of Jamshid, freely mixing Persianate symbolism to describe an Islamic education.
**            
*** The pen is my banner, the inkwell my chalice of Jamshid
**           
*** A single written page is my empire, preferable to all the material world
* It appears that the author spent these six months achieving the necessary language skills (  ) as well as enough money ( ) to finally go to Bukhara, though it does not say how he earned that money.
* Author sells his wares and procures a room () from  
* Hisari spent __10 years__ in that cell training.
13b
* Hisari spent 10 years in the pursuit of knowledge:   
* Sufism and Ulama: The author justifies his learning by the fact that he is embarked on a Sufi path:         
14
* Despite having spent 10 years engaged in training in Bukhara, the author expresses regret at having to leave through thick metaphors.
** (continues on to following page):       
14b
* There is some dense language about why exactly the author was forced to "abandon" his studies, but the end result was that, for the sake of money, he was forced into the service of the Amirs:          
* He also (may have; language dense) returned home to Hissar during this time; in any case, after some contemplation, he resolved to enter the service of the Amirs and improve his lot.

!!!Serving the Amirs in 
15
* To serve the amirs Hisari was forced to pick up and move to the province of  (called to , which according to Faizollah was a place where the Bukharan amirs used to vacation).
* It was Hisari's first visit to the province and he had no previous acquaintances, so it was a lonely place for him.  As a result, he was forced to spend 8 nights in a public sarai.
* He describes the province as desolate (owl-like? ) and writes a long poem about his loneliness there.
16
* A young man happens by his sarai and in his loneliness the author befriends him; the youth pointedly lavishes praise honors upon Hisari and flatters him as he is interrogating him.  Hisari obliges and tell him everything.
* After interrogating Hisari, the youth takes him to the  
16b
* The young man took him to the Iilchikhana, apparently to be registered.
* Khoja Ismail was one of the local hakim's relatives and the most powerful guy in the region, even though he had no official position (he was the owner of a sarai):                               
* Hisari too took refuge under Khoja Ismail's patronage; after 40 days Hisari moved into his residence and quickly moved up the ranks to become one of his most important advisers.
** Author was lavished with favor (continues on to next page):             
17
* The youth is appointed  and lavished with weatlh and in turn lavished wealth upon Hisari, who rarely left his side in service.
* Hisari served the youth as a  for a ( ) long time.  Hisari emphasizes his utter devotion to this "youth" come Amlakdar.

!                            
This section, starting on 18b, seems to depict a major government housecleaning.  A gallant deputy of the amir shows up, deposes the entire previous court (i.e. the court of the young amlakdar from the previous section; //the author's lack of names makes it difficult to follow who is who in this section//), and starts an accounting process.
18b
* A young rider in red clothing shows up like a whirlwind.
19
* The rider is spitting mad ( ) and immediately starts an investigation.
* In a rage he seized the various records of state:                              
19b
* Certain members of the court of questionable moral fiber () fear reprisal (presumably for the abuses that are being investigated) and fled.  This causes general disturbance as everyone who had taken from the general treasury was called to account and in the space of an evening disappeared.
21b
* After the initial tumult when the new governor ( ) arrives and conducts his investigation, the province is returned to order:      
* The new governor prepares lavish presents to take to the Amir's court in Bukhara:     
22
* Author goes into some detail here describing the courtly supplication on both sides.The new governor lavishes thanks upon the Amir and is in turn rewarded handsomely.
* "Beloved" imagery - two boy courtesans ( ), possibly eunochs, of great beauty are sent to the new governor.
** Even the ceder tree (known for its strength) would bend as they passed:           
** Continues on to the next page with another metaphor about a partridge throwing itself in water from the shame of feeling heat when they pass.
22b
** Continuing beloved metaphors, even mentions the little bells () that are tied to the feet:             
* The new governor had taken a bunch of his relatives with him, who would serve in his new government, and they were also rewarded.
23
* This page returns to the plight of Hisari throughout all of this.  The author ended up in the retinue of   who was the son of  , i.e. that influential person from the province of 
* They were sent to the province of , where the author spent three months.
* However, while the author continued to benefit from the proceeds of his patrons' largesse, he soon ran into money problems once again.
23b
* Somewhat melodramatically, he even compares his penury to a shepherd's dog:           
25
* Author continues with metaphors about the stinginess of his master.
25b
* (//check//) Author compares his plight to being imprisoned (pretty sure that is a metaphor... but possible that he was not allowed to leave) but that by withdrawing into religion he persevered.
* (//check//) The others in the government were suspicious of the author and investigating him, so he leaves for  once again.

!                             
26
* Author moves from  to  for work; journey takes 3 days, arrives on the fourth.  Stays at a public Sarai.
26b
* Near the city center (? - ) there is a special mosque where the Hakim and the ministers of the state pray (continued from previous page).
27
* Author cleverly (perhaps the  in the section title) begins spending time in this mosque illustrating his skill by putting the holy word in poetic verse.
** (continued from previous page):             .            
* Hisari's scheme works; the Hakim notices his prose, comes over to regard it intently, and hires him after his prayers.
* Hisari served the Hakim for 40 days.
28 
* In thick prose the author describes how he is rewarded lavishly for his labor and finally has money.
* Hisari describes the government jobs - mostly tax collection and accounting:                                   
28b
* From that wilayat the author was sent to the sub-province (?) of   and lived there 6 years.
** His post was probably in accounting (  ).
* //notice that Hisari spends 40 days at the side of the Hakim developing a personal relationship before he is sent out to his post//

!                                   
This section is about Hisari taking a wife and procreating.
31
* After his work in Jizzakh the author returns to his original (   ) place of residence in Ghijduvan.
* //The way he phrases his training at Bukhara is indicative of the coterminous nature of Sufism and formal learning//:              
31b
* Author settles in the village of 
* Quoting hadith affirming the desirability of marriage.
* Gets into extensive metaphors about his virginity.
* His marriage is essentially arranged when he drops by a shop in the bazar to visit a friend.
32
* (continued from previous) Hisari is careful to mention that this bazar shop owner is intelligent (), educated (), and  () eloquece.
32b
* Author spent several years in that village just reproducing.

!!!Unexpected Visitor and Journey to the Hakim's Court
33b
* An unexpected messenger shows up at Hisari's door bearing a letter from.  The government is in need of writers and accountants, and he is summoned for a position.
* Naturally, he is overjoyed.
34b
* The author accompanies the messenger to a meeting with the governor at 
35
* Author was again assigned to    , in which capacity he served for a year.
* He was handsomely rewarded for his troubles:       
37
* There was a tradition in the Bukharan emirate that every three years the Hakim would pay homage to the Amir:           
37b 
* To the amir's court the hakim brought lavish gifts, learned men of the court ( ), and the (         ) owed taxes.
38
* Author indulges in a lavish description of the Bukharan spring.
38b
* Describing the extreme pageantry of the Amir's court.
* The governor is assigned by the amir to a different province -   - where he and his entourage set off immediately.

!!!On service in the new post ( ) and some court intrigue
39
* Hisari is given his previous post at the new province.
* At this point, per an "ancient tradition," the hakim doles out favors to his relatives:                        
39b
* A lengthy description of the aforementioned pleasantries and patronage-building.
40
* The Hakim was very shrewd and watched his province like a hawk (colorful metaphor); he was careful to ease tension (   ) by participating in social gatherings of the people () such as weddings, etc.  I.e. he took care to be a "man of the people."
* For four months he served the hakim in this capacity with absolute loyalty and subservience.
40b
* This page once again emphasizes the importance of personal relationships.  After the four months the author is apart from the Hakim, which essentially leads to his end.
* When the hakim comes back to , the author notices that hakim is giving him the cold shoulder.
* The author suspects that his enemies in the court (   ) are plotting against him.
41b
* The author sends a letter to the hakim to get to the truth of the matter; but he is disappointed and forced into early retirement:              
42
* So the author leaves Ghijduvan and heads back to his home in (  ).  It is interesting to note that whenever the author moves about the country he stays at simple sarais and in the bazaar, as is evidenced on this and other pages.  He has connections amongst all of the shop and caravan owners in the region.
* The treachery of the author's enemies never came to light:       
42b
* So the author spends a year with his family.
* Author's last comments and ensuing poem highlights his Sufi leanings.
44b
* Author laments his destitution and bad fortune.

!!!Good luck from the brink of destitution and the death of a hakim
45
* Author still broke:      
* Hisari was also forced to seek handouts and take loans, which humiliates him:        
* Just when things look particularly bad a young man shows up at Hisari's door, just like the time before.
** //Interesting to see how the Turkic amirs come and go, but Hisari represents the Tajiki bureaucratic class that gets continually recycled//
45b
* As it happened, a new governor was appointed to Ghijduvan by the name of Sultan Khan.
* Hisari's presence was requested for chancellery () activities.
* The youth accompanies him to the Hakim's court.
46
* Hisari, overjoyed, goes to the court and accepts.
46b
* Once again describes tax season and the necessity of counting up and going to pay tribute to the amir.
47
* //rough translation// we counted up the dinero and took it to the amir per ancient tradition: (continued from previous page):              
* Shortly after his return from paying tribute the Hakim died.
* At the time of the amir's death, Hisari was in charge of the treasury (along with 7 Amlakdars):        
* With the passing of the guy in charge, all the Amlakdars tried to get their hands in the treasury.
47b
* Since author even more than the 8 Amlakdars was in charge, it was up to him to keep things in order:       
** No transactions were made without his approval:      
* Due to the author's vigilance, there was a smooth transition:           
* For 20 days the author was distraught as he singlehandedly guarded the affairs of state, and kept track of transactions verbally (presumably since only the late hakim had the power of the seal):                    
48
* After setting things in order, Hisari begged his leave and went home, happy to have escaped that debacle unscathed.

!!!Corruption and Punishment
49
* In the year 1295 the author went looking for work as a writer, as was his habit:          
* At that time   was in charge of .  One day on the pretext of tax collection () he visited Hisari's village of  ; naturally, he honored Hisari with a visit.
49b
* He served Musa for two years.
* Musa did not really pay his servants enough, but the author gave it his all anyway.  //check - prose is funny here//
50.1 (//looks like the vostokoved writing in the numbers made a mistake and labeled two pages 50 - 50  50//)
* Discussing the exploitation of the peasantry he witnessed (       ) the author discusses the low moral standing of the Amirs:                
** //implicit ethnic tension here?//
50.1 b
* Witnessing the depravity of the amirs, the author sees no choice but to leave:               
* Author returns to his home.
50.2
* It comes time for Hakim Musa to go pay homage to the amir; the author is retired at this point, but decides to go anyways since he is bored.  Or rather he tags along to go to a place called   , apparently on the way.  //Getting from point a to point b was not so easy back then, so he is probably just interested in the transport.//
* The courtiers of Ghijduvan wen to pay tribute to the Amir, unaware of the fate that awaited them:               
50.2 b
* The Amir punished the offenders severely and confiscated their possessions and wealth:                 
* When Hisari hears this, he fears that he will share their fate by association, and high tails it back to Ghijduvan with great fear and discretion.
51
* Hisari is fully aware that had he been at the court he would have suffered the same fate and is thankful for his escape.
51b
* As is often the case, this section is followed by a wine poem, which also includes references to seeing magians in dreams.
52
* The poem seems to exculpate the amir (he was not aware of what was going on) for the corruption and reviles his courtiers.

!!!Trouble with the local muftis
52b
* Following the corruption debacle, Hisari spends some serious time in R&R.
53
* But the reverie was not to last; one day, misfortune struck.  Hisari's ignorant () enemies accused him of  - whatever that means exactly.  Perhaps because he spent so much of his time away from Farishnakent?
* Essentially, he seems to be saying that his enemies "encouraged" ( ) the bribe-taking () muftis to come to his house and accuse him.
* The issue was over the author share in the estate of a deceased relative ( ) which they counted as part of communal lands (         ); the muftis went through all of the standard Islamic legal procedures to find against him:         
** //so here we have a local source also referring to endemic corruption in the judicial system...//
53b
* Hisari knows he has no real recourse in this situation and complies with the muftis' / elders' demands:               
54
* He had to take a loan out to fix the problem:       
* Which impoverished him, and he spent a good year "drinking from the cup of sorrow" or some ridiculous Persianism like that.
* The author is ostracized from the community as a result of the dispute:                        
** //note the reference to the very existence of the "majlis", an important Persianate social context//
* Hisari also received threats from his creditors.
54b
* Even though everyone was trying to drive him out of town, Hisari did not give up the faith and in effect turned the other cheek.
* Ultimately, however, he was able to pay off his debts by turning to the benevolence of God:         
* In the year 1294 he returned to the province of   for work.  Author spent the rest of his life serving the Hakim there:      .
55
* The money he made at that court shut up his detractors:                 
55b
* Goes on for a bit about this particular hakim's incredible generosity.

!!!Newspaper from Tashkent
57b
* One day a Turkish newspaper arrives from Tashkent:                 
** //notice the use of the import word "gazette"; also notice that he refers to Zia al-Din as a kingdom, not that that means much in this context//
* The newspaper included a number of anecdotes in Turki:               
58
* The hakim sent for all the smart people in his court to try and figure out the meaning of these anecdotes; Hisari was among those trying to figure out their meaning.
* The marinalia of this page is all in Turkic; //presumably he is reproducing the contents of said newspaper?//
* The author ended up writing an explanation of the Turkic for the Hakim.
** //is this because the riddles are so arcane or because the hakim's command of Turkic is not all that strong at this point?//

!!!Illness and Penpals
58b
* Year is 1296
* Author comes down with a sickness and is prescribed a kind of Bukharan wine:              
** //Michael Cook//: Lane 349b: muthallath = wine (sharaab) cooked until the quantity of the two thirds of it has gone; the expressed juice of grapes so cooked.  This is part of the great Hanafi nabiidh thing, and I dont think the permissibility of muthallath turns on medical use.  Najam Haider, a former NES graduate student now at Barnard, could probably fill you in on this.
* About this time the author sends a letter to his dear (     ) friend    in Samarkand.
* This Mirza Yusif is a celebrated scholar of his time, says Hisari.
59
* When he insists that his friend is incredibly learned what he is talking about is rhetoric and poetry:            
* In any case, the two of them exchanged wine poetry and the author copied both of their efforts in the ensuring pages.

!!!Perversity and Portent in Jizzakh
63b
* One day the author was staying as a guest in the outskirts of Jizzakh (   ) and goes for morning prayers when he notices a large crowd gathered near the wall of the ark.
64
* The still-born calf had two tails and two heads, one of the latter of which was a dog head:                                
* Many in the crowd were disturbed; the old ones could not bring themselves to look at the spectacle and wept openly; some among the young ridiculed the spectacle and made jokes.
64b
* Eventually this horror reached the ears of the  ; the following people were summoned to the ( ) court:        
** //so the rais is considered one of the ulama; does the author consider himself one in this sentence?//
* //check this page; I think it says that the amir had a turban made from the freak cow, but need to check//
65
* Two court riders show up and start engaging in idle talk about the calf; what if the two heads wanted to do different things, how would the creature get on?  What if one wanted to eat grass, for instance.
65b
* While everyone else is joking around about this strange occurance, the author is thinking about possible divine meanings:              
* The author, however, knew that something was wrong about the situation:                      
* Author connects these events directly to the Russian invasion which takes place two years later in 1283, when the Russians besieged the province.


[[Timeline of Chronicles]]

> Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh, 2 vols. (Tokyo: Muassasah-i Mutalaat-i Farhangha va Zabanha-yi Asiya va Afriqa, 2009).

Author opens by explicitly stating that his history is not just meant to inform, but to council as well.

Index

Volume 1
* [[Nadir Shah|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Nadir Shah]]
* [[Rahim through Murad|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Rahim Khan through Shah Murad]]
* [[Amir Haydar|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Amir Haydar]]
* [[Nasrullah|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Nasrullah]]

Volume 2 (Khoqand, travelogue)
* [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh: Khoqand through Alim Khan]]

General Notes on the Work:
* Complete description of author's life, the work's historical sources, and its importance in [[Asimov (ed) Muntakhab at-Tavarikh (Dushanbe 1983 edition)]]
* From Lola's CD: It is curious  that  everywhere  finds the name of the Kokand khan  Muhammad khan Muhammad  li Khan (Mallya - khan in common parlance), who expatriated the author  to Russian Siberia, the word   husband of his mother is added,2  though this word was apparently wiped away by later readers only to be replaced  - triumphant,   - martyr,etc.

> [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]

Continued from: [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Rahim Khan through Shah Murad]]

!!!Amir Haydar
387
* Haydar was suspicious of his brother, Nasir Khan, who was governor of Merv but fled to Iran as he was close with    .  Fath Ali Shah appointed him governor of 
** //interesting how close these dynasties are//
* Another brother,   , who governed Samarkand, also feared for his safety, and simply fled to the perpetually subversive    of Shahrisabz, where he was greeted warmly; even gave Muhammad Husain his own sister to marry.
388. Another failure to take Shahrisabz
* Haydar's first move was to move on Hisar, which was effectively an independent state (       ); he emerged victorious and humiliated and decapitated its ruler (         ).  Then he put    in power as governor.
* -@@Aside@@- Hisar (EI, Spuler): Called Shuman [] at the time of the Arab conquests and was a small independent principality until it came under the ruler of the Chaghaniyan; unruly even in that time, which was troublesome since it was considered the last bulwark against the encroaching Turks; name changed to Hisar-i Shadman [ ] in the Timurid period.
** "After the collapse of the Shaybanids Hisar fell into the hands of the Turkmen tribe of Yuz and - like four other begliks - was able to maintain what was to all intents and purposes an independent position in relation to the Amirs of Bukhara.  Only after the Russian conuest of Bukhara in 1868 was the town and its hinterland really subject to the Amirs." Hisar is now in the territory of Tajikistan.
* Next Haydar marched on Sahrisabz, but the   got wind of their approach and met Shahrisabz met them in battle; the battle was ferocious, but ultimately Haydar was forced to make peace and return to Bukhara.
** //No one can ever keep Shahrisabz down//
389. Personal feud and Uratipa
* To summarize, the elder son of the governor of Uratipa was inexperienced and in with the wrong crowd and pissed off his uncle, who then killed him.  This caused Haydar to march on Uratipa.
390
* The governor of Uratipa made peace without incident, and Haydar ruled that the son of the slain adviser be granted  on the uncle that murdered him.
* Uratipa, unlike Shahrsabz, is ultimately controlled by Haydar:          
* Interesting passage (which flows onto p 391) immediately after author records the subjugation of Uratipa:                                 @@  @@                
** So there is definitely a Uzbek-Tajik dichotomy; those terms mean something in the 19th century, even if they are not as rigid as under the Soviets.
** Haydar controls Uratipa so well that he can fire the old governor and install a Manghit.
** All of the luminaries of this city went to Bukhara.
391. Khwarazm attempts to conquer Turkestan
*    of Khwarazm fancied himself ruler of all Turkestan and marched on Bukhara.
392
* Also worth noting that in the mind of the author the amirs are a fairly distinct group; he refers to them as such in his battle descriptions, the  
* Ail Tuzar Khan attempts to escape on a boat, but his men drag him to his watery death in a panic.
393. Balance of Power in Mawaranahr
* That very day 5 fortresses of Urgench offered the khotba to Amir Haydar.
* The amirs of Bukhara wished to permanently conquer Khiva, //but//     was at that time marching on Uratipa with the army of Farghana; he succeeded, taking a number of princes and 4000 prisoners.
* Hence the amirs of Bukhara were forced to give up the conquest of Khwarazm when they were on the verge of victory.
394
* But Alim Khan did not really engage the Bukharan forces; he returned to Khoqand.
396
* About this time   visits Bukhara from Kabul.
397. On the Afghans
* At this point Hakim Khan devotes a few pages to the Afghans.  The categories he uses are interesting.  He clearly sees the Afghans as a people separate from the Uzbeks, of which the latter there are two kingdoms - Khoqand and Bukhara.  
** Nevertheless, like Rahim Khan, he emphasizes that in the time of Nadir all were subordinate to him:                 .                
** Also, Hakim Khan is certainly aware of the different Pashtun tribes, mentioning the  and the 
* Author relates an anecdote about Ahmad Khan meeting a dervish who whacks him, but Ahmad and a prince of Kabul show restraint and are rewarded with a blessing.
398
* Ahmad Shah in that moment with the dervish achieved religious certainty and gained the right to rule the world:       "           "
400
* Relates a story about two stones of rulership, one kept by Fath Ali Shah in Tehran, and the other by Afghan rulers.
* Author is a big fan of Amir Dost Muhammad, and personally traveled to Afghanistan and was friends with Dost Muhammad; mentions that his enemy Shah Shujah was on the British teat: ...            .                 .                                      ...
401
* In any case, after being blinded   shows up in Bukhara for permanent residence. Amir Haydar of course greets him warmly, but then hears about Zaman Shah's daughter behind kept behind the cover of the haram.  Haydar offers to marry the daughter, but the response is not positive:  :                       "            .       ."           
** In other words, we are not alike, you and I, and we are oathbound to be mere travelers in this land and one day return to Afghanistan.
* Haydar took the daughter anyway and branded Zaman, sending him to the house of God:                           
**//check into this - based on Wikipedia this is not his ultimate fate as it has come down into history//
* In the year 1225 Khoqandi    died and was replaced by  
402.  War between Khoqand and Bukhara.
* Meanwhile,     steals something from Haydar and seeks refuge with  .
* In retalation, Haydar takes his army to the fortress of .
* The author's brother    (who I //think// was the second son of the late  khan of Khoqand) manages to get the news to Omar Khan, who in turn came to war.
* Though no more than three farsangs were left between the two armies, Haydar flees to Bukhara.
* Omar Khan takes the fortress without seeing a trace of Haydar.
** A Khoqandi poet wrote of Haydar's retreat:    
* Note the language that Hakim Khan uses here - __there were many more than three emirates__.             .                          ____      __ __... 
403. Haydar's unsuccessful attempt to take shahrisabz and Kitab
* The two aforementioned brothers fought a succession war, and Haydar immediately moves in to take advantage.
* At his approach the two brothers made peace with one another.
* Haydar could either not countenance the casualties or perhaps fell sick (  ) and returned to Bukhara.
* //Here the status of the Amir of Shahrisabz is even less ambiguous// - ...                      ...
404.  Tale of the Cow
* At this point Hakim Khan comes up with a fairly bizarre story, though an illustrative one.  One day the amir of Shahrisabz (I think...) is going to Kitab.  On the way he asks a random guy in Persian what the name of his cow is, but the guy was Uzbek and hence did not understand.  The Amir became angry and the cow-owner confused.  Eventually the Amir whipped the man.
** //Intersting that an Uzbek Amir cannot even speak Turkish//
** The story itself:       .       .     "  "             .      .               .          .        "     ."     .          .      "      ."                      .        
* Hakim Khan relays that he has limited information on the Shahrisabz emirate after this; it was inherited by two boys that spent most of their time engaged in wine and little boys:          
405
* In 1233   swoops in to Shahrisabz and takes over the emirate.
405. Author's brother's exploits -       
* Such a Persianate reference comparing a vicious battle to one from the Shahnama:              
* //This section is somewhat confusing to me because Hakim Khan's brother is clearly fighting against Khoqand... but I thought he was a part of that Khanate//
* Rahim Divan Begi first takes the fortress  then .
407
* In the end Muhammad Rahim Begi is victorious and sets up a __hereditary__ begstvo in Uratipa:                             

407.                 
* The beginning of the fall of Haydar's government began in 1238 and the zenith of his sultanate came to an end (    ) and the realm erupted into general chaos.
** Note that he uses the term  to describe Haydar's realm; this paltry term may not be an accident.
* The fearless (        ) Qipchaq tribes (  ) were the cause of the chaos.
* It all started with the hakim of Samarkand (    ) went to a fortress (  ) for the wedding () of his nephew ( ).
408
* A watchman () led the Qipchaq to Samarkand and they plundered the treasury (  ) and abducted the hakim's wife and child and imprisoned the hakim himself ignomoniously ( ).
*   (amir of Khoqand) took this opportunity to siege the fortress of Jizakh ().  This prompted the Qipchaq to make entreaties to Khoqand, and the two lavished gifts upon each other.
* Meanwhile     gets in on the action and also attacks Bukhara, looting and pillaging (though it does not say he made it into the city).  He also took hostages:            
409. The burning of Bukhara
* The fighting was pretty vicious; the Khwarazmis were cutting off the ears of their victims: (quote continued from previous page):                       .          
* Then the Khwarezmis went to the gates of Bukhara and set the city on fire; it was an unprecedented tragedy:       
* Shahrisabz also decides to take advantage of the situation:                                              
* Finally, when Haydar hears that the Khwarazmis are pillaging  he sends    at the head of an army to face his enemy.
410
* The Bukharan army was defeated by Khwarezm fairly decisively.
** Described in [[Munis Khorezmii, Firdaws Al-Iqbal]] 496-497.
* Haydar got depressed, but then ended up taking an army (taking half of the amirs with him and leaving the other half in Bukhara) to Samarkand, where he managed to drive away the Qipchaqs and Khoqandis.
* Once Haydar arrived in Samarkand, a bunch of amirs from the surrounding provinces came to him, hungering for battle.
411
* However, the amirs could not achieve victory and were forced to return to Samarkand.
* Haydar hands the reigns of Samarkand over to his son (  ) and heads back to Bukhara.
* About that time news arrived to Bukhara of the death of     and the succession of     to the throne of Khoqand; Amir Haydar and Ghazi became close friends.  
412
* They sent esteemed embassadors to one another:        (Haydar may have been physically at Khoqand visiting, but it is unclear).
* Haydar suspects his son    and deposes him.
* Defection: Haydar gets sick of Ghazi (        ), and one of his men goes over to Ghazi's side:                      
** This defection prompts Haydar to go to war with the Qipchaqs, who (p. 408) were allied with Khoqand.
412
* Previously, Haydar had sent an envoy (  ) to Khoqand, who was accepted with honor. On their way to Tashkent they encountered Haydar's siege of the Qipchaq fortress and begged him to spare them.
* The Qipchags returned to their people and troubled Haydar no longer and pledged themselves to his service:        
414
* About this time news from  arrives that    died and was succeeded by his son    .  His brother    had a thousand horses (and presumably contested his brother's succession, which made Haydar happy.
415
* Lots of confusing proper nouns here, but the gist of it is that one of the losers from the succession struggle ends up working both for the Qajars and the Ottomans.  Even some travel to Russia, and eventually ends up in Bukhara.  There is a world of Turkic nobility at work here.
416.  Death of Amir Haydar
* Memories of Haydar and his pious learning:                                     
** Also, he was a Hafiz; also, he had completed the Sufi path:                       

[[Continue on to the reign of Nasrullah|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Nasrullah]]
> [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]

p. 342.  War in Ottoman lands, India, and Turan.     
* Recounts Nadir taking Baghdad and defeating the Ottomans and receiving tribute () from them ().
* After returning to Iran Nadir sends his son Riza Qoli Mirza (  ) on campaign to Turkestan with 12,000 men while Nadir himself was campaigning in Hindustan.
* After defeat the Mughal emperor gives Hindustan over to Nadir.
* Riza Qoli crossed the Amu Darya and got to Qarshi.  Abu al-Faiz (  ) heard of this and panicked, selling all of his belongings to raise an army (           ).

p. 343
* After a large battle near Qarshi, Riza Qoli emerged victorious.
** During the battle one of Rahim Khan's relatives who ruled Samarkand was killed.
* Relays an anecdote: One of Riza Qoli's lieutenants ( ) was the reason for the victory.  Another soldier's son, Bahadur, was slain in the battle.  The soldier became so angry that he tricked Hasan Khan into letting him circle around him in honor, whereupon the disgruntled soldier cut off his head.
* After his victory Riza Qoli returned to Iran to serve his father.

p. 344.         
* Nadir Shah goes to Turan himself with a massive army and ends up at Chor Bakr ( ).  
* So magnificent was Nadir's entourage that Abu al-Faiz and his amirs did not even know what to think or how to deal with this difficulty. Finally they wrote to a wise Ishan and asked him to visit Nadir.

p. 345.  @@very interesting passage@@: Nadir converts to Sunnism.  Also has anecdote about the foundation of the Bukharan madrasa in which the author studied.
* Nadir greeted the Ishan with full honors.  They became very close and spent the evening together.
* After this discussion Nadir returned to God (    ) and returned to Sunnism (             ).
* Anecdote: Nadir is so pleased with the Ishan that he gives a jewel to him; but the Ishan gives it to his servant (  ) instead.  The follower became a wealthy, globe-trotting merchant and founded a major madrasa in Bukhara.     . 
** This was also the madrasa which the author attended.
* The Ishan left and Abu al-Faiz went to Nadir's camp.  Nadir was very happy to meet Abu al-Faiz and greeted him with the amirs of Iran at attention.

p. 346
* Abu al-Faiz had a daughter of unmatched beauty.  This daughter Nadir took for himself and gave another one to his nephew
* Nadir Shah makes a number of changes, putting different amirs in different positions of power (including Rahim Khan of the Manghits), including relocating a number from Bukhara to Samarakand.  After that he "gifted" all of Mavrannahr to Abu al-Faiz Khan.
* Then he turned his sights on Khwarazm, conquering that as well.  The ruler there did not fare quite as well; Nadir had him killed.  He gave that khan's wife to Rahim.

p. 347.  Nadir returns to Iran.  The regicide.
* Upon Nadir's return to Iran, he began to suspect his son Riza Qoli and had him blinded ( ...  
* At this point Nadir starts going a bit mad and blinding even more people.
* According to the author he also orders people to abandon Shiism and convert to Sunnism.  Some converted, but most did not.
* At that time Nadir called a council outside of Mashhad.
* By this point the Amirs had become fed up with Nadir and decided to depose him.  Nadir was in his tent being serviced by a beautiful slave.  Then the slave noticed the killers approaching.  Nadir ignored her warnings and returned to sleep.

p. 348.  The slaying of Nadir Shah - presented as a tragedy by this author.
* Nadir cursed the slave girl attempting to warn him, blinded by pride and not believing that any in his own kingdom would move against him.
** Nadir did not realize that the world is a cruel, unpredictable place:       
* The murderers were 360 in number.
* Finally, Nadir drew his sword and leapt from the tent.  However, he tripped on a tent cord.  A killer cut off his head from behind.
** Author's tone and terminology:                      
*** (p. 349):        
*** (p. 350):                 

p. 350. Rahim Khan and Legitimacy
* After Nadir's death all the different leaders returned to their own groups; Rahim Khan was one of them - he had been an assistant () to the shah.
* @@Important@@ - Rahim's (and Ahmad Shah Durrani) legitimacy tied to Nadir Shah:                                  
* All the Uzbek amirs assembled at Bukhara and determined that Abu al-Faiz was no longer fit to rule.  After that they all returned to their respective homelands.

p. 351. Rahim Khan destroys the legacy of Abu al-Faiz and takes control of Bukhara.
* Rahim Khan imprisoned Abu al-Faiz in the Mir-i Arab madrasa.  Several days later he cut of his head.
** Abu al-Faiz had ruled 40 years and had 8 children.  Seven of those children he had grown suspicious of and executed.

p. 352
* This page goes on about how unique and awful the crime of Abu al-Faiz were.
* Rahim Khan married one of his own daughters off to the son of Abu al-Faiz, but then grows suspicious and executes that son.
* Thus ends the line of the Astarkhanids:           .      

> [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]

Previously: [[Amir Haydar|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Amir Haydar]]

417
* At the time (of his death) Nasrullah Khan (  ) was the Hakim of Qarshi.  Upon the news, Nasrullah makes for Bukhara, but falls sick such that even __Christian doctors__ (Russians?) ( ) could not cure him.
* The year was 1243 when Haydar died; he had ruled 28 years.
* Upon Haydar's death, it seems that the   was overseeing matters in Bukhara.  Riders were sent to Nasrullah urging him to Bukhara, but    also got wind of the situation and made for the Ark. 
** Husain Tura may have been able to rouse the masses to his side (    ), but the Qushbigi closed the gates and fired arrows and guns.
** Tura's head gets split open:                         
* Head wound notwithstanding, with the help of the  Tura busted down the Ark gate, stormed the palace, and imprisoned the Qushbegi.  A few hours later, Tura died from his wounds / sins:        
* Nevertheless, before he died, he did obtain all of the necessary approvals:                  
** Hakim Khan seems to give a very favorable review of his brief reign:                                              

418
* In his description of Husain Tura as a just king he says that he dons the clothing of a commoner and goes out to see the people:                       

419.  Death of Husain Tura
* Husain Tura died after three months on the throne.
* Meanwhile, Omar Khan ( ), Haydar's third son, was sitting on the throne of Karmina and heard the news and immediately entered the Ark in Bukhara and obtained the sanction of the Amirs.
* However, Omar Khan was      .  He spent all of his time drinking and carrousing with beloveds:                 
* The amirs saw that he was unsuitable and had no choice ( ) but to send messengers to Qarshi to summon Nasrullah.
* Nasrullah's first act after taking Bukhara from his brother was to visit Naqshband's mazar:                        

420
* At this point the story turns to recount the conflict twixt Omar Khan and Nasrullah.  By obtaining the favor of the Naqshbandi holy site Nasrullah enlists the support of             .
* Author's source:         
* Nasrullah goes from Qarshi to Samarkand with an army.
** Amir of Samarkand:             
* Nasrullah's alliance with the Naqib gets him proclaimed shah in Samarkand:                                

421. Battle for Bukhara:             
* Upon hearing this news, Omar Khan marched to  with an army.
* There Omar Khan's army was decimated and all the sons of Haydar went over to Nasrullah's side, who gave them positions beneath him.
* Upon learning of Omar Khan's defeat, Nasrullah chased him to Bukhara and laid siege:                            

422
* At this time the fuqara of Samarkand rise up against the hakim and endorse Nasruallah (check; cont. from 421):                        .                                
* Nasrullah besieged Bukhara for about 50 days.
* Consent of the umara crucial for conquest of Bukhara:                 .        1243           
* Nasrullah captured and imprisoned Omar.  At this point the Naqib (   ) as well as         arrived in Bukhara.

423
* The two aforementioned VIPs (Naqib and Muhammad Sharif) intervened and saved Omar Khan from execution.
* Anecdote about Omar Khan's head covering ( ) being stolen and verse from Alisher Navoi (in Persian, btw) about how quick the mighty fall.

424
* Omar Khan ends up heading to Khorasan after being spared.  
* At the time    was ruling Herat and greeted Omar Khan with honor:                              [ 425]       

425
* Omar Khan goes from exile in Herat to exile in Qunduz:                 
** Note that the contemporaneous ruler of Qunduz is:    
* From there Omar Khan goes to Badakhshan, and from there to    and ultimately Farghana.
* The author's own brother (  ) greeted Omar Khan; refers to brother Mahmud (?) as  ; full excerpt:                        
** So Omar found refuge and a position of honor in the Khoqand court.
* In 1244 Umar died in Khoqand as a result of a plague ( ).  Very poetic sentence about his passing:     1244                               

426.  Death of Omar, enthronement of Nasrullah
* Omar Khan had only ruled six months when he died and traveled in exile for 3 and a half years; he was 22 years old.  
* His body was sent to Bukhara and buried            
* Enthronement of Nasrullah:          ...                         
* Immediately put his brothers in positions of power.  They then became entrenched in their positions:                                   

427. Nasrullah murders his brothers
* Sending a Qalmyq to do his dirty work:               
* Killed their families as well; Hakim Khan considers the brothers martyrs:         
* Naturally Shahrisabz takes the opportunity of Nasrullah sieging Bukhara to retake territory:                                    

428
* Looks like Danial Divan Bigi of Shahrisabz payed off the governor at  
* Note that this is a //tribal// war between the Manghit and Kinagis:              
* Danial sent his brother   who was a warrior of his age to meet Nasrullah in battle. Rivers of blood flowed.
* Battle between Shahrisabz and Bukhara @@ends in a draw@@ (this is probably around 1826) and a bizarre sort of compromise:           .      ...                            
** But really this seems like a bit more of a victory for Shahrisabz.

429
* Appointment of a @@Shaykh al-Islam@@:    1245                          

429.         
* This section becomes autobiographical:    [1244]             [= ]                   
* Nasrullah gave Muhammad Rahim Divanbigi the right to rule Uratipa on the condition that he vacate Jizakh:            

430
* Hakim Khan joined Rahim Divanbigi on his journey back to Uratipa, because his father had just gone there from Shahrisabz.

* A messenger warns Hakim Khan once he is in Uratipa:        "       ."

> [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]

!!The Manghits () p. 353

!!!Rahim Khan
p. 353.  This page sets up Rahim Khan as a cruel, but cunning ruler who seized power in Transoxiana.
* Starts out stating that there have been seven figures (in the Manghit dynasty) until now and that they have reigned 93 years.  The first was Rahim Khan:              
* Rahim Khan subjugated many and took the title khan by giving away awards and titles (  ).
** Describes Rahim as cruel and a tyrant (   )
* Lists the governors of the different major cities in Transoxiana:
** In Khoqand ruled   
** In Uratipa () ruled     
** In Shar-i Sabz ruled:     
** In Hisar () ruled:     
* These are the amirs of Chingis Khan: " "
* None of the Uzbek (lit.) amirs were equal to Rahim, so he used deception to draw the stupid ( ) amirs to him like lambs to the slaughter (      ).
p. 354.  Interesting page because (a) Rahim Khan is confounded by some guy in a fortress and (b) he finds Shahr-i Sabz to be deserted - perhaps a result of the chaos of the mid 18th century?
* Rahim Khan was unable to subdue one of the amirs, who just remained in a fortress outside of Shari-i Sabz.  He was not able to defeat this individual so he married the daughter of the rebel's brother and so became his son-in-law () and then they settled terms ( ).  In a rage (?) Rahim had 32 Chingissid chancellery officials ( ) murdered.
* Rahim Khan then turned his eye on Shahr-i Sabz, the best of realms ( ), but found it empty (      ).
** He stayed there for a few days and then gave it to a slave (  ) to govern, the divan bigi, and returned to Bukhara.
p. 355: Recollections of Rahim Khan taking the army to Uratipa (       ).  Illustrates the balance of power during this period in Transoxiana as well as Rahim Khan being outsmarted by a rival.
* Rahim Khan declares    his honorary son (? -  ) and sends a herald to summon him to war, which he obeys.
* Rapprochement between Bukhara and Khoqand worries   , the ruler of Uratipa, and so he summons    of Hisar to help him.
* Rahim called for Uratipa and Hisar to surrender, but they holed up in the fortress of Istiravshan (), which Rahim and Irdaneh surround.
* The siege put the citizens of the city in dire straits, so Fazel Bey, who had a reputation of being extremely crafty () such that he was nicknamed   , hatched a plan.  He sent fake letters and seals to both Rahim and Irdaneh from each other causing them to suspect one another and disperse their armies.
p. 356
* That night there was a storm so severe that the author compares it to the one faced by Noah, forcing Rahim Khan to give up his army and Irdaneh to run back to Khoqand.  This resulted in a great victory for Uratipa and Hisar and a mountain of severed heads ( ) in the plain outside of Uratipa.
* However, Rahim Khan survived and returned to Bukhara and after a bit returned to Hisar with an army.
p. 357.  Interesting reference to rivalries left over from Nadir Shah.
* Rahim returned, subjugated Muhammad Amin Bey, plundered his treasury, and captured him.
* Exposition: Rahim Khan was considered exceptional under Nadir Shah, but in all respects Muhammad Amin Bey had been considered superior, and Rahim Khan did not get the respect he wished.  Rahim was jealous and wanted revenge.
* Rahim Khan summoned a council of the amirs, ulama, and sayyids.  Muhammad Amin Bey shows up bareheaded and barefoot (    ) and greets the ulama without even regarding Rahim Khan.
p. 358.  This is a crucial passage because it illustrates that Rahim Khan was dependent on the ulama to secure his own legitimacy for a Persian title.
* Rahim Khan is not pleased.  He drags Muhammad Amin to the bazar and has him killed, saying that he will never be amongst Muslims again (    ).  Amin gets hanged and beheaded.
* After this point Rahim Khan bowed to no one.  He gives Hisar to one of his amirs and returns to Bukhara.
* After some time he defeats Khorosan, but apparently does not incorporate it.
* After Rahim returned from Khorasan several sycophantic ulama (        ) wrote a fatwa proclaiming that any ruler who could support twelve thousand men was entitled to the tile of padishah, which Rahim adopted without delay.
p. 359
* To mark his new title they begin reading his name in the khutba and coining currency in his name.
* He had a favorite concubine named Mirza Baghir ( ) who sat on the harem throne and was always ready with a sweet word or advice.  (Note: this could actually have been a eunuch - unclear in text).
* One day he became angry with her and ordered her and ordered her death and she was brought before the khan, whereupon she read some verse.
p. 360
* Mirza Baghir tells the khan a witty verse or two and he forgives her, overcome with laughter.
p. 361.  The somewhat ignominious death of Rahim Khan.
* One day Rahim goes on pilgrimage to a great Sufi:          who is also known simply as  .  While there Rahim did something rude or ill-mannered (farted) and became very embarrassed and averted his head from the Sufi master.         .  After this incident Rahim Khan returned to Bukhara and departed from this world.
* Rahim Khan facts listed here: He was 36 when he died; was an amir for 10 years; a padishah for 2 years; ruled Bukhara for 12 years
* Rahim Khan had no children and one of his managers () named         wrested Shahr-i Sabz for himself, and the other Chingissid amirs rebelled as well.

!!!Danial Bey
* Danial Bey, Rahim's uncle, took the throne.  He was very honest and mild (    ) and did not proclaim himself padishah.  Instead he found a descendant of Chinggis named    and put him on the throne while holding the real power himself.
p. 362
* Has a good anecdote about how Danial would dress the Chinggisid up like a monarch for ceremonies and then send him back to his camp.
* Danial married Rahim's wife and was very in love with her.
p. 363.  This author has a genuine sense of humor.
* Author relays a story whereby Rahim's wife's wet-nurse () asks her what she got out of her marriage to each of the three kings.  She replies that she got happiness () from  , good disposition / manners () from Rahim Khan, and great sex ( ) from Danial Bey.
p. 364.  Death of Danial Bey, rise of Shah Murad
* Danial Bey dies of a fatal illness.  He was 75 years old and he ruled for 17 years.
* He had 5 children, but it was obvious to all that Shah Murad (the eldest) was the one fit to rule.

!!!Shah Murad
* Shah Murad was extremely pious, going so far as to imitate the behavior of a dervish, carrying loads around the streets of Bukhara.
* Shah Murad was known for his justice and the very day he took the throne he executed the Qazi Kalan of Bukhara who was known for taking bribes.  Also notes that he was well in touch with the affairs of his kingdom.
* Murad was also known for waging war on the Shia.  He conquered Mashhad.
* The governor of Marv at the time was   , who was appointed by   , king of Iran.
p. 365. War with Iran
* Murad conquered Marv in a single battle putting much of the populace to the sword and forcing many of the rest to move to Bukhara. He executed the ruler there (who had been appointed by the ruler of Iran).
* Murad captured the ruler of Marv's son,  .  Once in Bukhara he quickly escaped and went to Sharisabz where he was friends with     and remained there for about a year.
** Murad demanded that Haji Khan be handed over, offering a four thousand ashrafs.
p. 366.  A local governor defies the khan, taunts him, and gets away with it.  Anecdote also illustrates a notion of Uzbek identity.
*    , governor of Shahrisabz, responds to Shah Murad: "              .   " - even if you gave me seven years of Bukhara's income I would never hand over a guest.  We are Uzbeks.
* Author makes a woeful comparison between those times when such friendship was exhibited even between Sunni and Shia, and now when 5000 Muslims can be sold for a bit of money.
** //It seems here that the author views his own time as one of decadence and corruption.//
* After this Haji Khan went to Khoqand for two years and then on to Kashgar.  (He may or may not have returned to Iran - but he was eventually enthroned somewhere).
p. 367.  Goes on for a while about the beauty of Haji Khan's concubine.  Battles with Timur Shah of Afghanistan.
* In the age of Shah Murad, Timur Shah marched on Mavrannahr.  Shah Murad became aware of this and crossed the Jaihun and at Balkh they parlayed.
p. 368
* Timur Shah was taken aback by Murad's boldness and they reached a truce and returned to their respective thrones.
p. 369.  Shah Murad tries and fails to subdue Shahrisabz
* Shah Murad turned his attention to Shahrisabz and waged a fierce war there, but was unable to achieve victory.  He constructed 18 fortresses on its outskirts, but was nevertheless forced to quit the province.
* Stymied at Shahrisabz, he turned to the country of the Yoziah ().
p. 370.                
* Khudayar Bey heard this news (that Shah Murad was coming for him?) and took a massive army from Uratipa to Samarkand.  Abdallah Dadkhwah (  ) and Yadgar Bey ( ) came to assist him.
* The armies then met at Qara Baliq ( ) and engaged in fierce battle.
* Battle lasted 6 days, yet still no one could achieve victory, so everyone returned home.
* The author heard this story personally from            , who was the nephew of Khudayar himself, as well as from Yadgar Bey.
** //I.e. the author heard about the battle from eyewitnesses on the Khoqand side.//
p. 371.  The Affair of Baba Parvanchi (  )
* According to the author's sources, Khudayar was incredibly brave in the battle; there is a legend that he simply went to sleep in the middle of the battle.
* His (presumably Khudayar's) true brother was Baba Parvanchi, who conquered ( ) Hisar.  But after only a few days traitorous fate ( ) took it from him and he became a prisoner of Bairadi Taz ( ).
* After one year Parvanchi broke his chains and made a night escape along with two of his servants.  Morning broke and he could go further and was forced to hide out in a graveyard.
* The guards woke up and saw that he was gone and searched the entire city; Bairadi Taz put a rich bounty out for his capture.
p. 372
* As it happens, the cemetery was right beside a public thoroughfare.  An ugly old man who looked like the angel of death spied Parvanchi and wants to turn him in for the reward.  The young man responds that the old man is crazy and talking nonsense; fortune comes and goes for the great ones like Parvanchi and that they should not screw him over for their own benefit.
p. 373
* The old man cursed the boy for his words, but eventually left.  The young boy knelt in honor before Parvanchi and pledged himself to his service.
* Parvanchi wept and gave the boy his seal, which the boy took to a bearded man at a Caravansarai.
p. 374
* The man at the Caravansarai gave him some provisions saying that he had been waiting a year for the boy to come.
* The boy returned to Parvanchi and the two set off together.
p. 375
* Parvanchi & co. get stuck in a whirlpool famous throughout all of Mawaranahr.
p. 376
* Finally they are rescued by Mir Shir Abad (  ) 
* At first Parvanchi lies, saying "             ".  However, there was a man there who had been in the service of Khodaiar Bey Vallnami (  ) and he recognized Parvanchi immediately.  For this reason, Parvanchi was greeted with tears and embrace and given nice clothes and food.
* Despite being treated so, Parvanchi was pissed about it for some reason.
p. 377.  Shah Murad finds out about Parvanchi
* Shah Murad heard about this and summoned Parvanchi; Parvanchi sat in bondage in Bukhara for a year.
** Finally, Khodaiar managed to trick (      ) Murod into releasing Parvanchi, who was his brother.
* (Not totally positive here) Then Khodaiar gave Parvanchi Jizakh () to govern.
p. 378.  The Delirium () of Parvanchi
* Parvanchi, as it turns out, was a bit crazy and prone to exaggeration - which the next couple pages go through in some detail.
p. 380.  Back to Shah Murad: Shah Murad the Poor
* Relays the story about how during a visit to Samarkand Shah Murad runs out of money and is forced to hawk an old sheepskin coat () at the market.
** The mullah who bought the coat rescinded the contract, complaining of lice infesting it, and took the issue before a qadi.  Shah Murad chuckled at the encounter.
p. 381. Shah Murad the Poor continued.
* The qadi attempted to reach a settlement, but the mullah refused even that, saying that he would not pay a cent for such a coat. Unfortunately, Shah Murad had already spent the money.  In any case, they eventually settled.
* Mentions another account of him traveling, this time to Iran, where he had to go hungry and sell his own shoes.
p. 382.  The Attempted Assassination of Shah Murad        
* Two men dressed up as women and sneaked into Shah Murad's harem.  They were vile dogs, but brave:     
* These two men seriously messed Shah Murad up and ran away.  However, because God was watching over Shah Murad, he survived.
** Verse:        |        
* The assassins returned to the amirs and reported.  The amirs asked if they were absolutely sure Murad was dead, and naturally they confirmed.
** The amirs wanted to know where Murad's head was if he was actually dead.  They replied:        .       
* In fact, Murad was drenched in his own blood, but alive.
p. 383.  Murad shows mercy.
* Once Murad awoke and grieving turned to rejoicing, he ordered to be taken out to the people to show that he was still in control.
* Word spread of his survival and his brothers realized they were in trouble.
* Murad admonished them, but granted them mercy.  The brothers were shamed, but alive.
p. 384.                     
* (Murad recovering from assassination attempt).  Interesting that they characterize his treatment as the wisdom of Plato:   .  
* Notes (somewhat randomly) that    died at the age of 56.  I think he is an amir of Khoqand.
* As soon as news of this reaches Bukhara, without delay Murad marches on Uratipa.  They fight to a standstill.
* Mentions that he has guns () at his disposal.
p. 385.  Khoqand gets involved,          
* Khoqand gets involved and there ends up a war between three rulers.
* On the advice of the author's grandfather, they call a truce and return home.  Woot.
* After returning home, Murad gets it in his head that he should conquer Khojand.
p. 386.  Balance of Transoxianan Power
* After three days of besieging Khojand, Murad turns back simply out of the fear that Khoqand //might// intervene.
* As a consolation prize, he engages in wide-scale pillage as he leaves, and - @@interestingly@@ - forcibly resettles part of its population back to Samarkand.
p. 387.  The death of Shah Murad
* After his Khojand expedition, Murad fell sick.
* Murad proclaimed that the sickness was caused by the amir of Khojand and that he would never recover from the illness.
* Goes through how his realm was carved up between his kids.

[[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]
[[Khoqand Chronicles Index]]

> Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh, vol. 2 (Tokyo: Muassasah-i Mutalaat-i Farhangha va Zabanha-yi Asiya va Afriqa, 2009).

Abdul Rahm B (17211733)             
* Hakim Khan counts Rahim as the first Ming () ruler (1).
* In his time the Yuz ruled Khujand (1):                    
** Aq Buta Bey married Shahrukh Ataliq's daughter, i.e. Rahim's sister (1-2).
** Attacked Rahim Bey with Kyrgyz allies, but forced to retreat (2-3).
* Rahim Bey later used trickery to ambush Aq Buta in his Khujand fort (3).
* Rahim Bey took the Timur / Nadir laqab Sahibqiran; placed his brother Abd al-Karim in Khujand, kept his own court in Khoqand (4):                                     
* After conquering the Farghana Valley, Rahim Bey took Samarqand (4).
* Shahrisabz was then ruled by Hakim Bukri (pr.?); when Rahim marched on it, they reached an accord via marriage deal (4-5):          .               .            .                                                
* Shortly thereafter he fell sick in Samarqand, returned to Khoqand where he died (5).
** When he died, that daughter of Ibrahim Ataliq (Kenagis?) was already pregnant, and gave birth after his death.  Her daughter would eventually give birth to Irdana Bey (5).

Abd al-Karim (17331746)
* Abd al-Karim married Abd al-Rahim's (Kenagis?) wife   (p. 6).
* Details Kalmyk invasion (see also [[Sayyid Umar Beg, Anjum al-Tawrkh (IVANUz 11366)]]); Yunghars take over most of the Farghana Valley, besiege Khoqand itself (6-7).
* The Yuz ruling Uratepa at this time, Fazil Bey Valnami was Abd al-Karim's son (? - can't be right given ibn Sadiq Bey) (7):                      .          
** Fazil Bey (referred to as an  ) rushed to help Abd al-Karim (7).
** Uratepa sovereign, it seems, but subordinate (7):                     
* Ruler of Marghinan dies fighting Kyrgyz, son takes over the "imarat" (8):          .             
* //Note//: No mention here of Nadir Shah, in contrast with [[Sayyid Umar Beg, Anjum al-Tawrkh (IVANUz 11366)]].
* Chaos during the reign of Abu al-Fayz of Bukhara, no one to rule Samarqand (9):  ...    .           .                            .                        .              .                    
** Surviving son of the former ruler of Samarqand flees to Khoqand (9):                                           
* Abd al-Karim also marries Oyam Kenagis (i.e. the one who originally married Abd al-Rahim Bey - see also [[Mrz lim Tshkand, Ansb al-Saln wa-Tawrkh al-Khawqn (IVANUz no. 1314/I)]]) (9-10):                                            .

* Opening - standard Islamic sciences insufficient (232):

* (cont.) Teacher in Sulaymaniyya urges him to go to Delhi to study under Abu Sa'id Sahib (232-232b):                                    
* However, Qandahari hesitated, going back to Baghdad then visiting Basra and served a shaykh there for 8 months (232b).
* Description of how easy it was for Qandahari to travel almost anywhere via the sufi network (232b):                                     
** Kalat was a Baluchi khanate; probably referring to Muhammad Nasir Khan I (17491794), though his son Nasir Khan II also ruled 18401857.
* (cont.) In Kalat he met Abu Sa'id Sahib, who was on his way to the hajj, and pledged himself to the shaykh (232b):                   
* However, Qandahari was still hot and bothered () so the Abu Sa'id Sahib ordered him to continue on to Delhi and study under his son while he was on the hajj (232b):

* Mulla Haybat Akhund (240b-241)      and Mulla Mir Malik     (copied in full)
** From Shirvan (in the Caucasus?) (240b):          
** After they returned home Haybat went crazy (240b-241):                      
** The author met the two of them while traveling through Khorasan near a certain mountain (Katighar?).  Haybat was ecstatic and the author chastised him for doing his prayers improperly (241):           [=]           [ / ]                        
** Haybat replied that he was powerless to stop the fits.  His friend Mir said that in fact they had come to the author for help dealing with the issue (241):                                   
** //check meaning// (241):                                                                              []              
** Entering the order (241):                             
* Mulla Hati Kasighari (241-241b)   
** Prior murshid (241):                   []              
* Vali Muhammad Akhund Sahib

> Mulla Muhammad Sharif b. Muhammad Naqi, Taj al-Tawarikh (IVANRUz 2092)

Date of compilation of manuscript (copy)/compilation finished: 09 Ramadan 1274/April 22-23, 1858

1. Fols. 307a-312a are about a discussion between Bukharan and Afghan Sunni scholars and ulama on the one hand and Iranian Shiite ulama on the other, held at the court of Nadir Shah in either 1746 or 1747. Unfortunately, the author does not indicate the exact date of this conversation. The episode is of course written from the Bukharan Sunni perspective and therefore favors contemporary Sunni views. The whole thing ends with a triumph of the Sunni scholars, how they were gifted a number of presents and returned home.
* The shah (i.e. Nadir) had a group of both Hanfi and Shiite scholars (307a):                                   
* (cont.) Out of fear of Shah Ismail, much of the east had turned to Shiism (307a-307b):                          []                         []  [  ]  []   
* (cont.) Nadir assembles a small group from the many different peoples of his empire - Khurasan, Iran, Iraq, Fars, India, Qandahar, Turan. (Seems to be both scholars and military elite.) (307b):                                                                                     
** //Does not specify where this meeting takes place.//
* (cont.) Nadir sends out a messenger to all his lands to assemble the wise ones of the land (307b):                                                    
* (cont.) Great ulama coming from far and wide (307b):         [ ]    []                   
* (cont.) Great ulama from Balkh and Bukhara and the Afghans and Khurasan (308):                     []      []      
* (cont.) Assembling a majlis to debate matters of religion (308):                                             
* (cont.) Kissing the royal carpet (308):           [  ]                                  
* (cont.) Nadir has assembled the ulama to sort out differences and find the truth (    ) of religion, eliminate doubt and infighting (308-308b):     [ ]                                                                              
* (cont.) Imagery about polishing the mirrors of the consciences of the great and the small alike. Cleanse doubts. Identifies Ali Akbar Mulla Bashi as one of the opposing Shiites who uses invented hadith ( ) to make his false point (308b)                                                               
* (cont.) Shiite scholars engage in sophistry, truths mixed with falsehoods; enrages the Sunni scholars (308b):                        []    [  ]                         
* (cont.) After the blasphemous Shiites had finished, enter the good guy, along with a plethora of metaphors about his greatness and erudition (308b-309):                                 [ ]                              [ ]          []         []      
* (cont.) Through the power of this individual sense reached the shah (?) (309):                [ ]            []                      
* (cont.) His words persuaded everyone present of the truth of Hanafism, which enraged the Mulla Bashi (309-309b):        []                                         []                         []      
* (cont.) Mulla Bashi works to deny these Hanafi truths, making a fool of himself (309b):       [ ]                                                                          
* (cont.) Nadir calls a halt to the debate, seeing the truth of the matter for what it was, and embraces Sunnism (309b):                             []      []                 []         []                 
* (cont.) (309b-310)                         
* (cont.) Commanding everyone to obey the Sunni madhhab (310):                               []            
* (cont.) (310):                      []                      
* (cont.) Nadir writes a decree to follow Hanafi Islam and undo Shah Ismails wrongdoing (310):                         [   ]                                               [ ]                            
* (cont.) Quoting a hadith to the effect that the four rightly guided prophets are to be honored (310b):                                           [ ]                                                                          [ ]                       
* (cont.) (310b):                     []                            
* (cont.) (310b-311):                      [   ]   
* (cont.) Going through the selection the four rightly guided caliphs (311):              []                     []                                              []   []         
* (cont.) Continuing to praise the four rightly guided caliphs, who protected against innovation etc. (311):                                                 
* (cont.) We too are firm in this conviction (311):                               
* (cont.) Henceforth the cause of divine anger will also be the cause of wrath of the monarch - i.e. Nadir (311-311b):                                   
* (cont.) Nadir sends the order out to all the realm (311b):        []                            
* (cont.) Rewarding the Hanafi scholars handsomely with rupees, horses, cloaks, perfume; references a hazrat ishan in particular (311b):                                                     []           []                                            
* (cont.) [paleography problem here] (311b-312):   []    []  []           []                [   ]            [ ]  [  ]

> Mull Mrz lim, Dar Bayn-i Rh-i ajj, 1888 (al-Biruni 9379/III)

    [[Iusupova|Iusupova and R. P. Dzhalilova, Sobranie vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii nauk Respubliki Uzbekistan. Istoriia]] p. 378, 904; 9379/III l. 154b-159b.
* Written by Kokandi Mulla Mirza 'Alim in 1888. Goes through Bukhara and then Istanbul. Chaghatai.

> Mull Ava Muammad, Tufat al-Tawrkh Khn

[[Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia]] p. 329, 458; C 440 (572d)
* Title:    
* Author:         
* Written 1286/1869-1870.
* Contents: "     .    :  (. 1).     -   (. 15-16).         1283/1866-67 . (. 98)" (p. 330).

!!!Babur (18-):             


!!!Abd al-Rahim Beg (49b-51b)     
* Based not far from the modern city of Khoqand, but predated Khoqand's founding (49b):                                             
* Rival amirate in Khujand (49b-50):                                                                                 
* Buta Bay and Rahim fight a number of battles, make peace, fight again, until Rahim Khan kills Buta Bay during an assault on Khujand (51):                                                          
* Manages to conquer all of Farghana, then moved on Samarqand (51b):                                                    

!!!Abd al-Rahim Khan marches on Samarqand and Shahrisabz                (p. 51b-54)
* First Rahim Khan marches on Andijan to remind its rulers who they owe their allegiance to (51b-52).
* After that, they moved out and pillaged the outskirts of Bukhara, before turning to Samarqand (52):                 
* (cont.) Unsuccessfully laid siege to Yarmazar fortress near Samarqand (52):                                                  
* (cont.) (Unclear meaning) (52):                      []                                
* (cont.) Ultimately conquered (or just sacked?) Samarqand, and then turned sights on Qatta Qurghan (52b):         [  ]               
* (cont.) Qatta Qurghan submitted, turned sights on Shahrisabz (52b):                    
* (cont.) At that time, Shahrisabz was ruled by Hakim bey or Alim Bey - sources differ - brother of Ibrahim Ataliq; the two sides come to an accord (52b):                                                                          
** Note that Rahim Khan used the title Sahibqiran; on this and Shahrisabz episode more generally, see also [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh: Khoqand through Alim Khan]].
* Marriage to Ibrahim Kenagis's daughter as a settlement (52b):                                    
* (cont.) And so this is how the Kenagis have a marvelous connection to the Ming (53):             
* (cont.) Having achieved such glory, Rahim entered Samarqand (53):                             
* cont. about his illnesss in Samarqand

!!!Abd al-Karim   (p. 54-
* Abd al-Karim marries Rahim Bey's wife, the Kenagis princess (54b).
* Invasion of Kashgar by the Chinese (54b).
* The ruler of Kashgar,        fled to Badakhshan, where he continued to rule (54b).
** Until the people of Badakhshan sold out his sons to China, whereupon they were executed (54b).
** A third son (the oldest) fled to India, where he entered Aurangzeb's service. Seems to also say that Aurangzeb gave him one of his daughters to marry; and the shaykhs of Marghinan are descended from him (55).
* Mentions that a community of Kashgar emigres sprang up on Khoqand at that time (55).
* The great plague of Samarqand, accompanied by various chaos and depredations, leads to massive emigre communities in Khoqand (55):                                                                              []                              
* Invasion of Farghana by Qalmaqs, lay siege to Khoqand (55b).
* Assist by Uratepa (56).


!!!Irdana Khan         (p. 62b-64)
* Alliance with Bukhara, joint decision to remove the Yuz from power (64):                                                                          

!!!Irdana and Rahim Bey march on Uratepa         (p. 64-64b)
* Meeting each other personally, besieging Uratepa, Hisar coming to its aid, playing some kind of a trick to pit Bukhara and Khoqand against one another (64):                                                                            
* Uratepa presses its advantage and attacks Khoqand, inflicting a defeat (64b):                                          
** (cont.) Uratepa inflicts a massacre (64b):                                 

!!!Massacre at the second battle with Uratepa                (p. 64b-69b).

!!!Narbuta Beg       (p. 71-72)

!!! The fall of Khoqand to Bukhara in 1842:                                    (p. 225b-235)
* //on this episode see also [[Mr Salmn Samarqand, Tafsl wa Bayn-i Dawlat-i Jamat-i Manghit (IVRSP C 667)]]//
* Vilifying Nasrallah and setting up the the attack (225b):                                              1257                                                    []         
* Bukharan victory in Khujand - total rout, many important prisoners taken (226b):                                                                                                                                                  
* At this point Muhammad Ali Khan realizes all is lost, offers the throne to his brother Mahmud (226b):                                               
* Soliciting help from the ulama, collecting tribute and writing letters of apology to appease Nasrallah (227):                                                      
* Muhammad Ali's brother, Mahmud arrives from Tashkent with a big army, there is much rejoicing, Muhammad Ali installs him as khan in his place (227b):                                                   
* By this point the year is 1258 (228).
* Muhammad Ali had refortified and reconstructed all the kingdom's forts (228):                1258                                          
* The Khan still hoped to strike a deal even as Nasrallah advanced on Khoqand; Nasrallah says that only if he wishes to fully submit to Bukharan authority (228):                                    -        -                                             
* The fall of Khoqand, compares Nasrallah to Hulegu and Chingis - negatively (229):    1258                                                                                             
* Fleeing to Andijan loses Qizilbash (//interesting//) treasure to pillagers, women of the haram are violated (229b):             []                                                          
* Hiding out in Marghinan (229b):                                                                        
* Traitor in the midst, capture (229b-230):                                                                                                                                               
* Author lamenting the outrage of their capture (230-230b):                                    
* Execution of Muhammad Ali and his son (230b):                                                            []   1258        
* Queen mother and three wives executed (231):                                                                                                                                                              
* Detailing a population relocation of Khoqandis to Bukhara; Ibrahim put in charge as governor; another prince executed (231b):                                                           []                                                                                                                        
* Muhammad Ali Khan's age and rule (232):                       
* Poem by Ishan Qari Qunduzi about the sack of Khoqand by Bukhara; long tragic poems on following pages as well (232).
* Anecdote about Junayd Herati's condemnation of the pillage (note from other sources that he eventually had to flee to Shahrisabz) (233):                                  -  -      -
