* Describes the oppression under Ibrahim, then a confederation comes in from the mountain steppe out of Talas to put Shir Muhammad on the throne (233-233b):                                                           []                                            1258                                 
* (cont.) Amir Kabir conquers much of Farghana, visits a shrine for blessing, sets course for Khoqand (233b):                                                                               
* Qipchaks retake Khoqand, Ibrahim flees toward Khujand (234).

!!!Shir Muhammad Khan                                     (p. 235b-249b)
* Shir Muhammad's origins - he was one of Alim Khan's sons who fled to Talas when his father was murdered and made his life there until the 1840s when opportunity knocked (237-237b):                     1216                                                                                              []                  -  -        -        -                                                                    

!!!Mala Beg vs. the Yuz in Uratepa                (p. 326b-)

!!!Qanaatshah of Tashkent vs. the Russians              (p. 336b-)

!!!Mala Beg marches on the Russians himself              (p. 335-)






> Munis Khorezmii, Firdaws Al-Iqbal: History of Khorezm, trans. Yuri Bregel (Leiden: Brill, 1988).

Edited edition: Shir Muhammad Mirab Munis, Firdaws al-iqbal: history of Khorezm, ed. Yuri Bregel (Leiden; New York: E.J. Brill, 1988).

From Ulfat:

One of the learned men of his time was Mawlana Sayyid Muhammad Akhund who wrote a history entitled Gulshan-i iqbl about his (Shir Ghazi Khan's) ancestors, his genealogy, the circumstances of
his life and his victories. It was embellished with rhymed prose, metaphors, allegories, and all kinds of figures of speech. But before it could be copied it fell into the hands of the learned men (jUial')of Bukhara who, out of envy, destroyed it, tearing to pieces every chapter, section by section and page by page (Firdaws al-iqbal, 1999, 61-62)

Ilbars Khan
* Opening: "Ilbars Khan was the son of Shah Niyaz Khan, but some think he was one of the Qazaq sultans.  Due to the efforts of Ish Muhammad Biy and Jum'a-Quli Ataliq, he mounted the throne of sovereignty in the Year of the Monkey, 1140 A.H. [i.e. 1727/28].  In his time, for eight years the country (yurt) enjoyed peace and quiet" (62).
* After putting down an internal rebellion, Ilbars goes a raiding in Khurasan: "After this, in the Year of the Hare, Ilbars Khan sent the Yomut Jiyen Vekil, with 3,000 Turkmens, in a raid against Khorasan.  They divided themselves into two parties; one went to the desert f Mane, the other - to the Aladagh and Semelqan region, which is the abode of the Chamishgezek Kurds.  They came and they were already in the midst of plundering, when the governors of those provinces arrived with Qizilbash troops, and a great battle took place.  Many people on both sides were killed.  Finally the Qizilbashes were defeated, and the ghazis, having returned with plentiful booty, attained [the honor or] kissing the [khan's] threshold.  At that time Nadir Shah had conquered Shamakhi wand was before Ganja" (63).
* "In 1150 A.H., the Year of the Horse, prince Riza-Quli Mirza, son of Nadir Shah, captured Balkh, and in Rabi' II set out for Mavarannahr.  Therefore the ruler (hakim) of Bukhara, Abu'l-Fayz Khan, and Hakim Ataliq asked Ilbars Khan and Ish Muhammad Biy for help.  They sent them a reinforcement of 1,000 men, and Ilbars Khan himself followed them with a big army.  The khan had not yet reached Bukhara, when the news came that the Qizilbash army in Qarshi had concluded peace with Abu'l-Fayz Khan and had turned back, and so the khan [also] returned" (63-64).
** //Note that [[Astarabadi, Durrah-i Nadirah]] says that Ilbars chickened out.//
* Minor scuffle between Khiva and Riza Quli "At the end of the Year of the Sheep, in the month of Zu'l-Qa'da 1151 A.H. [9 February - 10 March 1739], the khan left Ish Muhammad Biy in Khiva as his deputy, set out himself for Khorasan with the army of Uzbeks and Turkmens and arrived in Tezhen.  At that time Riza-Quli Mirza, having returned from his father in India, was in Herat.  He heard this news, and went with all possible speed to repulse [the enemies] and came to Sarakhs.  At that time Ilbars Khan already had advanced five farsakhs from Tezhen.  The scouts [qaravul] of both sides clashed, and the ghazis captured and brought three Qizilbashes from the enemy's army.  On hearing news about the prince from them, [the khan] considered it unwise to confront him, turned the reigns of departure in the direction of Amvar, besieged the fortress Qakhlan, which is between Nesa and Abivard, and was already close to capturing it.  Its governor (hakim), who was at that time in Abivard, heard the news and came from Abivard with troops for reconnaissance. The khan thought that it was the army of the prince, lifted the siege, plundered the environs and returned [to Khiva]" (64).
* Invasion of Nadir Shah: "In the Year of the Monkey, 1152 A.H. [1739/1740], Nadir Shah, after the conquest of Bukhara, moved off from the environs of Bukhara on Sunday 16 Rajab [6 October 1740], and on Thursday the 21st of the aforementioned month [11 October] he passed Charjuy, intending to conquer Khorezm.  On Monday 13 Sha'ban [2 November 1740] he reached Tive-Boyun.  Muhammad 'Ali Ushaq, who came with an army of Uzbeks and Turkmens, confronted him and was defeated.  On the 20th of the same month Ilbars Khan and Ish Muhammad Biy and all the amirs of Khorezm came to Hazarasp with innumerable army to repulse [the enemy]" (65).
** "In the region of Pitnak they met [with the enemy] and joined battle.  However much they exerted themselves to kill the infidels, it was no avail.  Finally the Muslims were defeated and being unable to remain in Hazarasp, ensconced themselves in the city of Khanqah" (65).
*** Precise language here (165):                          
** (cont.) Nadir Shah pursued them and besieged the aforementioned city (balada).  The army of Islam fought well, but was defeated.  After seven days they were exhausted and left the fortress under the terms of a truce.  On Sunday the khan [also] left with the amirs.  On Tuesday the 27th of the same month, Nadir Shah put to death twenty amirs of Khorezm, with Ilbars Khan and Ish Muhammad Biy at their head" (65).
** (cont.) Nadir is after slaves from his territory, just like the Russians: "At the beginning of the month of Ramazan Nadir Shah left Khanqah, laid siege to Khiva, erected the sarkubs [a siege tower] and started bombarding [the city].  From the pounding by the balls of muskets, cannons (tufang va top) and swivel guns (zanburak), most of the buildings were destroyed.  After three days, Dost Muhammad Arbab surrendered the city (qal'a) to the shah.  The shah stayed in the city for three more days.  He gathered all the captives, men and women, who, in accordance with the holy shari'a, had been enslaved in the land of Khorezm, and turned them over to their kinsmen and relatives.  In the same way he also took some Qalmaq and Russian slaves.  Among them all, the number of Khorasanian captives exceeded twelve thousand, and four thousand of them were from the royal capital Khiva.  He sent them to Khorasan, and, having built a fortress (hisar) at a distance of four farsakhs from Abivard, which called Khiveabad, he settled them there" (65).

Tahir Khan
* "He was the son of Vali Muhammad Khan, who was one of the paternal cousins of the khans of Mavarannahr.  When Nadir Shah was leaving, he put him on the khan's throne and left [some of] his own troops with him.  On 17 Ramazan [5 December 1740] he set out from Khiva and went back to Khorasan.  Tahir Khan ruled for six months.  He would cut of the ears and noses of offenders, and he used to promote Shi'a rites 
** Wording (167):              
* (cont.) Consequences: "Muhammad Mirab b. 'Ayd Mirab the Nokuz could not stand this tyranny, entered Kat, embarked on the path of hostility and unfurled the banner of resistance" (66).

Nur 'Ali Khan
* "Nur 'Ali Khan was a son of Abu'l-Khayr Khan... With the help of the people (khalq) of Qahraman, they entered the city, and for three months fought the Qizilbashes under Tahir Khan who had ensconced themselves in the citadel (ark).  Finally, having [penetrated] to the well by means of a mine and filled it with earth, they left [the besieged] to thirst and thus captured the citadel.  They dispatched Tahir Khan and the Uyghur Qutli Khan to hell, together with the Qizilbashes.  Having entered the citadel, Nur 'Ali Khan mounted the royal throne" (66).
* (cont.) Legitimating the rebellion by Nadir: "The same year Artuq Inaq went to Iran, met the prince Nasrallah Mirza in Merv [son of Nadir Shah], and submitted a written report describing the dishonor and oppression meted out by Tahir Khan, so that the prince was pleased with the killing of Tahir Khan.  With the permission of his father, the prince showered him with infinite favors and royal largesses, made Abu'l-Ghazi Sultan ibn Ilbars Khan a khan, entrused him to the inaq and sent [them to Khiva]" (66).
** Bregel has an extensive footnote (370) recounting [[Kim, lam r-yi Ndir]]'s account of this episode.

Abu'l-Ghazi Khan II
* "His name was Abu'l-Muhammad Sultan. When Nadir Shah made him khan, he gave him the kunya Abu'l Ghazi" (67).
* Nadir changes de facto management of Khorezm: "In 1156 A.H. [1743-1744], the Chowdurs 'Ali Bay and Oraz Bay started hostilities, made an alliance with the Yomuts and conducted such a massive raid against Besh-Qal'a that nobody could venture out of his fortress (qurghan).  The calamity of famine spread.  Upon the advice of Abu'l-Ghazi Khan and Artuq Inaq, Muhammad Amin Mehter, one of the sons of Yarim Divan, went to Iran and reported these events to the shah.  to repulse the Turkmen rebels, Nadir Shah sent the great sipahsalar Fath 'Ali Khan ibn Ibrahim Khan, who was his own nephew, with 40,000 brave troops, to Khorezm, the dome of Islam, and sent Khuraz Bek with him, having handed authority over this country to him" (67).
* "In 1159 A.H., the Year of the Hare, Khuraz Bek went to Nadir Shah in Iraq.  In his absence, in the same year, Abu'l-Ghazi Khan put Artuq Inaq and Sayyid 'Ali Biy to death, together with their mother.  Khuraz Bek heard about this in Iraq, asked the shah to send Ghayib Sultan with him, and with the support of the shah, conquered Khorezm.  On hearing the news about the arrival of Khuraz Bek, the amirs of Khiva seized Abu'l-Ghazi Khan and detained him in the 'Arab Khan madrasa.  Khuraz Bek took him out of the madrasa and put him to a cruel death, in revenge for the blood of his elder brothers and mother" (67-68).
** Footnote 378: "Both the sequence of events and their chronology given by Munis contradict those in the account of Muhammad Kazim (see previous note).  Khuraz Bek could not have gone to Nadir Shah in Iraq in either 1159/1746 (the Year of the Leopard) or 1160/177 (the Year of the Hare), because the shah was not in Iraq after 1156/1743.  More importantly, Muhammad Kazim participated in the expedition of 'Ali-Quli Khan to Khorezm himself, and his account should therefore be preferred.  It is possible that Khuraz Bek killed Abu'l-Ghazi Khan, indeed, in the Year of the Hare - 1160/1747, but it could have happened only //after// the murder of Nadir Shah on 10 Jumadi II / 30 June 1747 (similar to the killing of Abu'l-Fayz Khan in Bukhara by Muhammad Rahim Ataliq, which took place immediately after the death of Nadir)" (584).

Ghayib Khan
* "Ghayib Khan.  He is the son of Bahadur Khan. In his youth, he went from the Qazaqs to Bukhara, and when Nadir Shah conquered Mavarannahr, he entered his service.  He was with the shah's retinue in most of the battles and campaigns.  He came with Khuraz Bek, and in the same year... he was exalted with the crown of the Khorezmshahs" (68).
* Figurehead: "During his time the subjects (fuqara) enjoyed peace, and the affairs of the state were in the mighty grasp and at the powerful will of Khuraz Bek, and Ghayib Khan had nothing except the title [of khan].  Therefore the khan was very depressed" (68).
** However, Khuraz Bek gets murdered, and Ghayib Khan gets to rule for real (69).


[[Indian Archives and Libraries Index]]

This catalog is written in Hindavi, first in Hindi, then in Urdu.  It includes descriptions of manuscript contents.  56 Persian entries.

> Muammad Shafq Murdbd, ed., Fihrist-i Makht (Arab, Frs aur Urd) (Lucknow: Amir al-Dawla Public Library, 2000).

No 15, p. 11:  
* Accession ( ): no. 48342
* 270 pages.
* Beginning pages are missing - which is problematic since the subsequent sections are highlighted by day, without a mention of year.
* I think this is actually about Babur and Humayun in Qandahar.


No. 43, p. 24:   by   
* Accession number: 48332
* 242 pages.
* Written in 1223 during the reign of Muhammad Shah, covering the period from Shahjahan up to Muhammad Shah Mughal.


[[Arabic Sources]]

> Abdallah bin Abd al-Raman bin Abd al-Rahm al-Muallim, Alm al-Makayyain min al-Qarn al-Tsia il al-Qarn al-Rbia Ashar al-Hijriyy, Part 1, (Muassasat al-Farqn lil-Turth al-Islam Far Muassasat Makka al-Mukarrama wa al-Madna al-Munawwara

         
        
          

__Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Husain al-Bukhari al-Maki__        (p. 276)
* ? - 938 h.
* The briefest of the Bukhari entries. It does not explicitly say when / if he came from Central Asia and the timeperiod is pretty early anyway - he died in 938 Hijri.  That said, he studied ( ) under a guy named Fahd al Qarshi   (among others).

__Akhundkhan bin Muhammad Hadi bin Muhammad Murad bin Idris al-Bukhari al-Mirghinani__            (p. 276-277)
* 1243-1320 h.
* He was born in his own country (      ), which was presumably Bukhara or Margilan, and migrated to Meca for the Hajj.
* He roosted in Madina for a while and learned what he could from the Ulama there, such as    from who he learned a great deal about the hadith and tafsir and fiqh (277).
** This Shaykh gave him permission to spread his views and rulings:    
** He also studied under  
* Then he moved to Mecca and settled there and presided over teaching ( ) at the  .
* This scholar then in turn gave permission to       to teach his views.

__Muhammad Ali bin Muhammad Vali al-Bukhari al-Hanafi__        (p. 277).
* 1015 - 1070 h.
* An ustath in  
* Born in Mecca.
* Hafiz; permission () to recite different texts by their masters is clearly a very important part of this tradition.  Also lists who he "took" () fiqh from.

__Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad al-Bukhari al-Rumaithi__       ,  ,   (p. 278).
* 818-890 h.; This guy is a little on the early side, but the entry has more details on his activities in Central Asia than usual; it is interesting that he traveled from Bukhara to Samarkand for learning (see below).
* Born and raised in Bukhara; memorized the Quran (just like everyone else) as well as other important texts.
* Studied with      and        
* Traveled from Bukhara to Samarkand for learning, not vice versa:          
* This guy was a serious traveller; he visited Mecca, Baghdad, Jerusalem, Cairo, and Sham (Damascus, presumably), learning everywhere he went:         .
* Eventually he settled down in the Shaikhdom of Mecca (    ) in 859 h.
* In Mecca he became Imam for all of the Hanafi Maktab there:        in 867 h.  This guy rose all the way to the top.
* Interestingly, he simultaneously taught the doctrine of Hamadani (//Naqshbandi by this point?//): ...       
** @@interesting@@ In Mecca, it seems, the Hamadani sufi order is associated with the Hanafi maktab.
* He authored a number of grammatical works:   ,    ,    

//There are also entries for a Samarqandi and a Balkhi, but the Samarqandi was born in Mecca and there is little information on the Balkhi//

__Muhi al-Din bin Sabir bin Dhakir Khalifa bin Abdallah Khalitat al-Kashghari al-Bukhari__              (p. 786).
* 1311-1369
* Initial training in Kashghar, where he learned all manner of Islamic sciences.
* Travelled to Bukhara in 1328 (//note the date - 1910 AD//) where he studied    from __   __ and    under __ __.
* Then he travelled to Madina by way of Syria (Sham), where he stayed (i.e. in Madina) for some time studying Hanafi fiqh and hadith, eloquence (), and tafsir.  Later he returned to Damascus where he studied hadith and got an   from one of th emasters there.
* After that he went to Mecca, where he died after teachin gat the  
* //this is an important entry illustrating the educational networks at a rather late stage in the game.//

[[Manuscripts Index]]

//Note: Do to a digitization error, I initially misidentified this manuscript as j Abd al-Am, Tadhkirat al-Shuar, 1277-1285 [[Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]], vol. 5 p. 79; 3575, 3396/III//

This text is identified as    in [[Frolova, Arabskie rukopisi Vostochnogo otdela Nauchnoi biblioteki Sankt-Peterburgskogo gosudarstvennogo universiteta]].
* Like al-Biruni's copy, the Vostfak SPGU copy is one of many chapters.  In the Vostfak case the first chapter is   (Arabic, 1b-62b); the second, short work is a short Hanafi treatise about various reliigous issues; the third is noted        (p. 73-99); and then the fourth being Mu'in al-Fuqara's work (101-149b).

> Amad bin Muhammad Mun al-Fuqars Risla-i Mull Zda, ms. IVANUz no. 3396/I
Author:    " 
Work:   ; in other copies, sometimes    or   

Catalog: [[Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]], vol. 5 p. 309; 3575, 3396/I
* This manuscript was recopied many times; Semenov's remarks on this particular copy:  -     - .     (, -,   XIX .).   -  (p. 309).
* Semenov's general description of the work: ...    ,         .      ,      ,           , ,                   .  .  .  .   - -,     -...         ,  ,   ,   ',   '.    1219/1804 . (3979 / 4355, p. 303).

!!!Reflection
This work truly blurs the line between Arabic and Persian; the author freely switches between the two even mid-sentence.  It will be interesting going forward to see if this was the norm for that milieu. Judging from the beginning, this work seems to be everything but a biography of poets; it is more of a legal work.  The majority of this work consists of description of the various sufi shrines in Bukhara and stories about those individuals.  It is kind of a pilgrimage manual.

!!!Introduction Praising God and Legends about Bukhara
//The author opens this book about Bukharan poetry with an extensive discussion of Bukhara's origin, all the while emphasizing its sanctity and physically rooting the city's sacred history in Islam.  Some version of Devin DeWeese's nativization theory seems to be going on here.  Bukhara as the new regional center.  Also worth noting that it is more than clear from the author's style of argumentation that he is deeply schooled in the Islamic sciences - to an extent greater than, for instance, [[Muhammad Hakim Khan|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]].//

2
* After praising God, Muhammad, and all of the worthy followers on p. 1b, the author begins with history and legends of Bukhara's founding.
* Mentions two apostasies from Islam in Bukhara () that were defeated ( ).
* Mentions a mosque built in Bukhara by  in the year 94.
** Draws significance to the fact that it was built in the same 10 years that the Umayyad mosque was built in Damascus.
* Begins another section quoting   by the writer most famous for the work ; Faizollah clarified that this is Mahmud Zamakhshiri ( ), a famous Sufi. 
** From EI (by Versteegh): "... one of the outstanding scholars of later mediaeval Islamic times who made important contributions, first, in the fields of the linguistic sciences of grammar, philology, lexicography and the collecting of proverbs, in which sciences he was, despite his own Iranian descent, a __strong proponent of the the Arab cause__ vis-a-vis the Persophile partisans of the Shu'ubiyya; and second, in the field of theology an dQur'an exegesis, his approach to these being that of the __Mu'tazila__, of whom he may be considered as one of their last significant representatives."
*** Ibn Batuta visited his tomb in Khwarazm.
*** Lived 1074 or 1075  1143 or 1144.
*** Traveled extensively and spent a great deal of time in Bukhara learning hadith (EI supplement by Maddelung).
*** On al Kashaf: "... his efforts in explaining the Holy Book's grammatical, lexicographical and rhetorical features, variant readings and miraculous nature of its beautiful language earned him universal admiration... His rationalist Mu'tazili interpretations, however, provoked criticism among traditionalist Sunnis" (EI supplement by Maddelung).
*** Tended to be anti-Sufi and often backed Shafi'i positions, even though he was from the Hanafi madhab (EI supplement, Maddelung).
*** "His voluminous Rabi' al-abrar wa-nusus al-akhbar contains extracts from literary and historical works arranged according to 92 topics.  It was meant to be a companion reader to his Qur'an commentary" (EI supplmenet by Maddelung).

2b
** From the Kashaf text, the author relays a hadith whereby the Prophet has a dialog with Gabriel in which Gabriel says that the city of  is known in Persian as Bukhara; Muhammad asks why, and Gabriel responds that on Judgment Day Bukhara will be distinguished by the quantity of its martyrs:         
** Quoting from the same hadith, author says that God blessed the denizens of Bukhara above all others.
* In the next section (i.e. section signaled by red lettering) the author is quoting the Juvayni work   , which mentions Bukhara as the pivot of Islam ( ).  Then:                        
** From EI (Barthold / Boyle): Djuwayni (623/1226-681/1283) was a Persian governor and historian, author of Ta'rikh-i djahangushay; son of a major collaborator with the Mongol conquerors who eventually became Sahib al-Diwan.
*** Serving under the Mongols, this was the public official who drew up the terms of surrender of the Isma'ilis at Alamut.
*** "The Ta'rikh=i djahan-gushay, which has considerably influenced historical tradition in the East, is for us also a historical authority of the first rank. The author was the only Persian historian to travel to Mongolia and describe the countries of Eastern Asia at first hand..." 
*** The edited edition of this work is by Mirza Muhammad Qazwini; also translated by J. A. Boyle.
** Author gets into the etymology of the term Bukhara; alleges that the Magians () used the term to refer to the agglomeration of knowledge ( ); adds that the languages of the idol-worshiping Uighurs and Chinese supports this derivation as they call their idol temples Bukhar as well.
** Another name for Bukhara was: 
* Next the author moves on to citing Narshakhi.

3
* Ghunjar's, as well as Asbat bin Alaysa, relay that Job was buried in Bukhara (2b-3):                                                               
** There is a legend that the prophet Job () came to Bukhara and was treated very well and in return he said a prayer for them.
* Author quotes a scholar of the prophets of Israel that one of them went to Bukhara and gave three blessings:            
* Another tradition also emphasizes Bukhara's sinlessness:          

3b
* Quotes a guy I can't quite read to say that Job's shrine () is in Bukhara.  Author describes a tree that remains green in winter and a spring that comes from heaven near the shrine.
** However, no sooner has the author relayed this story than he says that it is not in fact true:            
** Rather, Job's grave is in fact in a village near Damascus (see marginalia); it is next to a spring that is mentioned in the Quran.

!!!Section on Shrine Visitation:        
//At this point the author switches rather abruptly from a discussion of the legends of Bukhara to an in-depth legal analysis of the permissibility of grave visitation.  Perhaps he is concerned that having spelled out where different shrines are located, people might try to visit them.  In any case, it demonstrates where the bulk of his training lay.  It also indicates that shrine visitation was a contentious issue even back then.//

3b
* Sidenote: When this author praises the prophet, he says:     ____  ; //not sure if this added reference to the Prophet's family carries any significance vis-a-vis the Shia Sunni split//.

4
* At issue in the shrine pilgrimage debate is whether the Prophet visiting the grave of his mother is a privilege transferable to the population at large.  The author conveys a number of competing hadith, some which forbid it, some which permit it.  This entire section is pretty much in Arabic; not entirely surprising, given the topic.
* There is a hadith where the Prophet asks God to forgive his mother for being a polytheist, is refused, but then asks to be allowed to visit her grave and is allowed to.

5b
* Interesting that the author goes through a bunch of hadith about grave visitation, some in favor, some against, then switches into Persian when talking most generally about the wisdom of    

6
* These anonymous "ulama" concur that grave visitation is sunnat.
* Author even cites a hadith (generally, not citing specific authors like when he was writing in Arabic) that visiting the graves of your father and mother is tantamount to the hajj:              ...    

7
* This page has some interesting nativization traditions for Bukhara regarding the hair of the prophet:                   
**   
**     
** The most interesting reference is to the lock of hair kept with a Sogdian dihqan:                 
* Al this talk of shrines launches the author into a discussion of the proper ways to visit a shrine ( ); here the author is cautioning against the dangers of engaging in the practices of the ahl al-kitab, such as kissing the shrine.

8 
* Prayers and instructions for visiting shrines, including specific instructions for visiting the great ones and places where relics - i.e. the Prophet's hairs - are kept (7b-8):                           ... (instructions for revering Muhammad's hair continue).

10
* Bukhara was conquered in the time of the companions, but none of their graves remain:                                                                                           
** However, the ulama agree that if one's intention is pure, intervention will still take place even if you are mistaken about the identity of the shrine.

15.  The Samanids (aside from Ismail, mostly just listing birth and death information; goes through p. 16b)
* Ismail Samani:         []                                                                                              

16b
* Source for all the Samanid stuff is Ghunjar:

> Muammad Abd al-Jall Samarqand and Ab hir Khwja Samarqand, Qandiyya wa Samariyya: du risala dar tarikh-i mazarat wa jughrafiya-i Samarqand, ed. Iraj Afshar (Tehran: Muassasa-i Farhang-i Jahngr, 1367).

Notes from manuscript version of second part of this volume: [[Qr Mash Tamhd Samarqand, Samariyyah, 1957]]

Editor's introduction
* Muhammad Abd al-Jalil edited and updated a work by his teacher, Muhammad Nasafi (16).
* 1909 printing by      came with the following addition at the end of the volume (16-17):                                                                                        
** Note that it was actually printed in Samarqand (12).
** Said Nafisi got a hold of this rare edition of Qandiyya during a 1335 trip to Afghanistan, on which this edition is based (12).
*** As well as numerous manuscripts, including one from Bengal (13).

[[Chronicles Index]]

> Mr Salmn Samarqand, Tafsl wa Bayn-i Dawlat-i Jamat-i Manghit az Zamn-i Ram Khn

[[Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia]]
*           -     (p. 319, 453; C 667)
* Chronicle runs from p. 161a-178b and is one part of a longer manuscript.
* Written no earlier than 1860 and no later than 1868.
* Pages 177b-178b cover the life of the author himself: "...         ;   -  -  -              ...       -       ;           ,    .      ...         ;   ...       ,         ;              " (319).
* Miklukho-Maklai believes this to be an autograph copy (320).
* Description and value of the work: "      ,   1160/1747 .       , .. 1277/1860 .          ;       ,   ,   XIX .       " (319-320).
* Origin of the manuscript: ". . , 1890 ." (320).
* In the same volume as [[Dhikr-i Trkh-i Ab al-Fay Khn (Anonymous) (IVRSP C 667)]].

Rahim and Danial Bey
* Opening line introducing the righteous rule of Rahim Khan (161):                         1160                 []              
* (cont.) Enthronement of Danial Bey by consent of council (161):                                 
* (cont.) Danial Bey keeps a Chingissid on the throne to rule in name only (161-161b):                                                                       

Shahmurad
* (cont.) Throne passes to Shahmurad, extolling his religiosity (161b):                                                    
** (cont.) Continuing to praise his piety and austerity (161b):                                                           [ / ]     
* (cont.) Describing his battle prowess and his conquest of Marv, execution of its ruler, and bringing his head back to Bukhara (161b-162):                                                         
** (cont.) Reprisal from Timur Shah (162):                                                                                            
*** Enemy of my enemy - interesting detail about Uzbek solidarity in the face of Afghan aggression.
** (cont.) Narrative of events - Shahmurad takes some prisoners (or his men do without orders), and Timurshah sends a messenger protesting that it was not his intent to wage war against Shahmurad (162-162b):                                                                            
** (cont.) Shahmurad sends a messenger to Timur shah saying that if Timur be a sharia-abiding ruler, it is his duty before the all-powerful God to submit (162b):                                                                                           
** (cont.) Timur inquires about Shahmurad, and his messenger describes how pious and austere he is (162b):                                                                                           
** Outcome - gift of Timur to Shahmurad includes elephants and Balkh, Hisar, Badakhshan all submit to Shahmurad (162b - marginal note):                                                                    

Haydar
* Once again portrays the process of selecting the new khan as merit and consensus based (163):       []                                           [ ]                                    
* In the meanwhile Haydar had been serving as hakim of Qarshi; because the hakim of Hisar was his father in law, when that province was taken over by Kunduz, Shahmurad sent him to retaliate (163-163b):                                                                                   []                                                                
** (cont.) Haydar won a great victory, and there was much rejoicing (163b-164):            [=]            []                                   
** (cont.) Poets wrote about his exploits (164):       []           
* Haydar hurries to Bukhara on Shahmurad's death and is enthroned.  Discusses his mother's Chingissid heritage and the white felt carpet enthronement ceremony (see Sela) (164):                                                                                                                                                 []       []   
* Rebellion and unrest faced by Haydar; Qipchaq foment rebellion on the grounds of the misbehavior of Haydar's hakims (165-165b):                                                        []              
* (cont.) Many hakims rebelled, including Shahrisabz; lists the provinces taken by Shahrisabz and Qipchaq; even Bukhara itself put under siege and surrounding regions pillaged (165b):                      []                                            
* (cont.) A great victory by one of Haydar's generals against Khiva, in which the Khivan khan is drowned in the Amu Darya (165b-166):                  []      []                                                                                                                      
* (cont.) After Khiva, turns his sights on the rebellion in Samarqand, subdues one of the rebels and drives the other one to Khoqand (166-166b):                        [ ]                  []            []                              [ ]                                                                   []                                                   []                                                            
* Haydar died in 1242 (167)

The short, unhappy rule of Husayn Tura and even shorter reign of Umar
* Governorships of Haydar's different sons at the time of his death (167):                             
* Once again, the author depicts the great ones of the realm deciding to elevate him to khan using the same language (167).
* The Qushbigi decides to elevate Nasrallah, but Husayn Tura (who is actually in the city of Bukhara) gets wind of this and fears that he and his brothers will be put to death, and seizes the throne (167b).
* He tells everyone that Haydar is dead (167b):                                                                          
* Tura uses people power to seize the throne (168):                                                         
** The Qushbigi fires cannons and kills some of Tura's supporters, but he storms the gate and seizes the throne anyway (168).
** Tura spares Qushbigi's life (168).
* All the Ulama and Umara come in and they perform the white felt carpet ritual (168b).
* Nasrallah marches on Bukhara, but then retreats back to Qarshi and submits to Tura (169).
* Author is sort of vague on how Tura actually dies, but the tone is exclusively laudatory about his quality (169b).
** Blames the death on the treachery of the Qushbigi (170).
* Apparently Tura was also sick and realized he might die, and instructed his umara that his brother Umar Khan should succeed him, not Nasrallah (170b).
* In fact, Umar does briefly sit on the throne; but he ignores the sharia and goes to drink (170b).

Nasrallah
* The perils of ignoring the ulama and umara - Abu Sa'id Khwjah's role in Nasrallah's coup (170b-171):                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
** (cont.) Things don't end well for Umar, though the intervention of Ishan Tura "Husayn Khwajah" briefly saves his life (171b):                                                                                                                                                                                   
* Nasrallah's coronation (172):      1263            
* Nasrallah marches on Shahrisabz and subdues it (172):                                                                                                                                
** (cont.) Nasrallah graciously forgives the offense (172b):                                   
* (cont.) Because of Muhammad Ali Khan's alleged religious transgressions in Khoqand, as well Khoqand building a fortress on the frontier, Nasrallah resolves to go to war (172b):                                    []        []                                   []                                               []  
** (cont.) Muhammad Ali Khan is defeated at the fortress of [Bashaghir], flees to Uratippa to regroup (172b-173):                                                                                                                                              
** (cont.) Describing the battle in Uratippa (173-173b):                                                                                        
** Outcome - victory for Nasrallah, conquers Uratippa and Khujand, proceeds to Khoqand itself where Muhammad Ali is hiding (173b):                                                                                                 
**(cont.) Nasrallah marches into Khoqand, receives tribute from all the different governors, sends men to hunt down Muhammad Ali wherever in the city he might be hiding (173b-174):                                                                                                                                                                  
*** //on the fall of Khoqand see also [[Mull Ava Muammad, Tufat al-Tawrkh Khn (IVRSP C 440)]]//
** (cont.) After debating between advisers about whether to keep Muhammad Ali as a puppet khan or execute him, Nasrallah chose the latter, which the author judges to have been a bad decision; the queen mother was also executed when she spoke out against her son's execution (174-174b):                                                                                                                                
* Nasrallah installs Ibrahim Pravanachi as governor of Khoqand, but after six months of mis-rule he is driven out by Qipchaks (174b):                           ...                                                                    
** Things did not end well for the Bukharan soldiers that remained behind in Khoqand.  From this point the Qipchaq run the joint with Shir Ali Khan on the throne; Khoqand retakes all of its lost possessions from Bukhara except Khujand and Uratepa  (175):                                                        
* Nasrallah marches on Khoqand once again and sieges it for quite some time, but since his army was tired, this time he accepted the peace offering when made and returned to Bukhara (175):                                                                                                                    
* (cont.) Victorious war with Khiva, though no occupation (175-175b):        []                                                                                                                                           
* (cont.) Shahrisabz governor rebels (175b):                                                          
** (cont.) Describing the difficulty of maintaining a military presence for the siege, resistance of local population, and supply chain difficulties (176):                                                          
** (cont.) Explaining the importance of taking Shahrisabz since it is perpetually a haven for political subversives from Bukhara, difficulty of getting his commanders to cooperate (176):                                                                                                    
** (cont.) Decisive victory in 1858f (176):                    1275         
** (cont.) The two intransigent princes were pardoned and sent to Bukhara (176b):                    
*** Footnote:      
** (cont.) New governors put in their place; Shahrisabz held for four years by Nasrallah; Muzaffar visited the city once and replaced the governor; however, the people of Bukhara did not accept his governors and raised their own in place (176b):                                                                                           
** (cont.) Muzaffar takes his army to siege, but fails to take Shahrisabz; instead, he sieges Yakkabagh; finding themselves surrounded, Shahrisabz's independent governors send their daughters to marry Muzaffar (176b):                             [ ]                             
** (cont.) Shahrisabz was independent for ten years.  (Does not mention that it is the Russians who returned the city to Muzaffar's hands.) (177):                                         
* (cont.) Discusses where Nasrallah's body was buried - apparently next to Khwajah Imla (177):                                   
* Muzaffar was the only surviving son; Nasrallah also had two grandchildren.  He was 55 years old when he died and had ruled for 36 years (177).

Author's autobiography (177b-178b)
* Lineage: Son of Abu al-Hay bin Abu al-Khayr (177b):                                                        
* (cont.) Studied in Bukhara in the Kukaltash madrasa (177b):                         
* (cont.) Anecdote about Shah Murad; he has doubts about some legal issue, and none of the ulama can answer his question except Abu al-Hay (177b-178):                                                                                       
* (cont.) Impressed by Abu al-Hay's erudition, Shah Murad appoints him Qazi Kalan of Samarqand on the spot and signs a Yarliq to that effect, also appoints him as mudarris of the Shirdar madrasa (178):                                                                                                                    
* (cont.) Haydar elected to renew Abu al-Hay's tenure (178-178b):                    
* (cont.) Continued description of family's accolades (178b):

> Mrz lim Tshkand, Ansb al-Saln wa-Tawrkh al-Khawqn, ms. IVANUz no. 1314/I

Section on Junaydallh Haraw dhiq (referenced Beisembaev p. 157)

* Another version of the poem cited by [[Avaz Muhammad|Mull Ava Muammad, Tufat al-Tawrkh Khn (IVRSP C 440)]]:          

* Abd al-Rahim conquers Samarqand, Qata Qurghan, then sets sights on Shahrisabz (26-27):                    
** Shahrisabz was then ruled by Hakim (see also [[Hakim Khan's Muntakhab|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh: Khoqand through Alim Khan]]); they reach an accord involving marriage of his daughter (27):                           
* After his brother's death, Abd al-Karim also married the Shahrisabzi princess (28-29).
* Story involving Aurangzeb in India (//revisit//) (29).
* The Qalmaq / Yunghar invasion (30).
** Uratepa comes to the rescue (31).

[[Indian Archives and Libraries Index]]

!!!Guide Pt. 2
Police
* Police organization: "Prior to 1843 various measures were devised for a proper system of Police administration. This system varied in each Province, but the measures were never coordinated and placed on a systemic basis" (127).
* Prior to 1862, policing was dealt with by the Judicial department; in 1862 a separate "Police Branch" was created under the Home Department (127).
* "Intelligence Bureau and subsidiary organisations."

!!!R.R. Section Foreign Dept. Index 1830s & 40s
* [[Brief note on Kunduz's conquesst of Badakhshan (INA FD, 5 September 1833)]]
* [[Lord's Report on Kunduz (NAI FD 6 March 1839)]]
* [[Translation of a letter from the Mir Wali of Khulum (NIA FD, 12 July 1841)]]

* [[Report on Koondooz (NAI FD, 29 July 1859)]]

[[Assorted Khuda Bakhsh (Patna) Catalogs]]

> Navb Amn al-Dawlah Khall, Khulat al-Kalm (Khuda Bakhsh 1772)

  by               (cat. vol. 8, p. 137-142; 142-147, no. 704 & 705)

* 252 folios, completed 1783. Indexed in catalog.
* "A very valuable and rare Persian Tadhkirah, consisting of selections from Masnawis, with biographical notices of the poets, in two volumes" (137).
* //Note//: @@No. 706@@ (p. 147) is the same "without the poetical extracts" (147). @@Hand list 222@@.

Khalifah Ibrahim Dihlavi    (p. 4b-60)
* //From catalog//: "His father, Muhammad 'Ali, better known as Haji Baba-i Badakhshani, came to India from Turkistan, and Khalifah was born in Shahjahanabad, Dihli A.H. 1087 = A.D. 1676.  He became the disciple of Mir Jalal-ud-Din Husayn Badakhshani, who was born in India, and was a Jama'dar under Fath Ullah Khan of 'Alamgir's time" (138).
* Father's arrival from Badakhshan / Turkestan (4b):               
* Military service (4b):            []           
** (cont.) Meets his pir, who is his unit leader, in the military (5):                            [   ]                
* (cont.) Engaged with all the different Sufi orders, but got his sufi cloak from the Naqshbandiyya (5):                                  
* (cont.) Entering into courtly life and prestige (5):                           
** (cont.) After three years Jahandar Shah triumphs over his brothers and comes to power (5):       [ ]                      
** (cont.) However, due to the injustice of Jahandar, Ibrahim Dihlavi forsakes court life and his relationship with Jahandar (5):                                 
** (cont.) Six months later another brother removes Jahandar from power, but Ibrahim falls into disfavor for not wearing proper clothes and showing insufficient attention to the new emperor (5-6):              []              []                  []      
* (cont.) Ibrahim Dihlavi spends seven years in the Deccan, then returned to Delhi under the reign of Muhammad Shah (6):                     
* (cont.) At the request of Sa'dat Khan Burhan al-Mulk Ibrahim Dihlavi is appointed governor of Lucknow (6):                                     
* (cont.) Returns to Delhi after the withdrawal of Nadir Shah (6):                             
* From there the text describes his publications.  From the catalog: "At the request of his Pir, he added the seventh Daftar to the Masnavi, left incomplete by Maulana Rumi, and also incorporated an incomplete story of the princes at the end of the sixth Daftar (Catalogue p. 138).



[[National Archives of India Index]]
[[Cholera Index]]

> 1892 Foreign Department. Secret F. Pros. September 1892, Nos. 24-38. Abstract of news-letters received by the Agent to the Governor-General in Khorassan during the four weeks ending the 5th August 1892. G.C. Press Calcutta - 8.

"No. 142-A, dated Camp Gurakh, the 15th July 1892.  From - N. Elias, Esq., Agent to the Governor-General of India, and Her Britannic Majesty's Consul-General for Khorasan and Seistan, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department" 
* "News-letter dated 1st July 1892. Received Camp Gurakh, 11th July 1892" (1).
** "Railway traffic is suspended on account of cholera, and there are no travellers, except those who are furnished with passes by General Kuronpatkin [sic.].  These are permitted to travel once every ten days towards Russia, or in the direction of Merv, Charjui, or Bokhara" (1).
* "Via Herat. Enclosure to Khorasan Agency letter No. 142-A., dated 15th July 1892. Meshed. F. News-letter dated 9th July 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk 11th July 1892" (4).
** "Telegrams.  28th June 1892.  From the Amin-us-Sultan. To the Sahib Diwan."
*** "'According to information received from the British Legation, the slaughter-house of Meshed is situated close to the town, and the bad smell which issues forth from that place is likely to aggravate the epidemic.  This is quite true.  Issue orders at once that the slaughter-house should be removed to a long distance from the city, and that the place should be cleaned.  You ought to have thought of these things without being told.' [ssterisked note:] This order arrives after the epidemic has almost ceased, but if carried out the measure will still do good" (4).

"No. 147-A, dated Camp Gurakh, the 22nd July 1892.  From - N. Elias, Esq., Agent to the Governor-General of India, and Her Britannic Majesty's Consul-General for Khorasan and Seistan, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department" 
* "Askhkabad. C. News-letter dated 28th June 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk, 18th July 1892."
** "Great excitement and consternation prevail in Ashkhabad now-a-days on account of the cholera.  The epidemic is not of a very virulent type, and the number of deaths is only about ten a day, but the proceedings of the Russian doctors have greatly alarmed the people, who have run away in different directions.  The population of Ashkhabad has been reduced by about one-half.  If a person complains of even a headache he is at once carried off, by force, to the hospital where the Russian doctors administer to him a dose of poison, which kills him within half an hour.  This measure, it is said, is adopted to prevent the spread of cholera.  All dead bodies are burried [sic.[ without shrouds or coffins with the clothes of the deceased on them, in deep holes dug in the ground which are filled with lime.  Muhammadans are not allowed to inter their dead in accordance with the ceremonies and laws laid down by their religion. This hurts their feelings considerably and is causing great discontent, but the people are helpless" (1-2).
*** [asterisked note]: "I insert this letter as a specimen of many that have reached me to the same effect.  The report is general throughout these regions that the Russians are poisoning large numbers of Mussalmans in order to prevent the spread of cholera.  (Sd). N.E."
** "The railway trains run regularly, but no passenger or goods traffic is allowed" (2).
** "All the Russian doctors, with the exception of two who have been left at Ashkhabad, have been deputed towards Merv, Sarakhs, and Bokhara, &c." (2).
* "Meshed. D. News-letter dated 17th July 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk, 17th July 1892." (3).
** "A number of hazaras, who lately fled from Kalanau, went into Russian territory and asked for protection, but the Russians, having expressed their inability to support their cause, they obtained permission to proceed to Persian territory and came by Pul-i-Khatun to Turbat-i-Sheikh Jam. Their Kazi died of cholera at Sarakhs" (3).

"No. 152-A, dated Camp Gurakh, the 29th July 1892.  From - N. Elias, Esq., Agent to the Governor-General of India, and Her Britannic Majesty's Consul-General for Khorasan and Seistan, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department" 
* "News-letter dated 9th to 15th July 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk 22nd July 1892" (1).
** "About two hundred persons have died of cholera at Russian Sarakhs during this week.  The rate of mortality among the Russian soldiers is about five per day" (1).
* "Meshed. A. News-letter dated 24th July 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk, 26th July 1892" (2).
** "In recognition of the services rendered by the Russian Military Doctor during the outbreak of cholera at Meshed the Persian Government have conferred upon him the third class Order of the Lion and the Sun, but he has declined to accept it and demands a higher class of the Order" (2).
* "Meshed. A. News-letter dated 26rd July 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk, 26th July 1892" (2).
** "Owing to the restrictions placed on traffic on account of cholera, the price of Russian imports has gone up considerably in Meshed.  The price of sugar has risen by a hundred per cent" (2).
* "Via herat. Enclosure to Khorasan Agency letter No. 152-A. dated 29th July 1892." (3).
** "//17th July 1892.// - Telegraphic reports received from Shahrud state that the Russian Government having heard that plague is prevalent in Mazinan, have deputed a Doctor to ascertain if this is the case.  The Russian Doctor* in question has arrived at Shahrud and is proceeding to Mazinan at once." (3).
*** [asterisked note:] "He is said to have died of cholera at or near Mazinan about the 20th of July. (Sd.) N.E." (3).

"No. 157-A, dated Camp Gurakh, the 5th August 1892.  From - N. Elias, Esq., Agent to the Governor-General of India, and Her Britannic Majesty's Consul-General for Khorasan and Seistan, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department" 
* "Ashkabad. d. News-letter dated 3rd July 1892. Received Camp Gurakhk, 31st July 1892. (Delayed in transmission)." (1).
** "There is no intercourse between Ashkabad and other places at present.  No railway tickets are issued to passengers whether going towards Ozanada or Bokhara.  The Turkomans are not allowed to visit the town." (1).
** "Troops are posted all along the Persian frontier, and travellers going toward Persian territory are allowed to pass on, but none are allowed to enter Russian territory from Persia." (1).
** "It is reported that cholera prevails throughout the Caucasus.  It is also said to have broken out in Russia proper." (1).


[[National Archives of India Index]]
[[Cholera Index]]

> 1892 Foreign Department. Secret F. Pros. April 1893, Nos. 274-297. Abstract of news-letters received by the Agent to the Governor-General in Khorassan during the February and the first half of March 1893. Demonstrations against the Meshed Branch of the English Bank in Persia. G.C. Press Calcutta - 8.

"No. 43-A., dated Meshed, the 18th February 1893. From - Ney Elias, Esq., Agent of the Governor-General of India and Her Britannic Majesty's Consul-General for Khorassan and Seistan, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department." (1).
* "News-letter, dated 28the December 1892 to 16th January 1893. Received Meshed, 14th February 1893. (Delayed in transmission on account of snow.)" (1).
** "//4th January 1893//. - Usman Khan* [asterisked note: "Probably a Russian frontier police officer. (Sd.) N.E.") captured three Turkomans near Maruchak, and on searching their persons and saddle-bags he found three letters secreted in their long boots.  The letters were written by the Ishans and elders of the Sarik tribe to the Ishans and elders of Maimena, and the purport was as follows: - 'You and we belong to the same religion.  You are Mussalmans and we are also Mussalmans.  We inform you in the name of God, the Prophet and the four Caliphs that the Russian Government are not a good Government. They are great tyrants.  During the cholera epidemic they set fire to a large number of houses belonging to Mussalmans and burned their property.  They are yearly imposing enhanced taxes on the people of Ashkabad, Merve and Sarakhs, and their tyranny has reached its climax.  Take care lest you should offer your allegiance to the Russians and be deceived.  If you do so you will lose your country, your ruler and your religion, and will not see a happy day, and will become captives of the infidels.  We have given you warning to please God and the Prophet, but you may do as you like.  Peace be upon you." (1-2).
*** "Usman Khan brought the letters together with the three Turkomans to the Governor of Panjdeh who imprisoned the three men and telegraphed the matter to Ashkabad." (2).

"No. 67-A., dated Meshed, the 11th March 1893. From - E.C. Ringler Thomson, Esq., Her Britannic Majesty's Acting Consul-General for Khorassan and Seistan, and in charge of the Khorasan Agency, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department." (1).
* "Meshed. Be. News-letter, dated 8th March 1893. Received Meshed, 9th March 1893." (5).
** Russian Persianate subjects as a geopolitical tool: "The body of a Russian subject, who had been previously murdered by strangulation, was taken out of a well inside the town the other day. The Russian Consul-General has taken up the case, and says that he knows that the Persians have some hostile intentions against the Russians, as they constantly murder their subjects, several of whom have up to the present disappeared in this town." (5).
* "Near Meshed. N. News-letter, dated 1st March 1893. Received Meshed, 8th March 1893." (5).
** "The Russian Consul-General is getting lists prepared of the people who were formerly inhabitants of Khiva, Urganj and Merve, and are now settled in Khorasan.* [asterisked note: "These Khivans, Urganjis, and Mervis have been settled in Persia for several generations."] he is also causing a list of the Herat refugees to be prepared." (5).
* "Meshed. P. News-letter, dated 6th March 1893. Received Meshed, 7th March 1893." (4).
** "Some trustworthy men from Bokhara report that telegraphic information received from St. Petersburg states that the Amir of Bokhara has laid before the Russian Government a claim to the whole of Afghan Turkistan, including Maimena, Balkh, Andkhui, Saripul and Akhcha, and that active steps are being taken by the Russian government on the matter.  The Czar is said to have conferred the Amirship of bokhara permanently on the Amir." (4).

"No. 72-A., dated Meshed, the 18th March 1893. From - E.C. Ringler Thomson, Esq., Her Britannic Majesty's Acting Consul-General for Khorassan and Seistan, and in charge of the Khorasan Agency, To - The Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign Department." (1).
* "Meshed . M. Extracts from local Reports received during the week ending 17th March 1893." (3).
** The active currency in Meshed is the rouble: "Some of the Ulema of Meshed are objecting to the currency of rouble and other notes in Khorasan on the grounds that they have no real value, and as one individual is not responsible for them, they are illegal, and it is against the laws of the Shia religion to deal in them.  The matter was referred to Agha Mirza Hasan Shirazi, the Hujat-ul-Islam [asterisked note: "The chief Shia Mujtahid at Najaf (Sd.) E.R.T."] for orders, and His Holiness has decreed that in case notes are things in trust (amanat), it is lawful to deal in them, but that otherwise they are illegal.  Some of the Mullas of Meshed are of opinion that notes do not come under the heading of things in trust, but no final conclusion has yet been arrived at." (3-4).

[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

> Fond: 924 ( -    ) 561, Rossiskoi Natsional'noi Biblioteki.  66 .   19 . - 30- . 20,  

>  (Untitled, but catalogued as Tetrad s razlichnymi zapisiami), m.s. Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka in St. Petersburg, fond 924, no. 561, ff.

Belongs to a genre of qazi exemplar notebooks known as //jung// , often passed on from father to son  (conversation with Sanjar Ghulamov).

Description from unpublished opis .924      - , 1991 //but with new pages added in the back//:    .    , ' (),              ,     .    -    ...         , ,        -- "

Scanned pages: 0b-1 (inside cover, loose poetry); 11b-13; 17b-19; 22b-23 (cases); 26b-34.

Inside Cover
* Top inscription:   ...      1300 ...       ...
** //very difficult to decipher, lacunas, smudges; 1300 (if I have that right = 1882).//
* Bottom inscription:         1296 ()     ...    ()   () ...        
** //see inside page; clearer date//
** Judging by the date of a case below, I assume that the qazi is marking the birth dates of his sons, not himself.

!!!Main book of qazi notes (pages bound more securely than previous section, material of pages darker) begins on p. 11
11.  Probably the inside cover sheet of the Qazi journal and hence these cases were added to later.
* Case 11.2:
** (1)                    
** (2)             []     
** (3)  []             
** (4)         
*** I think that  may be a generic word for "good"; see Case 12b.1

* Case 11.3:
** (1)         
*** (1) Because a certain female so-and-so had affirmed and brought an action [against her husband, saying]: 
** (2)         
*** (2) so and so - my husband - for a year now has been unable to deflower me/ consummate our marriage" 
** (3)        
*** (3) and their marriage has been retained [Q2:231]  therefore,
*** //Cook//:  imsak ba-ma'ruf: The phrase derives from Q2:231 (and similarly Q65:2), where Arberry translates "retain them honourably" (as opposed to going ahead with the divorce).
** (4)          
*** (4) [the case] should be adjourned, from this date until the end of a period of one complete lunar year 
*** //Modaressi//: " Ta'jil nimudah shud" means "[the judgment about the case] is deferred" as you correctly said. In line 5, the word "haal" has dropped out as you correctly guessed and it is indeed to be understood as [the condition of] her husband becomes [definitely] known as you suggested.
** (5)           
*** (5) so that [the truth of the matter with regard to] her husband may be known. This was in the presence of a number of Muslims / in an assembly of Muslims
*** //Modaressi//: one might read the kih in ta kih shawharash malum gardad as either giir (= problem) or giid (= impotence)or is it clearly just kih?

11b actually seems to be the first page of the Qazi journal, as it begins with   etc.

17b contains a text of trusteeship:  

* Case 18b.6:

* Case 19.3:
** (1)               [ ]

** (5)               
** (6)  []      
     
* Case 22b.1
** (1)              

* Case 22b.2:
** (1)                 
*** //Zahir//: mubarak-namah; humayun -  I am not sure about the structure of political authority in the Bukharan emirate but it would be quite high up because of the term humayun which refers to royal, imperial, and in Iran for instance would be associated with the shah. I wouldn't translate it as blessed letter though, unless letters are what the khans you refer to would normally issue, I think it might be better to call is an edict, decree etc.
** (2)               
** (3)      ()       
*** //Zahir//: batan - This is not from the verb baata, I am quite sure this is from Ar. root ba-ta-ta, two words battan , and batatan , are used to mean definitively, categorically, once and for all, etc. c.f. Wehr, p. 51. Though I am not sure of the form  which I think also exists according to Lane. Also I am not sure hal has anything to do with it, I think the structure is furukhtah (Persian verb) then with bay'an as an Arabic derived verbal noun (masdar) which functions as a cognate accusative (al-maf'ul al-mutlaq) followed by modifying adjectives like batan, sahihan, laziman etc. I am planning to investigate how this works in the post-doc hopefully, its quite fascinating how Persian and Arabic combine in these texts.
*** //Zahir//:      is this transcribed correctly? Inqibad, does exist without the ya' but not sure how we would translate it. And what is this dual al-badalayn; badal can refer to 'what is given in exchange' so price, rate, sum, but I think here refers to the 'two things being exchanged' so 'with receipt of the two things being exchanged' maybe.
** //Zahir's translation//: On such and such date based upon an imperial edict, the resplendent piece of land of the bazar of such and such place was sold to the well known mulla so and so for a period of one complete lunar year in exchange for such and such (amount) in a confirmed, authentic and binding sale, with receipt of the two things being exchanged by both sides, and with [their] acceptance/agreement, dated...

** (1)

***  seems to make more sense than  (fast).

*** paraphrase: This went on for two months

*** who is this  ?  does that refer to the  ?

*** notice the subtitle  on the hidaya; reading (probably reciting) 11 lines from the hidaya was required for serving as a prayer leader

** (8)                 
** (9)                   [

* Case 26b.2: Madrasa-related issue; illiterate madrasa instructor
** (1)                 
** (2)                  
***  refers to reading the Quran or Islamic text correctly in a good voice; does not mean he is illiterate; here   means irresponsible
** (3)                
** (4)              [] 
** (5)                 
*** In response the qazi sent people to test the imam.
** (6)                   
*** This imam wasted a lot of time because of his irresponsibility;   here means that, for instance, he was not in the masjid at prayer time
** (7)        []   [ / ]      
** (8)                    
** (9)    [ / ]   []             
*** The qazi here is referring to someone at a higher station, perhaps an Uzbek official of some kind.
*** Issues:  (see also Case 21.1); 
*** Dehkhoda has a second definition for    (the first being "fearless):   

* Case 27.1: Jewish conversion to Islam
** (1)  
*** (1) O Compassionate Master!
*** //Zahir// translated   as "O compassionate master."  //Cook//: master? -how do we get than, given that banda means slave?
** (2)     15          ^  [  ] ^        
*** (2) Such and such Jew of about 15 years of age from the new quarter of the Jews, came before me and in the presence of many Muslims abjured himself from the invalid religion of his forefathers,
** (3)              [=]     
*** (3) and from all invalid religion and said 'I hereby become a Muslim'.  I instructed him in the good saying ('there is no god but God' - Q14:24 for the phrase, Tabari, Tafsir, 17:437 no. 20,659 for the equation of the good saying with the first part of the shahada) and the witnessing ('I bear witness that Muhammad is his messenger').
** (4)    [=]    [ / ]          
*** (4) He recited  these two noble sayings (the kalimah and the shahadah) with great enthusiasm [....]. Because of his recitation of the two noble sayings and his exoneration from invalid religions
*** //Cook//:  I dont get umidgaha
** (5)            ^      [] ^     
*** (5) The aforementioned so and so, became a Muslim and entered the ranks of the Muslims. I sent some people who were present [az haziran....firistadah] [to testify?] regarding the complete (dar haq-i kamali....) [something: conversion?] of the previously mentioned [Jew]
*** //Cook//:   Is the naw misplaced, i.e. should it not be naw-musalmaan or musalmaan-i naw (either near the start of the line or near the end)? Whats the yaa doing at the end of in-duagu?
*** //Cook & Zahir// agree that  means "I, myself."
** (6)          ( / )  ()      
*** (6) to the just court of his excellency so that it be brought to his radiant attention and deference/obeisance to him could be made.
*** //Cook//:  hazrat-am: whats the am doing here? I think anwar; gufta: seems to hang loose; arz-i bandagi: one expects a verbmikunad or the like.  What bothers me is that hazrat-i X is a standard formula for "his excellency X" (e.g. Hazret-i Muhammed" = the Prophet Muhammad (I'm used to this in Anatolian Turkish, whence the voewls).  On that analogy, hazrat-am would mean "my excellency", which seems out of line. alif-haa': I know this as an abbreviation for intahaa = it is finished (i.e. "this is the end of the quotation").
*** Issues:  / 

* Case 27.2: Something involving the  
** (1)           [= ]  []        
** (2)     []               
** (3) ]           []      [] 
** (4)     []       []     
** (5)   []     []        
** (6)                    
** (7)   []                  

* Case 27b.1: Testing a Mulla with the Hidaya
** (1)                 
** (2)                    
***     means presented himself at the author's service
***      means the author accepted the petitioner's request for consideration
** (3)            []    
** (4)                  [=]  
*** role of   is unclear; possibly a governor to whom he is conveying these details
** (5)                 
***   means that the author gave the testee help
** (6)                          
*** I.e. I have tested this mullah, he was found wanting, but the choice is up to you

* Case 27b.2.  Appointing a mufti and rais
** (1)     []           
***  here means petitioner of the position of rais and mufti
** (2)   [ / ]  []              
** (3)         [/ ]          
** (4)                 
***  probably also refers to the hakim or some high official; the extra alif signifies address
** (5)                 
*** with the junab alis blessing you will become mufti etc.
** (6)                   
** (7)           
*** prayer of supplication for the junab ali

* Case 27b.3.  Ruling on a wedding
** (1)   ]              
*** to seal the marriage the matter must go to the junab ali; not clear whether this is for all marriages or just second ones
** (2)                 
***  here refers to a woman;   means engaged
** (3)                    
** (4)        
*** So the qazi already ruled that the marriage was valid but sent it to the junab ali for approval

!!!29b: Prayers to the royal courts:     

!!!42- 43: Waqf-related material

!!!43b-44b: Khutbas
* These are sermons read at the establishment of waqfs.  They are probably exemplars, however, as they also use  etc. instead of proper nouns.

!!!43b: A final section of qadi court reports

!!!54-60: Handcopied poetry, usually couplets
* 54: Strange old-Cyrillic Persian transcription.  //clearly this notebook was kept in the family and read through the Soviet period//.
* 57b: Name    followed by some Turki poetry.

[[Master Index]]

* [[Astrological Court Documents (TsGARUz i-126 / 1 / 1978)]]
* [[Risla dar marifat-i shna (sheep bone divination - IVANUz 415/IV)]]

* [[Interview with Abd al-Ghafur Razzakov - 10 August 2014]]
[[Imperial Russian Sources]]

N.V. Ostroumov, Geografiia Turkestanskago kraiia s kratkimi svedeniiami o khanstvakh Bukharskom, Khivinskom i Zakaspiiskoi oblasti (rodinovedenie), 2nd ed. (Samarqand: Tipo-litografiia N. V. Poltoranova, 1891).

Description of ethnic breakdown in Turkestan ( )
* For the Russian population, differentiates between ie and  (58).
** Puts their number together at 110 thousand, including the army.
* Tajiks are the oldest residents of the region. Tajiks are traders, craftsmen, and farmers (,   ) (59).
** Residents of the Kuhistan (): galcha. Galcha are all herders and farmers (  ) (59).
** Together, puts their number at 300 thousand (59).
* Puts the number of Uzbeks at 350 thousand (59).
** However, there are lots of kinds of Uzbeks: "   ,      32   96" (59).
** Nomadic Uzbeks are sometimes called Kyrgyz (59).
** Settled Uzbeks differ from Tajiks //only in language//: ",     ,      ,  ,  ,   " (59).
*** Sarts: " ,     ,     ////    ,    " (59-60).
**** More Sarts than any other ethnicity: 650 thousand (60).
**** Biggest Sart populations: Tashkent, Kokand, Margelan, Namangan, Andijan (60).
* Kuramintsy: "       :  78 . .       " (60).
* Karakalpaks: 76 thousand (60).
* Total population breakdown: "    :  (5 1/2 .)   (5 1/2 .)   .;  (3 .),  (3 .)   .;  (7 1/2 .)  - .;  (16 .)  -   .;      (16 .),  (6 1/2 .),  (1 .)   (1 .)" (60).
** Kirghiz and their relatives the Qarakirghiz number 871 thousand (60).

Essays on the Khanates
* Ethnic breakdown of Bukhara: "       ,   .        ,   750 , - ,       ; 240 .   10 . -  , ,   ,      ,    " (77).
* Portrays the Tajiks as long since subjugated by the Uzbeks (77).

[[National Archives of India Index]]

> 1884 Foreign Department. Secret - E. Pros. May 1884, Nos. 52-78.  Afghanistan Boundaries.

//Very curious report; does this "prophet" Muhammad Abd-Allah Ben Omar "Kessidi" appear in any Central Asian sources?//

"No. 65. No. 65, dated St. Petersburgh, 14th March 1884. From - Sir E. Thornton, Her Majesty's Ambassador, St. Petersburgh, To - Earl Granville, K.G., Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs." (4).
* "I have the honor to enclose a translation by Mr. Michell of an extract from the St. Petersburgh //Vedemosti// of yesterday, reporting that some excitement is observed among the Mussulmans of Bokhara on account of the victories which it is reported to have been won by the Madhi over the English in the Soudan." (4).

"No. 66. The St. Petersburgh //Vedemosti// of the 1-13th March 1884, contains the following paragraph: -" (4).
* "According to intelligence received from Bokhara, excitement among the Mussulman fanatics is also observable there. Reports of the Mahdi's victories over the English have spread throughout the Central Asian bazars.  @@A new prophet@@ has even made his appearance in Bokhara in the person of Muhammad Abd-Allah Ben Omar, who has adopted the appellation of Kessidi.  He demands that the Sultan of Turkey should proclaim a holy war against the infidels, and threatens to proclaim the Sultan Abdul Hamid, an apostate, if he does not unfurl the green banner of Muhammad." (4).


[[TsGART Index]]

> Perepiska o litsakh, sostoyshchikh pod nadzorom politsii Khodzhenta 1907 (TsGART F64 O1 D19)

General Notes
* Note that the police seem to be almost entirely corresponding with the Mirovoi Sud, i.e. a Russian, not the Narodnyi Sud, i.e. the local Qazi.

Tracking an Iranian subject in Khojand (p. 2).
* 10 August 1907.     from   . 
*                .
* Goes on to describe the individual's physical appearance.

[[TsGARUz Index]]

> Permission from Katta-Kurgan Nachal'nik for local to study in Bukharan madrasa (1910: i-126 / 1 / 1191)

//Would have to revisit to get through some paleographic / language issues, but the basic point is that the Russians were stepping in and bureaucratizing a centuries-old educational route.//

!!!Russian Document (f. 1)
25 September 1910
Katta-Kurganskii U"ezdnyi Nachal'nik
No. 10722
* Individual in question: Mulla Berdimurad [Bey?] Ab al-Dhikr 
* Permission to go to Bukhara to study: ...               ...

!!!Turki-language Pass (f. 3)
* Titled as  , "open letter," //probably direct translation of  in the Russian version.//
* This is a blank printed form for traveling generally; the individual in question, his place of origin, and his destination are filled in with pen.

> Mr Sayyid Qamar Sudr

> Jung-i Q Mr Sayyid Qamar udr, ms. IVANUz no. 2588, f.

Author:     
Broadest date range listed: 1261- 1303 (1840s-1850s)

* Described in [[Gulomov, "O nekotorykh podlinnykh dokumentakh iz kollektsii rukopisnykh proizvedenii fonda Instituta Vostokovedeniia AN RUz"]]
** Inventory number 2588: astrological writings, divination. Also 151 rivayat. This collection was the personal archive of Qazi Sayyid Kamara (5). Also has some documents appointing a mudarris and qazi (6).
** Massive notebook of various rivayats, rescripts, astrological scribblings, etc.

[[Indian Archives and Libraries Index]]

See also: [[Perti, Catalogue of Manuscripts of the Fort William College Collection in the National Archives of India Library]]

> R.K. Perti, Catalogue of Acquired Manuscripts (New Delhi: National Archives of India, 1991).

Religion
* 8 - Intikhab-i Tarikh-i Aftab Numa: Acc. No. 2532 (p. 5)
** Important Sufi biographical dictionary, but only has four chapters of the original work.  Names of the writer and date of transcription missing.
* //There are a bunch of Sufi tazkirat in this section that do not specify dates, but are probably pre-18th century in content//
* 25 - Interestingly, there is some sort of treatise on jihad and the practicalities of war written for Tipu Sultan in this section (p. 14).

History of India
* 33 - Akhbar-i Darbar-i Bahadur Shah II: Acc. No. 369.
** History of several months in 1849.
* 34 - A hisotry of Oudh at the end of the 19th century (p. 20).
* 40 - Gulzar-i Kashmir, Kirpa Ram Kakhini Wala: Acc. No. 128 (p. 23).  Urdu
** History of Kashmir from earliers times through 1914.
* 43 - Ibrat Nama - History of 1791-92 (p. 26).
* 46 - History of Sayyids of Bilgram through 1756 (p. 27).
* 59 - Ruy-Dad-i Nadir Shah, Raja Jugal Kishor of Delhi: Acc. No. 324 (p. 35)
** "... an account of Nadir Shah's invasion of India with a special mention of the general massacre at Delhi."
* 69 - Tarikh-i Kashmir, Maulawi Nizam al-Din Muhammad: Acc. No. 2014 (p. 40).
** "It is a brief history of Kashmir dealing mainly with the later Mughal period."
* 81 - Waqiat-i Kashmir, Muhammad Azam bin Khair al-Zaman Khan: Acc. no. 319 (p. 47)
** "... a history of Kashmir from the earliest times down to 1160 A.H. (1747 A.D.).  The author commenced this work in 1848 A.H. (1735-36 A.D.) and dedicated it to Muhammad Shah.  It includes biographical notices and extracts from the writings of the principal Shaikh, Savants and poets of Kashmir."
** //Note: I have scans of the section on Hamadani (Salar Jung copy, f. 22b-32a)//
* 82b - Tarikh-i Nadir Shahi: Acc. No. 2025 (p. 48).
** Included in a tome called Zawabit-i Asaf Jah.
** "This anonymous work contains a brief account of Nadir Shah's invasion of India with narration of loot, plunder, and general massacre that he brought about in Delhi."  Written in 1838.

Biography
* 175 - Tazkirat al-Mu'asirin, Shaikh Muhammad 'Ali Hazin: Acc. No. 348 (p. 101)
** "... an important work containing notices on hundreds contemporary poets most of whom the author had met, and whose verses he quotes from memory. The work was written in India in 1165 A.H. (1751-1752 A.D.) and completed in just nine days as stated by the author at the end.  It is divided into two classes (Firqa), the first of which relates to the 'Ulama, who wrote verses, and the second; poets by profession, as shown in the list of contents."

General
* 184 - Jawahir al-'Ulum-i Humayuni, Muhammad Fazil al-Qazi Samarqandi: Acc. No. 2662 & 2663 (p. 106)
** "This important work is a kind of encyclopedia coverying 120 branches of learning viz., Poetry, Geneaology, Anatomy, Chemistry, Music, Jurisprudence, Geometry, Islamic history, Mongol history, stories of Prophets, Grammar, etc."
** Two volumes, over a thous and pages each.


[[Indian Archives and Libraries Index]]

> R.K. Perti, Catalogue of Books of the Fort William College Collection in the National Archives of India Library (New Delhi: National Archives of India, 1984).

Biography
* 495 - Wafiyat al-A'yan, Shams al-Din Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Abu Bakr Ibn-i-Khallikan: 920 W 212 W (p. 13)
** "A famous biography of eminent Arabic writers, poets, scholars and philosophers, with prefaces in Latin." 
** 13 volumes, 1835-1850; //probably about classical period, not contemporary India.//

History
* 523 - Siyer al-Mutakherin: 954 Si 99 S, p. 141.
** Deals with the history of India from 1707 to 1782.
* 602 - Durrah-i Nadiran, Mirza Muhammad Mahdi Khan: 955.03 D 938 D (p. 164)
** "A history of Nadir Shah with special reference to his expedition to India."
* 603 - Tarikh-i Jahankusha-i Nadiri, Muhammad Mahdi bin Muhammad Nasir Astrabadi: 955-03 T 174 T (p. 164).
** "Deals with the life of Nadir Shah Afshar..."







[[Indian Archives and Libraries Index]]
[[Repository Index]]

See also: [[Perti, Catalogue of Acquired Manuscripts]] (New Delhi: National Archives of India, 1991)

> R.K. Perti, Catalogue of Manuscripts of the Fort William College Collection in the National Archives of India Library (New Delhi: National Archives of India, 1989).

Preface
* Covers 199 manuscripts in Persian, Arabic, Sanscrit, Hindi, Urdu, and Bengali, once part of a much larger College of Fort William Calcutta collection, which was closed in 1854 (i).
* Upon its closure, the manuscripts wen to the Asiatic Society of Bengal; eventually the books were split between the National Archive and the Imperial Library (now National Library) in Calcutta (iii).
* The author of the catalog was director of the archive at the time of publication.

Religion
* 58 - Dabistan-i Mazahim, Mubad shah: Acc. No. 501 (p. 28).
** "It is a work on the various religious and philosophical doctrines of the eastern peoples with special reference to the religious conditions in India during the 17th century.  It contains twelve Talims (chapters) on Zoroastrians, Hindus, Jews, Muslims, etc., with a brief history of each religion... The work in all probability was completed after 1063 A.H. (1652-53 A.D.).

History
* 176 - Tawarikh-i Kashmir, Narain Kaul, Ajiz: Acc No. 510 (p. 85)
** History of Kashmir from earliest times through 1709 AD

Geneology
* 195 - Kitab-i Ansab, Sayyid Aman Allah: Acc. No. 485 (p. 94).
** Geneological trees of the Sayyids of Zangipur, Nonahra, Para,... along with village histories.  Compiled in 1738.

Ariza: 30 Jumada al-Awwal, 1331

Individual in question:         

Persian Ariza (f. 3)
* Three trips to Bukhara:        1268        1272   1274            1277
