[[Khoqand Chronicles Index]]

> Sayfani, Khullas al-Tawarikh (1914), IVANTaj no. 1220

Title:  
Author:        
Catalog: Mirzoev p. 133 index 32, no. 12220
* Written in 1332/1914.
* From p. 29a covers Shahnamah figures.

* Shahrukh Khan's sons, only the youngest of which never took the throne (7):                    
* Abd al-Rahim Bey took Samarqand and married daughter of ruler of Shahrisabz (7):                           
* Abd al-Karim Bey known for building the ark (7).  Puts date at 1153 (1740).
[[Khoqand Chronicles Index]]

> Sayyid Umar Beg bin Khudyr Khn, Anjum al-Tawrkh, m.s. IVANUz, no. 11366

Author born in 1857.  



!!!          
* Opening (79):                              
* While Abd al-Karim was in the middle of a war with the Jungars, Nadir Shah invaded Bukhara (81):                1153                                                          
* (cont.) Khoqand then controlled Samarqand, which Nadir Shah wrested in due course, as well as Katta Qurghan.  Leaders there returned to Khoqand wounded to report to Abd al-Karim (81):                                                                               
* (cont.) Despite the wretched state of his troops from his war with the Jungars, Abd al-Karim sends messengers to rally an army and builds a fortress and garrison outside of Khujand (81-81b)                                                                             
* (cont.) When Abd al-Karim heard that Nadir had marched on Khwarazm, he sent someone else to man the Khujand fortress (81b):                                           
* (cont.) Author takes a moment to tell us about Nadir Shah the man.  Portrays him as a bandit in his early days who would even raid pious darvishes (81b):                                                                                                         
* (cont.) Recounting the history of the end of the Safavid dynasty (81b):             (            )                        1134                                                                                                  
** //account of Nadir's support of Tahmasp shah continues//
* Nadir's conquests (82):        1150                                                                                                                        
* After a recap of Nadir's crossing of the Amu, summarizes his system of enlisting local talent; took representatives from the Manghit, Yuz, and Kenagis with him on campaign to Khwarazm (82b):                                                     
* Has Ilbars fleeign to Kazakhstan, which is different from the account in [[Munis Khorezmii, Firdaws Al-Iqbal]] (82b):                                           
* Describes approvingly Nadir's efforts to reign in the Shia, which got Nadir killed (82b):                                                                                                                                                                                     
* Getting back to the story of Abd al-Karim (the author admits he got sidetracked on Nadir), then more news from Khwarazm about the coup and intervention of Nadir shah (83-83b):                                                                                                                                                   
** For Khorezmian account, see: [[Munis Khorezmii, Firdaws Al-Iqbal]]
* After Nadir's death, his Uzbek lieutenants all returned home with their armies (83b):                                                                                           

[[Rukopisnyi Fond Index (Institut Vostochnykh Rukopisei)]]
[[Tazkirat Index]]

> Mr Sadatallah, Luf-i Buzrg

Very similar in terms of genre and language to: [[Manqib wa Maqmt-i Sayyid Muammad Aallah Shaykh al-Islm (PNB 200)]]

Purchased in Bukhara in 1917 by Ivanov.

* Amo bad (after  ) - dedication to Lutfallah by author Saadatallah (15b-16a):              [ ]                   [ ]                                  []           []       []              []  
* (cont.) (16a):                                      
** (continues along these lines first half of 16b).
* Shaykh told the author that he has two names - Khudayarberdi from his father, and Lutfallah from the Ghayb (16b):                              
* (cont.) For this reason the author decided to write (16b): ...        
* Author wanted to write a risala about Lutfallah, but there was chaos in Bukhara form all sides - especially Rahim Khan of Khiva (17a):                                       
* (cont.) Therefore (i.e. because of Khiva attacks, or for earlier reasons?), Haydar invited Lutfallah to Bukhara to be Imam of the Masjid-i Kalan (17a-17b):                         []   []   [  ]  
** (cont.) Lutfallah (Khuda Berdi) responded that he would do the prayers for seven weeks, but then recuse himself (//some very problematic words here//) ? (17b):  [=]                            
** (cont.) Then he sent deputies to do the prayer in his place for two years (17b):                  
** (cont.) ? (17b):        
** (cont.) Setting up a new Khanaqah in Ghijduvan and naming it after the amir (or prince) (17b-18a):                                     [ ]                        
** (cont.) Which is an metaphor for why he called this work Lutf-i Buzurg (18a):                          


!!!Childhood (18b-21b):  
* Lutfallah born in Balkh (18b):              
* (cont.) During a time of great turmoil by heretics (), Abdallah Khan built a fortress in Maymana and moved in a group of Talwara () to govern it. One of their number was named Khwaja Nazar, Lutfallah's grandfather (19a):                                                   
* (cont.) Khwaja Nazar had two sons, one of whom was Khuday Nazar, who was known for his piety and bravery (19a):                           
** (cont.) Tale of Khuday Nazar's ability to suffer in the desert without adequate food (19a-19b):                                        []             [  ]            
** Other such tale of his bravery as well, as told by his son,   Chut Sufi (19b).
** They also say that he didn't have any children until he was old, having them only after much prayer (19b). Which is why the author's father was named Khuday berdi (see p. 20a).
** Tale of Khuday Nazar's generosity - interestingly, singling out other Turks for his generosity (20a):                                                                
** (cont.) No children until later in life, when God granted (20a):                              
* (various other anecdotes, including death and burial at a mazar of his grandfather - revisit)
* When the Afghans encroached on Maymana, it was no longer possible for Khuday Berdi to remain. So he moved to Ramitin where his aunt was living, and stayed for six years (21b):                                                               
* (cont.) This was during the rule of Rahim Khan. Then Khuday Berdi moved to another village (21b):                                     

!!! Adolescence (21b-28b)
* Father told him such tales about the Other World that they simply must be shared (22a):                       
* (cont.) In his adolescence he was working as a tailor with his uncle (22a):                  
** (cont.) While praying one day in Charsu a door opened up to the Other World (22a):                        []   []                
** (cont.) Whole body goes numb while praying one day (22a-22b):     [  ]                           
** (cont.) (lost - revisit) (22b):                                      

* (@@interesting@@) One day someone asked him why he was running around to all those mazars; without learning (), shrine visiting in search of God will do you no good (24a):                                    
** (cont.) Khuda Berdi accepted this wisdom and immediately began studying in maktab under the imam of Ghardian, Bay Muhammad (24a):                                        
* (cont.) Khuda Berdi made money by collecting grass and carrying it back to the village on his back, visiting mazars by night (24a-24b):                         [  ]                            
* (cont.) Khuda Berdi assisted the imam in many things, and Bay Muhammad said prayers for him (24b):                                                     
* (cont.) The imam decided to start Khuda Berdi's lessons on a Friday, because there is a tradition that if one starts lessons, one will become an Alim, but if one begins lessons on Friday, one will become an Alim and a Zhid (24b-25a):                    []  [ ]                                                          
* (cont.) More on how Khuda Berdi would serve the imam (25a-25b):                                            [  ]          
* (cont.) Until the time when Khuda Berdi began frequenting dervishes in madrasas, sometimes those of the silent zikr, sometimes those of the vocal zikr (25a):                               
* (cont.) During much of this time he spent at mazars he would fast for days on end (25a):                       
* (cont.) Khuda Berdi studied variously in the Divanbegi madrasa - or at least prayed there (25b-26a):           [ ]                 
* (cont.) Describing his mazar visitation and prayer routine (25a):                        []   [ / ]                                      
** (cont.) Continuing description of his visitation routine, this time about time he spends studying at Amir Kulal's shrine (25a-25b):                        [  ]              
** (cont.) After running around to shrines all night, makes it back to Bukhara in time for lessons - and this while fasting (25b):                                      
** (cont.) Few people achieved the degree of discipline achieved by Khuda Berdi (?) (25b):          [=]          
* (cont.) Anecdote about carrying water to the Taharatkhana when it froze over; //missing the significance here// (25b-26a):                            [  ]                
* (cont.) The Mirshab never caught him during his nightly peregrinations to all the mazars in Bukhara (26a):                                        
**  (cont.) Classmates warned him that the "dogs of Bukhara" would eat him at night, but he paid no mind (26a):                                     
** (cont.) Asking God to protect him from both jinn and humans (26a-26b):              [  ]                                              
* (cont.) One day a classmate asked: how is it that your cheeks glow, when you have no money and don't eat, while other students eat sweets and don't have the same glow as you? (26b):                                             [ ]                
** Replies that he fasts all the time and gives everything he obtains to other students (27a).
* During the holidays he would work in the fields (28a):                                            [ ]                []    
** //The  means measure of dry goods... but the meaning breaks down without those two missing words.//
** (cont.) (28a-28b)        [  ]                                           
* Whenever he made a new cloak, he would gift it to other students rather than selling it (28b).

!!!Late Youth (28b-73a)          
Part 1 ( ) on miraculous events during his madrasa studies
* (cont.) Contents of the section, the first about his acquisition of Ilm-i Zahiri (29a):                     
* (cont.) It was at this time that the miracles started (29a):                   
* Miracle involving the appearance of a bird while sitting in Divanbegi madrasa (29a).
* A vision (29b).
* Another vision while studying   in the        Paraduz mazar (30a).
** Fashionable at that time to wear a red hat in Bukhara (30a-30b):                                 [ /  / ]                         [  ]                        [ = ]     
** (cont.) Two men in red hats sat down in a shrine he was studying in, and spoke to each other in a language he couldn't understand. When he followed them outside, all the buildings had disappeared, and they were in the middle of a desert (30a):                        []                                                
* In the Khwaja Bulghar ( ) madrasa, food miraculously appears when he needs it (31a, top).
* Tale about visiting Naqshband shrine (31b).
* Returning to Bukhara from Amir Kulal shrine (33a).
* Shrine visitation to      , story involving mosquitoes (33b).
** "This blood they are sucking is a gift for you, o' saint" (33b).
* Pilgrimage to Shahmardan in Nurata (35a-35b):          [  ]                                                        
*(cont.) Vision of Ali, involving his old Imam Bai Muhammad (35b-36a):                                              [ ]                                         [  ]   
* Another dream vision, this time involving the Prophet himself - and a cooked sheep (36a).

Part 2 ( ) on the Hajj (36b):          
* Shared a madrasa cell with Isam al-Din Khwaja in Divanbegi madrasa; but also studied at Kukaltash and Qushbegi madrasas, and eventually finished madrasa study (36b-37a):               [ ]                                             
** (cont.) They also studied under Qalandarjan, and then decided to go on the hajj (37a):              
* (cont.) They also had a hujra in the Kukaltash madrasa, which they gave to another student, despite they had purchased it themselves in exchange for fieldwork for the Guyamin (37a):                                  
** (cont.) Even though they could have legally rented the cell to the other student, they decided to take the high road and give it away for free (37b):                     
** (cont.) They also gave away the madrasa cell in Divanbegi madrasa to a student for free (37b):                  
* (cont.) Other students pointed out that this (implied) was a bad move since you need provisions and a guide to do the hajj (37b):                      
** (cont.) Khuda Berdi replies something along the lines that intention (tawakkul) is what matters for the hajj first and foremost (37b):                                       
* (cont.) Some miracle involving water (38a):                                                        [    ]         
* (cont.) In Urganj they meet a merchant heading for Astrakhan, something about water (?) (38a-38b):                                       []   [  ]          
* (cont.) So they go from Urganj to Mangishlaq, very difficult journey (38b):                          
** (cont.) Miracle of finding water out in the middle of the desert (38b):                                                                 
* (cont.) Takes a ship from Mangishlaq to Astrakhan (38b-39a):             [ ]                                  
* (cont.) In Astrakhan then randomly ran into a Bulghar they had met a in Irnazar madrasa in Bukhara, and he hosted them for 20 days (39a):                                                     
** (cont.) That Bulghar named his son Akhundjan, because he (the father, not the son) had studied under Akhundjan in Bukhara (39b):                       [  ]                                            
* (cont.) They are invited to stay with a Christian (39b):                                                       
** (cont.) People come from all over to ask the shaykh to pray for them, and leave gifts as presents, which Khuda Berdi promptly gives to their host, who is in turn amazed by the generosity (39b):    [  ]                                                                  
* (cont.) Strange anecdote about Hajis and boy love - revisit (40a-41a):                                 [  ]                                                                                                     [ ]                                      
* (cont.) Khuda Berdi ends up studying under the Bukharan shaykhs in Astrakhan (41a):                                                 

Third Fasl (41a):   
* (cont.) Shortly after returning from the hajj, author pledged himself to a shaykh - after completing madrasa study. He frequented the shaykhs of Bukhara, but did not put his faith in them, because some of them were busy with the umara (!), and others were lax in sharia because of adherence to jahr. Though he did not deny them / jahr per se, he did not want to become a shaykh from one of these guys (41b):                                                                               
* (cont.) So he decided to travel to travel to Dahbid, but the shaykh was away in Ura Tepa (41b-42a):                          []                              [=]                            
* (cont.) Rather than wait, he travels to Uratepa to meet the Dahbidi shaykh (42a):                                        
* (cont.) They go to Jizakh, where he again swears allegiance to the shaykh (42b):                                                                       
* (cont.) 42b-43):                          [ ]                 

Zikr training (44b)


* Securing royal permission to build a Khanaqa (54a):               [ ]                                                    
* (cont.) It then took them 12 years to build the wooden khanaqa and adjacent madrasa, completed in the time of Haydar (54a-54b):                   [  ]                               
* (cont.) Miraculous vision involving Shah Murad (54b-55a):                                                                          [ ]                                            
* (cont.) Niazquli sends a message that Shahmurad is about to wage holy war against Khurasan, and telling him to come with (who is talking toward the end starts to break down) (55a-55b):                                                                [  ]                                                        
* (cont.) So Khuda Berdi joins the Bukharan armies, taking Sufi Baqi with him on the campaign. But then the campaign runs into trouble at a particular fortress (55b-56b):                                          [ ]                                                                                             [  ]               
* (cont.) A problem Khuda Berdi miraculously solves; the fortress defenders are slaughtered, and the army gets the suupplies it needs (56b-57a):                                                                                                  [ ]                                     
* (cont.) Poetic imagery about the miracle / victory (57a):                                                                        
* (cont.) Prayer at the Amu (57b):               [ ]                                           
* (cont.) Discussion over who will be imam of the Masjid-i Kalan (57b-58a):                                                [ ]      [ ]                            [  
** (cont.) Ends up appointing Khuda Berdi, but Khuda Berdi gives up the position after Murad dies (58b):                                                                    


* Date of construction of the Altun Say mosque-khanaqah in Buzurgabad: 1217 (61a).
* Merchant giving money toward construction (61b):                        
* (cont.) Describing the layout of the khanaqa; Khuda Berdi lived there for forty years, until his death. Niyazquli visited on four occasions (62a):         []                                                                                        
* (cont.) Describing Khuda Berdi's routine (62a-62b):                                              

* Constructing a Saray in Ghijduvan (64a).



!!!His life as a Shaykh (73a-):   
* Contents of the Fasl - his khalifas, his children, in 15 sections (73a):                                            

First section on Khuda Berdi's wives
* (cont.) First daraja about his three wives (73b):                 
* (cont.) First wife was the daughter of Kalidi Sufi, who was extremely pious and ascetic (73b):                     
** (cont.) When Khuda Berdi moved into a havli, no one ever saw a woman (? - as in she kept out of sight) (73b):                           []                       
** (cont.) (Difficult to tell who is talking here) (73b-74a):                   [ ]                                                                                   
** (cont.) This first wife had two sons and five daughters (74a):                    
* (cont.) When Khuda Berdi fell, Niyaz Quli (identified here as their shaykh) offered to send a widow to cook bread (?); but Khuda Berdi preferred to marry a girl under his own order rather than at the behest of someone else (?) (74a-74b):                    [  ]                                                                                                   
** (cont.) This was right when Tash Muhammad became a student, and offered his daughter as a suitable bride (74b-75a):              [ ]                                                
** (cont.) Seems that the first wife died, leaving only the second, who had four sons and seven daughters (75)a:                    []                   
* (cont.) He also married the sister of the first wife, who had one son and three daughters (75a):                           

Second section on miraculous visions
* (79a)             

Third section on his Naqshbandi silsila
* (87b)                     

Fourth section on some miracles 
* (116b)                            

Fifth section
* (122b)              

Sixth section on his khalifas (129b-136a)
* (129b)                
* (cont.) Thirty-eight of his students completed their training under Khuda Berdi; but those who did not finish are beyond counting, since his career of training Sufis spanned 93 years (129b-130a):      [ ]                                                
* (cont.) He trained them both in the internal and external meaning of religion (130a):            
** (cont.) Expanding on Batin (130a):             [  ]          
** (cont.) Unlike other shaykhs, who sometimes give ijazat before (Batin and Zahir) are brought to an equal level (130a-130b):           [ ]                 [  ]  
** (cont.) (130b):          [ ]   
* (cont.) Nasrallah Khan decided to visit Khuda Berdi personally to pay his respects, and sent a person ahead to inquire how many khalifas he had (130b):                                              
** (cont.) Khuda Berdi responded that he had a thousand, but God knows (130b):                      
* (cont.) Khuda Berdi's wisdom on being a khalifa (130b-131a):              [ ]     [ ]          
* (cont.) So Nasrallah personally met with Khuda Beri, and the shaykh said "Be Suleiman, put the air beneath your feet" (131a):                           

Sixth section cont., listing the khalifas (131a)
* (cont.) First khalifa - Qurban Muhammad Qrishagi, who substituted for Khuda Berdi as the imam of the Masjid-i Kalan for two years (as mentioned on p. 17a) (131a):                                 
* (cont.) Second khalifa - Tilvay (?) Arali, last heard of living in Egypt while on the hajj (131a):                         
* (cont.) Third khalifa - Mu'min Bukhari (131a-131b):     [] [   ]  
** (cont.) Very capable (qbil), died in Bukhara (131b):                     
* (cont.) Fourth khalifa - Burhan al-Din Kurziyani (?), known for his height (131b):                        
** Note from description of khalifa no. 8, Nur Muhammad, that Kurzibani / Kurziyani is located in Maymana.
* (cont.) Fifth khalifa - Qurban Muhammad Maymanagi, who joined Khuda Berdi when the latter visited Maymana, and then completed his training after 30 years (131b):     []                             
* (cont.) Sixth khalifa - Yusuf Khwaja Khujandi, one of the children of Khwaja Baba, who is Khwaja Baba Makhdum Zinda Fil Jami (?) (131b):                     
** //check whether this is saying by awld that his is a descendant or son... since Zhinda Pil sounds like a famous saint; notice usage on khalifa 22 (f. 134a) - seems to mean descendant//
* (cont.) Seventh khalifa - Babayi Imkati (?), imam of the Imkat mosque, where he died (132a):                            
* (cont.) Eighth khalifa - Nur Muhammad of Maymana, who has a khaqah in Maymana, and planted most of the trees in Altun Say (where Khuda Berdi's khanaqa is) (132a):                            
* (cont.) Ninth khalifa - Muhammad Ali Khayr Ayati of Maymana; weird comment about how they wished him a short life (?) (132a):                               
* (cont.) Tenth khalifa - Qabad Maymanagi, who Khuda Berdi appointed kadkhud and sent him to Maymana; he was a qalandar type (majdhb al-awl) (132a):                    
* (cont.) Eleventh khalifa - Muhammad Safa of Miyankal, who had impeccable manners (db) - though the anecdote is unclear (132a-132b):    [  ] []                                       []                   
* (cont.) Twelfth khalifa - Damla Miankali Bay Sultan-i Rabat-i Miyankal (i.e. ruler of Miyankal?), who was very generous building a khanaqa that served for Friday prayers as well (132b):                         
* (cont.) Thirteenth khalifa - Muhammad Latif Baqi Mirazyi, an ecstatic sufi with tears always flowing from his eyes (132b-133a):                             [ ]    
* (cont.) Fourteenth khalifa - Umar Khwaja Kaftauli (?), who was descended from great families, but nevertheless the shaykh made him do manual labor of some kind (?) before giving him the ijazat (133a):                 [ ]                
* (cont.) Fifteenth khalifa - Ismatallah Baghchigi, who was skilled in the art of medicine (!) (133a):            
* (cont.) Sixteenth khalifa - Muhammad Saraf, who was in charge of administering the Altun Say khanaqah, including prayers (133a):                           
* (cont.) Seventeenth khalifa - Shah Muhammad Khoqandi, whom Khuda Berdi made a taalluqdr (? - in this context), who served as imam in Altun Say for a time, and then made his own khanaqa in Khatarchi (133b):                         [  ]                 
* (cont.) Eighteenth khalifa - Tash Muhammad Charkhni (?), who first studied under Khuda Berdi's pir, and then under Khuda Berdi himself (133b):                        
* (cont.) Nineteenth khalifa - Khal Muhammad Marvi, one of the ulama of Marv (133b):                         
* (cont.) Twentieth khalifa - Sayyid Khwaja Qarakuli, knowledgeable in the science of miracles (ilm-i karmat), and present at Khuda Berdi's funeral; later made his own khanaqa on the bank of the Amu Darya (133b-134a):                                    [ ]   
* (cont.) Twenty-first khalifa - Haq Berdi Khalji, served shaykh for 20 years, and sometimes gave sermon in Masjid-i Kalan in Bukhara (though only with permission), as well as imam of Altun Say Khanaqah (134a):                                           
* (cont.) Twenty-second khalifa - Nur Muhammad Marvi, who first was confirmed by Hazrat-i Kalan (presumably Khuda Berdi's pir), then by Khuda Berdi himself (134a):                      
* (cont.) Twenty-third khalifa - Sadatallah Khwaja Kulali, a descendant of Amir Kulal (134a):                  
** (cont.) Shaykh also put this guy to hard work in ( ) to complete his training (134a-134b):             [  ]                  
** (cont.) Every tenth of Ramadan he honors Amir Kulal by reading the Qur'an to completion outside the shrine and giving to the poor (134b):                        []              
** (cont.) Twenty-fourth khalifa - Muhammad Ziaudini, who runs a khanaqa in Zia al-Din, preaches there (khab), and has written a book on fiqh (134b):                                        
* (cont.) Twenty-fifth khalifa - Khwajam (sic.) Berdi Miri of Miyankal (134b-135):                [ ]             
** Note: There appear to be several pages missing. The transitional mark () reads , whereas the first word on f. 135a is . The penciled in folios are sequential, but the khalifas are not, suggesting that the intervening pages are gone for good.
* (cont. - with caveat) Thirty-first khalifa - Inayatallah Khwaja Qarachigi, who visited the shaykh on foot despite his advance age (135a):                                   
* (cont.) Thirty-second khalifa - Bek Buta Muhammad, who worked as an osh cooker for a while (135a):       []                  
* (cont.) Thirty-third khalifa - Iman Kalidi Marvi (of Marv), who was a master of Arabic grammar, died in Marv (135a):                       
* (cont.) Thirty-fourth khalifa - Isma'il Khwaja Mir Kulali was a master Qur'an reciter, which he did a the shaykh's funeral (135a-135b):                 [  ]                     [ ]    
* (cont.) Thirty-fifth khalifa - Akhund Mulla Niaz Muhammad Zarmatani (?), whose father was from the same circle of friends (?) as Khuda Berdi's grandfather (135b):                               
* (cont.) Thirty-sixth khalifa - Damla Safa Muhammad of Khorezm, descended from Khuday Quli Shaykh (135b):                            
* (cont.) Thirty-seventh khalifa - Akhund Damla Tahir Andkhuy, who was extremely rigorous despite advanced age, and eventually returned to Andkhuy to serve as shaykh (135b-136a):                              [ ]       
* (cont.) Thirty-eighth khalifa - Hasan Khwaja Kok Ata of Miyankal, specializes in Qur'an recitation (136a):                                       [ ]          
* (cont.) (136a):      


Seventh section (136a-143a)


Thirteenth section on Khuda Berdi's children (165a-173a):                
* One son was 23 years old when he died (165a):                          
* (cont.) The following marsiya was written in his honor (165a):           
* There were four other sons from the author's mother, one of whom was known for being especially brave and generous (166a-166b):           [  ]                 

* Poem about one of Khuda Berdi's deceased children (168b-169a):      -      -       -  []      -      -      -        -        -        -      -      -      -     -        -        -      -       -      -       -       -     
* (cont.) In mourning, everyone retired to their madrasa cells to focus first on Ilm-i Qal, then on Ilm-i Hal (170b):                                               
* (cont.) Then proceeded to sufi exercises in the tombs (), note mentions of the "two kinds of ilm" (170b):                                              [= ]        
* (cont.) Describing a prayer that Khuda Berdi used to say, dating it to 1246, which was 12 years before his death (171a-171b):                               [  ]                                                                          
** (cont.) Writing the words and keeping the tasbih to the day of judgment will guarantee salvation (171b-172a):                      [ / ]                  [ ]                                      


Fourteenth section on Khuda Berdi's surviving children (173a-176a):          
* After Khuda Berdi's death, five sons and four daughters survived him (173a):              
* (cont.) Nasrallah sent a stand-in from the Divan named Mirza Alim to the shaykh's funeral, and all the ulama of Bukhara attended as well (173b):        [  ]                      [= ]                           
* (cont.) (@@interesting@@) Mentions an especially prominent scholar who could not attend because he refused Nasrallah's request to serve as mufti; then goes on to say that it would not be polite to omit his name, which was Tash Muhammad (also mentioned above as one of the khalifas) (173b-174a):                                                          [ ]                       
* (cont.) Mirza Alim comes from the court and summons them to court to give prayers in the name of the sultan, which they had no choice but to do (174a):                                              
* (cont.) Amir Nasrallah had Abu al-Hadi, the eldest son, serve as his imam for the evening prayer, and the second eldest - that is, the author - serve as imam for the night prayer (174a-174b):                      [  ]               [= ]                          
* (cont.) Eldest son is appointed imam of the Ghijdivans shrine mosque (174b-175a):                                                           [ ]  
* (cont.) Mumin, the fourth son, was appointed mutawalli of that same shrine (175a):                      
** (cont.) On Mumin's virtues, reciting suras during the ten days of mourning, etc. (175a):                                                 
* (cont.) On the virtues of the youngest son, Abd al-Rasul (175a-175b):                                 [  ]                                    ... 

Fifteenth and final section (176a-180b)


Colophon (180b)
* Finished writing in 1256, then added some in 1258 (?) (180b):                                                 [  ]       [ ]         [ ]     




[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

> Fond: 924 ( -    ) 568

From the fond opis: -. 1  ( )... 2  ( )... : 1)       ,  , , ; 2) " -   -" (      ).  .  .  3)      -; 4)  "". .   .   ;     .  . 2002-1523/1.  228 .   - . -, 1231/1815-16 .

My main interest in this text is the flagrant beloved wine poetry; keep in mind that the first and largest section is a Persian-language treatise on Islamic law of some kind.  For instance, the opening point is about how it is haram to have sex with an infidel () woman (p. 2).

* Saqi Poem (p. 221b)

* p 226b: Random note scribbled - [  []   []       [ / ]     1337  20         //probably scribbled in much later as that date is around 1918//

[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

>    17-18 . (PNB F924 D624). 106 .  17-18.,  

From the Fond Opis:          .   .  . .  :        ,   ,     ...

General Notes:
* Scanned pages: 92b-93 (a fatwa); 96b-97 (cases)
* There are occasionally section headings written in red (e.g.  ), just as in [[delo 558|Sbornik vypisok iz sochinenii po fikkhu i iuridicheskikh kazusov (PNB F924 D558)]] (though absent a ToC), but generally the cases here seem to be organized more haphazardly.
** It almost seems as though there was some initial attempt to organize the book thematically, but then the cases ended up just being heaped together - possibly even by a different author, as the handwriting seems to change.
* Just like as in [[delo 558|Sbornik vypisok iz sochinenii po fikkhu i iuridicheskikh kazusov (PNB F924 D558)]], this author quotes      all the time to justify his fatwas.  (See, for instance, p. 85 where he does so twice).
* Some evidence that the text is Bukharan in origin:              (p. 38b).  Note that the same case references Balkh as well.
** Reference to   or possibly  (p. 41).
* Stray references to works used to justify rulings:  

Inconsistent Index (//mine, not the author's//)
* 2b-10: Property disputes.
* 10b-51b: Marriage; p. 11 has at the top written  
* 52-54b:  
* 55-64b:  
* 65:    //no cases, just injunctions//
* 65-66:  
* 65- 68b:  ; //following the word  it continues//:    []   [ //few cases - mostly excerpts and commentary//
* 69-72:   //few cases - mostly excerpts and commentary//
* 72b-73:   //few cases - mostly excerpts and commentary//
* 73- 78:  
* From p. 79 different handwriting begins and the continuity of the previous sections is lost; also possible that some pages were lost here.

[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

>         ,  18 -  20 . 469 .

Authors / owners:         :  - .   - 1212/1797-98 . (      ),  - .  ,  .   .

* Stray fatwa references:            

The book is organized based on the usual fiqh topics, complete with a __table of contents__ (//using internal pagination, not the archivist's//):   22   46   60   65   77   109   114   135     142   147   194   198   200   208   226   227    236   249   251   258   264   267   271   272   276   280    290  [] 316   332   333   334   336   338   339   345   360   363   398   409   423   423   428   437   438     452   //note that page 423 is marked twice in the book//.
* Also: Statements and Testimonies (p.426-467)

* Case 22.1. Slander between sufi pirs
** (1)             
** (2)            
** (3)             
** (4)          [] 
** (5)         []   
** (6)                
*** here   means 
** (7)             
** (8) ]          [ ]   [
** (9)            []    
***  means with a loud voice
** (10)              
** (11)                
*** Mufti is ruling in favor of the Sufi; others were slandering him, but his behavior was within the bounds of the tariqa.  Specifies a punishment for the slanderers.  Likely that this refers to the silent / loud zikr debate within the Naqshbandis.  This guy is performing Zikr silently .

!!!  (p. 88-92)
* Most of these concern accusations that a husband and wife had suckled from the same mother, which calls their marriage into question.

!!!  (p. 114)
* General notes
** Remember, slavery still existed in 19th century Transoxiana, so this section is still highly relevant.  Most of the cases are about cases related to shared ownership disputes over slaves and parenting a child with a slave.

!!!Kitab al-Waqf (p. 250)
* Many of the cases are about how mutawallis are (mis)using the waqf funds.  There are also a fair number about individuals waqf-ing state lands (254b.2, 255.1).

* Case 308.2.  Substitute qazi
** (1-2)       
** (3-4)        
** (5)       
** (6)           []  
*** //Modaressi//: ba-shariat: this is the first word of the next sentence, so In the view of the law.
** (7)        []  
*** //Modaressi//: bi-sharaitihi: if it meets other conditions for a valid judgment (i.e. despite the conflict of interest, there is no problem with the qadis deputy giving a judgment in a case to which his boss is party, provided the other conditions for a valid judgment are met).
*** //Modaressi//: The next word (your [ ]) should be h.aalii, and is the first word of the next sentence, so: Now that there is no obstacle.  //Cook// By the way, h.aalii would really (in Tajik or Afghan as opposed to Tehrani pronunciation) be h.aal-e with a long e, and Steingass has it in this form (409a) with the meaning "now".
** (8)    
*** //Modaressi & Cook//: He wonders if the mysterious phrase should be sawii al-wujuuh or bayyin al-wujuuh, and notes that it was common to write the final ha in an elevated position.  So now that there is no objection (to the deputy giving judgment in such a case), it is sound (for him to do so) from all points of view. sawi can have the sense "in good condition, perfect" (from Steingass, I think).

* Case 377b.3.  Rejecting a fatwa
** (1)              
** (2)         []

[[Afghan Chronicles Index]]

> Florian Schwarz, Sylloge Numorum Arabicorum Tbingen: Balh und die Landschaften am oberen Oxus XIV c Hurasan (Tbingen, Berlin: Ernst Wasmuth, 2002).

Badakhshan
* no. 444 (p. 64) - Coin from 1296 H.  Anonymous.
** Minted in Badakhshan:   
** Front bears the symbol of a flower between two swords.
* no. 445 (p. 64) - Coin from 1302 H.
** Front: 
** Back:  / 

Balkh
* Clear numismatic evidence of Balkh being ruled by Abd al-Aziz (p. 118), Subhanquli (p. 118), and Ubaydallah (p. 118).
* Then Sultan Sanjar, khan of Balkh from 1125-1130 H. (p. 118).
* Then Muhammad Sultan, khan of Balkh 1130-1132 (?) H. (p. 118).
* Then Arab Muhammad, khan of Balkh 1132-1145 (?) H. (p. 118).
* Then Chingiz Muhammad, chingizzid khan of Balkh 1145-1150 (?) H. (p. 119).
* Then Sayyid Abu l-Hasan, chingizzed khan of Balkh 1150 (?) (p. 119).
** Mentioned in [[Kim, lam r-yi Ndir]].
* Timur Shah Durrani (1187-1207 H.)
** Numismatic evidence for:
*** no. 1005 (p. 119) - Coin minted in 1197 H.  Front:  /  .  Rev:  
*** no. 1006 (p. 120) - Coin minted about 1200 H.
*** no. 1008 (p. 120) - Coin minted in 1200 H. Front:                  .  Rev:  /   / 
*** no. 1009 (p. 120) - Similar to first two, minted 1202 H.
*** no. 1011 (p. 120) - Similar, minted 1205 H.
*** no. 1012 (p. 120) - Similar, minted 1207 H.
* Then we have anonymous coins in Balkh in 1221 H. (nos. 1015, 1021, p. 120), 1233 H. (no. 1030, p. 120), 1234 H. (no. 1032, p. 120), 1267 H. (nos. 1036, 1038, p. 120-121), 1278 H. (no. 1042, p. 122), 1295 H. (no. 1047, p. 122).
** Another anonymous coin from 1258 (no. 1035, p. 120) bears the a similar flower surrounded by two swords emblem as Badakhshan coin no. 444.  Same true of no. 1039 (p. 122), minted in 1278 H.
*** The Timur Shah coins do not seem to have much in the way of symbols, mostly just Arabic script.

Tashqurgan
* no. 1060 (p. 122) - Minted in Tashqurgan sometime in the 13th century H.  Front: Flower.  Rev:  / 
* no. 1062 (p. 122) - Minted in 1300 H.  Front: Floral, Rev: 



[[Repository Index]]

> S. S. Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR, 11 vols. (Tashkent: Izd-vo Akademii nauk UzSSR, 1952).

According to "Research Trends" this book was superseded to some degree by [[the Iusupova volume|Iusupova and R. P. Dzhalilova, Sobranie vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii nauk Respubliki Uzbekistan. Istoriia]].  (But then again, a single volume could not possibly have superseded eleven...)  Also see [[Al-Biruni Card Catalog (Main Fond)]]
* __Vol. I__ (1952, Semenov): History, Biography, Acts - Letters & Correspondence, Travels and Memoirs, Stylistics, Natural Sciences, Medicine, Geography, Agriculture, Art
* __Vol. 2__ (1954, Semenov): Poetry, Artistic Prose, Folklore
* __Vol. 3__ (1955, Semenov): Philosophy, Sufism, Encyclopedias
* __Vol. 4__ (1957, Semenov): Hagiography, Koran, Hadith, Fikh, Scholastic Theology, Rituals and Prayers
* __Vol. 5__ (1960, Semenov): History, Biography, Acts & Epigraphs, Memoirs, Artistic Literature, Literary Theory, Philology, Natural Sciences, Secret Sciences (i.e. magic), Talismans, Medicine, Geography, Art, Philosophy, History of Religion, Sufism, Bibliography, Encyclopedia
* __Vol. 6__ 
* __Vol. 7__(1964, Urunbaev): History, Memoirs and Travel, Artistic Literature, Astronomy & Astrology, Cabalism and Dream Interpretation, Medicine, Cosmography, Folklore, History of Religion, Sufism
* __Vol. 8__ (1967, Semenov): History & Related Disciplines, Geography & Cosmography, Natural Sciences, Medicine, Philology & Artistic Literature, Poetry, Prose, & Folklore, Art (Sport, Calligraphy, Music), Philosophy, History of Religion, Encyclopedia & Bibliography
* __Vol. 9__ (1971, Urunbaev): History, Memoirs & Travel, Biography, Artistic Literature, Theory of Literature, "" (Letters?), Grammar, Natural Sciences, Secret Sciences, Medicine, Geography & Cosmography, Philosophy, History of Religion, Sufism, Rituals & Prayers, Letters and Correspondence
* __Vol. 10__ (1975, Voronovskii): History, Philology & Artistic Literature, Natural Sciences, Music & Sport, Philosophical Disciplines, History of Islam, Sufism, Encyclopeida
* __Vol. 11__ (1987, Urunbaev): History, Travel & Memoirs, Bibliography, Acts, Records, & Epistles, Philosophy, Natural Sciences, Medicine, Trade, Art, Philology, Theory of Literature, Artistic Literature, History of Religion, Secret Sciences, Sufism

Catalog Schema:
*I: 1-743
*II : 744-1878
*III: 1879-2800
*IV: 2801-3462
*V: 3463-4158
*VI: 4159-5000
*VII: 5001-5608
*VIII: 5609-6009


!!!Manghit Period

     Semenov 3, p. 136; 2101, 2979/XII
  
* Author lived in the first half of the 17th century, but the work apparently is extremely popular later on.
* "   ,     .       ,     ,     , ,  " (Semenov 3, p.136).
* Note: Semenov has this section mus-labled; it is marked section XI in the catalog.

__History__

         Semenov 5, p. 46; 3526, 2731/II
* A ... riddle about Rahim Khan's conquest of Kish in 1751; in verse.  Unclear what this is really about.

__Letters__

       vol. 1 p. 163; 386, 407 [[Link to notes|Mubraknmajt-i Amr Muaffar biq Mu al-Dn (al-Biruni 407)]]
* Letters from Muzafar to a regional court of Bukhara.
* 315 letters

  Semenov 1, p. 163; 2260/VI
* Entry is fairly cryptic; letters somehow related to Amir Muzafar calling for all of the local notables to assemble in Kagan outside Bukhara.  Later lithographed in Bukhara.  Somehow also related to melons.


__Travels and Memoirs__

  or   vol. 1 p. 173; 403, 2277
              
* Author was a high jurist of the Bukharan emirate (d. 1353/1935).
* Account details the authors experience starting in 1888, when Bukhara was hit by a devastating cholera epidemic.
* "In these memoirs there is a great deal of interesting information on Bukharan scholars, poets, and other figures..."

__Sufism__
  Semenov 3, p. 405; 2785, 37 VI
      
* Pseudonym: "Khumuli"; date: 1278/1861
* "                   " (Semenov 3, p. 405).
* Also see his [[autobiography in the Dushanbe collection|Tarjuma-i l-i Q Juma-Qul Khaml]]
* Another independent historian is omuli (b. 1776-77, d. after 1847) who served as the judge (qi) of Urgut near Samarqand. He left an untitled work which today is known as Tri-e omuli (von Kgelgen, 2002a, esp. pp. 157-67), but the work was not much cited during omulis lifetime. The text begins with a lengthy account of how he, the son of a herdsman, overcame many obstacles to obtain a comprehensive education in the esoteric and exoteric sciences (al-olum al-hira wal-olum al-bina). omulis intellectual autobiography is followed by the biographies of his teachers and of other Sufi sheikhs who belonged to the Naqbandiya-Mojaddediya branch of Dahbed near Samarqand. The work includes a section dedicated to the Mants, with many rare details about h Mord whom omuli greatly admired. But omuli is an exception among Transoxanian historians because he discusses how in 1743 Nder Shah Afr attempted to end the Shiite-Sunnite hostilities in Najaf. omuli idealistically judged Nder Shahs political move as an effort to implement an agreement, according to which Shiites and Sunnites would cease to consider each other infidels and which would thus end sectarian violence, warfare, and bloodshed (omuli, fols. 187a-188b). From: Kungelen, BUKHARA viii. Historiography of the Khanate, 1500-1920, Encyclopedia Iranica.

     Semenov 3, p. 401; 2782, 2933/II [[Link to notes|Mujaddid, Manqib al-Ahmadiyyah va Maqmt al-Sadiyyah (al-Biruni 2933/II)]]
  
* Date: 1300/1882
* This is a biography of an Indian Mujaddidi shaykh; also has some information on his khalifa, Qandahari.

      Semenov 3, p. 399; 2777 500/XXIII
    
* Date: 1298/1881; unique manuscript
* Author was part of thee separate orders: "    " "...   ,  ()  .     ,  "  "  ..." (Semenov 3, p. 400).

__Biographies__

       Semenov 5, p. 81; 3578, 1314/II
* Author:       
* "...     ,         (    ; , I, 90, No 230).          ,     , ,       ."
* In other words, this is an autobiography in verse, probably written by the author himself.
* Chaghatai
* Date 1319/1901.

      Semenov 5, p. 81; 3579, 2303
* Author:         
* Sadr Zia hated this guy and wrote a poetic tazkirat in rebuttal.  See [[adr , Takr-i Ashr]].

  /       Semenov 5, p. 82; 3581, 2252/I
* This is Hashmat's tazkirat; stars in 1495 but goes all the way to his time.


  vol. 5 p. 79; 3575, 3396/III 
 
* These are biographies of poets from the second half of the 19th century; however, judging by their titles, most of the poets were members of the Ulama as well.  E.g. Imama Malik Sahib Shaikh Naqshbandi.
* //Note: Do to a digitization error, I initially mistook [[Mun al-Fuqur, Rislah-i Mull Zdah, 1219]] vol. 5 p. 309; 3575, 3396/I for this manuscript//

      vol. 1, p. 138; 332, 59/III
       - 
* A collection of biographies of the latest Central Asian Tajik poets and exemplars of their works.
* Copied many times.
* Dushanbe also has a copy of which I obtained a full scan; notes: [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

  vol. 1, p. 140; 341, 2513/II
       
* Note: pulled this work; the "autobiography" of the article is ornate to the point of being useless.  The biographical entries all concern the poetry of various rulers.
* "       , ,      .    - __ __ (. 242- .)" (Semenov 1, 140).
* The author was a potential claimant for the throne, and hence spent his days under house arrest.
* Also see this author's biography of Bukharan poets:   Semenov 1, p. 141; 343, 2728/II; the second volume is #61.  [[ashmat, Takirat al-Shuar (al-Biruni 2728, 61)]]
**    (Vol. 7, 1987) on this tazkirat: 2 volumes, the first about 85 poets, the second about 88; included lots of information about poets from Afghanistan and Iran as well (p. 229).
*** //Note// that Hashmat used [[Vazih|Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]] as a source for some of his data:       . 19        ,    (.   )      " (p. 229).  Though he also added in scholars who lived after the publication of Vazih.
** This author had a second go at this work under the same title and under # 2729 in the collection.

       vol. 1, p. 141; 346, 63
        
* Another poet biography collection - 1904.

     vol. 1, p. 141; 347, 64

      Semenov 9, p. 68; 6084, 849
         
* This collection of biographies was written by one of the very last court poets of Bukhara.

         Semenov 9, p. 71; 6090, 5332/III
         
* Author (the famous Sadr-i Ziya) lived 1865-1932.
* Could be an autobiography; author served as a qazi for many years all around Bukhara.

__Encyclopedias__

Semenov 5, p. 420; 4147, 262 [[Link to notes|Vai, Majmua (personal notebook) (al-Biruni 262)]]
* Vazih's notebook; a collection of all kinds of thoughts - India, madrasas, poets, magian dictionary.

Semenov 5, p. 421; 4149, 299/IV
* Collection of random stuff

__Akhlaq__

Two works on women and treatment of women:   Semenov 3, p. 116; 2054, 3075/II
* Author unknown; quotes from the Hadith a great deal to illustrate why women should be subservient to men.
* Also see: 2055, 3075/IV

(No title) Semenov 3, p. 116; 2056, 368/XV
* Beginning of the 19th century.
* Moral tale about the Sasanids: "...     ,    ,      -..." (Semenov 3, 116).

  Semenov 3, p. 117; 2057, 2478/V
* Author unknown; transcribed 1253/1837.
* "... 8)    ,  ",    "" (Semenov 3, 117).
** //Perhaps the author elaborates on why that is?//

*      Semenov 3, p. 117; 2058, 1969/II
** Author unknown; this is a fragment.  Transcription date: 1282/1865.
** //possible that this might shed some light on informal poetic gatherings?//

  Semenov 3, p. 117; 2059, 412/I
     
* "  ,                 (1277/1860-1303/1885)    " (Semenov 3, 118).

  Semenov 3, p. 118; 2095
    
* Author also went by Ahmad0i Kalla, and was a well known intellectual in Bukhara - died 1314/1896-1897.
* Work is critical of the prevailing religious and moral conditions in the Khanate.
* Bertels wrote about this: Rukopisi proizvedenii Akhmada Kalle, Trudy Tadzhikskoi bazy Akademii Nauk SSR, t. III, p. 13-21, 1936.

__Fiqh__

    Semenov 4, p. 309; 3244, 2571/III
* Author unknown.  Mostly excerpts from other Arabic and Persian texts, though also includes commentary.
* Transcribed 1238 (1822f) in Bukhara.

    Semenov 4, p. 310; 3246, 254/V
* Three sections from an unknown work: one on various legal disputes of the day, one with anecdotes about prominent jurists, and one about their dates of death.
* References the work      , though its relationship to this work is unclear.
* Copied in 1840.
* //Basically, the question here is whether this is relevant to contemporary events in the 18th / 19th centuries.//

__Prayer and Ritual__

   Semenov 4, p. 421; 3435, 54/III
* Looks like it's just a single page khutba written by Khwaja Bukhari and transcribed by the son of Amir Muzaffar.


!!!Shibanid Period

    vol. 1 p. 60; 137, 1414
Fazlulla b. Ruzbekhan, aka Khoja Maulana Isfahani (d. 1518)
* Details the visit of an Iranian to the Shibanid court. Rare; one other copy in Istanbul.
* Details religious and ethical disputes prevalent in the day.

[[Chronicles Index]]
[[Timeline of Chronicles]]

> Shams Bukharayi, Tarikh-I Bukhara, Khuqand va Kashghar, ed. Muhammad Akbar Ashiq (Tehran: Ayinah-i Miras, 1998).

From von [[Kgelgen, BUKHARA viii. Historiography of the Khanate, 1500-1920|http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bukhara-viii]]
"The Bayn-e ba-i awdet-e Bor wa qand wa Kar is the published excerpt of a Mant chronicle that Mirz ams Bori (b. 1804, d. after 1860) wrote at the request of the Russian Orientalist Vasili V. Grigorev (1816-81). Mirz ams Bori had served several Mant rulers, and was therefore well acquainted with the Mant court and its internal conflicts over power. The account begins with Nder Shah Afrs campaign against Bukhara and Khiva in 1740, but the published excerpt starts with the detailed description of Amir aydars accession to the throne in 1800. Although Mirz ams Bori omits many political events, his chronicle provides some interesting glimpses of the ruling elites of Kar and Yrkand and of the power struggle among the Mants, when he condemns, for example, Amir Nar-Allhs brutality."

!!!                       
* Haydar received diplomatic recognition from all surrounding monarchs (69):        .          -    -                      
* Mother descended from Ghengis Khan (69):                        
* Islamic markers of sovereignty (69):                    
* Fearing disloyalty, Haydar recalls governors of Marv and Samarqand. Samarqand governor flees to Shahrisabz (70).
** The folks in Marv, however, liked their ruler and refused to turn him over.  They sent a letter to Haydar:


[[Repository Index]]

> Olimpiada Pavlovna Shcheglova, Katalog litografirovannykh knig na persidskom iazyk v sobranii leningradskogo otdeleniia AN SSSR, 2 vols. (Moscow: Glavnaia redaktsiia vostochnoi literatury, 1975).

Problem: The catalog only lists where a publication was produced, not where it was acquired.  Hence it is difficult to see whether Turkestanis were using lithographs produced in India before the late 19th century.  (Lithographs became widespread in India in the 1830s, but not in Central Asia until the 1880s).

!!!Introduction
* Lithograph production spread to Central Asia in the last third of the nineteenth century and the first decade of the twentieth (8).
* Everything that had previously been in manuscript form was eligible to be lithographed: "     , , ,   ,      ,     ..." (8).
* History of the collection: Starting in 1904, Russian orientalists began picking up lithographs in Europe and the Middle East.  Then, (important): " 1912 . ..                     .   ,   ,   ,    ,    1916 ." (11).
* Figures: Current collection is 1856 in number (1257 separate titles) (13).
** 700 from India; 616 from Iran; 146 from Central Asia

!!!Selections
  , " .. " 1310/1892.  Fiqh.  p. 287, #650; code:   7
*    . ' 
* Collection of instructions for carrying out Islamic rituals properly.
* Interesting because there are lots of copies, most coming from Tashkent, but also from:
** , "-. ", 1324/1906-07;   .
** , ". . ", 1329/1911.
** , ". ", 1335/1916-17;    - .  Note that this is the only lithograph from Kokand in the Petersburg collection.

    ,     .    1327/1909.  Sufism.  p. 228, #228; code:  405
* This is a lithograph of the treatise of the founder of the Naqshbandis.

[[Card Catologue - Alisher Navoi Rare Books Collection]]

. 
:    ,  1: 
: . ". - . ", 1910
*  9103
* 324 pages


 (p. 5)
* Companion volume to "The Sarts": " , ""      ,      ""."
* Used the literature available in Tashkent to write the book.
* Laments the lack of information on the mountain Tajiks: "               ."


7.    (p. 81-)
* On the language of the Tajiks - connecting them to ancient Avestan language: " .     .     ,  , - -   ,     -  ..." (88).
* Mentions Ossetians, Kurds, Afghans / Pushtuns, Baluchi, as all belonging to this older Iranian "zend" group (88).
* Author discusses the different regional dialects, asserting that Khujand is the closest to classical Persian: "     ,    ,            ,     .  ,     ( )              .     ,   ,       ,      ,  " (88).
* Locals are still able to switch from their local dialects to the classical tongue: "  ,          ,   ,     ,      " (88)
* On Yaghnobi (and referring to language as "Tajik" rather than Persian): "  ,    -  ; , ,       ;   ,       ,    ,    - ...    ,                .           .      :        ,             ..."  (90).

> Sirj al-Dn Bukhr, Tufah-i Ahl-i Bukhr

[[Iusupova|Iusupova and R. P. Dzhalilova, Sobranie vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii nauk Respubliki Uzbekistan. Istoriia]]    p. 379, 907; 2142, 190 l.

Author:       

General Notes
* The author's Farsi is very Iranian; he uses words like  and even .  He also uses the word , which I think might be a Constitutionalist Iranian word for capitalist.


Education and Early Background
* Introduction (1b):                                                                 []                      []             
* Early years and education, learning Russian (2):                                   []                []                                                   []

Khoqand and the Ferghana Valley
* (cont.) Business trip to Ferghana to buy silk (2b):                                                                                                                  
* Speaks glowingly about the prosperity of the Ferghana valley (3):        []                               []                        []         
* Rapid advancements in trade also thanks to Russia (3):                                                            
* Silk exchanged for Russian goods; Jews in control of the trade of Russian goods (3b):                                                    []                  []                  
* (cont.) Describing Farghana factories (3b):      ()                                    
**    = //silk or cotton loom?//
* (cont.) Locals don't understand the new ways of business; author laments the prosperity Turkestanis could potentially achieve (3b):                                                       ...                               
* Describing the city of Khoqand (3b-4):   [= ]                               
* Russians installed electric street lighting and other wondrous improvements (4):        ...                                                               
* Remarks on Khujand, but has never traveled there (4):              

Other cities in Turkestan
* Describes tombs, architecture, and weather of Samarkand (4-4b).
* A railroad connects Khoqand to Margilan, a city specializing in silk (4b):                  [ ]                                  ...         
* Russians built their own city outside of Margilan (4b):                               
* Andijan - so prosperous that many of the local inhabitants even own cars (5):   []                                                        
** Earthquake in Andijan (5):                      
** On the 1898 Andijan rebellion (5b):                                                                                                                                                        []

** (cont.) Author had family in Tashkent, but no way of finding them (7):                                   



Primary Sources on Bukhara and Environs
Bactriana

T. K Beisembiev, Annotated Indices to the Kokand Chronicles (Tokyo: Research Institute for Languages and Cultures of Asia and Africa (ILCAA), 2008).

Golib Negmatovich [[Kurbanov, Pechati Bukharskogo khanstva XIX - nachala XX vekov]] (Moscow: Akademiia Nauk SSSR, Institut Vostokovedeniia, 1990).  This dissertation has a survey of documents in  and Bukharan Museum.

N. D. [[Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia]], 3rd ed. (Moscow: Izdatel'stvo "Nauka", 1975).

Ch. A. [[Stori and Iu. E. Bregel, Persidskaia literatura: Bio-bibliograficheskii obzor]], 3 vols. (Moscow: Glavnaia redaktsiia vostochnoi literatury, 1972).

[[Cholera Index]]
[[National Archives of India Index]]

> 1893. Foreign Department.  External - B. Prosgs. March 1893, Nos. 108/111. Srinagar Water Works Project.

Printed pamphlet: 
* Author: William Hill Climo, M.D., Brigade Surgeon Lieut. Colonel Army Medical Staff
* Title: Kashmir A New Focus of Endemic Cholera
* Publisher: Lahore: Civil and Military Gazette Press
* Year: 1892

Introduction
* Focus on water: "... I feel certain nothing will save Srinagar from periodic attacks of cholera until its sewage is collected and removed, that I ask for the water and sewage schemes to be taken together, and only the best for both to be adopted after careful investigation.  The above is written bearing in mind the fact that the city of Jummo has been practically free from cholera this year, while all around the disease has been prevalent.  That this immunity is due to its water-supply I have no doubt" (2).
* "4. There has been no epidemic of cholera whose history I am acquainted with, which brings out more strongly the truth that cholera is begotten of dirt, and is conveyed by dirty people than this Kashmir epidemic of 1892.  The State of Kashmir itself is only hinted at in these papers.  It is too utterly repulsive and loathsome to describe.  This being so, it can be easily understood what an easy road cholera finds to travel back to India..." (2).

Kashmir a new focus of Endemic Cholera
* The theory: "... in a series of letters which appeared in the //Pioneer// in the early part of 1889 under the signature of 'Medicus,' I advanced, //inter alia//, the following proposition: - First, that cholera prevailed in countries where there was an entire absence of sanitation, the habits of the people being so barbarous or so primitive that the air they breathe, the food they eat, and the water they drink are always polluted with sewage, and second, that enteric fever occurred in more civilized communities where some attempt had been made to remove and dispose of this sewage, but which was done so imperfectly, that the excreta in under-ground drains or sewers, or buried in bulk in the soil, underwent fermentation with its complement bacterial development. Kashmir was the instance I had in view, as illustrating my first proposition, subsequent investigation not only confirmed those views, but advanced them to more precise limits" (3).
* Origins in India: "The history of the present epidemic, it is believed, will bring out the fact that the disease was imported from India, and which originating at Hurdwar passed over Northern India in the early part of the hot season.  As usual the disease travelled in a north-westerly direction ultimately finding its way to Srinigar in the beginning of May, its rate of progress being in direct proportion to the ordinary means of locomotion, that is tosay, most rapidly in the plains of India where railways lend themselves to its more rapid diffusion" (3-4).
* Conclusions: "The conclusions then I have come to are that, to prevent cholera becoming endemic in Kashmir, there are three essentials: - The first is a pure water-supply to be given to Srinagar; the second is the construction of sewage works, and, bearing in mind the economic conditions of the people, the remodelling of the city, until opportunity offers, should be limited to effect this in the first instance; and the third is the prevention of the pollution of the Jhelum river, which exists to an extent beyond description" (8).


[[National Archives of India Index]]
[[Cholera Index]]

> 1893 Foreign Department. Secret F. Pros. January 1893, No. 296. Notes en route from Srinagar to St. Petersburgh by Captain H. Picot.

"Received from the Director of Military Intelligence, Intelligence Division, War Office, London, S.W., by Sir H.M. Durand, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Foreign Department, Calcutta."

Opening (p. 1): "Towards the end of April 1892, I received a telegram from Prince N. Galitzin in Srinagar, saying he was obliged to start for Ladakh at once, owing to the scarcities of supplies in the Kashmir Valley.  As I had arranged to travel with him overland, back to Russia, I hastened to Srinagar, and thence to Leh, where I joined him."

Travel party (p. 1): "Our caravan consisted of Galitzin and myself, five Russian attendants, and 30 followers, with 70 ponies, not to speak of four monkeys, a mangoose, and six dogs, belonging to Galitzin."

Russian vs. British residencies in Kashgar (p. 3): "What struck one forcibly, on arrival, was the difference in ceremonial maintained by the respective agencies of England and Russia.  Petroffsky has a Secretary, an Assistant Secretary in the person of an officer, and an escort of fifty Cossacks, under a sous-officier.  His house is spacious, surrounded by walls, and approached through an imposing gateway, emblazoned with the Russian arms.  He never moves abroad without an escort, and on official occasions is proceeded by a banner.  On the other hand, our agent, having no official residence, and no guard of like nature, can make no impression on the minds of the Orientals.  Both Galitzin and Petroffsky asked whether Macartney held any accredited position.  There may be reasons for thus effacing ourselves in Kashgar, but my impression is, that an English Consul, equalling the Russian in attributes of power, would do much to increase our credit on the frontier.  Petroffsky mentioned that the relationship between himself and our agent was much strained.  This strain, Mr. Hendrikse, a Jesuit father and a friend of Macartney's, told me, commenced with the opening of Macartney's post by Petroffsky.  Galitzin, on the other hand, told me, the strain commenced by Macartney sending Petroffsky a copy of //Punch//, containing a caricature of the Emperor of Russia."

Cholera (p. 4): "The fear of quarantine on the Caspian, where cholera was raging, made me decide upon the Siberian route, in the company of Cherboff... At Semipalatinsk and on the river we found cholera in a bad form.  Bodies of Kirghiz were being buried only 6 inches below the ground, so that another outbreak is considered probable next spring."

Closing line (p. 4): "No one, I think, can traverse Siberia and Russia, without feeling the giant powers lying concealed within.  Both countries are swayed by a resistless [sic.] tide of deep religious conviction."
[[RGIA Index]]

//Note: see also data relayed in Kiriak Efimovich [[Bendrikov, Ocherki po istorii narodnogo obrazovaniia v Turkestane, 1865-1924|file:///C:/Users/James/Documents/Academics/Academic%20Notes%20%28TiddlyWiki%29/Imperial%20Russia.html]] gody (Moscow: Izd-vo Akademii pedagog. nauk RSFSR, 1960).//

** Students: 680

** female students: 196
