* Housholds : 11982
* Individuals: 35518
* Neighborhoods : 5918

Religion Statistics  1906 (p. 22)
* : 617 in 1905, 476 in 1906
** Note that broken down by gender there are fewer men but more women (women 118 - 131, men 499 - 345)
* Muslims: 17508 in 1905, 18099 in 1906
* Jews: 106 in 1905, 116 in 1906

Nationality (p. 26) is interesting; it lists 617 Russians (the exact same number as the Orthodox); for Uzbeks, Kirgiz, Sarts, and Tajiks, they are all lumped together without differentiation.  It does differentiate between Russian Jews (8) and local ones (106).  There are also 12 Armenians and an Iranian.

List of Ishans active in the city of Khujand (name, order, murids) (p. 80). There are 8 of them divided between the  and  orders.
* The Khufiya boast 220 murids total, the Chakhriya 230 (calculations mine).








!!Manghit Court Histories

p. 1152, #1009: Muhammad Sharif b. Muhamamd Naqi
Taj at-tavarikh
RIFIAS: T 60; Tashkent Biruni: No. 2092 (SVR I, 214)
* History of the Astrakhanids and Manghits through Haydar.
* This source is discussed in [[Bregel, The Administration of Bukhara Under the Manghits|file:///C:/Users/James/Documents/Academics/Princeton/Fall%202009/Gross%20-%20Central%20Asia/Gross%20-%20Pre-Colonial%20Central%20Asia.html]]

p. 1155, #1015: Mir 'Abd al-Karim "Nadim"
Afghan va Kabul va Khivaq va Khoqand 
* Valuable and famous history of Central Asia from 1747-1818.
* Author traveled as a consul to Russia, Afghanistan, Kashmir, Constantinople.
* Has been translated both into French and Russian: Materialy po istorii turkmen i Turkmenii, vol. 2, ed. Struve.
* Dushanbe also has or had a copy.

p. 1163, #1020: Muhammad Husain "Miri" b. Shah-Murad Ma'sum
Makhazin al-taqva fi tarikh Bukhara
RIFIAS: T38; Tashkent Biruni: No. 2773 (SVR VIII, 5835)
* Author was the sun of Shah-Murad (1785-1800) with an Ishan from Kulab; ruled Shahrisabz.
* Written in 1830.
* Autobiographical; goes into detail about the rule of Amir Haidar (1800-1826).
* Description in Bartold, Zaniatiia v Turkestanskikh bibliotekakh...: 230-234 = Bartold, Sochineniia, v. VIII.

p. 1166, #1024: Mirza Shams, or Mirza Iusufov, Bukhari
RIFIAS: Missing; Also available at Harvard
* O nekotorykh sobytiiakh v Bukhare, Khokande i Kashgare.  Zapiski Mirzy-Shemsa Bukhari, Ed. Trans. V. V. Grigor'ev.
* Mirza's father, Mirza Yusuf, served in the chancellery under Amir Haidar (1800-1826) and so was always close to the court.
* This source covers the period from Nadir Shah's attack (1740) up to Amir Nasrallah (1827-1860).

p. 1168, #1027: Mir Salman (Sulayman) Khwaja Samarqandi
Tafsil va bayan-i dawlat-i jama'at-i Manghit az zaman-i Rahim Khan
RIFIAS: SPb 33; Petersburg Orientalist: C667 XIII 161a-178b 738dd
* Author was a mudarris in Samarqand in the Ulug-beg Madrassa during the reign of Amir Haidar (1800-1826) and then in the Tila-Kari madrassa under Amir Nasrallah (1827-1860) and Amir Muzaffar al-Din (1860-1885).
* A short history of the Manghits; there is a more detailed description in [[Miklukho-Maklai, Opisanie persidskikh i tadzhikskikh rukopisei Instituta vostokevedeniia]], p. 319 #454.
** The author does have stuff in this about him and his family (177b-178b).

p. 1168, #1029: Ahmad Danish (transliterate full name)
Risala
* Imam critical of Muzaffar al-Din's reform; did a stint in the St. Petersburg embassy.
* Translated in full into Russian: Traktat Akhmada Donisha "Istoriia Mangitskoi dinastii"
** Available at 9 libraries; may be possible to get via loan.
* Another of his works: A. Mirzoev, Pervaia redaktsiia "Navodir-ul-vakoe" i vremia ee sostavleniia in Sbornik statei po istorii i filologii narodov Srednei Azii; also may be possible to get on loan.


/* horizontal main menu */

#displayArea { margin: 1em 15.5em 0em 1em; } /* use the full horizontal width */

#topMenu { background: [[ColorPalette::PrimaryMid]]; color: [[ColorPalette::PrimaryPale]]; padding: 0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.5em; border-bottom: 2px solid #000000; }

#topMenu br { display: none; }

#topMenu .button, #topMenu .tiddlyLink, #topMenu a { margin-left: 0.25em; margin-right: 0.25em; padding-left: 0.5em; padding-right: 0.5em; color: [[ColorPalette::PrimaryPale]]; font-size: 1.15em; }

#topMenu .button:hover, #topMenu .tiddlyLink:hover { background: [[ColorPalette::PrimaryDark]]; }

/***
|Name|TagCloudPlugin|
|Source|http://www.TiddlyTools.com/#TagCloudPlugin|
|Version|1.2.0|
|Author|Eric Shulman|
|Original Author|Clint Checketts|
|License|unknown|
|~CoreVersion|2.1|
|Type|plugin|
|Requires||
|Overrides||
|Description|present a 'cloud' of tags using proportional font display|
!Usage
<<<
{{{<<tagCloud>>}}}
> show all tags in the document
{{{<<tagCloud tag tag tag...>>}}}
> show all tags except those listed as parameters
{{{<<tagCloud =tagvalue>>}}}
> show only tags that are themselves tagged with the indicated tag value (i.e., ~TagglyTagging usage)
<<<
!Examples
<<<
{{{<<tagCloud>>}}}
<<tagCloud>>
----
{{{<<tagCloud =package>>}}}
<<tagCloud =package>>
<<<
!Revisions
<<<
2008.09.05 [1.2.0] ELS: added '=tagname' parameter to include only tags that are themselves tagged with the specified value (i.e., ~TagglyTagging usage)
2008.07.03 [1.1.0] ELS: added 'segments' property to macro object.  Extensive code cleanup
<<<
!Code
***/
//{{{
version.extensions.TagCloudPlugin= {major: 1, minor: 2 , revision: 0, date: new Date(2008,9,5)};
//Created by Clint Checketts, contributions by Jonny Leroy and Eric Shulman

config.shadowTiddlers.TagCloud="<<tagCloud>>";

setStylesheet("\
	.tagCloud span{height: 3.5em;margin: 3px;}\
	.tagCloud1{font-size: 80%;}\
	.tagCloud2{font-size: 100%;}\
	.tagCloud3{font-size: 120%;}\
	.tagCloud4{font-size: 150%;}\
	.tagCloud5{font-size: 180%;}\
	.tagCloud6{font-size: 200%;}\
	",
	"tagCloudsStyles");

config.macros.tagCloud = {
	noTags: "No tag cloud created because there are no tags.",
	tooltip: "%1 tiddlers tagged with '%0'",
	segments: 5,
	handler: function(place,macroName,params) {

		var tags=store.getTags();

		if (params.length) {
			if (params[0].substr(0,1)=="=") {
				// include only specifically tagged tags
				var tagged=store.getTaggedTiddlers(params[0].substr(1));
				for (var t=0; t<tagged.length; t++)
					tagged[t]=tagged[t].title;
				for (var t=0; t<tags.length; t++)
					if (!tagged.contains(tags[t][0])) tags[t][0]="";
			} else {
				// include all tags except those listed as params
				for (var t=0; t<tags.length; t++)
					if (params.contains(tags[t][0])) tags[t][0]="";
			}
		}

		// get maximum number of tags to calculate tagCloud segment sizes
		var mostTags=0;
		for (var t=0; t<tags.length; t++) if (tags[t][0].length > 0)
			if (tags[t][1]>mostTags) mostTags=tags[t][1];
		var tagSegment=mostTags/config.macros.tagCloud.segments;

		// output
		var tagCloudWrapper = createTiddlyElement(place,"div",null,"tagCloud",null);
		if(!tags.length)
			createTiddlyElement(tagCloudWrapper,"span",null,null,this.noTags);
		else for (var t=0; t<tags.length; t++) if (tags[t][0].length > 0){
			tagCloudWrapper.appendChild(document.createTextNode(" "));
			var theTag = createTiddlyButton(tagCloudWrapper,
				tags[t][0],this.tooltip.format(tags[t]),onClickTag,
				"tagCloudtag tagCloud" + (Math.round(tags[t][1]/tagSegment)+1));
			theTag.setAttribute("tag",tags[t][0]);
		}
	}
};
//}}}
[[Chronicles Index]]

> Abd al-Rahman Dawlat Tali, Istoriia Abulfeiz-khana, trans. A. A. Semenov, Biblioteka redkikh knig Khaidarbeka (Tashkent: Institut istorii narodov Srednei Azii imeni Makhpirat, 2009).

* Ubaydallah had planned a visit to Balkh the spring before his death, but his amirs refused (16).
* Adil Ataliq Ming was the ruler of Balkh at that time (17).

!!!   (p. 58)
* Conquest of Balkh in 17th century from Kunduz (59).
* Recounting an incredible event from 1131/1719, such that (60): " ,        ,     ,  ,    ,    ."

* Shahrisabz raids (62): "     ,  ,  ,   ,   ,   ,     , ,   .  (),   ,                ."
** Ibrahim Atalik told Abu al-Fayz he was dealing with his son's raid, but in fact did nothing (62).  //check//
** Ismail and Ibrahim plotted to get his band into the arg itself (presumably to kill or capture the khan) (62-64).
** Abu al-Fayz's mahram deliberates and begins to doubt whether it can take the Kenagis at its gates (p. 64), when one brave soul (Bargin Bey) rallies them (65): " ,      ,  , ,   ,  ,    () ,            (   ) ?"
** Ibrahim Atalik tries to trick them into opening the Arg door for him so that the rebels can slip in as well, but is foiled (65).


[[Chronicles Index]]

Dynastic list from [[Wikipedia|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mirs_of_Badakhshan]]:
* Mir Yar Beg Sahibzada (16??-1699), was appointed Mir of Badakhshan by Subhan Kuli Khan of Kunduz. Previously in 1651, Sahibzada, who was originally from Samarkand, was invited by the local tribes of Yaftal to become the local mir. When Sahibzada failed to pay the required tribute to Subhan Kuli Khan, Khan sent Mahmud Bi Atalik, chief of Balkh and Bokhara, against Mir Beg. Mir Beg, buckling under pressure, agreed to pay tribute for two years.The Mir had ten sons when he was died in 1699. He divided the province of Badakhshan amongst his nine sons because his eldest son Arab was settled in Chitral.
* Mir Yar Beg (18??), was the Mir of Badakhshan in the early 19th century until he was defeated by the khan of Kunduz, Mir Muhammad Murad Beg.
* Mir Shah(1844-1864).( ) His brother was Mir Yusuf 'Ali, the Mir of Rustaq.
* Mir Jahandar Shah (1864-1869). ( ) Jahandar Shah came to power through his close relations with Muhammad Afzal Khan, who was Governor of Afghan Turkestan from 1852-1864. At one point Jahandar Shah raised forced in Badakhshan and briefly took control of Kunduz in 1866-67. He was ousted from power in 1869 by Sardar Faiz Muhammad Khan, an ally of Sher Ali Khan, the Amir of Afghanistan. Faiz Muhammad Khan appointed Jahandar Shah's nephew, Mizrab Shah, in power.
* Mir Mizrab Shah (1869). He was installed in power by Faiz Muhammad Khan, but his reign lasted less than a year. He was the nephew of Jahandar Shah.
* Mir Mahmud Shah (1869-1873). Mahamad Shah was a paternal cousin of Mizrab Shah. He established his authority in Badakhshan with the aid of Amir Sher Ali Khan. He was the last mir to ruler over Badakhshan. In 1873 Mahmud Shah was ousted from power by the governor of Afghan Turkestan, Naib Muhammad Alam Khan. Alam Khan appointed Hafizullah Khan as governor of Badakhshan.

> Fal Al-Bek Surkhafsr and Sang-Muhammad, Tarkh-i&nbsp; Badakhshn, Istoriia Badakhshana, ed. A.N. Boldyrev (Leningrad: Izd. Leningradskogo Universiteta, 1959).

Index:
* Kunduz: 13b, 14a, 15b, 16ab, 39b, 54b, 59a, 60a, 61a, 63ab, 64b, 64a, [83b], 88a, 91b, 93ab, 94ab, 95a, 96b, 99b, 108b	
* Allah Berdi: 69b
* Nabat Khan: 15b-25a, 70a
* Muhammad Murad Beg: 87-88, 91-93 

!!!Yari Bek Khan
* Opening - Badakhshan originally controlled by Qataghan clan of Uzbeks until they were thrown out by a Badakhshi Alid from Dahbid in 1067/1656f (4):                                                                                                     
* Mir Yar Bek Khan (2b):    
** From 2b - he was a just, shrewd ruler, etc.
* Something bad happens (//revisit//), Yar Bek gets upset and goes to India (3b).
* Qataghan (under Mahmud Bey) march on Badakhshan already only after a few years of Yar Bek's reign (3b).
* Yar Bek gets invited back, retakes Badakhshan (5).
* Bukharan approval still important for this shah of Badakhshan - obtains right to independent rule from Subhan Quli (5-5b):                                                                 
* From 6a there are details on interactions with the Sufis of Samarqand.
* Yari Bek Khan ruled 50 years, had many sons (more than listed here) (7):                                  
* Yari Bek died in 1118 h. (7b).

!!!Sulayman Bek, the eldest son, takes over in 1118/1706f
* Sulayman Bek, the oldest, takes over (8).
* Mahmud Bey Qataghan (characterized as a ) is still around at this point and musters an army upon hearing of Yari Bek's death (8b).
* Author reports vicious fighting followed by a Yarid victory (9b-10).
* Sulayman Bek died in 1125/1713f; civil war erupts upon his death (11).

!!!Early 18th Century
* Civil war prevailed until the Qataghan invaded again, taking Kunduz and subjugating Badakhshan (?) (13b):                        []               
* Qataghan rule Badakhshan for 5 years, until they are overthrown by a Timurid, who then kills the Yarid ruler (14):                                                       
** //recall that Yusuf Ali Khan is the second-born son of Mir Yar Bek//
* Zia al-Din wounded by a spear in battle, surrenders Fayzabad (15b).
* After the Qataghan ruler is driven from Fayzabad, he seeks help from the Qataghan in Kunduz to retake it (15b):                                              
** At this time Yusuf Bey Qataghan is characterized as the amir of Kunduz (16):    
* Seems that Zia al-Din then got Qalmaq help and drove the Qataghan back to Kunduz (16b):                                    
* (cont.) Thus began the 18 year rule of independent Badakhshan ruler Zia al-Din, the sixth son of Yari Bek (16b):          
* (strange events surrounding the burning of a madrasa) (14b)
* Mirza Nabat, son of Zia al-Din, brings to an end the rule of the sons of Yari Bek in 1147/1735f (17b):                            
* Mirza Nabat becomes Hakim of Fayzabad (18).
* Sulayman bin Shah Sulayman reaches some kind of accord with Mirza Nabat, is installed in Fayzabad (18).
* Mirza Nabat ends up fighting (and defeating) Mirza Padshah, another contender for the thrown, while Sulayman flees (19b).
* Mirza Padshah gets Qalmaq help, Mirza Nabat pays them off, they form their own kingdom (?) (20).  Sends his son as a hostage, who gets sick and dies (20b).
* Some notes on madrasas and ulama in the realm (21b).
** Including a Qazi al-Quza (22b):                                                                                   
* Rules for 12 years (23b).  Died in 1161/1748f (24):                    
** //no mention of Nadir Shah//


Sultan-Shah I (1747f-1765f)

Muhammad-Shah (1792-1821)

!!!Last years before incorporation into Afghanistan / Bukhara - second half of 19th century
* Muhammad Murad Beg (whom [[British reports|Report on Koondooz (NAI FD, 29 July 1859)]] characterize as the greatest of the Qataghan Kunduz rulers) marches on Badakhshan rules it from 1272-1277 / 1855-1860 (87-87b):                                                                         
* In 1860 Mir Kalan kicks out the Qataghan and rules from 1277-1283; then ruled by Mir Muhammad Shah until 1285 (88).
* In 1285 Muhammad Murad Beg retakes Badakhshan, imprisons Sulayman Shah and all his brothers in Kunduz, pillaging Badakhshan (88).
** Proceeded to rule Badakhshan from 1285 - 1300 (88b).
* Eventually Murad Beg installs Muhamd Yarbeg Khan as governor of Fayzabad (92):              

[[Chronicles Index]]

On the fall of Baljuvan to Bukhara in 1888, see also RGVIA 483-1-132, ll. 54-68 (serial 167).

SVR vol. 1 232 p. 91, 2663/III
*      ,       ,     1244/1828-1287/1870 .   - 1300/1883 . 22 .

Copied in full:

* In 1243 Katta Khan took over from his father as hakim of Baljuvan, the fortress of which was located above the old city at that time (37b):       []                                  
* Succeeded by son Mizrab Khan, who builds a bridge to facilitate trade (37b):                            []                                                   [   = ]       [ ]                    []        [[          
* Kulab apparently ruled by his brother (37b-38):                                                     
* Mizrab succeeded by Qamchan (?) Khan, his brother, who was succeeded Sara Khan ruled; Sara Khan went to Bukhara for year, during which time his brother Hamrah Khan ruled and minted coins in his own name (38):          []                []                                 
* Sara Khan was awarded the post of ataliq, but apparently fell out with Bukhara and forced to flee to Afghanistan when Bukhara marched on him.  After that, other governors (38):                     [=]                             
* (meaning?) (38):   []                 [ \  \ ]                     []                          
* Written in Sha'ban 1335 (38):       




[[Kazan Index]]

> Abdallh bin Muhammad rif al-Mudh, Trkh-i Mudhyya (Trkh-i Bukhr wa-Tarjumat al-Ulam) (Orenburg, 1908).

* Title:     
* Edited by:                    
** One of the Siberian Bukharan Khojas, most likely
* 1908, Orenburg 
* Frank cites this work as: 'Abdullah b.Muhammad-'Arif al-Mu'azi, Tarikh-i Mu'aziya,(Orenburg,1908).

Madrasas of Bukhara
* Opening line praising Bukhara as a bastion of the Ulama (2):                 
* Starts with a description of Qutayba's conquest of Central Asia, describing some of the physical geography (2).
* Mentions the death of       (p. 3).
* Listing the various imam-khatibs of the masjid-i kalan:
** Niazquli gave the khutba until he died in 1237 (3):              1237          
** After that it was Khalifa Ubaydallah bin Balta al-Qarakuli, who died in 1250:          1250  
** After that Mian Malik was Khatib at the time when the author was in Bukhara (3):           
*** At the time of his death in 1109 (1209?), he was buried to one side of a khanaqah (3):  1109       
** Now the Khatib is Fayz al-Rahman al-Hafiz al-Astrali (3):       [] 
* In    there are 390 masjids and 190 madrasas.

Great Teachers of Bukhara     (p. 17)
* On Ata Allah (17):              1290 
** (cont.) Ata Allah's publication (17):                 
** (cont.) Ata Allah's children (17):              
** (cont.) Ata Allah's students (17):                                          
*** //note that Abd al-Hay Samarqandi is listed here as on eof Ata Allah's students//.
** (cont.) Hadi Khwajah and Ata Allah's burial place becomes a tomb in its own right (17):                      
* (cont.) Hadi Khwajah's silsila of knowledge (17-18):                            .                                .                   996                                                   
** Eventually traces his pedigree all the way back to the Prophet.  Only three generations back traces his silsila to a group of Shirazi scholars.  //were they sunni or shia?//

* Title written in pencil by same hand as pagination:

* "    ,         ,  - -, - -, - -,  ."
* Author also wrote: [[ashmat, Takirat al-Shuar (al-Biruni 2728, 61)]]; [[Autobiography of Muhammad Sidiq Hashmat (al-Biruni 2663/V)]]
* Author's autobiography begins on p. 118.

* Shahrisabz (89b):                                  []      ...                       []

* Khwarazm was always raiding Bukhara - particularly when Bukhara was fighting with Shahrisabz and the defenses were left wide open (96b):                                                             
** Nasrallah goes on a victorious war to punish the Khorezmians in 1260

[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Tarjuma-i l-i Q Juma-Qul Khaml
      p. 188; 177, 294
        

Q Juma-Qul al-Mulaqqab bil-Khaml bin Sf Tugha Turk al-Samarqand


This is the autobiography of a qazi that lived outside of Samarkand in the second half of the 18th century (born 1190/1776-1777). It was composed in 1252 / 1836-1837.  None that while the [[Mirzoev catalog|Mirzoev and A. M. Boldyrev, eds., Katalog vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii Nauk Tadzhikskoi SSR]] goes with Kh__a__muli, [[Semenov|Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]] went with Kh__u__muli; the Persian word "obscure" has a damma.  This manuscript is identical to pages 133b-183b of [[Trkh-i Khuml (al-Biruni 37)]]

1b
* Starts out the memoir by thanking God that he was saved from the ranks (  ) of the ignorant - specifically the ranks of the Turks.
* From the ranks of the ignorant he joined the ranks of the learned.
* Author is quoting the Koran about the Arabs who were brought into the ranks of Islam from ignorance; those remaining behind are a metaphor for the Turks.         __  __
** Once these Turks came in to the fold they were negligent in Islam:           
** Moreover:         
*         
* Sufi learning:         
* Makes some cryptic reference to a "third degree" of something or rather: (continuing on to next page)        () 
2
* Parable of Umar and Ali: Umar claims that he is stronger in faith than Ali:          
** Naturally, Ali asks "how do you figure?" Umar replies that his faith is greater because he was once an infidel:                   
** Ali accepts this logic and agrees with Umar.
** //It seems that, as a Turk, Khamuli had a bit of a chip on his shoulder, which here he turns to his advantage//
2b
* His learning has brought him wealth:                           
** So not only is our author a Turk, he came from modest a background at that.
* Sources of authority - Fath al-Bari:               
* Names Hanifa as a Sufi:      
* Quotes a sura about good works being rewarded by God - another self-serving metaphor.
3
* Goes on a bit about good works and grace in the afterlife, faith, etc.
* Knowledge is the source of all prosperity in this world and the next:         
* Khamuli's membership in a Sufi order of some variety seems rather clear based on his references to secret knowledge -  , etc.
* His Sufi credentials notwithstanding, Khamuli nevertheless elevates the Ulama:               
** i.e. the __ulama__ as a category have access to the secret knowledge of the prophet.
3b
* Makes a direct horse riding metaphor (illustrating his Turkish background) to express the necessity of using his learning for God's work.
* A cryptic reference to the four mothers (i.e. four elements) and the seven fathers:                ...
* At this point the author introduces his father whom he respects a great deal, which will lead into a story about the miraculous circumstances of his birth:  ...   
4
* Father eschewed doubtful food and drink (     )
* My boy, before your birth I witnessed a miracle:              
* Father was out wandering in the desert when he was hailed by amazing apparitions:                  
* The father would again see these apparitions in mazars and places of purity ( ).
* These meetings allowed his father spiritual insight and divine favor:    
* His father, however, was an uneducated man and did not understand these signs:            
* Mysteriously, after sexual union with the author's mother and his conception the strange apparitions no longer appeared to his father:                             
* Which of course put the father into a depression... that is until a holy shaykh offered him an interpretation.
4b
* As it turns out, the holy apparitions witnessed by his father were all for the sake of his auspicious child:         ( ) 
* Khamuli was born in       in the year of 1190,      
5
* His father tells the good news of the miraculous birth to his friends:                
* The friends witness and affirm the miracle and later told the author about these events, including the tale of the widow (discussed below).
* At this point Khamuli begins the tail of a poor, destitute widow caring for four orphan girls.
* When Khamuli's mother was pregnant this woman had a miraculous dream.  A piece of paper bigger than a carpet (    ) fell from the sky.  The paper was full of various writing.  Everyone was watching and hoping that it would fall on their house.
* Author describes his house as  , suggesting that his family was living in a Turkish tent, though should check the term Khirgah.
5b
* As the paper entered the tent of Khamuli's parents it was miraculously lit up with light:                  
* Upon hearing the miraculous story of the widow, the father praises God and asserts that his son (Khamuli) will become an Alim:     
** And his followers will be prosperous:          
* Khamuli is careful to constantly remind readers that these stories were relayed to him by others, i.e. he did not make them up himself.
* The widow told him these stories in the year of 1226 when he was residing in the    in the village  .
* At this point Khamuli begins a story of his own miraculous dream in which he witnessed heaven itself, just as has been relayed by the Ulama of Islam:                   
6
* Much of this page is a description of heaven as seen by Khamuli in a dream.
* This vision took place in the year 1252, (25?) years ago.
* Author writes that despite the passage of time he remembers everything he saw without alteration ( ).
6b
* So overpowering is the vision that he rarely recites the ayat.
* In his vision of heaven he saw no women - only men made it there:        
** //except// he did see the aforementioned widow in heaven, though he did not have the opportunity to speak with her because he woke up.  He is very upset about this fact (          ).
7
* References the Ghazali book  
* Spends this page discussing a hadith about why women do not get into heaven and the importance of men educating them.
8
* Through this page he continues discussing the hadith about women and hell, offering and explanation.
* Origin of his name () arises from the fact that he was born on a Friday morning, the most auspicious of days ( ).  The  part of his name is Turkish for slave.
8b.  //This is the page where the autobiography really begins//
* Interesting - Khamuli has a poem here about how he is proud //not// to be a Sayyid, but rather happy to be a slave of God:                 
* Claims that he can remember the events of his youth like it was yesterday.          
* In his youth he was ignorant of ilm and the ways of the ulama, but held an internal faith: 
* Author had 6 siblings, 3 of which were older and all of which were literate.
9
* Therefore, his father ordered Khamuli to become a shepherd ().  //Unclear why his father would have this planned for him after all the miraculous visions//...
* Thus by his thirteenth year never been to a maktab:       
* Nevertheless, Khamuli possessed divinely inspired learning, so this was not a hindrance:       
* His teachers were amazed at how quickly he could internalize his training; they could not understand where his knowledge came from.
* People were amazed that he could recite suras without knowing what an alif was:                
* In the year 1202 he had memorized 1102 suras.
* Having completed this feat and having served his parents faithfully, he gained permission () from them to continue in the maktab.  But it was tradition that the pupil go to the maktab and ask the Ustod for permission to train alone without the parents.
* Khamuli quickly surpassed his teacher in the basics (continuing on to the next page):                   
9b
* Continues to emphasize his miraculous skills:         , thus shocking his teachers:        
* There were many witnesses who all testified that they had never before seen such a miraculously gifted youth.
* Borrowing books (         ) from the Akhund, Khamuli quickly passed through the ten degrees of learning:        
10
* Funny anecdote illustrating Khamuli's passion for learning -  Every day when the other children would go to the bathroom he would read their books while they were gone:            ()           
* Khamuli left many other students behind in the first rank, so fast did he progress.
* The Akhund believed that Khamuli had studied with somebody else previously since he was so quick:           
10b
* Suspicious, the Akhund would give him constant tests, but his knowledge was imparted by God:                   
* One day Khamuli made a mistake in his recitation (       ) and the Akhund became very angry and punished him severeley.
* For the life of him Khamuli could not figure out the answer and hence remained silent, which pissed the instructor off even more.
* Simple verse describing the Akhund's sudden anger:      
* Despite 50 years passing since that day, Khamuli still tastes the bitterness of that lesson, though he values the consequence:       
11
* When Khamuli received this beating from the Akhund, so loud was his cry that his parents came running and interceded.
* The Akhund calmed down and his parents asked for an explanation:     
* The Akhund claimed that Khamuli had tricked him:       
* Khamuli was reading verses better than the Akhund and hence must have been tricking him somehow:                
** The Akhund could not understand how Khamuli could fail to understand something he wrote down (i.e. be illiterate) and yet flawlessly recite it. (Duh - because he was divinely inspired.)
* An uncle (?) declared that it was divine will (    ) and that the child must be trained; the akhund complied (            )
11b
* Wine intoxication metaphors for how quickly he gained literacy at the hands of the persuaded akhund:               
* So quickly did he progress that it was not long before he had outgrown the maktab and it became his prison:                
* Goes through some florid prose about how important learning was to him.  For instance, he was ignorant and unannointed until:                  
* His perspective changed for ever one day in the fall () when a Dervish () passed by him on his way to school. (//check this//)
* Khamuli says that it is a custom of the Turks ( ) to send children to maktab in  because there is not much work for them to do (     ); their stint in school ( ) ends in  as a rule of the tribe ( ) because this is when the sheep give birth (    ).  In all, they have 6 months for study.
12
* Khamuli advanced sufficiently rapidly that he quickly effectively became the akhund's assistant:        
** And very soon thereafter Khamuli himself ended up taking the role of the akhund:      
* At age 14 he finished maktab.
* In the sense of outward, formal learning he had made great progress, but his spiritual, internal growth left much to be desired:                
* At the end of the page he concludes that if outward learning (zahir) is all there is to knowledge (ilm), then he is the best of them.
12b
* Khamuli is driven to understand the Arabic in Farsi books (//I can relate//):                
** //this is important; it means that in the maktab children were taught to recite and literacy, but not to understand the Arabic they were reading.//
* Khamuli has some choice words about the state of learning in his tribe; once he got to a certain level, he was surprised to realize anyone who had achieved even basic literacy was called an akhund, mulla, or alim:                                      
** As paltry as their skills were, there was no one better where he was from.
* Khamuli realizes / is divinely inspired (       ) that his tribe was common and ignorant () and that there must be better scholars in the world:        
** So he splits with them and leaves in search of something better:           ()      
13
* All of Khamuli's being was pinned on this superior milieu of scholars:            
* Khamuli was trapped; his parents wanted him to be a shepherd () but he was thirsty for more ilm.
* He exhibits remorse at disobeying his parents wishes that he become a shepherd:       
13b
* It was God who swayed his parents to his side:            
* The author did not initially even know what a madrassa was:              
* Recites a brief poem in Turki about how his eyes were fixated on going to madrasa.
* This situation persisted until 1202 when the author was in Shahrisabz. (//from here gets into some garbled metaphors about beling lost in the desert of ignorance//)
14
* Ultimately, his mother takes his side and agrees to intercede on his behalf to his father:                 
* It was a tear-filled decision; Khamuli could not sleep that night.
* His parents accept that he is no use for non-academic work:                    
* And so his father finally acquiesed, but emphasized that it would be a difficult life because Khamuli had not yet even reached 15 years of age and they have no relatives in the city (as of yet unclear //which// city) to watch over him:                    
* Also, notes the father, the city is full of scoundrels:      
* Based on the last sentence of this page, it is also possible that the father is worried they are going to make a bacha bazi out of him (//check//).
14b
* //based on first sentence of this page and the last one of the previous I am pretty sure his dad is worried about him becoming a bache bazi//
* Father says that, in any case, they must send him to a __chaste__ () alim:          
** After all:          
* Father rationalizes that if things get too bad the youth can always return home.
* There was much weeping at his impending departure:                
15. Off to the Madrasa (finally) in Kitab
* This Zahir - Batin distinction is ubiquitous for Khamuli, even when he is not using it in a Sufi sense.  For instance, when he is discussing how his parents are reacting to his imminent departure:                 
* It happened to be the bazaar day that his father told him that he was going to madrassa.  //Not sure if this is significant or not... perhaps connected with travel arrangments?//
* Father sends him to Kitab, which is on the outskirds of Kish (i.e. Shahrisabz).  The madrassa was named (roughly)   
* Author was under the tutelage of Irnazar Namangani  
15b.  Minibiography of Khamuli's Mu'allim
* Despite the name, Khamuli's teacher was not originally from Namangan.
* Namangani was born in Farghana (valley or town?), then went to Bukhara to study, then went to Namangan, which is why he has the name.
* In Namangan he became engaged in teaching the hard Islamic sciences ( ) to students:           
** Just as he was simultaneously bedecked in inner () piety, asceticism, etc:           
* All the local residents were his murids:             
* @@important@@ No one in the town mixed with the government; they were devoted exclusively to piety:                 ...       
* The muallim was never tied down by children or marriage.  
16
* The Hakim of Namangan called the Mudarris to be a qazi, but the Mudarris refused:                      
* The Qaziship here is described as a burden and the Mudarris's resisting it as a triumph:                       
** //on the one hand this fits very well with the Crone thesis; on the other hand, we know that Khamuli himself becomes a qazi of Samarkand, so... (then again even this is not so different from the situation of Abu Hanifa and Abu Yusuf)//
* For this reason the Mudarris abandoned his homeland of Ferghana and migrated to Kish / Shahrisabz.
* The people of his new province of residence were immediately captivated by him:             
16b
* Describes a scene where the Mudarris (described as a  ) triumphantly enters the city on horseback and all come out to greet him.
* According to the author's hyperbole, the Mudarris is veritably freeing the people of Kish from living in ignorance like a bunch of animals.
* Tribe ruling Shahrisabz (@@important@@); the Mudarris quickly made powerful friends in this emirate :        ((                              
17
* The ruler of Shahrisabz builds a madrasa for this Mudarris:                                            
17b
* The Mudarris's followers at the madrassa were well provided for:     
* On this page Khamuli finishes the Mudarris's tale and returns to the part where his parents drop him off and entrust him over to the teacher:             
* Instant initiation (hazing): The tradition was to dive right into the lessons; luckily, Khamuli passed with spades:              
* His precociousness quickly caught the special attention of the Mudarris (//i.e. Akhund; in the notes so far I have used the word Mudarris as I am trying to figure out what exactly to call the guy, but Khamuli uses the word Akhund//)
* The Mudarris tells Khamuli to stay near his room at night and not to mix with the other students:                (continued on to p. 18).
18
* Importance of rote memorization:                 
* Khamuli's incredible memory allowed him to quickly surpass expectations and he demanded more and more lessons, which the mudarris obliged.
* Khamuli surpassed any study partners he was given within a week:           ()       
* Khamuli's genius quickly became the talk of the town.
18b
* An angel warns Khamuli against the other students in the school with the face of men but hearts of demons:                        
* These peculiar, sinister denizens of the madrasa were wolves in sheeps clothing:        
* The only thing that saved Khamuli from corruption was his prior arrangement with the Mudarris:                          
19. The strange tale of the infidel Shah's daughter
* Author is seriously playing up the dire fate that awaited him had he not met his Mudarris before the evil students:                               
* Premise of the tale of the king's daughter:                   
* Basically she was really beautiful and a flirt, so people from all over the land fell in love and asked for her hand in marriage.
19b
* This kafir princess became enamored with Islam.  One day she could not conceal her secret any longer and revealed it to a co-religionist ().
* She asks one of her co-religionists to send her to talk with one of the great men of Islam.
* One of the handmaidens () informed the king of this.  He became livid with rage, as colorfully relayed by Khamuli:                   .
* The shah turns to his Brahman () for counsel, realizing that he needs to take firm action before the matter is out of his hands:                            
* The infidel padishah makes a deal: if the brahman can get his daughter to turn from the Muslim path, he will give him a thousand dinar.  If, however, the daughter remains Muslim, he will destroy his idols to, @@interestingly@@, the gods of the Satanic verses:     .  Full quote: ..                    
20
* The brahmin hatches a plan: show the daughter the worse Islam has to offer (  ) and she will return to the fold.
* The brahmin found a community of Muslims in the   who had a muezzen with a repulsive voice and ugly face:            
20b
* So they order the princess onto the back of a howdah; the princess was tormented by her desire to learn the inner secrets of Islam.
* The princess then hears his horrible voice:                  
* Upon hearing the horrible voice, the princess turns white like death and faints.
* The awfulness of the sound damages her very soul:                        
21
* The daughter is so stunned that she does not even know what the sound is.  The Brahman leaps out from hiding and gleefully informs her that the sound is the call to prayer which is a pillar of the Islamic relgion.
* Colorful language describing the princess' reaction:         
21b
* Just to be an asshole, the brahman sends his reward to the bad-voiced muezzen.  Then to add insult to injury the brahman says that in the future he will send every wavering kafir to the muezzen to cure them:            
* It seems that the entire story of the princess and the brahman was to illustrate the areligiosity of the other students in the school.
* In any case, he had already exhausted everything there was to learn after 6 months in the madrassa:                 

22. Return to the Adventures of Khamuli's Akhund
* Khamuli's brilliance was also a cause for jealousy among his rivals.
* In any case, after some time the Akhund decided to go on hajj:                       
* So the Akhund took his leave of Kitab and made for India () where he would take the sea route.
** Interesting remark about India, which at that time seems to have had a reputation for Sufism:            
* Khamuli describes his anguish at the departure of his mentor.
* Describes his mentor as    - the glory of his age.
* On the way to India the Akhund passes through Kabul - but never ends up making it any further because there was a glorious Pir whom he met there. (We know he was glorious because Khamuli spends nearly a full page describing his grandeur.)

22b
* This is the first time the author mentions the Naqshbandiyya by name, implying that the Akhund was not a part of the order previously - at least the Mujaddiya: ...              (= )
* The Afghan Pir's name:   
* In Kabul Khamuli's mentor embraces Hazrat Fayzi's leadership and joins the order:             
* The Akhund spent approximately two years (and 11 months?) studying the Naqshbandi ways in Kabul engaging in        

23
* The Akhund was appointed to go out and improve the inadequate (beginning on previous page):                  
* @@important@@: Moreover, the Pir of the order forbids him from going on the hajj in favor of recruiting new members in his homeland:                                                              
** //notice how the Pir employs the hadith to justify his decision//
* The Akhund nodded in assent and left Kabul for Mavrannahr.  From Shahrisabz and Qarshi he went to Samarkand.
* As it happened, at that time the author's father was with his tribe () at the base of a mountain to the south of Samarkand.  The Akhund and his followers were going through a pass () at that time and ran into Khamuli's father on the slope of the pass.
* Naturally, the father took the Akhund in as his guest.

23b
* The Akhund got reacquainted with Khamuli's father and they stayed up all night catching up:         
* The Akhund __recruits__ new Naqshbandi disciples in this village:                                
** //so it seems only a few days are necessary to recruit new disciples into the order; also... can women join in any capacity?//
* After this the Akhund goes to visit shrines in Bukhara:         
* After that the Akhund returned to Samarkand on his way to Farghana.
* Meanwhile Khamuli was in Shahrisabz; when he heard that the Akhund visited his father's house he traveled home, but just missed the Akhund.  Luckily, Khamuli caught him on the way back.
* //Note that the language Khamuli uses to describe the Akhund is nearly romantic and appears to be following Persian literary conventions of the Beloved//

24
* The Akhund finally returns to Samarkand on his way to Farghana and Khamuli of course falls before his feet and showers him with honor.
* It seems that the Akhund then made Khamuli one of his murids:               
* Then the Akhund finally left Khamuli for Namangan.

24b
* Once in Namangan the Akhund immediately gained a devoted following:                  @@     @@   
* The Akhund died in approximantely 1212 hijri (1797/1798 AD).

25. Wherein Khamuli takes on a New Teacher
* After the Akhund left for Namangan, Khamuli obtained permission to study under a new teacher, who had been a student of the Akhund in his youth:                       
* And so Khamuli set off for Shahrisabz to study with the new teacher.
* Khamuli recites a poem comparing his new mentor to Plato ().
* Interesting that his new teacher is described as a    , among many other things, //though I am not totally sure what to make of this title.//
* The __name__ of Khamuli's new teacher:     
* From this point Khamuli traces his lineage.  His father is:   

25b
* //starting at the end of the previous page is a confusing section of honorifics that mentions some names without saying exactly why//
* Tursun Khwaja Chalabiyya (   ): father or Muhammad Muminin Khoja and hence grandfarther of Lutf Allah.
* This family traces their ancestors both to Ali and Abu Hanifa.
* Author notes that Tursunkhwaja deserves his a separate book, so great is he; in lieu of that, the author relates two miraculous episodes () from his life:               
* The __first miracle__ () is relayed from Tursunkhwaja's father   
* The story takes place in the court of the Hakim        of Urgut ().  Note that this guy is a @@Ming@@ dynast.
** Note that Musa's rulership of Urgut was dynastic; the author notes that it was inherited hereditarily (quote continues on to the next page):            

26. Tursun Khwaja's first miracle: Intervention during an execution
* Because of "various affairs of the Uzbeks" (  ) the slave / servant () named Baqi () fell into disfavor in front of Hakim Musa; Musa ordered his execution.
* When Baqi's children and wife heard the news they came to the court to plead for his life.  Tursun Khaja agreed to intervene.
* Tursun goes to the court and demands that the amir intervene and pardon the offender, noting that on the day of ressurection those who forgave will be in turn forgiven, quoting a hadtih of course.

26b
* The Hakim is outraged and says soomething along the lines of "who the hell do you think you are waltzing in here from another province and telling me what to do?"  Also notes that he consulted with all of the great men of the court on this issue and so is in the right.
* Then Tursun says something that really pisses the Hakim off: "If God does not wish you to kill this man, then you will not be able to."                                                 
* Those in attendance realized that Tursun's words had ensured the execution lest the Hakim lose face in front of his court.

27
* With grim resolution, the Hakim grabbed a knife and plunged into the slave's heart:           
* But the sound that emerged was like two stones striking one another.  
* Those in attendance were amazed to open their eyes and see that the prisoner was totally unharmed:          
* Even more incredibly, the knife handle was broken in two (quote spills on to next page):                      

27b
* The Hakim's hands were all black and blue () from the force of the strike.
* Upon seeing this miracle, some members of the court fainted immediately, others began shouting in amazement. Some began falling at Turson's feet, rependting and begging him to guide them.
* Hakim Musa, too, miracurously returned to the fold:                  
* Implies that those in attentance became his murids:                
** And even more explicitly:              @@@@     () 
** Author names some of the individual Amirs who became his murids.

28
* Not clear how seriously he means the term, but Khamuli uses the term  when describing the state from which they entered the muridship of Turson.
* From this point and for half of the next page Khamuli records a poem - one of the longer ones of this work.

28b.  Tursun Khwaja's second miracle: The incredible growing beams
* Turson Khaja sends his murids too all the cities of Central Asia (?).
* There was a mountain to the south of Urgut () near Shahrisabz.  The pass there must have been a waystation because Turson decided to build a congregational mosque ( ) for travellers.

29
* Just as they were consecrating the mosque with the Fatiha they realized that the beams were too short, which made everyone sad and ashamed.
* Turson proclaimed that they would put the beams in place anyway.
* Miraculously, the beams grew about 9 inches () and fit the walls:           
* Naturally, everyone fell upon their knees and cried out admiration of the Khwaja.
* There are many other examples of this sort of miracle:             
* Khamuli conducted his own investigation of the matter and found witnesses; he condemns the doubters of these miracles.

29b. On the nature of miracles and the possibility of female prophets
* //It's hard to know what to make of this section; for several pages Khamuli first seems to be proving to us that miracles are indeed possible and that friends of God exist; then he gets sidetracked (?) on a lengthy discussion of the possibility of female prophets - he comes down strongly on the negative side.  The language is also particularly challenging here.//
* References the miraculous transfer of 's throne to the court of Sulayman.  Then talks about a miracle involving Maryam and the miraculous production of water from parched ground.
* Khamuli's directly stated take on miracles:                      
* //At the very least, it seems clear from these pages that there is a debate over the existence of miracles, or at least// who //is capable of them//.

30
* This is the page where Khamuli really gets started on the tangent (?) of denying female prophethood:         
* To make his point the author referenecs a famous commentary on the hadith of Bukhari:  . Apparently this book rules negatively on the mother of Moses, who performed miracles (?), but was not a prophet.
* As it turns out, however, there is not universal agreement on this matter among the ulama, though they only mean that they mean it in the sense of a messenger:                   
* Another fiqh commentary referenced:   (?)
* //Thought: it may also be possible that he is using the women prophethood issue more positively to show that there are non-prophets capable of miracles; i.e. his opponents are saying that there cannot be miracles because that is the domain only of prophets.//

30b
* References a Sharh by  , who is the Afghan pir mentioned earlier in this book (see p. 22b), which discusses the sanctity of Maryam.
* Khamuli seems to concede that the issue of female prophethood is not immediatley clear from the sources:                                        
** Note the reference to ; see also [[Trkh-i Humyn-i Gulshan, 1328]] for such a reference.

31
* Woman can't possibly be prophets because they can't go out and mix with the public at large, activity essential for a prophet.
* Also lists other reasons, like women are not smart enough to be prophets (?).
* At this point Khamuli references his late Akhund as well, who, while not on par with Fayzi in Kabul, is also worty of emulation and he says women are not prophets.
* At this point the author directly addresses why he is going on about this with such verbosity (     ) because there was a group of ulama propounding the opposing view.

31b
* Note that the venue in which Khamuli witnessed this group express their views was the informal discussion group (  ).
* At this point the author starts a new  about just such a debate he had with a prominent Qazi.
* A majlis was held by the Samarkand Qazi      though he is called popularly .
* In this majlis, Khamuli himself challenges the esteemed Qazi of Samarkand:          
* Qazi Maghiun, naturally, is stunned at this challenge from an opponent of lesser status.  Khamuli proceeds to recite two passages of the Qur'an to make his point.
* Maghium replies that he is basing his position on history after the Quran ( ).  Khamuli is outraged at this response:             .  The qazi retorts something along the lines of that it is in fact Khamuli who is out of line.
* Most people in attendance took Maghiun's side:       
* Khamuli expresses his feelings on the matter through poetry:        

32. Back to the autobiography
* Khamuli did not waste any opportunity for learning with his new teacher.  At this point he turns to similar self-praise as expressed previously in the work about how gifted he was and how quickly he passed through the different subjects.
* For instance, he studied subjects that others did not study until a much more advanced stage, such as poetic meter (     ) and poetry, geography / topography ( ), inheritance law ().
** //Notice that poetry and meter is placed right along side the Islamic sciences.//
* Importance of memorization - he could not progress from one lesson to the next until he memorized the last one:              
** In this fashion he could pass on his knowledge to others:           
* In this manner Khamuli studied for 3-4 years until there was nothing left for the ustod to teach him.

32b. Journey to Samarkand
* Khamuli's ustod, Lutfallah, entrusts him with a letter to take to the mother of his bride in Samarkand who is also the bother of the Qazi of Samarkand (but not Maghiun):                            and bring back the response.
* However, there was a problem: the road was hazardous due to war between Shah Murod (       ()        ) and... (continued on next page)

33
* ... and the Hakim of Shahrisabz (    ()    ).
* Because of the war, the usual war was unpassable.  But Khamuli takes a lesser-known road and gets there and back.
* It seems that the Ustod was requesting from Shah Mausum the right to head the Yalnaktush Bey Madrassa in Samarkand (    ) and the right to write fatwas for Samarkand.
* The request was granted.  With great fanfare, Khamuli was sent from Bukhara to Samarkand to make this announcement:          ()                           

33b
* Installed in Samarkand, Lutfallah achieves great success imparting learning to students, to whom he was beloved.
* Khamuli as well studied under his relocated mentor in Samarkand with utter singlemindedness.
* Lutfallah was much loved by the luminaries of Samarkand, but many also were jealous and resented him.
* The aforementioned Qazi Kalon Abdal Hay (            ) - who was also Lutfallah's brother in law (    ) - became sick with jealousy at the adoration Lutfallah received:                    
* As a result, Lutfallah was essentially driven from Samarkand:           

34
* The elite of the city did not bother to seek out the truth, but instead persecuted Lutfallah; Khamuli cites some hadith to justify the retreat of the wrongfully persecuted.
* And so Lutfallah ditches Samarkand for Shahrisabz, where he was welcomed with open arms by the Hakim there:                                            
* And so Lutfallah ends up in Kitab, where he was greeted, clothed, and fed by the Ulama and Sayyids and great ones.

34b
* Lutfallah remained in that tranquil place (which he compares to Iram) where he was revered for 5-6 years.
* Nevertheless, he always pined for Bukhara and Samarkand:        
* It seems that he was not satisfied with the quality of his students in Shahrisabz (?).
* Once again Lutfallah found himself waiting for a letter from his female intermediary ( ) until 1210 / 1795-6 when the same intermediary (the wife of the Shaykh al-Islam in Samarkand) obtained a writ from the Amir of Bukhara to reestablish Lutfallah in the Samarkand madrassa -    (spelling?).

35.  Hikayat: It's not polite to tell secrets in the presence of others
* In his lifetime the Amir of Bukhara gave him two posts: (1)     and (2)    
* Lutfallah was renowned for giving honest advice to the powerful and his patrons without fear.
* He also had mad Majlis skills:                   
* Here begins a ; one day in the madrasa     (?) the Hakim of Samarkand visited the house of the  , who was        .  Khamuli has great praise for this Qazi.

35b
* Khamuli was also personally in attendance at this majlis.  //Note that he participates even though he later praises another Sufi for abstaining.//
* During the majlis the Hakim and the Qazi began to exchange whispers:                  
* When the whispering became gratuitous, Lutfullah ( ) remarked that whispering between two individuals in a majlis was contrary to the rulings of the mujtahids of Islam ( ). I.e.:                  
* The Hakim had nothing to say to this.  The Qazi manages a comeback - you should not have been listening in on our conersation.
* Lutfallah rejoinds: Shame on you, a Muslim of such stature, lest others follow your example.
* Lutfallah makes his point by vaguely referencing scholarly consensus and then references a hadith.

36
* Ultimately, the Hakim and the Qazi back down:         
* The great ones of the majlis expressed their approval of Lutfallah's position:    
* After a poem, the author writes that in the year 1215 Amir Mausum (Shah Murad) and Haydar came to the thrown.
* Upon taking the thrown, Haydar summons Lutfallah to Bukhara.

36b.  Lutfallah is summoned to Bukhara by Amir Haydar then moves to Hisar
* In Bukhara Lutfallah is appointed by Haydar to a prominaent madrassa:        
* After several years in Bukhara, the Hakim of Hisar    , who was the father of Haydar's ( ) daughter, whose ancestors had been murids of   (presumably referring to Lutfallah's teacher and Khamuli's first teacher from Namangan?), and who himself was (again, presumably reffering to:) Lutfallah's student:       .  
* This Hakim invited Lutfallah to his province.  Lutfallah obtained permission from the Amir to serve as Qazi in Hisar:                
* Lutfallah spent several years in Hisar where he both served as Qazi and instructed students.
* (check) @@interesting@@: The heathen ways of the Mongols were still alive amongst the Uzbek tribes in the region.
* Lutfallah brought this province back into accordance with the Sharia:     
* Thanks to his efforts of bringing these provincial heathens back to God, the province prospered:              ((    

37.  Death of Lutfullah
* And so it went until Lutfallah died of a headcold and blindness (pnemounia?):           
* Khamuli assures us that Lutfallah's good works on earth assure him nymphs in heaven and boy beloveds:       
* For the last 3-4 months of his life he was blind, but his insight () remained holy:           
* On a Tuesday in Muharram the year 1228 (1812) in Dihnaw ( ) he passed away.
* At this point Khamuli offers us some poetry that he composed in the month of Lutfallah's death.

37b. Lutfallah's children
* Lutfallah had five children, one of whom died in his early childhood.
* (placeholder: return to a sentance here about the importance of fatwas and the amir's sanction)
* One son was Malla Khoja  .  He is described as ascetic ().  He is now a Shaykh in the Kubraviyya Ashaaiyya ( ).
** //so the son is in a different order than his father?//
** Currently Malla Khoja is in Zia ul-Din ( ) where the light of his greatness shines brightly for the people:         
* It is very clear in this page that the barakat extends through the generations; Lutfallah's children are attributed to inherit his greatness.

38
* Three other children:      
* Shirin Khoja - goes through the various subjects he mastered -        .  His studies included trigonometry and music.  Also, despite limited opportunity, he learned correspondence writing -   .
* Compares his bravery () to that of Rustam ().
* Spends a lot of time layering generic praise onto this son.

38b
* At this point we move on to Ofoq Khoja ( ), marked here as the ustod's second son, which is curious given the presense of Malla Khoja.
* Ofoq Khoja has a designation of unclear significance:   
* Aside from generic praise, Khamuli remarks on Ofoq's enthusiasm for debate (  ).

39. Ofoq Khoja the Philosopher
* Ofoq Khoja spent most of his time in Bukhara, apparently, because Khamuli relays a story about how he comes back to his home village of Urgut to visit his father (or mother) and brothers.  //note this suggests a strong tie between Lutfallah's family and this village of Urgut.//
** Specifically, he returns to visit   ; so  could either be the Arabic "his father" or .
* At the time Khamuli was in the service of Lutfalla (?):              Or possibly more temporal responsibilities.
* Afaq Khoja comes to Khamuli's abode (  ) while Khamuli was teaching two other students:               
* They interrupted Khamuli's lesson; he had not seen Afaq Khoja for so long that he did not recognize his old friend at first:             

39b
* Lutfallah comes to Khamuli to discuss two philosophical issues ().  [[Link to transcription of the philosophical points|Transcription of Lutfallah's Philosophical Points of Contention (Khamuli 39b-40)]]
* //my Persian is not up to this highly philosophical language; will need to @@seek help@@//
* Note that this philosophical debate seems to be playing out over some kind of correspondence ( ).

41b.  Qazi Khoja Javon; Lutfallah's Bros
* Here Khamuli starts a new section:    
* Lauds the qazi's erudition, etc., using wine metaphors:        
** Also compares his knowledge and studying to an .
* Author moves on from the Qazi Javon section somewhat abruptly
* Aside from Lutfallah, Mumin Khoja (his father) had three other children as well.  (Who are therefore Lutfallah's brothers.)  They are:
**       
* Qasim Khuja died in his youth (     ).
* Sufi Khoja was two years younger than Lutfallah; named "Sufi" because:         

41. Sufi Khoja (Lutfallah's bro)
* More on Sufi Khoja's quality:        
* Sufi Khoja's occupation (not sure this gets us anywhere):                 
* Humble in how he conducted himself:            
* Educated in Bukhara:                 
* Author notes with approval that he copied an eigth of the Sharh-i Jalali (@@identify@@) in find writing:        
* Sufi Khoja was so pious that he avoided the halls of power:       
* Sounds like this guy was a zahid given his eating habits:       
* Interesting that Khamuli sees Sufi Khoja's avoidance of majlises as a virture:            [=]     
* Khoja Sufi was frequently in an ecstatic state:                                  

41b
* Sufi Khoja shunned temporal power:          
* His mastery was superior to that of the ulama:      [ / ]           []            
* The amir hears of his erudition, invites him to the court and offers to give him a post, (but he refuses):                   ...                      
* It seems that the ulama were telling the amir about Sufi Khoja's quality and the amir wanted to see for his own eyes:      
* One day it came to pass that   (probably Lutfallah, Sufi Khoja's brother) was paying his respects to the amir in Bukhara and was requested to go fetch his brother:                               []    

42
* Amir of Bukhara suggests that perhaps Sufi Khoja will listen to his brother Lutfallah; bring him and you shall be richly rewarded:                                
* Lutfallah accepted the amir's order and went in search of Sufi Khoja.  At this time Khamuli too was in in Bukhara.  At that time he was living in the madrasa  
** Basir:         
* They arrive at Sufi Khoja's dwelling:  [ / ]                          
* Khamuli is overjoyed to be a part of this auspicious encounter.  Note that he uses the term  to describe it.
* Description of Sufi Khoja's appearance:           

42b
* Despite the tattered clothes, there was an aura of beauty about Sufi Khoja:        []               

[[Master Index]]

!!!Of the Poets, Poetic Anthologies
* [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]] 1870
** Persian.  Widely copied, copies both in Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.  Also a 1977 Dushanbe edited edition.  My notes are from a scan I have from a Dushanbe copy.
** Progress: About halfway through, all entered in database.
* [[Shar'i, Tazkirat al-Shu'ara-i Haji Azim Shar'i|Takirat al-Shuar-i Abd al-Am Shar (al-Biruni 3396/III)]] (    )
** Two copies at al-Biruni: Semenov 5 p. 79; 3575, 3396/III 
* Pirmasti: [[Afl al-Takr fi ikr al-Shuar va al-Ashr (al-Biruni 2303)]]            written 1903
** Two copies at al-Biruni: Semenov 5, p. 81; 3579, 2303
*** Also:        Semenov 1, p. 141; 346, 63
* [[Hashmat, Tazkirat al-Shu'ara-i Hashmat|ashmat, Takirat al-Shuar (al-Biruni 2728, 61)]]      , written 1904-5
** Semenov 1, p. 141; 343, 2728/II; the second volume is #61.
* [[Takirat al-Shuar- Abdallah Khwjah Abd, 1904]]
** Persian.  Widely copied and also facsimile edition published in Dushanbe in 1983.
** Covers 118 individuals, mostly Bukharan intellectuals, but also a few Iranians and Afghans
** Progress: Minimal.  //check to see if they have this at Alisher Navoi//
* [[adr , Takr-i Ashr]], 1907
** Persian.  Not copied widely (as far as I know), but there is an excellent Iranian edited edition that also draws supplementary information from Zia's other works.
* [[Tazkirat al-Shu'ara-i Muhtaram|j Nimatallah, Takirat al-Shuar-i Mutaram (al-Biruni 2252 II)]] (   by    ) written 1908
** Includes poets from the 19th and early 20th centuries. There are two copies, the author's own draft in Tajikistan (which has been edited and published) and one copied by Sadr Zia in Uzbekistan. Not completed. The Zia version has an additional conclusion.
** 1975 published Dushanbe edition.
** Progress: none.  //check Alisher Navoi//
* [[Abd al-Am Muammad Sm, Mirt al-Khayl (IVRSP C 1943)]]
** Mostly in verse, written to praise Abd al-Ahad.

!!!Of the Calligraphers
* [[Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]]
** Persian, written in 1936.  
** In many ways a bunch of mini-biographies about Sadr Zia's friends amongst the Bukharan high elite.
** Progress: almost done reading and note-taking, entered into database along the way

!!!Of the Ulama
* [[Marjn, Wafiyyat al-Aslf, 19th century]]
** Arabic, finished after 1889 (date of the last entry). 
** Unique manuscript, currently unpublished, available in Nauchnoi biblioteki Kazan National University
** Covers ulama from the entire Islamic world; original material on Tatar and Transoxiana ulama
** Progress: partially examined, examined entries in database
* [[Ramz, Talfq al-Akhbr wa Talq al-Athr fi Waqi Qazn wa Bulghr wa Mulk al-Tatr (1908)]]
** Famous, printed source (though only a few copies exist due to crack-down by Tsarist authorites)
** Combined history and tazkirat
** Progress: minimal
* [[Muallim, Alm al-Makayyain]]          
** Arabic, published (but rare) source in Mecca.
** Details scholars who visited Mecca on the hajj; I scanned the entries with Central Asian nisbats.
** Progress: partially examined, not entered into database
* [[fi, Ulam Dimashq]]
** Modern edited edition.  Only have a scan of one entry.
** Progress: Notes taken, not entered in database.

!!!Of the Sufis
* [[Biografiia sheikhov Naqshbandiia i Mudzhadddidiia (untitled - IVRSP C 2019-2)]]
* [[Dhikr-i Junb Mustaghn al-Alqb Shaykh Sad al-Dn Amad Anr (Anonymous), IVRSP C 1404-5]]
* [[Takirah-i hir shn (aka Silsilah-i Khwjagn-i Naqshbandiyyah) (al-Biruni 855/I)]]
** Persian, covers Naqshbandi shaykhs up to the middle of the 18th century.
* [[Takirat-i arat Majb Namangn (al-Biruni 2662/II)]]
** Persian, written in second half of 18th century.
* [[Mir Musayyab Bukhari, Kitab-i Maqamat-i Mashayikh (SPbGU 854)]]

!!!Unique Memoirs or Detailed Biographies
* [[Tarjuma-i l-i Q Juma-Qul Khaml]], 1836
** An autobiography that also turns into something of a tazkirat of Khamuli's majuddiya order.
** Unique manuscript available only in Tajik Institute or Oriental Studies; have a full scan
** Progress: fully read, mostly finished taken notes, almost no entry into database
* [[Muhammad isari, Yddshth, 1268-1296]] 1880
** Progress: fully read and annotated, not entered into database
* Hashmat's Autobiography   
** Available at al-Biruni: Semenov. 1, p. 140; 341, 2513/II
* Tarjuma of Sadr Zia's father Zia Shukuri (            ) ([[Link|adr , ikr-i Chand Nafar-i Ulam-i Mutabbair-i Nmdr, al-Biruni 1304/IV]])
* [[Sadatallah, Luf-i Buzrg (IVRSP B 1932)]]
* [[Dhikr-i Junb Mustaghn al-Alqb Shaykh Sad al-Dn Amad Anr (Anonymous), IVRSP C 1404-5]]

[[Tazkirat Index]]

> Takirah-i hir shn

Titles:    or   
Author:       Muhammad hir bin Muammad ayyib Khwrazm

SVR 3 p. 364, 2692-2696; 855/I
* Numerous other copies, including the initial described one - 69 - and 75, 856/I (an Uzbek translation from Khiva).
* 321 individuals going through to the first half of the 18th century.
* Author was a murid of     (d. 1134 / 1722).
* Written in Khorezm in 1157 under Abu Muhammad Abu al-Gazi II (r. 1154/1742-1158/1745).
* Transcriber of copy 855b:            ; date of transcription: 1311 / 1894.

General Observations
* This tazkirat is comparatively personal, i.e. the author is not afraid to recount his personal experiences interacting with the different characters - and, at least at the end, he has had personal interactions with almost everyone.

Aman Tirmizi Bukhari (346b-349b)
* Name:       
* Discipleship - Ali Afghani; Abd al-Raziq; assistant shaykh Muhammad Khalifah-i Tirmizi in Damascus (346b):                                                                                 
* Travels - Damascus, the Hajj, Astarbad, Khorezm, back to Bukhara (346b):                                                                         [ ]                    
* Khorezmian ancestry (347):                                      
* (cont.) Father (347):        
* (cont.) Studied in Balkh and Bukhara, offers some specifics on the sufi curriculum (347-347b):                                                                                                                                        
* (cont.) Served as qazi of Tirmiz under Subhanquli Khan (347b):                                    []                         
* After Aman's shaykh Muhammad Khalifah-i Tirmizi left for Mecca, Aman came to Bukhara (347b):           
** (cont.) At the time when Aman came to Bukhara, Muhammad Tahir (the author) was in the service of Qasim Turkestani in the qishlaq of "Kalan" (347b-348):                                
* Private financial arrangements allowing for Aman to live in Bukhara for 2 years (348):                                                                           
* Tahir Ishan goes into Aman's service.  Note the phrasing here; //is Tahir Ishan literally in his service, or is he supported by the madrasa waqf?//:                        
* Tahir Ishan introduced Aman to S'adallah and the two became great friends, and S'adallah challenged Aman to sequester himself in the Naqshbandi complex. Tahir was 17 at the time (348b):                               [ ]  
* Aman went on the hajj via Herat and Charjuy, visited shrines on the way (348b):                                                     
* Meeting with Abu al-Fayz Khan (349):                                          
* Died in 1135; also information for inferring both the age of the author and when he was writing this text (349):                                       
* Purpose in writing the book - apparently Aman's idea (349):                                
* Children (349b):                                      

Husayn Khwajah Suyunji (349b-350b)
* Name:    
* Parentage (349b):                    
* (cont.) Like his brother, studied under S'adallah after his father died when he was around 20 years old (349b):         []                                               
* //p. 350 - revisit//
* Died in 1140 (350b):               

Muhammad Sadiq Khwajah (350b-351)
* Name:     
* Parentage (350b):        
* Sufi master (350b):           
* Died in 1146; grave location (350b):              
* Children (350b):               

Muhammad Tayyib Khwarazmi (351-353b)
* Name:     
* Father of the author, Tahir Ishan (351).
* Teacher - Baba Haji Bukhari travels to Khwarazm where he meets Muhammad Tayyib (351):                            []                             
** //not certain who the mentioned khan here is//
* Father of Tayyib studied in Bukhara; mother taught him in his father's absence (351):                                              
* (cont.) Tayyib's fame grew in Khwarazm (351):                                               
* (cont.) Tahir Ishan also trained under his father when he got back from Bukhara (351b):                  []          
* Full name of Tayyib's father (351b):                                    
** (cont.) Continuing the family history - Zuhrab's brother, i.e. Tayyib's great uncle, had a son Mirzab who's son went to India and got in with the kings there, and lived out his days there (351b):                                                       
*** //story not reflected in database//
** (cont.) Mavlana Dawlatshah studied in Bukhara during the reign of Abdallah Khan (16th century) (351b):                                         
*** (cont.) Abu Hanifa-ish story of Mavlana refusing the post of qazi of Khwarazm (351b-352):                                                                                                                                                                                     [  ]                                                     
* //story I can't follow// (p. 352)
* Memory of the year of Tahir Ishan's birth (352):                                            
* Tahir Ishan can trace his lineage to Sayyid Ata on his mother's side (352b):                                                                                                                                         
** (cont.) His father, for his part, was a sayyid via Ali (his mother was through Fatima - see previous entry) (352b):                                                                                                  
* Origin of Muhammad Tayyib's khanaqah (353):                                                              
* (cont.) Tayyib's children (353):     -                               
** (cont) Muhammad Salih and son (353):                                                       
** (cont) Pir Quli (353):                   
** (cont.) Abd al-Rahim (353):                      
** (cont.) Only two sons left standing at the time of writing - the author and Abd al-Rahman, mentions Abd al-Rahman's children (353):                                              
* (cont.) The author Muhammad Tahir's children (353): 
** (cont.) Fathallah was a mudarris appointed by the khan of Khiva (353):                                                                                 
** (cont.) Sa'dallah studies in Bukhara with his father, his youngest son he has not seen and is back in Khorezm; hopes to finish writing this book so that he can go back and see his son (353b):                                                                                  
* (cont.) He is well provided for in Bukhara and the patricians of Bukhara are encouraging him to bring his family there as well, which he is considering / intending (?) (353b):                                                                    

!!!Hazrat Husayn Khwajah (353b-354)
* (cont.) Correspondence between Muhammad Tayyib in Khwarazm and Husayn Khwajah in Bukhara (353b):                                            
* (cont.) Tahir was in Bukhara at the time of this correspondence.  Mulana Iman (who was Tahir's teacher) greatly respected Husayn Khwajah. Husayn Khwajah took up hunting and horsemanship like a soldier, people started to hear less from him (353b-354):                                                                                                                              

!!!Shah Mansur Khwajah (354-355)        
* Spiritual pedigree - khalifa of Yar Muhammad (p. 337b), who was a murid of Hashimi Balkhi (354):                      
* (cont.) After the death of his master Shah Mansur returned to his home village of Sughud in Samarqand (354):                                                              
* (cont.) Narrative of author Muhammad Tahir's pilgrimage to a shrine outside of Samarqand (354-354b):                                                                                                                                                                                       
* (cont.) Mansur Khwajah was in close communication with Aman Tirmizi, traveling to Bukhara frequently (354b):                                                                                         
* (cont.) Had a farm and house in Ghijduvan (354b):                                                
* Death (354b-355):                                                                                       []      
* Son, ancestor, descended from Ahmad Yasawwi (355):                                                                     
** Notice how the author uses "Jahriyya" to refer to all non-Naqshbandi tariqas (or perhaps the Yasaviyya in particular).
* Muhammad Tahir went on pilgrimage to visit Ashiq Ata (355):              

* Author comes to Bukhara, studies under Sa'dallah (355):                                                                                                                                   





[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- 1304/III, 1936

       
* Pages: 67-97b.
* Colophon (97b):  1350  [1936 .]       []   []             

//Note//: Physically bound in the same volume as [[adr , ikr-i Chand Nafar-i Ulam-i Mutabbair-i Nmdr, al-Biruni 1304/IV]]

It is clear generally from these entries that the very act of transcribing the Quran is a holy act, kind of like memorizing it.

     Halvaiyy (69b) //not entered database//
* Lauded as the master of his age (69b):             
* Lived in the time of Ubaydallah Shibani (1534  1539 C.E.)
* Origin of his nickname:            

   Mir Ubayd Katib (70) //not entered database//
* Teacher:                  
** But after learning the basics he abandoned his teacher and forged his own style:                                
* His innovation won him fame, even becoming the standard in Bukhara:                    
** Not, however, in Hindustan or Afghanistan:                
* Served in the court of Ubaydallah Khan (//Shibani or Janid?//) and earned royal titles there:                              

    Ubayd Quli Turkman Katib (70-70b) //not entered in database//
* A leading student of Ubayd Katib's; people would mistake their productions for each other:           
** Some even maintain he surpassed his master:          
* Zia personally has works of this scribe in his collection:                []  
* Contemporaries / family (70b):             

    Qari Abd al-Rahim (70-70b)
* Intro (70):                       [  ]          
** Amir Muzaffar Khan: 1860-1885.
* Context here is that this guy collected the works of the previous two works and commented to Zia about how they were often confused with one another.
* //see subsequent entry//

        Chappa Navis (70b-71)
* This character is mentioned as Atash's teacher in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]
* Lived in the Guzar of   in Bukhara.

    Qari Abd al-Rahim Tarabi (72)
* //see previous entry as well//
* died in 1322 at the age of 70-something.
* Obviously a big deal, given his subtitle; he tutored the princes of Bukhara:           
* Also an expert in Tajwid:    
* Sufi shaykh:          
* Hafiz:   

            Abdallah Bik "Yakkabaghi" (72-73b)
* Descriptions of this guy follow the tropes of the beloved (73):            ...           ...          ...                         
* Descended from the princes of Yakkabagh, a city not far from Shahrisabz, which was independent until conquered by Muzaffar Khan; Abdallah Bik's brother was executed after the conquest (72b):                                                                                        
** Abdallah Bik - only 12 years old at the time - languishes in prison, but uses that time to teach himself the art of calligraphy (72b):                                                             
* Spends time comparing Abdallah Bik's calligraphic skill to other famous calligraphers (     )  (p. 72b):           
* Recognizing the quality of the boy's calligraphy, yet Muzaffar kept him imprisoned (72b):                                     
**                                          (p. 72b).
* Abd al-Ahad comes to power (73):        
** According to tradition his accession is accompanied by releasing prisoners (73):        
*** poetic verse:    -             []       
*** However, hardened criminals were also freed; Charjuy as a refuge of exiles (73):                                 []      []               
*** //revisit// spends the better part of the page discussing forced relocation in Charjuy
* Against precedent and custom Sadiq Khan Turah "Hashmat" takes the boy under his wing (73b):              [. 74]                                    
* Even protected by Hashmat, for the rest of his life he is in peril (74):                    
* Buried near Ishaq Gulabadi (74):                       
* Zia aspires to write a separate biography of this character if he lives long enough, but feared reprisal previously (74):                                             

         Qari Muhammad Husayn Katib (73b)
* One of Qari Ahmad Katib's students.
* One of the most prolific calligraphers of his day, though he did not surpass his master:                               
* Died during the reign of Alim Khan.
