* Excerpt from Bakhtiyar Khan's tazkirat (p. 74b-80b):    


!!!                (p. 81-81b)

!!! 
Introduction to this section (in red heading ink) takes up an entire page (82):                                                                                                              
* In particular focuses on Mawlabi Saqi Muhammad Balkhi who invented on the "saqi-gi" style:            @@ @@                                         [ \ ]       
* Another innovator - Sadiq Jan Katib:                  
* And others:                                                         [ \ ]      
* //note the emphasis on originality and innovation//

        Saqi Muhammad Balkhi (82b-83)
* From Balkh:          (p. 82b).
* Father (82b):              ...                           
* Hence calligraphy was passed from father to son (82b):              
* Innovated a new style and was prolific in producing exemplars (82b):                                          
* Served as mufti under Subhan Quli Khan (16801702) (p. 83):                       []         
** Once Subhanquli took Bukhara as well Saqi Muhammad followed as well and became mufti (83):                                                      
* Finished out his life in Bukhara (83):        

         Rahmatallah Balkhi "Mavlavi Julli" (83-83b)
* //note:  here probably means "jasmine"//
* One of Saqi's students (83):                         
* Honors bestowed on him by Amir Haydar (83b):                                                                                     
** (cont.) so because of Haydar's direct and extensive patronage Julli is able work prolifically (83b):         
** Haydar ends up with a particular, well-known mark (83b):                                                                                 

       Mavlavi Abdallah Balkhi (83b-84)
* Brother ( ) of previous entry (Julli) (83b).
** Father of both of them:      
* Also one of Saqi's students (83b).
* In Zia's opinion his replication of Saqi's style is superior to that of his brother (83b):                                      
* Also patronized by Haydar (84):                                                  
* Zia's personal relationship to them (84):                               

        Mulla Abd al-Rahman Balkhi (84)
* Part of the same family, but his work does not match up to his brothers:                                     
** //note: Zia does not explicitly say this guy is the brother of the previous two; I am inferring that from the fact that they apparently have the same father; in fact, Zia's phrasing suggests that they are not brothers (see below) - perhaps step brothers from another mother?//
* Nevertheless, his work is perfectly acceptable:              

        Abd al-Wahid Sadr Sarir Balkhi (84-84b)
* Also an imitator of Saqi:    []               
** However, unlike the brothers, who were personally close with Saqi, Sarir did not train with him directly, even though they were all from the same village outside of Balkh (84):                                                                                      
** (cont.) as for Sarir himself (84):                                
** (cont.) as a result, Sarir ended up innovating an even more exquisite style (84):                        
* Also compliments his excellent poetry (84b):                
* Qazi posts (84b):                                   
* His library (84b):                     
* Passed away as qazi of Ghijduvan (84b):           

                Haji Mir 'Isa Makhdum (84b-85)
* A great one of Bukhara; especially skilled at accounting and geometry (84b):               []                           
* Also a great poet and imitator of Saqi's style of calligraphy; like Sarir, he did not study with Saqi personally, but was still very good in a slightly different way (84b):                                 []    []  
* Known for being fast (84b):                  []  
* Origins go to Balkh (84b):             
* Isa Makhdum, however, was born in Bukhara (85):         
* Employment - mufti, Tursunjan madrasa (85):                     
* Death (85):      

      Mullah Nadrallah Awraq "Lutfi" (85)
* Imitator of Haji Isa Makhdum's style:              
* Nickname:                
* Also a poet and a courtesan of Abd al-Ahad; worked as a qazi in numerous provinces:                                           

   Qari Ahmad Katib (85)
* Nadrallah's inlaw:                          
* //note - this guy was already mentioned previously//

           Mulla Sadiq Jan "Kufri" "Kuy Dirakht" (85-85b)
* Father (85):        
* From the time of Amir Haydar (85):          
* Name comes from his neighborhood (85):             
** His other nickname comes from his harshly sarcastic poetry (85):                 
* At first he followed Saqi and 'Isa Makhdum, but then he innovated his own style (85):                          []                                                 
* Quantity of works (85):                    
* Taught both Turks and Tajiks (huh...) (85):            
* Zia's personal collection (85b):                  

    Mirza Abd al-Quyum Katib (85)
* Son of Sadiq Jan Kufri (85b):                                    
* However, he was never very prolific due to the death of his father, which prompted him to offer his writing services to local governors which in turn caused his style to deteriorate (85b):                              

           Qazi Mir Zia al-Din Makhdum (85b)
* Lineage:               
* Nickname (?):       
* Wrote in the style of Sadiq Jan Kufri Kuydirakhti and the two were friends:               
* Hereditary judgship (?):                          
** i.e. he was a peer of Sadiq Jan Kufri Kuy Dirakht and both were going down the calligraphy path, but his work had to come to an end to take up the matle of qazi from his father.

     [  Qazi Mulla Amin Sudur [] (85b)
* A follower of Sadiq Jan Kufri who also created his own style:                   
* Qaziship in Pirmast and Hisar, muftiship, taught at Tursunjan madrasa:

* Moved to Bukhara after Russian conquest (86b):

      Abd al-Samad Khwajah Sudur (86b).
* Son of Abu al-Hay and older brother of Abdallah Khwaja.
* Young, but also very skilled; despite his youth, he was appointed to various qazi-ships and also ra'is of Bukhar:                                      
* During the revolution he was exiled and then killed:                                    
* Summing up the greatness of the family as a whole                           

       Abd al-Jabar Urguti (86b-87b)
* This guy is another innovator of a style of calligraphy.  Zia goes on for an entire page singing his praises in part because - unlike Saqi, Mavlavi Julli, Sadiq Jan - Zia was unable to copy Abd al-Jabar's style (87).
* Finally, Zia sends Abd al-Rahim ( see [[adr , Takr-i Ashr]]; I believe this is "Khial") to Urgut:                   [=]                      [=  ]             3        
* (not sure exactly what is going on here) (87b):                                           [ ]       [ ]                                                                      
* After entering Shukuri's service (see previous note), Abd al-Jabar is appointed a mudarris in Bukhara's madrasas (87b):                                                         
** Interesting: He is appointed qazi in Urgut by Muzaffar, but then continues his appointment under the Russians.
* Left this verse at the end of his writings (87b):                     []           -        -    []

       Mulla Hamdam Mudarris Katib (88)

* However, Rabi'a Makhdum is superior (?):           [] []         

     Mulla Sadiq Mudarris Katib Bukhari (88)
* Another emulator of Abu al-Jabar, though it does not say that he was one of his students.
* A good calligrapher, but not very productive:     
* Served in various capacities, including (unusually) muhtassib:       

      Mulla 'Ivaz Baqi Muhammad Urguti (88)
* Young, studied in Bukhara:          
* (cont.) during the holidays would return to Urgut to study under Abu al-Jabar, working for him:            
* Until eventually he found employment as a qazi under the Russians:           
* Lived out his life in this appointment (?):

       Abd al-Halim Jan Makhdum (92)
* Brother of Abd al-Na'imjan
* Neither he nor his brother were innovators, though they were good:

* Lived in the age of Muzaffar:          
* Wrote in Nastaliq without innovation.
* Not sure what this compliment means precisely; Zia has a copy of his Jung manual:                                           

Other children of Niazqul:                                            
* Served as secretaries under Haydar:                   
* Notable works produced:                      
** //note which books Haydar saw fit to commission//

      Mirza Sadiq Munshi Katib (92 - name only; entire text on 92b)

         Nasr al-Din Baysuni "Muhaqqiq Tusi" (93b)

      Mulla Sayyid Ahmad Katib (93b)

** Of them this guy is the third most skilled:                         
* Died young

      Damulla Faziljan Katib (93b)
* A famous alim from the time of Haydar and Nasrallah:

      Shahab al-Din Makhdum Katib (93b)

* Lived in the time of Abd al-Ahad:           
* One of the best calligraphers of his time.  Also pious like his father:           

     Mulla Hayyat "Pahlavan" Katib (93b)

Shar'i, Tazkirat al-Shu'ara-i Haji Azim Shar'i (    )
* In comparison with the other poetical tazkirat, there are fewer poets considered here but with much longer biographies.

** The author is the grandson of Abd al-Wahid Sadr Sarir Balkhi.

The Original Text
* Although the title is framed as specifically about the poets, the introduction ( ) clarifies that it is about the ulama much more broadly (10):                              
* Memories of the original Persian poets (10-11):                          .                  :        []      

>Abdallah Khwjah Abd. Takirat al-Shuar- Abdallah Khwjah Abd (al-Biruni 64)

//Note:// Most of these individuals are also mentioned in [[Muhtaram|j Nimatallah, Takirat al-Shuar-i Mutaram (al-Biruni 2252 II)]] (which I have mined most thoroughly, [[Afzal Pirmasti|Afl al-Takr fi ikr al-Shuar va al-Ashr (al-Biruni 2303)]], and [[Hashmat|ashmat, Takirat al-Shuar (al-Biruni 2728, 61)]]; I will make a note of it if this tazkirat is the first time I am seeing an individual.  I am also only taking note of new information.
* Generally, Abdi seems to be worse for death dates than Muhtaram, but better for madrasa specifics and ancestry.

* Also apparently involved in cannons (169b):                           [

Nahi (169b-170)    
* //not in the other tazkirats//
* Originally from Badakhshan (169b):                      

Nur (170-171b)
* Opening - mudarris and imam of Baba-yi Al (170):                   
* Came from Urgench to study in Bukhara (170):                
* On his zikr circle (170-171b):                                   [] 
* revisit rest of p. 171b - difficult to make out.

Nazifi (p. 171b)
* Opening:                    
* //note: not in other tazkirats, but not added to the database because his name is unclear and there is so little info in the entry//

Nazim (aka Bibak) (171b-172b)          
* Family background  (172):           
* His former takhallus is Bibak, who is [[discussed by Vazih|Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]] (172):                             
* Long description of a mystical dream (172-172b).

Nuzhat (181-183)       
* //not mentioned in other tazkirats//
* After finishing his studies taught at Fathallah Qushbigi madrasa (181):                                             

Vahshi
* From Kulab (183):                       
* (cont.) Mudarris and Qazi (183-183b):              [ ]            []     
** //can't identity the location of his qaziship//
* (cont.) Personality (183b):                 

Vazih (184)

Yahya  
* Also mentioned in [[Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]] in a list of ulama who fought against Russia with Muzaffar.
* Descended from Sayyid Ata (191):        
* (cont.) Full name (191b):         
* (cont.) Taught by Chappa Navis (191b):              
* (cont.) Career in madrasa teaching; continued to teach even when his body was ruined by an illness (191b):                [ ]           []                
* He was very poor and stayed away from worldly employment (191b):          ...          []       

Yaghma (192) 
* No real information, not even his real name.



[[Tazkirat Index]]

> Takirat-i arat Majb Namangn

SVR 3 p. 374, 2714; 2662/II
* Title:     SVR translation of title: ,    
** "...      "
** //Note: DeWeese directed me toward this work identified as Tazkira Tahiri; the SVR index directed me to this source, but the reason for the Tahiri title is unclear//
* Author:       
* Father of this author has a poetry divan no. 1046.
* Probably written in the second half of the 18th century since much of the data relates to the times of Rahim Khan and Shah Murad, though there is information from the Ashtarkhanids as well.
* Transcribed in 1335 / 1917.
* 120 lists,: 13a-132a
* Used in Bakhtiar Babadzhanov, On the History of the Naqshbandiya Mujaddidiya in Central Mawarannahr in the Late 18th and Early 19th Centuries, in Muslim Culture in Russia and Central Asia from the 18th to the Early 20th Centuries, ed. Anke von Kugelgen, Michael Kemper, and Allen Frank (Berlin: Klaus, Schwartz, Verlag, 1998). (//though no footnotes past folio 60//)

Opening - his purpose is to write about the lesser-known dervishes here:                                                     

Mulla Khwajah Ishan Namangani
* Full name, got his mojo from his father (14):                             
* (cont.) Transmission of his information (14):                               
* (cont.) Tale of Ivaz A'ma and Rahim Khan (14-14b):                                                                       

Story about a Tashkandi Sufi in love (36b-38)
* Opening - he was a student of ilm, so naturally he should go to Bukhara, but he did not make it there (36b):    []                     []                       

Story about rain prayers (80)

Story about Satanic possession in a madrasa (80-80b)
*  -                                                     

Story involving Turki language (revisit) (80b)

Story involving contact with Hindustan (82)




Being an attempt to get a handle on the Arabic texts (generally legal) that qazis and muftis would most frequently consult drawing on my primary sources and select secondary ones.

!!!Kenichi Isogai, Seven Fatwa Documents from Early 20th Century Samarqand: The Function of Mufti in the Judicial Proceedings Adopted at Central Asian Islamic Court. Annals of Japan Association for Middle East Studies 27, no. 1 (July 2011): 259282.  ([[Notes|file:///C:/Users/James/Documents/Academics/Academic%20Notes%20(TiddlyWiki)/Transoxiana.html]])
* Note: "SVR" refers to [[Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]]
* 'Ala al-Din b. 'Ali b. Muhammad al-Haskafi (d. 1677), al-Durr al-Mukhtar [Brockelmann v. 2: 311]
* 'Ali b. Muhammad 'Ali b. Mahmud al-Mukhtari al-Khwarazmi al-Kubrawi (16 c.), Fatawa al-Shaybani [SVR v.8: 290-296]
* Fakhr al-Din al-Hasan b. Mansur al-Uzjandi al-Farghani Qadikhan (d. 1196), Fatawa Qadikhan [Brockelmann v.1: 376]
* 'Abd al-'Ali b. Muhammad b. al-Husayn al-Barjandi (16 c.), Sharh Mukhtasar al-Wiqaya [SVR v. 4: 241-242]
* Hafiz al-Din Muhammad b. Muhammad b. al-Bazzazi al-Herderi (ca. 1424), al-Fatawa al-Bazzaziya [Brockelmann v.2:225; Brockelmann s.2: 316]
* Niyaz Muhammad Mufti al-Bukhari, Bahr al-Manafi' [SVR v.11: 310]
* Abu Bakr Ahmad b. 'Umar al-Shaybani al-Khassaf (d 874), Kitab Adab al-Qadi [Brockelmann v.1: 173].  //Isogai comments: "identification doubtful"//
* al-Husayn b. Muhammad al-Sam'ani al-Hanafi (14c.), Khazinat al-Muftin [Brockelmann v.2: 163]
* Fakhr al-Din 'Uthman b. 'Ali b. Mihjan al-Bari'i al-Zayla'i (d. 1342), Tabyin al-Haqa'iq or Sharh Kanz al-Daqa'iq [Brockelmann v.2: 78; Brockelmann s.2: 265]
* 'Ubaydallah b. Mas'ud Sadr al-Shari'a al-Thani al-Mahbubi (d. 1346), Sharh al-Wiqaya [Brockelmann v.1: 377; SVR v.4: 232-233]
* Abu al-Fath Rukn al-Din b. Husam al-Din al-Mufti al-Naguri (before 1666), al-Fatawi al-Hammadiya [Brockelmann s.2: 605]
* 'Ubaydallah b. Mas'ud Sadr al-Shari'a al-Thani al-Mahbubi (d. 1346), al-Nuqaya [Brockelmann v.1: 378]
* Shaykh Nizam et al. (17 c.), Fatawi 'Alamgiri [Brockelmann v. 2: 417; SVR v. 4: 293-294]
* Shams al-Din Muhammad al-Kuhistani (16 c.), Jami' al-Rumuz [Brockelmann v.1: 378]
* Kabir b. Kabir b. Kabir al-Dizaqi al-Samarqandi (14 c.), Fatawa al-Kabiri [SVR v.8: 282-284]

!!!Garaeva, N.G. Murad Ramzi (1855-1934). In Iz Istorii Almetevskogo Regiona, 1:187198. Almetevsk: Izdatelstvo Tatpoligraf, 1999.
* Students often studied commentaries of - by al-Nafisi and  - (189).
*  - -- a commentary on  - by  - - (189). 

[[Master Index]]
[[Khoqand Chronicles Index]]

Pulled in part from Sela's chronology.

!!!Bukharan Chronicles Timeline
* 1747 Abd al-Rahman Tali: __Tarikh-i Abul Fayz Khan__ [P., Bukh.] 
** Semenov translation, Tashkent 1959 (Storey-Bregel p. 1149, 1005) [[Tali, Istoriia Abulfeiz-khana]]
* 1719-48 Mir M. Salim: __Silsilat al-salatin__ [P., Bukh.] * 
* 1745-68/9 M. Vafa Karminagi: __Tuhfat al-khani__ [P., Bukh.] * 
** Excerpt translated into Russian (Storey Bregel p. 1150, 1007).
** Four copies at al-Biruni: Semenov 1 p. 77, 195-199; 16, 2721, 2726/III, 1508, 615/III ; best quality is probably 2721 [[Muhammad Vif- Karmnag, Tuhfat al-Khn (al-Biruni, 2721)]]
** [[Mirzoev|Mirzoev and A. M. Boldyrev, eds., Katalog vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii Nauk Tadzhikskoi SSR]] 1, p. 101; 105, 1426/1.
* 1785 M. Sadiq Jandari: __Dakhma-i shahan__ [P., Bukh.] * Janid rulers repenting 
* 1797 Mirza Badi Divan: __Majma al-arkam__ [P., Man.] 
** Excerpt included in [[Levi Sela volume|Levi and Ron Sela, eds., Islamic Central Asia: An Anthology of Historical Sources]]
** Used by: Bregel, The Administration of Bukhara Under the Manghits
** According to Ilyor Karimov, A.B. Vil'danova has a full Russian translation of this.
* 1800 M. Sharif b. M. Naqi: __Taj al-tavarikh__ [P., Bukh.] *  [[Link to Notes|Mulla Muhammad Sharif, Taj al-Tawarikh (IVANRUz 2092)]]
** ",  ,          ,   (. 295  ,)   - (1148/1736-1160/1747) "        "...         , ,     ,                " (Semenov 1, 85).
** Mirzoev 1, p. 105; 109, 2282.
** Used by: Bregel, The Administration of Bukhara Under the Manghits
* 1818 Abd al-Karim Bukhari: __Afghan va Kabul__... [P., Bukh.] 
** Transcribed by Charles Schefer, 1873.
* 1822 Fazli Namangani: __Umar-nama__ [P., Ferg.]*
* 1822 Mushrif Isfaragi: __Shah-nama-i Umar-khani__ [P., Ferg.]* 
* 1826 Muin: __Tarikh-i avail i avakhir__ [P., Bukh.]
** Mirzoev 1, p. 96; 100, 629.
* 1778-1829 Munis historian of Khiva [& Agahi, Firdaws al-iqbal, T., 1805-42]
* 1826 __Tarikh-i Amir Haidar__ [P., Bukh.]* 
** Semenov has a full translation of this work - but unpublished and probably in Dushanbe (Semenov 1, 86).
* 1824-30 M. Yaqub: __Gulshan al-muluk__; (1828-30) __Risalah__ [P., Bukh.] * 
** (Gulshan) Mirzoev 1, p. 104; 108, 2663.
** [[Risla-i Muammad Yaqb Bukhr]]
** [[Notes on a Petersburg copy|Muhammad Yusuf Munshi, Tarikh-i Muqim Khan and Gulshan al-Muluk (V 681)]]
* 1830s Husayn b. Shah Murad: __Mahazin al-taqwa__ [P., Bukh.]* 
* 1830s Mir Alim Bukhari: __Fath-nama-i sultani__ [P., Bukh.] [[Link to notes|Risla-i Muammad Yaqb Bukhr]]
** Semenov 1, p. 87; 218, 1838.
** Author was ordered to produce this work by Mhammad Alim-bek to glorify his polity.  Covers the deeds of Shah-Murad, Haidar, and Nasrulla (Semenov 1, 87).
* 1842-3 M. Hakim Khan: __Muntakhab al-Tavrkh__ [P., Ferg] [[Link to notes|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]
** Semenov 1, p. 88; 219, 592
** This work is by the son of Sa'id Mas'um Khan and focuses on Kokand, but is a general work as well.  " ,              ,   " (Semenov 1, 88).
** In addition to a Dushanbe facsimile, there seems to be an edited edition (though it was in a display case and I could not look inside): Muhammad Hakim Khan, Muntakhab al-Tawarikh, Selected History, Research Institute for Languages and Cultures of Asia and Africa, ILCAA 2009.  [[Link|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842]]
* 1845 Shigavul: __Tarikh-i Ali Quli__
* 1860 Mirza Shams Bukhari: __Bayan-i bad-i khawadisat-i Bukhara__ [P., Bukh.] 
** Translation: V.V. Grigor'evyi, O nekotorykh" sobytiiakh" v" Bukhare, Kokande i Kashgare (Kazan: Universitetskaia tipografiia, 1861).  Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond: -10597.
** A nice Tehrani edition: [[Shams Bukharayi, Tarikh-i Bukhara, Khuqand va Kashghar]], ed. Muhammad Akbar Ashiq (Tehran: Ayinah-i Miras, 1998).
* 1860-1869 [[Mr Salmn Samarqand, Tafsl wa Bayn-i Dawlat-i Jamat-i Manghit (IVRSP C 667)]]
* 1867-8 Avaz M. Attar: __Tuhfat al-tavarikh-i khani__ [P., Ferg.]* 
* 1860s Thanai: __Tavarikh-i khorezm shahi__ [T.] 
* 1871-2 Niyaz M. b. Ashur M. Khoqandi: __Tavarikh-i Shahrukhiyya__ [P., Ferg.] 
* 1871-2 [[Dhikr-i Trkh-i Ab al-Fay Khn (Anonymous) (IVRSP C 667)]]
* 1862-87 M. Salih Khoja Tashkandi: __Tarikh-i Jadida-ye Tashkent__ [P., Ferg.]
** Unpublished, but partially transcribed by Babajanov: http://zerrspiegel.orientphil.uni-halle.de/t386.html
* 1895-1897 Ahmad Danish (Ahmad b. Mir Nasir b. Yusuf al-Hanafi al-Sidiqi al-Bukhari): __Tarjimat al-ahwal-i amiran-i Bukhara-i sharif az amir Daniyal ta 'asr-i amir 'Abd al-Ahad__
** Iusupova p. 214; 586, 1987.  Iusupova has a detailed biography of the author.
** ff. 22a-23b, 29a-b describes the uprising of madrassa students against the Amir (Babajanov, "Foreword," 18).
** Translation: .. , "   '  ' Dushanbe, 1967.
** Mirzoev 1 p. 109; 113, 572. 
* late 1800s [[Tarikh-i Muhammad Sidiq Hashmat (al-Biruni 2663/III)]]
* early 1900s Alim Khoja b. Mirza Sayyid Khoja Mushrif Bukharai: __Ta'rikh-i Amiran-i Manghit-i Bukhara__
** A general history of the late Manghit period.
** Mirzoev 1, p. 120; 123, 2354/IV.  "...          ()..." (p. 121).  
* 1901/1906-7 Abd al-Azim Sami: __Tuhfa-i shahi__ [P., Bukh]*; __Tarikh-i salatin-i manghitiyya__ [P., Bukh.]
** (Tarikh-i) Mirzoev 1, p. 116; 120, 786/II.
** Tuhfa-i shahi: Semenov 1, p. 92; 236, 1458/II
** Dissertation housed at the library next to al-Biruni has Russian translation of the latter: L.M. Epifanova, Neofitsial'naia versiia istorii Bukhary Mirzy 'Abdalazima Sami 'Ta'rikh-i salatin-i mangitiia dar as-saltana-i Bukhara-i Sharif.  Dissertation, Akademia nauk Uzbekskoi SSR, Institut Vostokovedeniia, Tashkent, 1959.
* 1885-1910 Muhammad Sadiq Khoja Gulshani 'Abdul'l Ahad: __Tarikh-i Humayun-i Gulshani__.  [[link to notes|Trkh-i Humyn-i Gulshan, 1328]]
** Institute of Oriental Studies and Written Heritage in Dushanbe, the late Amriyazdon Alimardonov was working on publishing it.  (Ref. Gross - see note).
* 1911-14 M. Yusuf Beg Bayani: __Shajara-i khorezm shahi__ [T., Khorezm] 
* 1920 M. Salim Bek Salimi: __Tarikh-i Salimi__ [P., Bukh.]
** Semenov 1, p. 93: 237, 2016.
** Used by: Wennberg, An Inquiry into Bukharan Qadimism
** Full translation: N.K. Norkulov, 'Tar'ikh-i Salimi' - Tsennyi istochnik po istorii Bukharskogo emirata 1860-1920 gg. (Tashkent: Akademiia Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR, Institut Vostokovedeniia, 1968).
* 1923-27 Muammad  Al  ibn-i Muammad  Sayyid  Baljuwn,  Tarkh-i  Nf,  ed.  Ahror Muxtorov (Dushanbe, 1994) in the Arabic script.
** Used by: Fragner, Traces of Modernisation and Westernisation? Some Comparative Considerations concerning Late Bukhran Chronicles" (2005).
* Sharif-jan Makhdum-i Sadr-i Ziya.  __Ruznamih__
** Used by: Dudoignon, Faction struggles among the Bukharan ulama during the colonial, the revolutionary and the early Soviet periods (1826-1929)
** Partial translation: Sharf Jn Makhdm [[adr Ziy et al., The Personal History of a Bukharan Intellectual]] (Leiden: Brill, 2004).
* [[adr , Trkh-i Saln Uthmn va Nasab-i Ishn (al-Biruni 1304-II)]]
** Inappropriately named - in fact covers Transoxiana, Iran, Afghanistan, and Russia
* 1931-1932: Hamid Bakaef: __Muntakhab-i Ta'rikh-i Amiran-i Manghit__
** Mirzoev 1, p. 123; 124, 1329.  "...       1285/1868 .         ..." (p. 123).

[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]

> Fond 933. Tiurkskie rukopisi. Novaia seriia. Opis' fonda.  Leningrad, 1985.  Gosudarstvennaia Ordena Trudovogo Krasnogo Znameni Publichnaia Biblioteka im. M. E. Caltykova-Shedrina.  Otdel rukopisei

Many of the contents of this opis are 19th century Turkchi translations of Persian works.  Here I am merely jotting down some notes to get a sense of which works were being translated. I didn't record the individual volumes, but there is loads of Alisher Navoi.  Translations directly from Arabic or Turkish to Uzbek are fewer, but not absent.  293 entries total.

//Note: the original opis uses Cyrillic diacriticals, but instead I doubled vowels to indicate a long vowel.  I have not yet to determine if the author indicates the translator or the original.//

* 6. .  . . . . " -", . -    -.  1868-1869.
* 14. .  . . . . " -," .    -. 1846-1850.
** Also: #27 (1860-1861)
* 16. " -" - .  . . . . "-". .  - -.  1868-1869.
* 19. .  . . . . "- ", .  - .  1868-1869.
* 21. .  . . . . " - ", . -- .  1860-1862.
* 23. "-  - .  . . . . "-  ", .  --    .  1852-1853.
* 72. .  . . . . " -" .   .  1852-1853.
* 78. .  . . . . " -  ' -". .  -    -.  1861-1862.
** //I pulled this manuscript but did not see any information about its origins//
* 80. "- " - .  . . . . "- ". .  -.  1862 - 1863.
* 94. .  . . . . " " .        .  XIX .
* 95. .  . . . . .  XIX .
** Also #97 1869-1870.

[[Master Index]]

!!Translated from Persian (or Chaghatai)
* [[Materialy po istorii Ura-Tiube (trans Mukhtarov)]]
* [[Levi and Ron Sela, eds., Islamic Central Asia: An Anthology of Historical Sources]]
* [[adr Ziy et al., The Personal History of a Bukharan Intellectual]]


[[National Archives of India Index]]

Foreign Department 1841, Secret, Consultation 12 July, No. 44-46

To H. Maddock Esquire, Secretary to the Government of India Fort William
[From] [?] Cabool 11 June 1841
* "2. It may be hoped therefore that the Ameer of Bokhara will be relieved of any suspicions which he might otherwise have sustained of the security of our professions, and that the tranquility of Turkestan will be no further disturbed" (1).


!!!Translation of a letter from the Meer Walee of Khoolloom to the Envoy and Minister at Cabool (p. 5)
* "My movements of late have been been guided solely by my zeal in the service of the British Government. With regard to the affairs of Bulkh, I had obtained possession of that City, although I knew that it was a morsel for me to devour, yet the affair was finished, the Army of the King of Bokhara which had arrived at [Mudluns], had retired in disappointment and had [recrossed] the Oxus, the inhabitants of the Country, rich & poor, were enjoying peace and happiness and [praying] for the prosperity of his Majesty Shah Shoojah and the British Government" (5).
* (cont.) "The respectable Khajeh Nukeeb, who formerly was Governor of Bulkh but having been removed from that Office has been for some time past residing at Bokhara, has in consequence of late occurrences been sent as Governor of Akcheh" (5).
* "Now that I have received your commands to the effect that the British Government is on terms of peace and amity with the King of Bokhara, and requires me to make peace with that monarch, I have sent for the above mentioned Khojeh Nukeeb and the [Behee?] of the King of Bokhara, and have made over to them the four forts, namely, [Chehl Guzzee (the Citadel of Bulkh), Mukhluns, Douluhabad, and Chooehik].  Of these four they have restored to me the fort of [Dowlhhabad] which I have garrisoned with my own people 

!!!Abstract Translation of a Letter from the Envoy and Minister to the address of the Meer Walee of Khooloom dated June the 11th 1841 (p. 7)
* "Your former proceeding in attacking Bulkh and bringing down upon yourself the enmity of the ruler of Bokhara was not sanctioned either by His Majesty or the British Government and was not therefore agreeable to either" (7).
* "I now am satisfied that your former proceeding was really undertaken with a view to the benefit of His Majesty and the British Government" (7).
* "I take this opportunity of acquainting you that Major [Pottinger] the gallant defender of Herat against the Persians has been appointed by His Majesty to fill the place of the lamented [Dr. Sord?].  I trust that you will occasionally favor him with your correspondence" (8).

[[Master Index]]

* [[Safarnmah-i Q Hd Khwjah az Bukhr bah Irn (al-Biruni 5255/XVIII)]]
* [[Muhammad Fazil Khan, Tarikh-i Manazil-i Bukhara (trans. Siddiqui)]]
* [[Sirj al-Dn Bukhr, Tufah-i Ahl-i Bukhr (al-Biruni 2142)]]

* [[Beneveni, Poslannik Petra I na vostoke: Posolstvo Florio Beneveni v Persiyu i Bukharu v 1718-1725 godakh]]
* [[Lal, Travels in the Panjab, Afghanistan, & Turkistan, to Balk, Bokhara, and Herat]]

Drawn in part from the introduction to I.M. Muminov, ed., Istoriia Bukhary s drevneishikh vremen do nashikh dnei (Tashkent: Izd-vo "Fan" Uzbekskoi SSR, 1976).

* Histoire General des Voyages ou Nouvelle Collection de Toutes les Relations de Voyages Parmeret Par Terre (Paris, 1749.  Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond:  3155 9.
** The 9th volume of this massive, French-language set is devoted exclusively to Central Asia.  on p. 176-177 is the first European description of an Uzbek man and woman. 
* Mir Izzat Ulla 1812-1813
** Translated in 1957 by Iu.A. Sokoloev.  (Muminov, 11).
* [[Meiendorf, Otryvok" iz" puteshestviia v" Bukhariiu, 1821]]
* "Nekotoriia svedeniia o Bukharii," Otechestvennyia zapiski, Pavl Svin'inyi, vol. 6.  St. Petersburg, 1821.
** Very basic, cut and try data.  Possible that this is also just based entirely off the Meiendorf expedition.
** Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond:  1980 2.
* Noveishee opisanie Velikoi Bukharii, in Aziiatskii Vestnik" (St. Petersburg: Grigorii Spasskii, 1825).
** Not clear what this source is exactly; author not listed.
* P.I. Demezon, 1833. 
** Unpublished as of 1976, but discussed in N.A. Khalfin, Rossiia i khanstva Srednei Azii, p. 236-239  (Muminov, 12).
* V.A. Pereovskii, 1836.
** Visited Bukhara with a merchant caravan; fluent in Uzbek.  Unpublished description in , , 67, No. 103  (Muminov, 12).
* A.A. Leman, K.F. Butenev, 1841-1842.  Expedition leader N.V. Khanikov, "Opisanie Bukharskogo khanstva (1843).
** Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond:  8493
** Naturalist Leman who wrote a great deal about education in Bukhara (Muminov, 12).
* [[Vambery, Travels in Central Asia]] 1864 (?)
** See also E. Shuiler" / Schuyler, "Na skol'ko dostoverny razskazy Vambery o Srelnei Azii (Turk. Sbornik T. 81, p. 437; Znanie, 1873, No. 10).
* V.P. Baturin, 1869.  
** Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond: V.P. Baturin, "Poezdka v" Bukharu" (Turk. Sbornik T. 24, p. 83; Russk. Vestnik" 1875 no. 6).
* L.F. Kostenko, 1870.
** Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond: L.F. Kostenko, "Puteshestvie v" Bukharu russkoi missii v" 1870 godu.  S" marshrutom" ot" Tashkenta do Bukhary," (Turk. Sbornik T. 32, p. 239).
* I.L. Iavorskii, 1878-1879. I.L. Iavorskii, Puteshestvie russkago posol'stva po Avganistanu i Bukharskomu khanstvu v" 1878-1879 gg., 2 vols. (St. Petersburg: Tipografiia d-ra M.A. Khana, 1882).
** Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond:  1716
* G.A. Arendarenko, 1880.  G.A. Arendarenko, Bukhara i Afganistan v nachale 80-kh godov XIX veka (zhurnaly komandirovok G.A. Arendarenko), ed. B.G. Gafurov (Moscow: Izd. "Nauka" Glavnaia redaktsiia vostochnoi literatury, 1974).
** Alisher Navoi Redkii Fond:  11473.
** Sent on a political mission by Kaufman and related to British encroachment.
* V.P. Nalivkin, 1880s-1910s.  Many publications, most about Kokand / Fergana.
* N.P. Ostroumov, 18802-1910s.  More of an Islamoved than a traveler.
* V.I. Lipskii, 1896-1897. Gornaia Bukhara: Rezul'taty trekhletnikh" puteshestvii v" Sredniuiu Aziiu v" 1896, 1897 i 1899 godu, 2 vols. (St. Petersburg: Tipo-Litografiia "Gerol'da", 1902).
** More of a naturalist, really, but might have some ethnographic notes anyway.
* Logofet, 1911(?).  D. Logofet, Bukharskoe khanstvo pod russkim protektoratom, 1911.  //Many other publications as well.//

!!!Sela's List

Late Uzbek Period:
* Abbott, James. Narrative of a Journey from Heraut to Khiva, Moscow, and St. Petersburgh, during  the  late Russian Invasion of Khiva, with some account of the court of Khiva and the  kingdom of Khaurism (London: W. H. Allen, 1884).
* Atkinson, Thomas Witlam. Oriental and western Siberia: a narrative of seven years' explorations and adventures in Siberia, Mongolia the Kirghis steppes, Chinese Tartary, and part of Central Asia (London: Hurst and Blackett, 1858).
* Burnes, Alexander. Travels into Bukhara: Being an Account of a Journey from India to Cabool, Tartary and Persia (Philadelphia: Carey & Hart, 1835).
** //also on this expedition//: [[Lal, Travels in the Panjab, Afghanistan, & Turkistan, to Balk, Bokhara, and Herat]]
* Conolly, Arthur. Journey to the North of India, overland from England, through Russia, Persia, and Affghaunistaun (London: R. Bentley, 1834).
* Ferrier,  J.  P.  Caravan journeys and wanderings in Persia, Afghanistan, Turkistan, and Beloochistan (London, J. Murray, 1856).
* Khanykov, N. V. Bokhara; Its Amir and Its People. Translated from Russian by the Baron Clement A. de Bode, London: J. Madden, 1845.
* Meiendorf, Yegor Fiodorovich.  Journey of  the Russian mission  from Orenbourg to Bokhara, translated by Colonel Monteith (Madras: Spectator Press, 1840).  
** [[Link to my notes from the original Russian|Meiendorf, Otryvok" iz" puteshestviia v" Bukhariiu, 1821]]
* Muravyov, Nikolay. Journey to Khiva:  through  the Turkoman  country  (London: Oguz Press, 1977).
* Russian Missions into the Interior of Asia  (London:  R.  Phillips,  1823).  [including  Nazaroff, Eversmann, and Muraviev]
* Shaw, Robert. Visits to high Tartary, Yarkand, and Kashgar (Hong Kong; New York :  Oxford University Press, 1984. [Reprint. Originally published: London : J. Murray, 1871].Page 5 of  6
* Stirling, Edward Hamilton. The journals of Edward Stirling in Persia and Afganistan 1828-1829, edited by Jonathan L. Lee (Naples:  Istituto  Universitario Orientale, Dipartimento di Studi Asiatici ; Rome : Istituto Italiano per il Medio ed Estremo Oriente, 1991).
* The Country of the Turkomans: An Anthology of Exploration from the Royal Geographical Society (London: Oguz Press, 1977).
* Vambery, A. Travels in Central Asia. London, 1864; New York: Arno Press, 1970.
* Wolff, Joseph. Narrative of a mission to Bokhara (New York, Arno Press, 1970). [Reprint of the 1845 ed., published under title: Narrative of a mission to Bokhara, in the years 1843-1845, to ascertain the fate of Colonel Stoddart and Captain Conolly]. 

Under Russian Rule:
* Burnaby, Fred. A  ride  to Khiva  :  travels and adventures  in Central Asia  (London:  Century Publishing : Gentry Books Limited, 1983. [Reprint of the 1877 ed.]
* Hedin, Sven. Through Asia (London : Methuen & Co., 1899).
* Lansdell, H. Russian Central Asia, including Kuldja, Bokhara, Khiva and Merv (London: S. Low, Marston, Searle and Rivington, 1885).
* MacGahan, J.A. Campaigning on the Oxus, and the Fall of Khiva (London: Sampson Low etc., 1874).
* O'Donovan, Edmund. The Merv Oasis (New York, Arno Press, 1970). [Reprint of the 1882 ed.]
* Schuyler, Eugene. Turkistan: Notes on a Journey in Russian Turkistan, Khokand, Bukhara, and Khiva (New York: Scribner, Armstrong & Co., 1877), 2 v.
20th Century Travel:
* Byron,  Robert.  The  road to Oxiana  (London:  Picador,  1994)  [Originally  published:   London: Macmillan, 1937.]
* Christie, Ella R.  Through Khiva  to golden Samarkand;  the  remarkable  story of a woman's adventurous journey alone through the deserts of Central Asia to the heart of Turkestan (London,1925).
* Fleming, Peter. News from Tartary: a journey from Peking to Kashmir (New York: C. Scribner's sons, 1936).
* Hopkirk, Kathleen. A traveller's companion to central Asia (London: John Murray, 1993).
* Maillart, Ella. Turkestan solo : one woman's expedition from the Tien Shan to the Kizil Kum (London; Toronto, 1985. [Originally published: London: Putnam, 1934).
* Meakin, Annette M. B. In Russian Turkestan; a garden of Asia and its people (London: G. Allen, 1903).
* Moorhouse, Geoffrey. Apples in the snow: a journey to Samarkand (London: Hodder & Stoughton,1990).
* Nazarov, Pavel Stepanovich. Hunted through Central Asia (Edinburgh, Blackwood, 1932).
* Olufsen, Ole. The emir of Bokhara and his country (Copenhagen, Gyldendal, Nordisk forlag, 1911.
* Stein, Aurel. On ancient Central-Asian tracks; brief narrative of three expeditions in innermost Asia and northwestern China (New York: Pantheon Books [1964]
* Thubron, Colin. The lost heart of Asia (London: Heinemann, 1994).

[[Card Catologue - Alisher Navoi Rare Books Collection]]

General Comments
* A bi-weekly supplement to [[Bukhara-i Sharif|Bukhara-i Sharif (1912 Farsi newspaper, Navoi F-72)]] (from no. 1 Sreda 11-go Iiulia 1912):            
** //note: the catalog lists it as tri-weekly, but the newspaper itself is clearly marked as bi-weekly//
* Tagline (from no. 1 Sreda 11-go Iiulia 1912):                
* Turkey news factors much earlier and more prominently in this newspaper than in Bukhara-i Sharif, and does not even have Iran-specific news section.

!!!No. 9 Piatnitsa 10-go Avgusta 1912 g. 1-i god" Izdaniia
* More extensive description of the supplement (p. 1):  -  ""   " "              .  ""   " "               
* Announcement of the death of a prominent Qarshi alim in the   section (p. 2):   -                     .           .                     .       .          []                .           

!!!No. 38 Vtornik" 4-go Dekabria 1912 g.
* Qazi appointment and depositions in   section (p. 3):    -                
* Death and replacement of a Samarkand qazi (//check//) in the   section (p. 3): -            25                         .   

!!!No. 39 Chetverg" 6-go Dekabria 1912 g.
* Soldier punished for alcohol consumption in Armenian shop in the bazar with lashings -   section (p. 3):  -                       29  21       
* Reading room in Tashkent (p. 3):

[[RGIA Index]]

    -    -       (p.264)
* No date or author, but judging by the dates listed, probably written sometime in the 1890s.
* Note that this is a general description of all of Russian madrasas, including Tatarstan.  In fact, it seems to be more about Tatarstan.
* //Footnote//:         (264).
* Notes that maktab students begin studying the alphabet using the book -, the seventh part of the Koran (), and also: "...    ,       " (264).
* Who teaches?  "        " (264).
* Curriculum of the madrassa; static nature of its basis: "...  ,  ,  ,  ,   :  , ,  ,        ,  ,    .        XII-XV ,       " (264b).
* What was it like to study there? "   ,      .    ,   ,  ,   " (264b). "   ,        " (265).
** Peer instructors:  ,          ,         .     ,  ,     (265).
** Always live-in, overcrowded:   -  -       -    .  ,  ,  , ,    ,       (265).
* Madrassa professors:        ,    , ,   ,   ;      ,       ,      (265).
** The fame of certain professors occasionally attracts young students from afar.
** The student-teacher bond:  ,       ,    ,           (265).
* Courses of study often continue for 10-15 years at their home madrassa, and then another 10 elsewhere:         .      -    -  10  15,         10.  @@     ,    ,       ,        ,    ,  ,   ,   ,       ,    @@" (265).
** Footnote:          ,           16  1887 .  13512 (265).
* Colonialism - direct observation of French and English examples: , ,        ,        ,   ,   ,              ,      -      ,       -        ,      -   ..." (267).

   -      - 22  1903 -  10257 (p. 322).
* Note that this report is referring generally to Muslims throughout Russia, not just Turkestan.  Also, an author is listed at the end, but I cannot read the handwriting - something like  ...
* Like the "   ", this report also puts madrassa education at about 10 years, though notes there is no set limit (322b).
* One mudarris (//note: [[Goriachkin|Goriachkin, Doklad po gorodu Samarkandu (RGIA F1396 O1 D342)]] says otherwise//, though with special helpers:    .        ,   , ,  ,      .           ,                    .     "" (322b).
* Categories of knowledge: The report categories certain subjects within the madrassa as "secular":    , ,     -     , ,   " (322b-323).
* Occasionally one finds Russian language instruction in the madrassas, though it is taught separately from the rest and by a separate teacher:  ,  ,    ,  ,   ,  ,  ,         .               .        ,   .           ,                 " (323).
* Evolution of the madrassa curriculum: ...    -,         ,    " (323).
[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Trkh-i Humyn
Institute call number: 2968
Title:  
Author's full name:     ()  
Muhammad diq Qarvul Bgiyy (mutakhalli) Gulshaniyy Bukhriyy
Written: 1328 / 1911
Discovered: 1999 (and hence not in any of the catalogs)

Edited edition in Tajik: Jurabek Nazriev, Ta'rikhi Humoyun, Mukhammad Sodiqkhojai Gulshani, Dushanbe 2006, Pazhuhishgohi farhangi forsi-tojiki, 500 prints


This is the manuscript version of what will soon be an edited edition; the late Amriyazdon Alimardonov was working on publishing it.  This source does not seem to be listed in any of the catalogs.  Even though it is called a history, this is really more of a geography.  Much of this text is straight-up data (i.e. number of madrasas, population size); where especially interesting, I will copy down said data and elsewhere I will merely index where it can be found.  Generally, I tried to write down the proper nouns to enable easy searching later on.

!!!Introduction
1 (//note: Gulshani himself also numbers the pages starting from here, which means 1b = the author's page 2, page 2 = the author's page 3, etc.//)
* Author's father's name:     
* Author mentions that he has reviewed ( ) a work by    who wrote  
* Also mentions a Russian traveler named [[Meiendorf|Meiendorf, Otryvok" iz" puteshestviia v" Bukhariiu, 1821]] () who traveled about the region and wrote about its geography in 1820 (1228 hijri in the margin); //interesting that he uses the Christian era when referring to the travels of a Russian and the hijri everywhere else//
1b
* Remarks that in the 86 years since "Meiendorf"'s travels ago many formerly independent cities have been brought under Bukharan control:            ()                   
* Also remarks that Bukhara made great advances (  ) and that there were great changes ( ) during these years.
* The title of the book is a reference to one of Abd al-Ahad's titles:                
** //the titles they lavish upon these khans are unbelievable... they address him as a caliph//
2
* This text is arranged into 8 chapters () in accordance with the number of states () of Bukhara.

!!!Chapter 1: Bukhara and its Environs -      
2
* Opens by mentioning some of the early history of Bukhara, Qutaiba, etc. starting in the year 24 h.
2b
* Qutaiba himself built 7 mosques in Bukhara.
*  himself helped Qutaiba determine the proper direction for the qibla to face.
** Specifically, Hizr showed the qibla for the     and       , the latter of which was destroyed in an earthquake ( ).  The mosque that stands there now was constructed by Alb Arslan in 455 h.

* City length:                        
3
* Mahallas (  ) / neighborhoods: 196; each mahalla has between 1-3 mosques.

* () Population: 180,000.

* The  of ____:

15b
* The province is extremely populous and also has a lot of fruit and water.
* Province is made up almost exclusively of Uzbeks, but there are also Najib Arabs.  In a village there are also about 200 Iranians.  In the Qurghan there are some Hindu Magians, as well as some wealthy Jews.

!!!Chapter 3: Labi Ab  
27b
* This is a long thin province - east to west it is 50 farsakhs.
* It also separates Bukhara from Afghanistan and touches Khiva.
* The province is almost entirely made up of Turkmen. They are the bravest and most fervent of all Central Asia:              
* On the importance of the Amu Darya:                      .  
** Also discusses the source of the Amu Darya in the Pamirs:     
28
** The Amu Darya flows all the way to the Aral Sea ( ) which is between Astrakhan and Khiva:        
* Mentions Kirkih , which is today in Turkmenistan and called Ata Murod, named after Niyazov's father.
* This province () is divided into into 11 () districts.
[[Manuscripts Index]]
[[Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]]

General Comments
* Folios Trkh-i Khuml (al-Biruni 37) 133b-183b are identical to: [[Tarjuma-i l-i Q Juma-Qul Khaml]]
* Full length: 133b-345b; Sections V and / or VI (SVR lists VI, V actually listed on p. 133b)
* Discussed extensively in Anke von Kugelgen, Legitimatsiia sredneaziatskoi dinastii mangitov d proizvedeniiakh ikh istorikov, XVIII-XIX vv. (Almaty: Daik-Press, 2004).
** Text not written all at once: " 138-280,         ,  , ,  1252/1836-37 .  1253/1837-38 .       (280-345)   " (214).
** pages 208a-281b are about Muhammad and the rightly guided caliphs (164).
* Another independent historian is omuli (b. 1776-77, d. after 1847) who served as the judge (qi) of Urgut near Samarqand. He left an untitled work which today is known as Tri-e omuli (von Kgelgen, 2002a, esp. pp. 157-67), but the work was not much cited during omulis lifetime. The text begins with a lengthy account of how he, the son of a herdsman, overcame many obstacles to obtain a comprehensive education in the esoteric and exoteric sciences (al-olum al-hira wal-olum al-bina). omulis intellectual autobiography is followed by the biographies of his teachers and of other Sufi sheikhs who belonged to the Naqbandiya-Mojaddediya branch of Dahbed near Samarqand. The work includes a section dedicated to the Mants, with many rare details about h Mord whom omuli greatly admired. But omuli is an exception among Transoxanian historians because he discusses how in 1743 Nder Shah Afr attempted to end the Shiite-Sunnite hostilities in Najaf. omuli idealistically judged Nder Shahs political move as an effort to implement an agreement, according to which Shiites and Sunnites would cease to consider each other infidels and which would thus end sectarian violence, warfare, and bloodshed (omuli, fols. 187a-188b). From: Kungelen, BUKHARA viii. Historiography of the Khanate, 1500-1920, Encyclopedia Iranica.


!!!Historical Section (183b-
Introduction
* Opening line relating Manghit dynasty to sacred history (183b):   -                          []     
** Poem comparing Manghits to Quraysh (183b):       -      -      -      

Nadir Shah (187-189b):                         
* Opening line on Nadir Shah's religious goals (187):                                         
* (cont.) Bringing Sunnis and Shias together (i.e. convincing the Shiites to renounce their heresy) (187):                            []                                           [
* (cont.) Hadi Khwajah's participation, conclusions of the council (187-187b):                                                                                                                                                       []       
** (cont.) signing an agreement to this effect (187b-188):                                            []                         
* (cont.) Involving the Ottomans in the reform (188):                       [ ]                                                  []               
** Ottoman response (188b):                       []                                   
* Nadir's Qizilbash become suspicious that he is a closet Sunni and murder him for it (189):                                                                                                                           
* Khumuli summing up his thoughts on Nadir Shah (189b):  ]                 1252                                              

Rahim Khan and the end of Abu al-Fayz (189b-):          
* Opening - Rahim Khan left in charge of the Uzbek tribes (189b):                                                       
* (cont.) Upon hearing of the murder of Nadir Shah, Rahim orders that the news be kept secret and begins to march on Bukhara (189b-190):                           [ = ]                                                                              
* (cont.) Abu al-Fayz (190): (section on Abu al-Fayz I don't quite understand)
* The Shia commanders wish to avenge Nadir Shah (190b):        []                                                   
* The general chaos under Abu al-Fayz was so great that Nadir Shah was welcomed (192):                                                                            
* Khumuli explains the necessity of keeping a Chingissid on the throne and that Rahim took the position of Ataliq.  Then Rahim's relation to Nadir's power and incorporating Nadir's military rules (192b-193):                        [ ]          
* Hisar and the Yuz rebellion (193):                               
** //I think he subdues the rebellion, but don't fully understand the rest of this page//
* After securing Bukhara, Rahim Khan conquers the rest of Mawarannahr, but not without a fight.  Rahim Khan wins the battle, but he does not take those cities or remove the governors from power (193b-194):                                                                                                                                                                                       
* Describing the battle of four armies (see also [[Hakim Khan|Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Rahim Khan through Shah Murad]]) - Uratipa and Hisar on one side, Bukhara and Khoqand on the other - using Shahnamah terminology (194b-195):

(Shahrisabz letter - 279b)




[[Travel Literature Index]]

> Armenius Vambery, Travels in Central Asia; Being the Account of a Journey from Teheran Across the Turkoman Desert on the Eastern Shore of the Caspian to Khiva, Bokhara, and Samarcand (New York: Harper & Brothers, 1865).

See also E. Shuiler" / Schuyler, "Na skol'ko dostoverny razskazy Vambery o Srelnei Azii (Turk. Sbornik T. 81, p. 437; Znanie, 1873, No. 10).  There is actually tons of debate  over the veracity of Vambery's journey - see Turkestanskii Sbornik Ukazatel' 1 starting on p. 19.

About the author and his quest:
* Born in Hungary in 1832; became interested in Oriental languages - i.e. trying to figure out what branch Hungarian belonged to (vii).
* Spent several years in Istanbul, then decided to travel to Central Asia disguised as an effendi (viii).
* "My attention was for the most part directed to the races inhabiting Central Asia, of whose social and political relations, character, usages, and customs I have striven, however, imperfectly, to giver a sketch in the following pages" (viii).
* High adventure: "... I wandered about for months and months with only a few rags as my covering, without necessary food, and in constant peril of perishing by a death of cruelty, if not of torture" (xiii).

Getting ready to depart
* Turkey vs. Iran: "... Iran, the theme of so much poetic enthusiasm, is, after all, nothing but a frightful waste, whereas Turkey is really an earthly paradise" (23).
** "The Persian can boast a poetic organization and an ancient civilization.  The superiority of the Osmanli results from the attention he is paying to the langauges of Europe, and his disposition gradually to acquaint himself with the progress that European savans have made in chemistry, physics, and history" (23).
* Dost Muhammad was laying siege to Herat, where Vambery was heading: "Persians themselves dared not venture their wares or their lives; but there would have been far more cause for apprehension in the case of a European, whose foreign lineaments would, in those savage Asiatic districts, even in periods of peace, be regarded by an Oriental with mistrust, and must singularly displease him in time of war" (26).  This is the reason he disguised himself as a dervish.
* Ottomans and the Hajj: "It is an old custom of the Turkish embassy to accord a small subsidy to the hadjis and dervishes, who every year are in the habit of passing in considerable numbers through Persia toward the Turkish empire... The consequence was, that the hotel of the embassy received guests from the most remote parts of Turkestan" (28).
* Orientalism: "Words so unselfish proceeding from the mouth of an Oriental much surpised me" (29).
** "The Oriental does not understand the thirst for knowledge, and does not believe much in its existence" (32).
* Tajiks vs. Uzbeks: "The hostility of the Osbeg (Tartar) tribes of CEntral Asia to the Tadjiks (the ancient Persian inhabitants) had long previously been known to me..." (31).
* Bukhara's bad rep: "... Bokhara, the only city in CEntral Asia that I really feared from having learned the unhappy lot of the travelers who had peceded me tither" (32).
* How Vambery gets in with the Dervishes: "I told them, for instance, that I had long silently, but earnestly, desired to visit Turkestan (Centra Asia), not merely to see the only source of Islamite virtue that still remained undefiled, but to behold the saints of Khiva, Bokhara, and Samarcand" (32).

The Expedition Begins - Turkmen Lands
* Impression of his traveling companions (numbering 23): "... they are in reality the most honest people I shall ever meet with in those parts" (42).
* Heh - His disguise as a dervish does not really fool anyone; they can tell from his skin that he is high-born (51).
* Author runs into geopolitics before even getting out of Iran: Afghans and Turkmens in service of the Russians.  "How great, then, was my astonishment when I learned that this Afghan was ready for the voyage; that he would allow the hadjis to accompnay him, but that he objected bo my highness, whom he regarded as a secret emissary of the sultan, fearing lest he might lose his meanso f subsistence from the Russians should he venture to take such an individual on board his vessel" (54).
* More orientalism: "The Oriental, and particularly the Islamite, bred up in lies and treachery, always believes the very contrary of what a man shows particular earnestness in convincing him of..." (55).
* Russians and the Turkmen problem: "The Russian government makes, naturally, the greatest exertions and at the greatest cost to paralyze the predatory habits of the TUrkomans... The Russian ships cruise incessantly day and night in the Turkoman waters..." (60).
** Southernmost Russian possession: Ashourada.
** Turkmens in the Russian service: "Khidr Khan still continued to live in a tent in the middle of the semi-European colony; his functions consisted in using his influence with the TUrkomans generally to prevent their piracies, or at least in conveying ot the Russians intelligence of any intended expedition... This Khidr Khan, though once so good a Mussulman, had formed at an early date acquaintance with the genreous vodki (Russian brandy)..." (61).
* Slavery: Not so relative a term?  "... a Persian slave, heavily laden with chains..." (70).
** "I was astonished to find how many of my fellow-travelers, the poorest of the poor, in spite of the noble hospitality of which they had been partakers, were already weary of the Turkomans; for it would be, they said, impossible for men having the least sentiment of humanity to be eye-witnesses any longer of the cruel treatment to which the wretched Persian slaves had to submit.  'True, the Persians are heretics, and they tormented us terribly in our journey through their country; bu twhat the poor wretches here suffer is really too much'" (81-82).
** "No other termination to his sufferings than the payment of a ransom by his friends; and, failing this, he is liable to be sold, and perhaps __hurried off to Khiva and Bokhara__!" (82).
** Describes the miserable state of Russian slaves, who die in captivity (105).
* "No other termination to his sufferings than the payment of a ransom by his friends; and, failing this, he is liable to be sold, and perhaps __hurried off to Khiva and Bokhara__!" (82)
* People begin to question his Dervish-ness, suspecting he is an Ottoman agent; but then never think he is European (78).
* Reach of the Bukhara madrassas: "I found particular advantage in the friendship of Kizil Akhond (his proper name was Mollah Murad), a Turkoman 'savant' of high distinction, with whom I was upon the best footing and whose recommendtation procurred access for me everywhere.  Kizil Akhond had in his time, __when sudying in Bokhara__, fallen upon a work in the Osmanil Turkish language, a sort of comment or explanation of sentences and expressions in the Koran" (73).
* Interesting stuff about how the Turkmen use Greek bricks they find from Alexander's time to build a mosque (77).
** Goes into local Alexander myths: "According to Kizil, the wall had been erected by the genii (djinns), at the command of the mighty sovereign Alexander.  'Alexander,' he said, 'was a more pious Mussulman than we are, and therefore all subterranean spirits, whether they would or no, owed him allegiance'" (79).
* Even among the tribes, the mullah enjoys incredible respect: ""Nor was the difference great between the manner in which he was received in his own tents and those of strangers... Even in the settlments of hostile tribes he was not only treated with honorable distinction, but laden with presents..." (80).
* Vambery's is not a purely negative orientalism by any means.  One of the author's fellow hadjis was robbed in a mosque.  "After a long search in every direction, as no discovery was made, the ishan (priest) declared that he would at once utter his malediction upon the thief should he not restore the stolen property.  Before twenty-four hours had expired the conscience-stricken criminal came forward, bringing with him not only the stolen property, but a present as atonement.  I venture to recommend this practice to the London detectives as as a substitute for their present system" (80-81).
* These here parts have their own rules.  Author is about to buy himself a camel to cross the desert, "... but I was dissuaded by Hadji Bilal and Sultan Mahmoud, who remarked that an appearance of wretchedness calculated to excite compassion was the best guarantee for safety among these nomads...  They named several of the hadjis who were well provided with means, and who, nevertheless, for the sake of prudence, were obliged to wander on in rags and on foot " (87).
* The Khan of Khiva's defense is the desert itself; relates that years before a Farangi was taken to Khiva and managed to take notes of where all the wells were, which was a major security risk (118).
* Out of our minds (crossing the desert to Khiva): "This evening my appetite left me. I had not the slightest craving for even the smallest piece of bread: my sensations were those of extreme debility; the heat of the day was indescribable" (188).
* Alexander: "Quite out of breath, I fell down before the tomb, which was thirty feet long, and ornamented with rams' horns, the signs of supremacy in Central Asia" (140).
* Huge tombs: "The Orientals love to dignify their saints also with the attribute of bodily size.  In Persia I have remarked several giant graves; and even in Constantinople, on the Asiatic shore of the Bosphorous, on the so-called Mount of Joshua, exists a long tomb which the TUrks venerate as that of Joshua of the Bible, but the Greeks as that of Hercules" (140).
* Weak rule of the khans: "I made inquiries, and found that we were taking a circuitous way for the sake of security.  The Ozbeg met yesterday had warned us to be on our guard, for that the Tchaudors were in open rebellion against the khan, and that their alamans were often making forays on these frontiers" (147).
* Ethnicity: There is definitely an understood difference between Turkomans and Ozbegs. "Although they [Turkomans] have dwelt now several centuries side by side with the Ozbegs, they detest the manners and customs of the latter, avoid their company, and, alghouth of kindred origin and tongue, an Ozbeg is as much a stranger in their eyes as a Hottentot is in ours" (149-150).

Khiva
* "Had the Eastern poets turned their lyres here, they would have found a more worthy theme than in the horrid wastes of Persia!" (150).
* Khivan khan's reputation: "I was well aware that the Khan of Khiva, whose cruelty was displeasing to the Tartars themselves, would, in case he felt any distrust, become far severer to me than the other Turkomans.  I had heard that the khan was in the habit of at once making slaves of all strangers of doubtful character; that he had, not long before, so treated a Hindustani, who claimed to be of princely origin, and who was now, like the other slaves, employed in dragging along the artillery carriages" (151).
* Khiva and the hajj: "For years so numerous a troop of hadjis had not arrived in Khiva.  All stared us in astonishment..." (152).
* Function of the caravansarai (interesting): "In accordance with the custom of the country, we dismounted at the caravanserai.  This served also as a custom-house, where the new arrivals of men and merchandise are subjected to severe examination" (158).
* "My first step was to go to Shukrullah Bay, who, without filling any functions, occupied a cell at that time in the medresse of Mehemmed Emin-Khan, the finest edifice in Khiva" (154).
** Shakrullah Bay's reaction: "In God's name, effendi, what induced you to come to this fearful country, and to come to us, too, from that paradise on earth, from Stamboul?" (154).
* Khan addresses public grievances personally: "... crowded with petitioners of every class, sex, and age.  They were attired in their ordinary dresses, and many women had even children in their arms, waiting to obtain a hearing; for no one is required to inscribe his name, and he who has managed to force his way first is admitted" (157).
* Power of the Ottomans: "... for my personal security, I had with me a firman, bearing at the top the tugra (seal of the sultan).  I then handed him my printed pass.  On receiving this sign of paramount sovereignty, he kissed it reverently, rubbed it on his forehead, rose to place it in the hands of the khan, and, returning almost immediately, told me to step into the hall of audience" (158).
** LOL: "A man might place his life in jeopardy who should assert the fact that the sultan has head and beard shaved a la Fiesko, and clothes made for him at Paris by Dusetoye" (163).
** Too good to make up: A Khivan asks the author "... whether the great sultan really had his each day's dinner and supper forwarded to him from Mecca, and whether they passed to his palace from the Kaaba in one minute.  Ah! if the good Ozbegs only knew how much Chateau Lafitte and Margot garnished the sovereign's table in the reign of Abdul Medjid!" (164).
* Author's attitude toward the Khivan khan: "When I found myself again alone within the four walls of my cell I drew a long breath, not a little pleased to find that the khan, who in appearance was so fearfully dissolute, and who presents in every feature of his countenance the real picture of an enervated, imbecile, and savage tyrant, had behaved to me in a manner so unexceptionable; and that, so long as my time permitted, I could now traverse the khanat in all directions unmolested" (160).	
* Functionality of the mosque: "What in Europ idlers seek in coffee-houses they find in Khiva in the courts of the mosques.  These have in most cases a reservoir of water, and are shaded by the finest palms and elm-trees" (164).
* Khan considers self to be a severe defender of religion: "The khan has affixed the punishment of death not only to adultery, but to other offenses against religion, so that in the first years of his reign the ulemas were even obliged to cool his religious zeal..." (168).
* Reports that many of the dervishes are opium addicts (183).  "In Khiva, beng is the favorite narcotic; and many are addicted to this vice, because indulgence in wine and spiritous liqours is forbidden by the Koran, and any infringement is a sin punished by the government with death" (184).
* Khiva - Bukhara road: "Although the way between Khiva and Bokhara had been described to me as a frequented one, we had as yet, wit hthe exception of the frontier-watchers and the nomads who were roaming about, not met a single traveler" (186).

Bukhara
* Government apparatus: "In Khakemir there are but 200 houses... We were obliged to pass the night here, that the tax-collector (Badjghir) and reporter (vakanuviz), informed of our arrival in accordance with the law, might be in a position to complete their report of search and examination outside the city.  The very same day a messenger went express, and the following one, very early in the morning, arrived three of the emir's officers, with faces full of official dignity and importance, to levy upon us the imposts and duties, but more especially to learn tidings concerning the adjoining countries" (199).
** There is a bureaucratic apparatus at work here (where it its paper trail?) - "... Hadji Salih gave him explanations as to my rank, my character, as well as the object I had in view in my journey, all of which he noted down carefully, accompanying the act with a look at me and a shake of the head full of meaning.  When th ecollector had finished with us, the functions of the vakanuvisz (writer of events) began.  He first took down the name of each traveler, with a detailed description of his person, and then whatever information or news each might have it in his power to give" (200).
* The Tekkie Vambery stays at in Bukhara: "I had fallen, without having remarked it, upon the chief nest of Islamite fanaticism in Bukhara... in the tekkie the emir's orders were inoperative" (204).
* Merchandise at the bazaar: "I kept close to my companions, casting as I passed glances at the booths, which contain, with a few articles from the other countries in Europe, fancy goods and merchandise, more especially of Russian manufacture" (207).
* Description of the Naqshbandi: "... dervishes of the order of the Nakishbendi, of whom this city is the place of origin and the principle abode.  Never shall I forget that scene when those fellows, with their wild enthusiasm and thier high conical caps, fluttering hair, and long staves, danced round like men possessed, bellowing out at the same tiem a hymn, each strophe of which was first sung for them by their gray-bearded chief" (210).
** //Naqshbandi... singing and dancing?//
* Comparing Bukhara and Khiva: "They praised me, but not a farthing did I ever get from them; and the semblance of sanctity in this nation presented a singular contrast with the genuine piety and benevolence of the Khivan Ozbegs" (212).
* Conolly and Stoddart: "The sad fate of these two martyrs has continued to remain, as I remarked, a secret even in Bokhara..." (212).
* There is a book bazaar: "I then proceeded to the book bazar, which contains twenty-six shops.  A printed book is here a rarity" (215).
* Guinea worm in Bukhara? "... but another circumstance doubled my sufferings - the apprehension of the rishte (filaria Medinensis), by which, during the season, one person in ten is attacked.  This obliged me to be continually drinking warm wateror tea.  This affection is quite usual, and is treated with as much indifference by those residing in Bokhara during the summer season as colds are with us;.  one feels, at first, on the foot, or on some other part of the body, a tickling sensation, then a spot becomes visible whence issues a worm like a thread.  This is often an ell long, and it ought some days after to be carefully wound off on a reel.  This is the common treatment, and occasions no extraordinary pain; but if the worm if broken off, an inflammation ensues, and instead of one, from six to ten make thier appearance, which forces the patient to keep his bed a week, subjecting him to intense suffering.  The more courageous have the rishte cut out at the very beginning.  The barbers in Bokhara are tolerably expert in this operation." (218-219).
* Bukhara the city and Islam: "I often heard it affirmed that 'Bokhara is the true support of Islam.' The title is too weak; it should rather be termed the 'Rome of Islam,' since mecca and Medina are its Jerusalem.  Bukhara is aware of her superiority, and plumes herslelf upon it in the face of all other nations of Islam; yes, even before the sultan himself, who is yet acknowledged as the official chief of religion; but he is not so readily pardoned for having suffered so much to be corrupted in his territories by the influence of the Frenghis" (220-221).
** //Khiva, which is not competing for Islamic cred., revers the Sultan, while Bukhara holds itself superior//
* Administration: the Rais. "Each city has its reis, who, with a cat-o'-four-tails in his hand, traverses the streets and public places, examines each passer-by in teh principles of Islamism, and sends the ignorant, even if they be gray-bearded men of threescore years, for periods varying from eight to fourteen days, to the boy's school; or he drives them into the mosques at the hour of prayer" (222-223).
** "Every trace of gladness and cheerfulness is banished from those circles where the influence of religion and the system of surveillance are so tyrannically felt.  The emir's spies force their way even into the sanctuaries of families, and woe to the man who permits himself to offend against the forms of religion or the authority of the sovereign" (223).
* Religiosity of Amir Muzaffar al-Din Khan: "He carries out strictly the political principles of his father, adn in his capacity as mollah and pious Musulman is the declared enemy of every innovation, even when he may be convinced of its utility" (224).
** Portrays the lifestyle of the amir as extremely austere, destroying palaces instead of seizing them.  "The expression 'princely table' is inapplicable to Bokhara, where one and the same dish satisfies prince, official, merchant, mechanic, and peasant" (227).

[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Qr Ramat Allah ibn shr Muhammad al-Bukhr mutakhallis bih Vai, Majmua (personal notebook)

    
[[Semenov|Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]] 5, p. 420; 4147, 262

By same author:
* [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]
* [[Vi, Gharb al-Khabar fi Ajb al-Safar (al-Biruni 2106)]]

General Observations
* Vazih was a very curious fellow, it seems.  Many of these pages discuss far-off places and exotic ideas like the equator (36b) ( ).  Excerpts about different places (e.g.   - p. 38b,   p. 37b excerpted from a wide variety of texts.

Permissibility of Poetry (p. 18).

List of manuscripts copied by Vazih:        (p. 23)
