[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Qr Ramat Allah ibn shr Muhammad al-Bukhr mutakhallis bih Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b

Edited version: Vai, Qr Ramat Allah ibn shr Muhammad al-Bukhr. Tufat al-Abb Fi Takirat al-b. Edited by A. M. Mirzoev. Dushanbe: Izd-vo Donish, 1977.

General Observations
* Organized alphabetically by 
* Note that this work is paginated every page (as opposed to by leaf)

!!![[Moujani and Amr Yazdan Ali Mardan, eds., Fihrist-i Nosakh-i Khati-i Farsi-i Institui Asar-i Khati-i Tajikistan]]
     p. 112; 483
         
* Author lived 1817 - 1893. Book written 1864-1870.
* This is a poetical biography / excerpts type text. Interesting because it includes Iranian and Central Asian authors. It also includes information on a circle of Khoqandi poets.
* From this page forward there are lots of other poetical biographies as well - tons of em. About Tajik poets in the late 18th and 19th century.

!!!Introduction
* There are so many titans of the arts in Turan that they are impossible to count (p. 3):                [=]                              

!!!The Biographies (alphabetical by takhallus)
Ada:     (p. 12-14)
* death date (13): 1250
* Takhallus (12): 
* Assuming based on nisbat that he was born in Samarkand
* Father (12):    
** Judging by the nature of father's titles (  etc) he was a sufi.  Apparently a very famous one at that as the author notes that no description of his exploits is necessary:     
* Entry has a pretty ornate passage lauding the amir of Bukhara for his incredible generosity (12).
* Lived during the age of Umar Khan of Khoqand (p. 13):                  
** Apparently Umar Khan's largesse attracted him to the Khoqand court.  Gave him the title "king of the poets" (p. 14):            
* After that he returned to Bukhara and became the Shaykh al-Islam (13).
* Note that he composed poetry both in Farsi and Turki (p. 13):                            
** Particularly famous for the qasida named    (afghan, not Afghan), which was printed ( ) (p. 13).
* Ada was also reputed to have performed miracles, but the author has no examples:               
* Note: Ada is also mentioned in [[Muntakhab al-Tavarikh|Asimov (ed) Muntakhab at-Tavarikh (Dushanbe 1983 edition)]]:
** * Sufi influence on Hakim Khan: "         ( )    , ,  ,        -,     ...   ,            ,     (. 689).          ,      -    .          ,     "" ()".              " (25).

Atashi      (p. 13-16)
* Takhallus (13): 
* Noble ancestor (13):    
* In the service of (taught by) (14)      
** On Chappa Navis, see [[Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]]
* Entry makes big point of his studies (14):                                 
* Seriousness and melancholiness (sometimes from his studies) prompted him to write poetry (14).

Ansab    (p. 16-18)
* Takhallus: 
* Descended from (16):    
* Always wrote / spoke about independence, tyranny:      

Akbar   (p. 18-19)
* His actual name is  but he is known as  
* Started as a Quran reader:
* After completing his studies he became a mudarris (18):                    

Afzah    (p. 19-20)
* Takhallus:  
* Antinomian dervish (19):           

Irsi (p. 20-22)
* Takhallus: 
* Traveled from Hisar to Bukhara to study (20):        
* His wittiness gained him the attention of the rulers; he also had qalandar tendencies (20):                 

Afghan     (p. 22-24)
* This poet comes from the ranks of the amirs (22):      
** and he served as a governor (22):          
*** Khatarchi per Dehkhoda:          
**** Unclear if this province fell under Russian possession in 1868.
* Followed in the poetic tradition of Bidal (22):          
* This poet was also very much in the tradition of "beloved" poetry; he fell in love with a particular slave boy (22):                          
** Very sexual innuendo - the slave boy is so beautiful he overpowers the fortitude to resist (22):                     
** But there is a tragedy; using very flowerly language, author conveys that the boy died (23).
** The death of his beloved sent him into heartbreak (23):                     
* Broken, Afghan quit his job with the army and wrote poetry about his beloved full time (23):     

Ishan       (p. 24-26)
* Aside from holding the rank of Shaykh al-Islam, this individual is also descended from the Juybari shaykhs (24):            
* He also held two notable bloodlines on his mother's side (24-25):                                   
** Possible that  should be 
* Seems that he was very familiar with the history of the prophets, etc (25).
* His house was always filled with guests coming to visit him (25):                       
* Ishan had a habit of venturing out into the desert / field () with other intellectuals to discuss high issues (25):                     (followed by the prayer they would sing).
** @@description of Persianate high culture@@ (25):                               
* Ishan is the maternal nephew of Ata (26).

A'raj      (p. 26-29)
* Takhallus: 
* Descendant of     (p. 26).
* Was familiar with soothsaying (27):     
* Family suffered from poverty; family too big for the money to go around (27):                       
* He served as an imam and as a Masnavi Khwan (27):             
** However after a year or two at that position he had an accident and hurt his leg preventing further work (27).
** Because of his infirmity he withdrew from society and was not really heard from; now he educates children in his home (27):              

Amir       (p. 29-31)
* Takhallus: 
* Muhammad Umar Khan (ruled 1810 - 1822)
* Renowned for his generosity to poets, etc., along with an unspecified deceased Amir (29).
* This Khoqandi khan is counted among the great poets (30):          
* Wrote his own divan in Turki and Farsi (30):         

Akmal    (p. 31-33)
* Takhallus: 
* His bi-lingual works (32):                     
* He was a trusted confidant of Umar Khan (32):            

Afqar    (p. 33-37)
* Takhallus: 
* Exalted lineage (33):     
** From Dehkoda - full name:                              
*** Name of the Sufi shaykh under whom he trained (Sultan Sadr al-Din Musa d. 1291 of the Safavid order):                              
*** Sufi, Poet, scholar of the 9th century hijri:               
*** Travels; began sufi training in Herat:            
**** Also visited Balkh
*** Originally from a village near Nishapur; died 837 hijri:                             835  837  838  .  .     
* Describing his training (33):                  []               
* He was a very free person unburdened by pleasantries etc (34):         
* Composed in both Farsi and Turki (34).
* Wrote a work (a ) called   (p. 34):                      
* He was a prolific traveller; he visited the grave of Ali, for instance (35):                 
** Note that it does not say which grave of Ali he visited - Mazar-i Sharif or Iraq (35):                          
* Served as an Imam (35):                           
* Can infer that he was a member of the Qadiriyya (35).
* He was also a mudarris; gathered students to him and payed them (35):                    
* So he says a Qadiriyya prayer near his ancestor's grave (in Herat) 35

Amlah     (p. 37-39)
* Takhallus: 
* Memorized the Quran at an early age and mastered tajwid (37):        
* He is also a top-notch poet - hence his inclusion here (37).

Baqa     (p. 39-40)
* Takhallus: 
* Sayyid; the family of sayyids he came from traditionally served as ra'is, sadr, and mirasad (39):                       
** Bosworth on the ra'is in eastern Islamdom during the middle ages (EI): "... the ra'is, whether appointed by an outside ruling body or not, was not simply a salaried official of the state but the representative of his town and its interests vis-a-vis the provincial or central government, above all, over questions of the taxation due from the town, and he could reprort back to the sultan's diwan if any of the state officials were grossly abusing their power locally."
*** "The ra'is recedes from mention in the history of the Persian lands by the time of the Mongol invasions, but it should be noted that the Al-i Burhan, the line of Hanafi ru'asa' in the Transoxianian city of Bukhara, held hereditary office there from the mid-6th/12th century well into th emiddle of the 7th/13th one, with the additional title, expressive of their religious leadership also in the city, of sadr al-sudur."
* Also detailed the posts Baqa in particular held, including qazi in various provinces and ra'is in Bukhara and then qazi in Bukhara until he died (39):                                       
* Very generous in providing answers and help to those who came to him (39).

Bahar     (p. 40-41)
* Takhallus: 
* Taught in the madrasa  - possibly in Bukhara but does not specify (40).
* Was a classmate of Vazih, the author (41):      

Bibak    (p. 41-43)
* note that [[Afl al-Takr fi ikr al-Shuar va al-Ashr (al-Biruni 2303)]] has his name as "Muhammad Baqi."
* Takhallus: 
* ancestor (41):      who is counted among the great scholars of Bukhara     
* Even tough he was very rich he had no need for the material comforts of the world (41).
* Became a mudarris after finishing his studies (41-42):               
* Composed a book called  (p. 42).

Bahjat (p. 43-44)
* Takhallus: 
* A Khoqandi poet patronized by Muhammad Umar Khan (43):                 

Pari     (p. 44-45)
* Takhallus 
* Composed beatiful poetry despite his illiteracy (44):           
** Not totally certain that Vazih really means that he was illiterate; he may mean that he was simply ignorant in the science of poetry.
* Seems that he was kind of a local court poet in Hisar (44):                 \\

Parsa       (p. 45-48)
* Takhallus: 
* Is a sayyid.
* sacred lineage of Sayyid Ata, i.e. most probably Yasawiyya (45-46):                 
* Yasawi lineage allowed him the title of Naqib, Sadr inter alia (46):                                                 
** DeWeese, The Descendants of Sayyid Ata and the Rank of Naqb in Central Asia,
* In the age of the previous amir Parsa served as an Ilchi (46):                        
** According to Basir the last part of that sentence means "on top of the affairs of the province."
* In this entry Vazih relays a couple of anecdotes, which is in itself interesting:
** Describes a majlis held by Parsa in his home (46):                   
*** They discussed scholarly issues from every field (47):          
*** The point of the anecdote seems to be a play on words presented by Parsa when an individual brought up the topic of corruption brought by love of worldy things (46) ( ); he connected that phrase to         (p. 47).
*** Everyone was astonished by Parsa's erudition on this issue (46-47):             
** The second anecdote concerns a certain Indian alim (  ) who had become famous in Bukhara; seems that he refused to reveal his name or origin (47):                                    
*** The Indian alim in the face of insistence offers his name in the form of a riddle that had to do with specifying connected and disconnected Arabic letters; Parsa is so smart that he guesses the right answer immediately (Iblis) - though obviously Iblis is not his real name so Parsa solved the riddle but Hindustani kept his real name secret (47):     
**** However, his real name is , (his takhallus is , which is also in this tabaqat), which also follows the rules of the riddle, so Parsa basically scored a huge public burn on Asi (48).
* Died in 1270 (48).
* Wrote poetry in the age of "Turaki" (identity unclear) in the Bukharan province of Karmina (50): 
** 	The poem itself contains an abjad date, presumably specifying the date of the hakim's rulership of Karmina (50):             

Parsa       (p. 48-50)
* Takhallus and name: 
* Oldest son and student of (48):      
* Served as a tutor for the previous amir and another guy (Hazrat Iskandar) and as a result received high station (49):                        
** As a result he gained very high station amongst the ulama (49):                      
* Here Vazih offers a paralel story of naysaying and jealousy in Aurangzeb's court: During the era of Aurangzib (of Hindustan) Mirza Abu Talib Hakim had the title of king of the poets (49):                 
** The Indian poet's takhallus was Kilim () (p. 49).
* Much like that anecdote about India (Kilim) he had many naysayers and enemies (49):                 
* Serving as the tutor of the amir gets him appointed as the military mufti (49):                     
* Breadth of his knowledge (49):                 
* Served as an ambassador in both Ottoman and Hindustan (49-50):              

Taqi     (p. 50-54)
* Takhallus and name (50, 51): ; also known as  
* Came to Marv with the Qajar army, taken prisoner by the Turkmen, ended up in Bukhara as a slave (50):                                  
** poem comparing his bondage to that of Joseph (50):            
* Ends up in the service of the Qushbigi (50):          
* He is one of the Sayyids of Iran (50):          
* Trained in Tehran; in particular he was a calligrapher (50-51):                                  
** But also had other expertises (51):               
* Became very sick with an illness (51):                     
* When he was sick they freed him and sent him back to Iran (51).

Jalal      (p. 54-57)
* Takhallus: 
* From the Juybari guzar (but probably not from the famous family) (54):     
* Lots of poetical excerpts, but not very much biographical information.

Jalal  (p. 57-59)
* Takhallus: 
* Real name not given.  //not entered into database//
* One of Nasruddin Shah Qajar's court poets (57):         
* Wrote praise poetry () of Nasruddin (57).

Jawhar     (p. 59-61)
* Takhallus: 
* From his nisbat we know that his ancestors were probably from Marv.
* Composed divans in both Farsi and Arabic (59):         
* Wrote a qasida dedicated to Husein (59-60):                                 
** //possible Shia leanings//

Jamali      (p. 61-63)
* Takhallus: 
* Came from Khulum to study in Bukhara with his brother (61-62):          
* Extremely allegorically and poetically implies that he died while he was still young (62): 
* Jamali was on his way to the Shah to pay his respect ( ) but stayed in Karmina for some time as that was where the Amir was roosting (see Gulshani - there was a palace there) (62):                   
* Then he got permission to go to Bukhara (62). 
* Then he ended up in Hisar as well, served the hakim there, and died there (62):                       
* Student of ilm, especially riddles and poetry (63):              

Hasrat    (p. 63-64)
* Takhallus: 
* From Hisar
* Came to Bukhara for study in the time of (the rule of Amir Kabir and Sa'id) (61):            
** Amir Kabir is the title of Danial Ataliq (?) and Amir Sa'id is Haydar; most likely that he emigrated in the early 19th century.
* Died of leprosy (); his wife had to leave him as a result of this illness (61-62):                     
* His poetry was known for being heartwrenching ( ) and some of his poetry samples seem to be about his separation from his wife (62).

Haziq      (p. 63-68)
* Takhallus: 
* Note: Abd al-Vahid Sarir mentions Haziq in [[his notebook|Qazi Abd al-Vahid Sarir Balkhi's Notebook (al-Biruni, 2260)]] as a colleague from his school days in the Tursonjan madrasa.
*  = from Herat
* Came to Bukhara (presumably from Herat) and enjoyed great favor at the court who patronized his studies (62-63):                           
** //who is Amir Mabrur? Given that he later went to Umar's court, probably another title of Haydar//
* Trained to be a doctor, which was recognized with great acclaim (63):             
* After some time he was summoned to Khoqand where he wrote a poem about Joseph and Zulaykha for the amir there (63):                           
** After the death of Omar Khan of Khoqand Haziq returns to Bukhara, where he again received all manner of honors (63).
* Ultimately, however, the sultan became suspicious and Haziq fled to Shahrisabz, where he was executed (63):              
* In addition to the usual praise, the author describes him as   (p. 63).
* In every age there are examples of bad things befalling great men; Vazih is praising him further for the misfortune that befell him (63):
* Includes some verses about a chorbagh gifted to him by the amir (67):                     
**          
**             
**             
*** I.e. sarcastically noting that perhaps the garden that the amir meant was heaven itself which he will not see before death.
* Haziq would verbally joust especially often with Makhdum Jalali (68).

Haji       (p. 68-69)
* Son of the Hakim of Marv (68).
* Came to Bukhara after the murder of his father and was greeted with great honor by the amir (68):                                  
* Studied the Islamic sciences under Damulla Mirak A'lam (68):              
** Note that Mirak also taught Abu Nasr Tughi.
* Then for an unspecified reason he went to Najaf in Iran where he died (68):                
* Wrote poetry in praise of Amir Sa'id (i.e. Haydar) (68).

Hasan (p. 69-70)
* This indvidual was a courtesan of Bayram the Hakim of Marv - just like previous entry Haji (69):                         
* Famous for his stone engraving; also known for jokes and witticism (69).
* After murder of the Hakim he went to Bukhara (69).
* He was especially close to the Juybari shaykhs (69): 
* Wrote a poem complaining about a bad poem (69):                    
** There is also a poem that someone else wrote in response to this couplet.

Hayrat
* Full name (70):  ...         
* Shows up in multiple sources, including [[Marjn, Wafiyyat al-Aslf, 19th century]]
* Patronized by previous amir; appointed ra'is and qazi (70):                      
* (cont.) A bibliophile - copied and edited volumes (70):                                    

Habibi
* Name, scribing endeavors (71b):                                     
* Still alive, serving as an imam (71b):          

Khamil
* Name, origin from Shahrisabz, born in Bukhara (72):                     
* (cont.) Spent much of his time in service and traveling; seems that he was something of a wine-drinking dandy who enjoyed the finer things (72):                                       
* (cont.) Afficionado of Bidal, Navoy, Jami, and Baba Sa'ib (//don't recognize that last one//) (72):              
* (cont.) //very interesting Beloved passage//(72):                
* Followed by a sufi vision involving Jami //revisit//.
* Ardent sufi, kept to himself, which earned him his nickname (72b):                                         
* (cont.) That said, he did serve the prince (which one?) in Karmina (72b):                        
* Died 1272.

Khumuli (see also: [[Tarjuma-i l-i Q Juma-Qul Khaml]])
* Opening - name, from an Uzbek tribe in Urgut (73):                      
** (cont.) Except apparently Khumuli was a serious opium abuser (73):                                                   
** (cont.) Nevertheless he as able to write history and poetry through the opium cloud (73):            

Khijlat (76b-77b) (this is the famous Bedil)
* Name (76b):    
* No real info given, just poetry.

Kha'if (77b-78b)        
* One of the nobles of Uratippa (77b):                                    
* (cont.) Ordered to Bukhara, where he stayed (77b):                         

Khatif (78b-79)
* Opening:                  
* Umar Khan favored him over others (78b):              
* Died in 1258

Khaqan (79-83)
* This is the bio of Fath Ali Khan Qajar; discussing him as a patron of the arts.
* Many poetical excerpts, some anecdotes (one involving Muhammad Ali Khan Khoqandi which I don't understand on p. 81)
 
Khalis (83-84)
* Opening - son of Ismail khwajah, who was a trader; appointed imam and mutavalli of a madrasa by father(83):                                      
* Wrote a qasida about the conquest of Khoqand (83-84).

Khazani (84-85)
* Opening - Sayyid from Qaratigin (84):          
* He was also known as Valih-i Samarqandi at first until he  heard that people were calling him that and changed his name to Khazani (84).

Danish (85-88)    
* Finished his studies during the age of Amir Sa'id and Amir Maghfur (i.e. Haydar and Nasrallah) (85).
* Activity after his studies - served Qazi Kalan Muhammad Sharif (?) writing fatwas, also author of a history that came out in 1243 (85-86):                                                                   
** Note: Ahmad Danish was born in 1244, so this has to be a different guy.

Danish (88- 89)      
* Lived in the age of amir Firdus Makan - possibly Nasrallah (?) (88).
* After finishing his studies he became a poet and received great acclaim and material reward from the amir and the umara (88).
* Fun poem about the necessity of lampooning poetry (88):            
* Died in 1248

Zabiha (89-90)
* Dehkhoda:  -            
* Emigrated to Samarqand during the reign of Amir Kabir (Danial?); wrote poetry in Persian and Arabic praising God; author sees his Judaism as stubborn, but admires his poetry (89):                                         

Zakir (90-92)
* Opening:       
* Studied initially in Khoqand, then came to Bukhara to study under Akhund Jan Bukhari (90):                        
* (cont.) So impressed was his teacher that when he completed his studies he gave Zakir his own turban and commanded him to carry his knowledge to his homeland in Namangan (90):                                               
* (cont.) From Bukhara he went to Dahbid where he achieved great Sufi renown, then he went to Namangan (90):                                              
* Umar Khan appointed him Shaykh al-Islam (90):                      
* Died in 1240, buried in Namangan (92):     1240      ...               

Zawqi (92-93)      
* From Khatlan (92):                   
* @@important@@ Here Vazih remarks on the current year (1288 h.) at time of writing; Zawqi wrote poetry in praise of a Kulab governor (Sura / Sara Khan) built (93):                                    

Ramzi (93-94)          
* Lived in the time of Firdus Makan - whichever amir that was (probably Shah Murad) (93):          
* Khanly favors (93):              
** He wrote praise poetry for Haydar (93).

Rayikh (94)     
* From Bukhara; died young in 1288.

Rahim Divana Rahimi (94-95)       
* Lived in Samarqand, a qalandar type (94):           
* Was under the tutelage of the Shaykh al-Islam of Samarqand (94-95):                                  []  
* An expert in Navoi and Bedil (95):                  

Rahim Balkhi Rahimi (95-96)      
* Drug addict (95):            
* Musician, had a few students (95):              
* Hung out in the bazar until he died in 1246 (95):            1246        
* Vazih is reproducing much of these poetical excerpts from memory (96):      

Raqim (96- )                
* Longer string of religious honorifics than usual at the beginning.
* Served as qazi of Katta Qurghan (96):                  
* Also a very skilled poet and historian, asserts the author.  Wrote a history in verse of the conquest of Shahrisabz (possibly al-Biruni 2731/II?):                                     
* Has excerpt from his poetical epic on the Shahrisabz conquest in which he refers to it as a "city of innovation" ( ); //revisit//.

Rashid (97-99)       
* Sayyid (?); in honorifics (97):  
* From Bukhara:       
* Received great accolades in the time of Amir Kabir (Danial?), who appointed him personal tutor of Shah Murad; Murad then appionted him Qazi Kalan and Shaykh al-Islam, as well as Akhund of Kukaltash madrasa (97):                                           
* (cont.) Also wrote numerous treatises that became the basis for instructing ulama (97):                                  
* Died in 1228 (99).

Ramzi (       (99-100
* One of Muhammad Omar Khan's poets:               

Randi (100-101)   
* Also one of Umar Khan's poets (100):            
* (cont.) Qalandar-type (100):                                

Zahid (101)
* From Khoqand originally, now serves in the Bukharan court in the position of Mir Akhuri; also skilled in insha, but gained his reputation in the court from his poetry (101):                                                      

Zaki (101-103)       
* A scribe for the umara (102):          
* (cont.) Worked his way up the ranks until he became something like the chief secretary of Bukhara, which Vazih makes a really big deal out of (102):                          
* Died 1280.

Savda (103-107)         (described in multiple other sources as well)
* Sacred lineage from Hazrat Mulana Sharif al-Husayni; his ancestors were always appointed to qaziships and rais-ships (103-104):                                       
* Went through all of the standard () marasa sciences, specialized in music, miniature painting, gold working, as well as raml and astrology (104):                                                               
* On his good fortune (104):                              

Sayrat (107 -           (covered in numerous other sources)
* Emigrated from Balkh to Bukhara in his youth (108):                    
* Particularly well-versed in language and history (108):                  
* Also a Sufi (108):                   
* (cont.) Career as a qazi (108):         

Sima (109-110)       
* Balkh origin (109):                            
* (cont.) Skills (109):                                      
* (cont.) Emigration / exile to Shahrisabz (109):                           

Sipandi (110)      
* From Samarqand, student:  ...          

Sarvi (110-112)       
* Sacred lineage from Amir Kulal (110):            
* Memorized the Qur'an at an early age, served as a clerk for Muhamad Shakuri Bay Inaq (111):            
* After that he found service in the royal court (111):       
* Died 1277.


Shivan      (p. 113-116)
* I.e. this is Ata Allah's son.
* Trained many of the great Bukharan Ulama (113):               
* (cont.) Ancestors holding the highest posts in the land (113):                                                        
* (cont.) Spent 18 years training in the hard sciences with his grandfather Hadi Khwajah (113):               
* (cont.) Khalifa of Muhammad Amin Dahbidi (113):                                                      
* (cont.) Personally teaching amir Haydar (113-114):                                          
* Goes on to describe the poetry he scribed whenever he got the chance.  (Note that he wrote wine poetry.)
* Death (116):                                      

Shawqi (116-117)
* Opening - studied in Katta Qurghan, wrote in Arabic, Turki, and Farsi, wrote a legal commentary (116):                                     
* Cryptic remark ( is referred to in Dehkhoda as the language of ; //merits further investigation//) (116):        
* Died in 1278.

Sharifi             (p. 117-118)
* Young at the time of writing (117).
* Known for his excellent scribing (117).
* Now serving in Hisar (117):              

Shakuri        (p. 118)
* From Samarqand, not well educated, but excelled at poetry and history (118):                                           

Shirin (118-119)
* Opening (118):                   
* Career as a chaiwallah and arms dealer (119):         
* (cont.) Also a doctor (119):                       
* Put the Joseph Zuleikha story into verse (119):        

Mahmid Sharif Shirin               (p. 119-121)
* (Name seems strange, but the writing is fairly clear)
* Young at time of writing (19):                       
* Trading with Russia and Turkey made him rich (120):                           [ / ]     
* (cont.) Hajj (120):                
* (cont.) On top of all this he is a bit of a dervish (120):               

Sarir (121-125)       
* Opening - describing his self-imposed spiritual poverty despite coming from wealth (121):               [   ]                 
* (cont.) Qazi, Mudarris (121):                     
* (cont.) Writings for the previous Amir (Nasrallah) (121):                        
* Remarks on his many works in draft form (121):                           
* Coming to Bukhara to study, high praise of his calligraphy (121-122):                                                   
* Followed by a very generous poetical excerpt.

Sadiq       (p. 125-128)
* Opening - Possibly a Bedil afficionado (125):           
* Was a munshi under Haydar (125):               
* Follows with some commentary on his poetic style (126).
* Origins in a place called Jandar not far from Bukhara, story about his townsmen imploring him to use his streetcred with the amir to alleviate a drought (126-128):                                                []                    
* (ends with a weird anecdote about an apple in a charbagh with the amir)

Suhbi       (p. 128)
* Origins in Mian Kal / Panjshanbe (// are those the same place//), studied in Bukhara, now teaches in madrasas (128):                       
* Wrote very wine, Sufi poetry //revisit// (128).

Sufi     (p. 128-130)
* AKA Ishan Sufi Khwajah Bayza Khatlani
* Ranks held (128):                                               
* Relationship with Muhammad Yaqub Qushbigi, patronage (128-129):                                     -  -          -     

Zarir (130-131)
*              - also covered in Muhtaram.
* Connected to the Dahbidis on his mother's side (130):           
* Writes (or at least knows) poetry in both Turkic and Farsi (130):       

Tahir (p. 131)
* Opening (131):     
* Ilm-i mashghuf? (131):      

Zahir (131-132)
* Opening - son of someone important, but doesn't specify who, also a colleague of the author:                 
* Death (132):          1284         
* A mudarris (132):           

Zuhuri                (p. 132-133)
* Man of many talents, including medicine and the occult (132):                            []                                 

Arif        (p. 133-134)
* Lived in the age of Haydar (133):                   
* Wrote a history called Taj al-Tawarikh about amirs Kabir and Sa'id (Murad and Haydar) (see Semenov 1, 85):                           

Asi      (p. 135-137)
* Opening - from a Turkic noble family outside of Peshawar:         [  =  ]          
** gives a poem, then continues - he wandered the world looking for knowledge and trade (135):                                   
* After another poem, continues that he eventually arrived in Bukhara, a master of the Islamic sciences and poetry (135):                                   
* (cont) All he had was the clothes on his back; a dervish, wrote lampooning poetry (135):                                                       
* (cont.) Death in Balkh, though rumors abound that he is alive and well in Kabul (135-136):                                      
* (cont.) On his qualities - wrote poetry in Arabic and Farsi (136):                           

Anbar     (p. 137)
* Still a student at the time of Vazih's writing, but included in many other Tazkirat as well (e.g. Muhtaram).
* Origin of takhallus, family history as merchants (137):                              

Azmi        (p. 137-138)
* Old at time of writing (137).
* Famous Juybari shaykh (138):                                

Isa        (p. 138-140)
* Covered in numerous other sources.
* Age at time of writing (138):                

Uzlat     (p. 140-141)
* One of the praisers of Haydar and Nasrallah; trained by Sa'd Allah Juybari in Juybar (140):                        
* (cont.) Trained as a musician and mirza (140):                        
* (cont.) In the year 1270 he was fired and went into seclusion in a Zawiya (140):                           

Izzat         (p. 140-143)
* From the family of mutawallis of the shrine of Ali in Balkh (140):                                
* (cont.) Came to Bukhara to study (140):                          
* Very strange passage - //revisit//
* Granted permission to return to Balkh (141):                         

Azizi        (p. 143-144) 
* A young student at the time of writing (143).
* Died young (143):                                        
* Spends a great deal of time lamenting the tragedy and praising Azizi.
* Mostly wrote his poetry in Turki, but Persian as well (144):           

Arif        (p. 144)
* Time in Karmina, qazi and imam in Bukhara (144):                                                  
* (cont.) Death (144):            []    

Abdi            (p. 144-146)
* From Samarqand (144-145):                  
* (cont.) Migrated to Muhammad Ali Khan's court in Khoqand, until the weakening of that kingdom () when he returned to Samarqand laden with goods (145):                                                        []          
* (cont.) He was a Farsi speaker (says nothing about Tajikness) (145):                       
* (cont.) Anecdote (145):                                              
** (cont.) Includes a praise poem to Muhammad Umar Khan Khoqandi, suggesting that the Shah of Bukhara should be subordinated to Khoqand (145):                 -  -        -       -                                             
** From here it gets into a discussion of correct verse and meter, which is the actual point of the anecdote (revisit)
* Old at the time of writing (146).

Ajzi       (p. 147)
* Grandchild of (147):    ...                   
* Finished studies, wrote praise poetry for the khan (147):                

Ghugha         (p. 147-148)
* From noble family of Bistam (147):          
* Wrote praise poetry for Nasr al-Din Shah as well as the twelve Shiite imams (147):                       
* (cont.) His poetry entered Bukhara as a result of the defeat of the Qajar army (in Marv?) and was well-received (147-148):                 

Fa'yiq         (p. 149-150)
* Appointed imam of Lab-i Hawz khanaqah by the amir (149):                     

Fitrat      (p. 150-152)
* Included in numerous other tazkirat.
* Studied in Bukhara (150).
* Mostly poetical exemplars, including a poem in praise of tea chai.

Fazil       (p. 152-153)
* Old at the time of writing, very wise, etc., but he was engaged in pursuits unbecoming one of his station (152):                                 
* Served as a writer for Muhammad Amin Khwajah Shaykh al-Islam (153):                 1276      

Furughi       (p. 153-156)
* (p. 153):               
* Iranian from Bistam, writing poetry for Fath Ali Shah Qajar through Nasir al-Din.
* //not entered into database since he never left Iran//

Fazli        (p. 156-157)
* One of Umar Khan's court poets; may have also composed a poetical tazkirat for Umar Khan:                                                 

Fada               (p. 157-158)
* Father is a high level bureaucrat for the reigning amir; young at the time of writing (157):                                      
* Famous ancestors (157):                                     

Fa'yiq       (p. 158-161)
* Opening - served as ra'is and qazi in Bukhara (158):                     
** //not clear who he is referring to with this Makhdum Namangani//
* Poetry caught the attention of the amir (158):             
* Still young at the time of writing (158).
* Appointed librarian by the amir (158):                

Qarin         (p. 161-162)
* Studied poetry in his school days (161):       
* Died very young (161):             

Qavami           (p. 162-163)
* Martyred in Samarqand (presumably during Russian conquest) (162):        
* Also covered in Zia Tashkar Ashar.

Qa'ani        (p. 163-
* Known as a poet and historian (163).
* Shiite, wrote a book of poetry Vazih thinks is as good as Sa'di's Gulestan (163):                                                 
** Book came to Bukhara during defeat of Qajars (163):                   
* Includes a number of humorous anecdotes (latifa).
* Note: This guy is famous enough to appear in Dehkhoda under .
* //not included in database since he never went to Bukhara//

Qari         (p. 167)
* Sacred lineage (?) (167):  ...                     
* Teaching postion - taught in Jafar Khwajah madrasa (cont.) (167):                
         
* Praises his austerity from worldy goods and his indebtedness (167).

Qasim        (p. 167-168)
* Praised as one of the best ulama (and a ra'is - p. 167), then Sufi credentials (168):                
* Also mudarris of a khanaqa (168):                    
** //date is written, but I can't make it out//

Qasimi          (p. 168-169)
* Migrated from Maimana to Bukhara for studies (168):          
* (cont.) Sufi nature - literally says he sometimes donned the Sufi garb (168):                                                    
* Returned to Maimana in 1256 (p. 168-169):                               

Qadari        (p. 169-170)
* Originated from a village near Balkh, left on his own volition at a very young age to study in Bukhara (169):                                         
* (cont.) Exalting Bukhara, married and settled there (169):          -  -     -          -  -      -     
** //interesting that the poem about Bukhara is in Arabic//
* Served Abd al-Wahid Sadr (169):                          

Kamal         (p. 170-171)
* Son of Tursun Baqi; rais and qazi, enjoyed favor of the khan (170):                                          
* Died in 1287 (170):              

Katib       (p. 171)
* From Bukhara, after studying a bit went to maktab teaching (171):                        
** //this Joseph and Zuleikha story is really popular//
* Still alive at the time of writing (171):                  

Kasrat (p. 171-172)
* Doens't specify his given name, just that he was one of Umar Khan's poets (171):                
* Vazih met Subhanquli Khwajah, who spoke highly of Kasrat from travels to Khoqand (172):                                                          

Gulkhani        (p. 172-173)
* A hamam owner (172):              
* Has excerpts of ghazals in praise of Umar Khan (173).

Under the heading "Tanbih" on p. 173 the author has a peculiar exposition on his choice of domestic and foreign poets.

Lam'i          (p. 174-175)
* Enjoyed the favor of Shah Murad (174):                        
* Taught four hundred students, also a calligrapher (174):                              
* Death (174-175):                          

Lisani             (p. 175-177)
* Also covered in Zia's Takirat al-Khan.
* The opening honorifics make much of his prowess with the Arabic sciences, particularly hadith and tafsir (175-176).
* Came to Bukhara, Qubbat al-Islam, to study; studied under Alim Khwajah (176):                              
* (cont.) Also a princely tutor for Haydar and Nasrallah (176):              
* (cont.) Appointed ra'is and mudarris (176):                 
* Author also studied under this scholar (176):                 

Muzmar        (p. 177-178)
* Died in the age of Nasrallah (177).
* Very little concrete information.

Mahir          (p. 178-181)
* From Volga-Urals, but born and raised in Bukhara (178):                 
* Taught many students in Bukhara, particularly in ilm al-faraid - including the author (178-179):                    [ ]              
* (cont.) Appointments (179):             
* Eventually retired to a Khanaqah (179):                       
* A linguist - knew Arabic, Persian, Farsi, Turki, Russian, Hindi, and Farangi (French), and Afghan (170):                  
* Death in 1288 (179):            

Muqbil           (p. 181-183)
* Mastered the common and arcane sciences (181):                        
* Seems to have had some sort of relationship with the amir //revisit//
* Wrote poetry in Turki and Farsi (182):                     
* Death in 1277 (182):               

Majnun       (p. 183-185)
* Originally from Marv (183):          
* Origin of takhallus (183):               
* (cont.) Visited Husayn's shrine in Karbala, spent two and a half years in India, now works as a Perfumer (183):                                                              
* Wrote poetry following (tatabu') Rumi (184):                   

Mirak Khwajah A'lam     (p. 185-186)
* One of the great scholars of Bukhara (185):      
* Particularly well-versed in a book by Qarabaghi (185):                                              

Mirak      (p. 186-189)
* also mentioned in [[Abdi|Takirat al-Shuar- Abdallah Khwjah Abd, 1904]] //though I initially had separate entries in the database//
* Descended from the Ismail Samani (!) (186):             
* One of Ata Allah's students (186):                             
* (cont.) Despite his youth, during this time he would participate in Arabic-language disputations on Islamic law, always winning them  (186):                           
* (cont.) Brother of Mir Zayn al-Din, from whom Vazih personally heard that Mirak taught out of love of teaching, not for money (186):                                              
* (cont.) Was a master of Jafr (186):                 
* Tutored Haydar, appointed ra'is and qazi while the prince was governing Qarshi (187):                                                 
* (cont.) When Hisar revolted, Haydar marched on Hisar, and Mirak used his Jafr to help him achieve victory; died shortly thereafter at age of 42 (187-188):                                                                                                                       
** //This story has interesting parallels with some of the events depicted in// [[Manqib wa Maqmt-i Sayyid Muammad Aallah Shaykh al-Islm (PNB 200)]]
* Mentioning Abd al-Ali, a mudarris, and a joking verse penned by Mirak (188-189):                          -  -         -       
* (cont.) Death in 1215 (189):          

Masiha       (p. 189-190)
* A calligrapher (189):          
* (cont.) Qazi of Baysun (189):          

Muztarab           (p. 190-191)
* Young student at the time of writing (190).
* Wrote poetry in praise of the amir (191).
* strange account by the author //revisit//

Matba'i       (p. 191-192)
* Bureaucrat; also a riddler (191):                  

Mirak     (p. 192)
* //very confusingly, this entry comes several entries after the previous two Miraks.  Despite the same name, it appears to be a different individual; who knows how he aligns with the Mirak Jans mentioned in the other sources.  No mentinon of him training Haydar though, so that narrows it somewhat.//
* After losing his job, he again found royal favor and got appointed to teaching in Karmina (192):                               

Muzmar        (p. 192-193)
* Lineage with Abu al-Fazl (192):              
* Spent time in the hakim's court in Hisar (192):                       
* Legacy in Bukhara (192):                

Mansab          (p. 193-194)
* Tutored the amir (which one?) and was rewarded with the post of mir-i shab in reward (193):                                      
** //followed with some cryptic verses about the mir-i shab post//

Matlab       (p. 194-196)
* No real information; also not positive if "Marvi" is part of his name.

Mansur     (p. 196)
* From Khoqand (196):          
* Connection to verbal zikr, qawali (196):                          
* Death (196): includes a chronogram //which I calculated to 1209, but would need to reexamine; that seems early//

Munir         (p. 196-199)
* Old at the time of writing (197).
* Knew everything, etc etc, but especially medicine (197):                                         
* (cont.) Also a calligrapher (197):                                                   
* Ancestors were all merchants; Munir had associates who did his trading for him so that he could concentrate on learning; Vazih studied medicine under this man (197):                                                        
* Death in 1278 (198):         

Niyaz Kashmiri           (p. 199-200)
* One of Muhammad Amin Dahbidi's khalifas; his father had moved to Kashmir, which is where he was trained, and was part of a Khanaqah there (199):                                               
* (cont.) Also a calligrapher; became one of Muhammad Amin's khalifas while on pilgrimage to Dahbid, then later returned to Kashmir (199):                                          
* (cont.) When the Hindus conquered Kashmir he moved to Kabul, which is where he died in 1242 (199):                         
* Poetry about tea and the climate of Kashmir (199):                               

Niaz Sirhindi         (p. 200-202)
* //revisit or consult; this does not make sense to me, who is who; not entered in database//
* //not positive about the  part of his name//
* Studied the hard sciences in his home province in India; traveled to Marghinan via Peshawar and Badakhstan, then to Khoqand, where he died (200):                                 
* (cont.) After finishing his studies, he studied Sufism under Ahdallah Baghdadi (200):                                           
* After receiving his cloak and ijazat, he went to live in Bareilly, doing sufi stuff, then died there in 1250 (200-201):
                                               
* (cont.) His most advanced student was Nizam al-Din Husayn, who took over; they perform ecstatic rituals at his grave to the present day (201):                                        

Nava        (p. 202-
* Part of the famous Abu al-Hay Samarqandi line
** //note: this is probably the same character who shows up as Abu al-Zahir in other sources//
* Lineage (203):                                       
* (cont.) Trained under his father; states explicitly that his family always dominated the top posts in Samarqand (203):                                        
* (cont.) Skillset (203):                    
* Copied the Qandiyya (203):                     

Natiq         (p. 204)
* Young at the time of writing (204).
* In 1272 he traveled to Turkistan (from Herat) arriving in Bukhara (204):                        
* (cont.) Musician (204):                   
* (cont.) Eventually returned to his homeland; still living at time of writing (204):                

Nala        (p. 204-206)
* One of Umar Khan's poets (204).
* Also close to Muhammad Ali Khan (205):        

Nusrat (p. 206)
* Opening - takhallus same as name, from the villages surrounding Bukhara (206):               
* Death in 1230 (206):                

Nakhat               (p. 206-209)
* His father was extemely famous (208):                     
* Nakhat was 16 years old at the time of writing (208)

Nisari        (p. 208)
* From Nasaf / Qarshi (208).
* Served as a scribe for umara (208):           
* Also wrote poetry in Turki.

Nazmi       (p. 209-210)
* Young man at the time of writing, from Bukhara (209).
* Also wrote poetry in Turki (210).
* Died at age 19 (?) (210):                  

Nuzhat         (p. 210-211)
* Appointed mudarris of Fathallah Qush Begi; also a calligrapher and geomancer (210):                                
* Continues explaining his takhallus, some other virtues.

Na'ir         (p. 211-213)
* From those who issue the stamp / seal in Bukhara (211):                      
* Assistant ra'is of Bukhara to Baqa Khajah (211-212):                       
* Still alive at time of writing (213).

Najib (p. 213-214)
* Opening - From Shahjahanabad, came to Bukhara, Hindu by descent, calligrapher and poet in Afghani, Hindi, and Farsi; after mixing with the Ulama of Bukhara for some time, he returned to Hindustan (213):                                                
* (cont.) Anecdote //consult on meaning// (213):                                       

Valih      (p. 214-215)
* From Samarqand, resides in Yangi Qurghon (214):            
* (cont.) Kuknar; receives a salary for being a sayyid (214):                                      
* Composed in Turki and Farsi (214).

Vaysi        (p. 215-218)
* Young at time of writing (215).
* Like his father known for mastery of ilm al-fara'id (215).
* Wrote qasidas in praise of the amir (215).
* Died young in 1280 (216).  Very dear to his father's heart, who was Vazih's teacher, so lots of poetical excerpts.

Varis       (p. 219-220)
* Successor (khalaf) of Mahmud Khwajah; young at time of writing (219):                        
* Imam and scribe (220):          [=]       

Vazir (p. 220)
* Opening - his actual name is not known, but he was one of Umar Khan's vazirs (220):            
* //not enough info to enter into database//

Varid      (p. 221)
* One of the supporters (mavali?) of Hamanquli Parvanchi (221):        

Vazih (p. 221-236)
* Opening (221):            
* Autobio - after completing school, was called to serve the amir in Karmina (222-223):                                                                                                                                
* Went on the Hajj (223).
* Mentioning the Russian conquest //revisit// (224):                                        
* Has exceprts from qasidas praising the Bukharan amirs.

Himmat        (p. 236-237)
* Secretary in Amir Husayn's (??) court (236):             

Haran          (p. 237-238)
* Selfless teacher //also says he was either addicted or free from narcotics - revisit// (237):                                     
*  While traveling together one day Vazih asked him the meaning of his takhallus, and he replied that his grandfather was given that nickname by Umar Khan of Khoqand (238):                                                                  

Hijri (p. 238-239)
* //no information, not even name, not entered in database; probably one of Umar Khan's ulama//

Hamdam (p. 239-241)
* Takhallus same as name.
* //not entered in database for lack of info//

Hatif          (p. 241-243)
* Migrating from Uratepa to study in Bukhara, got in with amirs Murad - Nasrallah (241-242):                                                                      
* Died at age of 105 in 1269 (242):                 
* Tale about Hatif's properties and taxes in Uratepa (//interesting//) (242-243):                                                                          -         -      -       -                                                

Yakdil       (p. 243-246)
* Sufi silsila to Niyaz Muhammad (//though not sure which one in the database//) (244):              
* Native of Bukhara, inducted many students into the Naqshbandi order (244):                   
* Wrote poetry in the ages of Murad and Haydar (244).

//revisit closing at some point//




> Vi, Gharb al-Khabar fi Ajb al-Safar

Full name:         , Qr Ramat Allah ibn shr Muhammad al-Bukhr mutakhallis bih Vai
See also his poetical tazkirat: [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

[[Iusupova and R. P. Dzhalilova, Sobranie vostochnykh rukopisei Akademii nauk Respubliki Uzbekistan. Istoriia]]
*     p. 377, 900; 2106, 153 l.
** This is Vazih (of the poetical anthology)'s hajnamah. He goes via Istanbul.
** In 1904 a lithograph was produced in Kagan (i.e. Bukhara). Copied by hand numerous times as well.

Meandering Prologue (philosophy, praise)
* Praises Abd al-Ahad using these titles (3b):              
* Intention to embark on the journey to Mecca (3b-4):                                              
* This work is a gift for Abd al-Ahad (4).
* In preparation for his travels he goes on about the one-ness of God (Ibn Arabi) (6):                                                                  
** (cont.) (6-6b):                    []       []                                         []     
*** //this train of thought continues//
** From there Vazih moves on from God to discussing the unity of Muhammad (7):                             3             

Bukhara to Marv
* Left in 1303 / 1886 (9b):            1303                  [ ]  
* Old Marv is 6 days from Charjuy (9b):          
* Marv at this point is recently conquered by Russia (10):                 
** Description of New Marv (10):                 []                     []         
** (cont.):                              
* (cont.) Russians, Armenians, and Jews dominate Marv, living by Sharia is problematic and sin is rife (10-10b):                                                   
* Russian official in charge of exit visas, the railroad (10b):                                                       
* Visiting a saint's shrine (11b):                                                              
* Note weaving Tus into the Persianate geography (12):                  []      -  
** //what is 'ajaib al-tabaqat?//

Mashhad
* Entered Mashhad on the first of Ramadan when everyone was fasting; visited a shrine (12):               
* Distance from Bukhara to Mashhad (12):                  
* Vazih is extremely impressed with the Mashhad shrine and praises in length its golden cupola and other embellishments (12b-19).
** Physical remnants of Nadir Shah's empire - and the Qajars, and the Timurids (13):                [ / ]                                                                     
* Describes Mashhad's famous madrasas (13b-14).
* Vazih is impressed by the shoe-guy in the Mashhad shrine (15-15b):                     
* The shrine was equipped with a kitchen and guesthouse for pilgrims (18):        []                 
* Arabs also visited Mashhad in large numbers (21b):                          
* Comparing sweets and fruits in Mashhad with Bukhara (22):                              
* Remained in Mashhad for 13 days (22b).

From Mashhad
* Next stop was Asqhabad:                 
* Then:       
** Quchan is the resting place of Ibrahim, son of Imam Riza (22).
* Mentions Shia preaching (22.1):                                     
** //note that if Vazih disapproves of this, he gives no indication//

Religious Debate with an Armenian Christian Trader in (22b-27)
 * Anecdote about an Armenian trader asking Vazih where he was going and upon hearing the answer - how it could be that God has a house (22b-23).
** The debate deepens (23-23):  []        []                                             4                                                                                                                                   
** (cont.) a crowd gathers (23b-24):                                                                                                                    
** //Vazih continues making his case for Islam for about two pages 24-25//
** The debate has turned into a major spectacle (25):                             
* Vazih makes some long metaphor of the miraculous nature of the Quran (revisit), which has an effect on the Christians (27):                               

Train, boat, train to Baku to Tiblisi
* From there they take the train (27-27b):               
* //is he actually renting a Quran?// (27b):      
* Town of Zarif bears heavy Russian influence (27b):                     
* Train to Baku (28):                                         
** The Caspian (- why is he calling it Haji Turkhan?) (28):                            
* Baku (28): Vazih is generally very impressed with the stonework and buildings of the city.
* From there Vazih took a train toward Batum () via Tiblisi () (p. 28b):                       
* (cont.) no comparison between Baku and Tiblisi in terms of prosperity (28b):            
* States that Tiblisi, like Baku, was taken from Iran by the Russians; recalling the classical period when Georgia was known for being a source of slaves (28b-29):                                                    []            
* Continuing on the train to Batum (29):                               
* Arriving in Batum, ethnic composition of the city (29):                                   
** (cont.) (29b):             
* From Batum they took a steam (?) ship to Istanbul via Trebizon (29b):                                            
** Very impressed with the goods in Trebizon (29b):                       
** (cont.) Registration (29b):                     
* Batum - Trebizon: 11 hours; Trebizon -  Samsam: 12 hours; Samsam - somewhere else: 13 hours; that location to Istanbul: 12 hours (29b-30b).

Istanbul 
* Registration and meeting other Central Asians (30b):                                                                                        
** (cont.) Some negative impressions of Istanbulis and other hajis (30b):                                                                      
* Describing the Haga Sofia Vazih implicitly reveals that he does not know the word "kalisa" (32):                             
* Ethnic composition (33):              []                            
** (cont.) Jews (33-33b):                                  
*** note that Vazih does refer to the Ottoman sultan as "khalifa"
* Seeing the Sultan (34):                                                 


[[TsGARUz Index]]

> Waqf for students from Andakhud (northern Afghanistan) TsGARUz F i-323 O 1 D 127

* Dated Rajab 1284 (Oct-Nov 1867) in a courthouse ( ) of Bukhara.
* Endower:            
* Long list of witnesses to the act of endowing.
* Candle store as an endowment (18-28):                                                                                     
* Sets self up as mutawalli, and his son upon his death (27-30):                                   
* Stipulating how the revenue is used - it's for students studying in Bukhara but from Andkhui - even lists one of the recipient students (31-34):                                                    
** Probably , which is near Balkh.  Dehkhoda:              
* Also stipulates that the benficiary students gather weekly to read a specific sura for his family's glory and the prophet's (35-:                                               []                 
* Stipulates something to be haram, //but word is unclear ( )// (line 41)

[[Repository Index]]

> Thomas Welsford and Nouryaghdi Tashev, eds., A Catalogue of Arabic-Script Documents from the Samarqand Museum (Samarqand - Istanbul: International Institute for Central Asian Studies, 2012).

Original documents are available online: "The catalogue has been produced to complement an online digital archive of photographed document images produced by IICAS and maintained on the IICAS website www.unesco-iicas.org" (9).
 
Description of the collection and some statistics: "On the basis of our 848 textual descriptions, we may offer a few observations about the contours of the materials under discussion. 738 of our 848 texts, or 87.0% of the total number, are composed partly or wholly in Persian. 88 texts, or 10.3%, are composed partly or wholly in Turki; 49, or 5.9%, are composed partly or wholly in Arabic; and 4, or 0.5%, are composed partly or wholly in Russian. Of the total number of texts under discussion, meanwhile, 550 are dated by their authors to some degree of precision. Of these clearly dated texts, the earliest was composed between 12 December 1586 and 1 December 1587, and the latest was composed between 4 July and 1 August 1924. Just one such clearly dated text was produced in the 16th century: 5 were produced in the 17th century, 20 were produced in the 18th century, 310 were produced in the 19th century and 214 were produced after 1900. 124 texts, comprising 22.5% of all clearly dated items, were composed in the period before the Russian conquest of Samarqand in 1868; the remaining 426, or 77.5%, were composed thereafter. 488 texts, or 88.8%, were produced in the 50 years before or after the events of 1868; and 75 texts, or fully 13.5% of all clearly dated items, were produced in the years 1906-1909, the period for which we have the densest body of documentation"(10).

!!!Hadi Khwaja's line

* Entry 32 (5: KP 1079), p. 56
** Nothing particularly interesting about this document, except for the fact that it has Muammad A-Allh Khwjah Shaykh al-Islm notarizing a fatwa in 1203 (2 October 1788  22 September 1789).
* Entry 52 (425: KP 5991/171), p. 68
** Dated: 1214 (5 June 1799  24 May 1800)
** Fatwa, stamp: Ramat-Allh Khwjah b. Aq al-qut A-Allh Khwjah Alaw, 1194
* Entry 67 (1127: KP 5991/669), p. 78
** Declaration of debt dated 17 Rajab 1254 (6 October 1838)
** Stamp: Q al-qut Q Muammad Sharf Khwjah Mawlaw b. A-Allh Khwjah Shaykh al-Islm al-Alaw
*** Useful footnote: "This person is to be identified as the son of that Muammad A-AllhKhwjah noted in 32(3). He is first attested active in 1234/31 October 1818-19 October 1819 (see Kurbanov, Materialy po sredneaziatskoi sfragistike, p. 66). In 1236/9 October 1820-27 September 1821 he was appointed q-yi askar, and in 1242/5 August 1826-26 July 1826 he was appointed qa-yi kaln; he is known to have remained active until ca. Shabn 1257/September-October 1841 (doc. 68)."
* Entry 68 (666: KP 5991/387), p. 78
** Declaration of sale and rent, dated Shabn 1257 (18 September  16 October 1841).
** See note for previous entry; this is latest documented activity of Muammad Sharf Khwjah.
* Entry 151 (174: KP 3791/54), p. 128
** Reported declaration of cessation of claim, dated Rajab 1297 (9 June  8 July 1880).
** Stamp: Q Muammad lim Khwjah udr b. Q al-qut Mawlaw Muammad Sharf Khwjah Alaw
*** Footnote: "Attested active from ca. Rajab 1297/June-July 1880 (doc. 151) to 1304/1886-87 (see Kurbanov, Materialy po sredneaziatskoi sfragistike, p. 103. This figure is perhaps also to be identified as that Q Muammad [xxx] Mawlaw Muammad Sharf Khwjah Alaw encountered as a Nasaf q in doc. 171, dating from Rajab 1304 (26 March  24 April 1887)."
* Entry 171 (722: KP 5991/442), p. 140-142
** Declaration of endowment dated Rajab 1304 (26 March  24 April 1887).
** Stamp: Q Muammad [xxx] Mawlaw Muammad Sharf Khwjah Alaw
*** Footnote: "This figure is perhaps to be identified as that Q Muammad lim Khwjah udr b. Q al-qut Mawlaw Muammad Sharf Khwjah Alaw encountered as a Chahrjy qin doc. 151, dated Rajab 1297 (9 June  8 July 1880)."

!!!Abd al-Hayy Line
* "Q Mull Abdallh Khwjah could very well here be the eponymous son of the Samarqandi q al-qutMr Abd al-ayy Khwjah Shaykh al-Islm (1169/October 1755-September 1756-1243/ July 1827-July 1828" (181).
* Entry 410, p. 271-272
** Re-drafted endowment deed, 1233 (11 November 1817  30 October 1818)
** Seal: Q al-qut Mr Abd al-ayy Khwjah Shaykh al-Islm b. Mawlaw Abul-Khayr
*** Footnote: This individual lived from 1169 (October 1755-September 1756) to 1243 (July 1827-July 1828), and was a prominent Samarqandi jurist, and author of numerous theological works. He was the father of (a) Mull Abdallh Khwjah (doc. 243(1)?), (b) Ab Sad Khwjah (doc. 426(2)) and (c) Mr Salmn Khwjah. For discussion, see Muammad-Sharf-i adr-i Ziy,The Personal History of a bukharan Intellectual, p. 159, n. 263
** Note that there is a second Qazi al-Quzat seal on the same document: Q al-qut Mr Nimat-Allh Khwjah b. Mr Qsim Khwjah Msaw
* Entry 426 (1083: KP 1618), p. 284-285
** Declaration of sale, Raman 1262 (23 August  21 September 1846)
** Seal: Q al-qut Mr Ab Sad Khwjah Q-yi kaln b. Mawlaw Mr Abd al-ayy Khwjah Shaykh al-Islm
* Entry 428 (1082: KP 1618), p. 286
** Declaration of sale, Rajab 1265 (23 May  23 June 1849)
** Seal: Q al-qut Ab Sad Khwjah Q-yi kaln b. Abd al-ayy Khwjah Shaykh al-Islm 
** Seal: Mr Ab hir Khwjah Muft-yi Samarqand b. shn Q Mr Ab Sad Khwjah
*** Footnote: "Mr Ab hir Khwjah, well known as author of the Samaryah: attested active from 1250/1835 (Faiziev, Istoriia Samarkanda pervoi pol. XIX veka, pp. 48-49 (waqfdoc. 8) to Rajab 1265/May-June 1849 (doc. 428)."
* Entry 688: "For several years, shn Mr Abd al-ayy, the q-yi kaln, and Mull Rfi qsaql have together owned and cultivated a a plot of land located in Ramatbd" (508).
** //however, cannot be sure if this is the same Abd al-Hay//
* Entry 160 (741: KP 5991/461), p. 134
** Declaration of sale, afar 1303 (9 November  7 December 1885)
** Seal: Q Mull Mr Abul-ayy Khwjah udr b. Q Mr Mam Khwjah, 1302
[[Rossiskaia Natsional'naia Biblioteka (St. Petersburg) Index]]
[[Iastrebova, Persidskie i Tadzhikskie dokumenty v Otdele Rukopisei Rossiskoi Natsional'noi Biblioteki]]

> Yarliq appointing the Qadi Matchi 1222/ 1807f (F940 Kaufman 9)

This document is very short - less than half a page.  And while it has an official seal, it looks as if the sheet of paper has been written over several times, with fainter writing visible upside down in the background.

* Note the   title.

[[Fond 33, A.L. Kun]]

>  -,       F33 O1 D149
> Zhizneopisanie Abdully-beka, odnogo iz pridvornykh Bukharskogo emira Mozaffara, Sankt-Peterburgskii Filial Instituta Vostokovedenii Rossiiskoi Akademii Nauk: Arkhiv Vostokovedov, F 33 (Kun, Aleksandr Lyudvigovich) O 1 D 149

General Notes: 
* Strikethrough is intentional and indicates that something was crossed out in the text as well

1.       

1b.
* (1)      
* (2)     []    []       []  [] []  
* (3)        []     
Family Background
* (4)                         
** Account is in Abdallah Bek's own words.
* (5)       --       --        
** Father and ancestors served as governors of Panjikent
* (6)                           
** Mother's family from Samarqand.
* (7)                           
**  :                                     .
** His ancestors all sported the laqab "dadkhah".
* (8)                      []  []  
** Father called to Bukhara and given a golden staff by Nasrallah.
* (9)                           [  
** Father died when he was 20.
* (10)                       [= ]

* (11)                       []  
** When he was 20 years old Nasrallah assigned him to his personal entourage, though he was not the most favored.
* (12)                       
** Spent 8 years in the personal entourage til he was 28.
* (13)  []                []   
** Served as Yasavol, then Shifavoli.

[[Fond 17, V.A. Zhukovskii]]

>            .   .  17 1 11.

//Note: Handwritten essay; also, I did not transcribe the old Russian characters//

* First line of the essay - notice the lack of any mention of Turkestan or Tajiks:  ,     ,   []     "  " ...    ... (1).
* The first section (list 1-5) engages in the ancient history of the language - Aryans, Sasanians, etc.
* Author notes that New Persian is primarily a written and official language. "...   ?              , [] [?]       ,     " (5b).
* Lists the other Russian scholars that have studied Iranian dialects: , , ,  (5b).
* Zhukovskii is interested in dialects as a window into the ancient tongues.  He says of northern dialects, such as those in Rasht: "            [?]     " (6).
* Some dialects, notes Zhukovskii, even have their own literature, for instance ; others had to be created, it seems, by recording what had until then been spoken: "    :    [ ??],  ,       . " (6-6b).
** In fact, Mazandaran can be said to have its own language: " ,         [],   ,      " (6b).


[[Fond 17, V.A. Zhukovskii]]

> .. .    . . . .  I   84-  ,       ,          -   .  17 1 183

//Note: this document is in the old alphabet, but I have not transcribed the , i, etc.//

This is a useful document simply for making the point about direct connections between Russian orientalism and the west (rather than simply assuming it.

Latest date listed: 1907

First paragraph (list 1) in its entirety:                           ,           ,         .             ,         @@ @@         ,      ,  84-         -   (1).

Comparison Cases
* Essay begins examining the French case (1). 
** Algeria:           ... (1-1b).
** Emphasis on //living languages//:                (1b).
*** This institute was founded 30 March 1795 to educate interpreters for various government branches (1b).
***     Ecole speciale  ,       8000              (2).
* Notes that the purpose of the German "...      ,        ,        ,         " (2b).
** Germans also have a special emphasis on dialects: ...       ,           (2b).
* Also discusses Austria (3), England (5)
* Notes that the Ministry of Internal Affairs involves itself in teaching foreign languages in three out of the four discussed countries, and the fourth - England - is currently investigating doing just that (5-5b).

Russia
*  1883      .                      ;      11  1885 " (9).
** The ultimate goal of the courses was service in "...    " (9).
** It also included funding for  in Turkey and Persia (9).
** Direct connection with British India:                  "" ()  ,             (, , );            .         ,  ,         ;  ,  -  - ,            (, , --,     (9b).

[[Tazkirat Index]]
[[Miklukho-Maklai, Persidskie i Tadzhikskie Rukopisi Instituta Vostokovedeniia]]

> Abd al-Am Muammad Munsh mutakhallis ba Sm, Mirt al-Khayl

       -   (p. 540, 4002; C 1943)

* Written in 1322 in honor of Abd al-Ahad. Described in in Miklukho-Maklai's Opisanie, vol. 2, No. 123, and Khadizade p. 127.
* Mostly written in verse except at the end.  Of broader scope than just poets; concerned with praising various aspects of Abd al-Ahad's rule.

!!!Alphabetical poetical tazkirat (175b-191)

Ayyat
* No information of value, just praise.

Tahsin       (p. 176-176b)
* Confirms his descent from Rahmatallah and appointment as a Qazi in Kamat / Vabkand.

Tajir        /     (p. 176b-177)
* No new information not already given by [[Muhtaram|j Nimatallah, Takirat al-Shuar-i Mutaram (al-Biruni 2252 II)]]

Tamkin        (p. 177-179b)
* Notorious for his caustic poetry (177-177b):              []   []  
** (cont.) (177b):                    
** (cont.) Example from a majlis (177b):                                                                                       
* //continue revisit//
* An anecdote commonly told by Tamkin about a dispute between a Hindu and Jewish moneylender (178b).

Hazini        (p. 179b-182)
* Sami has this individual as a Naqshbandi, whereas [[Pirmasti|Afl al-Takr fi ikr al-Shuar va al-Ashr (al-Biruni 2303)]] had him as a Kubravi (180):           
* Long ago Hazini was a local village imam (180):             
** People in the village purchased a photograph from a European store of a local girl in her youth and gave it to Hazini (180b):                                                                              
** (cont.) (180b):                                          
** (cont.) (180b-181):                                  
** (cont.) Fard on tricking Hazini (181):  -      -     
                           -  -       [ ] -      
* The punchline is that the picture was from a long time ago so he ended up marrying an old woman.  Note that this story is also in [[Pirmasti|Afl al-Takr fi ikr al-Shuar va al-Ashr (al-Biruni 2303)]]




[[Jung Literature from al-Biruni Card Catalog]]

> abballah bin Jall al-usayn, Jung-i Majmah-i Rivyt

2802   
* Author:        

General Notes
* Pagination is very strange in this manuscript; there are page numbers penciled in every 10-20 pages or so, hence references will be somewhat rough.
* Date references: 1265 (p. 14); 1258 (p. 24).
* Rivayat are arranged in the standard order of a fiqh manual.

[[Tazkirat Index]]
[[Manuscripts Index]]

> Sayyid Mr adq Trah ashmat, Takirat al-Shuar (al-Biruni 2728, 61)

  

[[Semenov|Semenov, ed., Sobranie Vostochnykh Rukopisei Akademii Nauk Uzbekskoi SSR]] 1, p. 141; 343, 2728/II; the second volume is #61.
*    (Vol. 7, 1987) on this tazkirat: 2 volumes, the first about 85 poets, the second about 88; included lots of information about poets from Afghanistan and Iran as well (p. 229).
* Note that Hashmat used Vazih as a source for some of his data:       . 19        ,    (.   )      " (p. 229). Though he also added in scholars who lived after the publication of Vazih.
* This author had a second go at this work under the same title and under # 2729 in the collection.

General Observations
* There are few original entries in this tazkirat.  Most poets are already described in other tazkirat, especially [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]].
* Most of the poets are Bukharan, but there are also Iranian and Indian exemplars.
* Hashmat is pretty good about citing his sources when he is drawing the information from elsewhere.

Azad (5b-8)
* An Indian poet Hashmat learned about from  .  This is Azad Bilgrami, famous enough to have his own wikipedia page.
* Opening (5b):    ...      
* (cont.) Origin (5b):                 [
* Birth: 1116

Afghan (8-12b)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]
*      []           []          []                 []       []  []                            []        
* //revisit - about the conquest of a fortress with Shah Murad - see p. 9b//

Ada (12b-13)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]
* Marginalia (12b)       []            []     [ ]            []          []              []     []              []                         
** uzbek poerty:
***          = dar javoni dil nakandam az dilraboyon 
***              = dar piri az baroyi chi? [dil] kandam az [onho] baroi asoho.  

Ansab (13-13b)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

Akbar (13b-14)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

Amir (i.e. Umar Khan) (14-15)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]
* (14):                       
** (cont.) Marginal note on Timurid legacy (14):                

Amlah (15-15b)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

I'raj (15b-16)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

Afqar (16-16b)
* Also covered in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]]

Asiri (17-18)
* Also covered in [[j Nimatallah, Takirat al-Shuar-i Mutaram (al-Biruni 2252 II)]]

Arzu (18b-19)
* Indian poet
* Opening (18b):             
* (cont.) Ancestry (18b):

 __Abd al-Rasul al-Bukharli   __ //the 'l' in Bukharli is not a typo, at least on my part//

* Immigrated from Bukhara to Damascus where he was accepted by commmoners and nobles alike (  ).
* Bukharli's qualities:  ,  ,   ,        ,  ,  ,    ,    ,    
* Exact date of death:   25   1297

Hijri (177)
