[[Fihrist-i Nuskhah-yi Kha-yi Frs-yi Kitb Khnah-i Nadvat al-Ulam]]

> lt-i Shi Ghulm Al Amad

No.  140, p. 710:     
* Nadwa designation: Tazkira 51
* Written 1299, 3 pages.

* Birth (1):      1258   [  ]  
* (cont.) Sayyid claim (1):            
* Graduated at age 22 and took the mujaddidi Sufi path (1):                      [  ]    

[[Translated Sources Index]]

> Sharf Jn Makhdm adr Ziy and Edward Allworth, The Personal History of a Bukharan Intellectual, ed. Rustam Shukurov and Muammadjon Shukurov (Leiden: Brill, 2004).

See also: Stephane Dudoignon, Faction struggles among the Bukharan ulama during the colonial, the revolutionary and the early Soviet periods (1826-1929): a paradigm for history writing?, in Muslim Societies: Historical and comparative aspects, ed. Sato Tsugitaka (London: RoutledgeCurzon, 2004), 62-96.

* The work in question (Editor's Note - Edward Alworth): "Dr. Rustam M. Shukurov, who teaches in the Faculty of History, Moscow State University, lists some of his most recent contributions to scholarship in the biographical section given below. In the present study, he translated from Persian or Tajik into English and annotated with great sensitivity and care both the basic manuscript text of the Diary (Rznma) and the extensive Introduction. Furthermore, his intimate knowledge about the life of his grandfather, adr-i iy, confers special authenticity upon the Translators rendition of every page in this book" (xiii).
* Notes from the Project Director Shahrbanou Tadjbakhsh: "The project took almost ten years to bear fruit, from 1993 to 2002, a long process in search of reestablishing the links that were thought to have been broken when typhoid hit the madrasah of Sharifi-Ghaziyan (Mull Muhammad-Sharf madrasah in the quarter of ziyn) turned prison during the purges of 1932 in Bukhara. During that period,  Sadr-i Ziya died, and his son was shipped off to live with his aunt, and then to Stalinabad, the capital of a new republic of Tajikistan. Sadr-i Zias personal Diary, together with his and the Amrs personal libraries, were sent to the Institute of Oriental Studies in Tashkent..." (xix).
** Sadr-i Ziya was a patron of Aini, among others: "He used what we would call today his good oces, his position, his own home, often his personal funds and his vast imagination, to create a venue for thinkers through literary salons at the end of the century. Later, as political events drove these thinkers into revolutionary action, he chose instead to devote his time to diligently recording the creations of poets, calligraphers, architects and politicians" (xxii).

Introduction by Muhammadjon Shakuri (Shukurov): "Sadr-i Ziya and his //Diary//"
* //Useful information, but Shukurov also spends a great deal of time defending the legacy of his father against the slander of other Jadids//
* Is this the definition of the Ulama?: "His name was sharif.  __Makhdum was the appelation given to offspring of the 'ulama__ (the intellectual, judicial and theological elite of Bukhara)... Sadr was the 'scholarly title which, in the last decades of the Amirate of Bukhara, was the highest in dignity in the third in order following after the inferior titles of uraq and sudur.  Ziya was his literary name" (1).
* Son of a merchant; sent to a madrassa when his talents were noticed (1).
* Majlises: "We learn from Sadr. al-Din-i 'Ayni that every week 'on school holidays, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the house of Sharif-jan Makhdum turned into a gatehring place of poets, devotees of poesy, tellers of entertaining anrratives and wits'" (2).
* Sadr Ziya was a student and admirer of Ahmad Danish, another 19th century luminary (4).
* Relationship with Jadidism: "Sharif-jan Makhdum never took direct part in the Jadid movement, yet the Jadids always benefited from his moral and material support and assistance" (5).
* Amir issues reform manifesto 17 April 1917: "On the 8th (21st) of April, progressivists organized a demonstration of gratitude throughout the city. As demonstrators progressed toward the Rgistn, where the Ark was situated, they were surrounded by students and mullahs, conservative opponents to the reforms. The Amrs soldiers then dispersed the demonstrators and arrested a number of the Jadds. Pressure increased, and the eect of the Reform Manifesto, having not become operational yet, was reduced" (10).
** "Thus, the post of Sharif-jan Makhdum-i Sadr-i Ziya as Chief Justice lasted only for fteen days, from March 26 to April 9 1917 (or from the 8th to 22nd of April according to Gregorian calendar). In the history of the Bukharan Amirate, we can hardly  nd any other person who served such a short term in this position" (12).
* Died in a madrassa turned into a prison: "The prison was located in the madrasah of Mullah Muhammad-Sharif (in the quarter of Ghaziyan) and this was the name of Sadri-i Ziya himself" (15).
* Possible major souce: "For example [of one of his many works], one of his roughts, which is kept as Number 2367 in the Collection of the Institute of Oriental Studies of the Academy of Sciences in Tashkent, contains much information on his schoolmates, on the visit of the Amir of Bukhara to Russia, about the relations between Bukhara and Afghanistan, samples of his own letters and applications... consisting of more than 60 stories" (17).
* Bukharan Enlightenment in caps, huh?  "Sady-i Ziya was one of those writers of the Bukharan Enlightenment who contributed to the beginning of the foundation of the national Tajik literature" (18).
** Tajik nationalism: "Writers began to pay more attention to national and social realities, their specic concerns and their local peculiarities, to those traits which dierentiated the specic experience of the Tajik people from that of Persian-speakers of othercountries, Afghanistan and Iran. The general humanistic approach of literature, a common feature for Persian-speaking literature, did not decrease, but the specic Tajik national and local color and characteristics increased. Until then, the Persian-speaking literature of Mawarannahr par excellence was Persian literature; it became Persian Tajik literature from then on" (18-19).
** More on the so-called Enlightenment: "The Bukharan Enlightenment was an ideology of national revival. The agents of Enlightenment hoped to achieve the revival by means of uplifting culture (in a general sense) and spirituality, being sure that edication and general cultural betterment would lead the coun-try to spiritual revival (37).
* Lists most of Zia's various works on p. 21.
* Zia's objective: "The main reason why he would turn to history was his search for the ideal of the just king and the prudent minister.  He wanted to define the ideal characteristics of kings and ministers and their rule, in order to be taken into account in the social and political reforms of the day" (22).
** Zia had biographies of the poets as well (22).
*** one was published in Iran: Sharif-jan Makhdum-i Sadr-i Ziya, Tazkar-i ash'ar.  Sharh=i hal-i barkhiaz sha'iran-i mu'asir-i Tajikistan wa namunahayi az shi'r anan, ba tashih-i Sahab al-Din-i Siddiq (Tehran, "Soroush Press", 1380/2002) (23).
* Check out some of these sources: Zikr-i chand nafar 'ulama-i dawr-i akhir (On some 'ulama of the Last Epoch); other great citations on this page (24).
** Also (!): Zikr-i asam-i madaris-i dakhila-i Bukhara-i Sharif (On the Madrasahs, Located in Noble Bukhara).  No. 2193XIII at Biruni. 400 pages.
*** "Sadr-i Ziya mentioned two hundred and four madrasahs, with an indication of their location in the city. His mentioning the number of cells is also important because it shows the size and capacity of a madrasah. On the basis of Sadr-i Ziyas list one may learn that the biggest madrasahs had up to one hundred and forty-seven cells (such as, for instance, the famous Kulkaltash madrasah), while the smallest ones had only eight or nine cells; some madrasahs had only two cells (such as Mehtar 'rif madrasah). The number of those madrasahs which had more than twenty cells added up to sixty; twenty madrasahs had more than  fty cells. In the last column of the table the author gave the name of a person who built the madrasah, the year of construction or the name of the Bukharan Amr during whose reign the madrasah was build" (27).
* Aini's unabridged Yaddashtha consists of about four volumes and 1000 pages (25).
* Timespan of the diary: 1306/1929 - 1348/1929 (30).
* Gaps in Zia's account: "Why did Sadr-i Zia dedicate about twenty pages of his diary and plenty of details to the Russian-Japanese War, while completely neglecting in some sense the heroic ght of Tajik intellectuals of the Enlightenment who brought Bukhara out of backwardness?" (34).
** "Completely ignor-ing such notable events as the emergence of new method schools, publishing of the new text-books and rst liberal newspaper, starting of anti-Jadd persecutions by the authorities and the like..." (36).
* Jadids vs. Qadimis: Jadids led by Mufti Ikram / Mulla Ikramcha (1847-1925); Qadimis led by qazi Burhan al-Din, Bukharan chief Justice (37).
* Zia followed Danish's example: "Ahmad-i Danish and his followers opened their eyes, seeking for an exemplar, to the order of life, in other coun-tries and nations, which they compared with the habits of their home-land" (39).
* Stance towards colonialism and the Amir of Bukhara: "It is clear that the writers tonality in regard to both oppressing colonizers and those who failed to defend the nation against oppres-sors is very sharp. This was also a broad hint to the Bukharan amirs who had been unable to defend their nation and country" (44).
* Shukuri considers Zia a man of the "Central Asian Enlightenment" (46).

!!!The Diary (Translated Persian)


[[Assorted Khuda Bakhsh (Patna) Catalogs]]

> adr al-Dn Amad al-Bhr al-Bardavn, Ravay al-Muaf min Azhr al-Murta (Khuda Bakhsh1884 c.e.)

     by            (cat. vol. 8, p. 167-168, no. 724) (hand. vol. 1, p. 44, 245, no. 245)
* 2 vols., 300 pages; author born in 1843, completed work in 1885, died 1905.  The work was lithographed in Cawnpore in 1307.
* "An exhaustive work in two volumes, containing notices and accounts of Imams, Ulama, and Saints, ancient and modern" (167).
* "The author is chiefly to be remembered as the donor of the Buhar Library (Imperial Library, Calcutta), a collection of 960 Arabic and Persian MSS. and 1500 Arabic, Persian and Urdu books, printed or lithographed" (167).
* Organized alphabetically, not chronologically.

> Lithograph edition:            1308

Badr al-Din Bukhari         (p. 366)
* Spiritual lineage:             [ / ]  
* Travels - Went to Delhi to study from Bukhara, found that lacking, then set off for Bukhara:                                     
* (cont.)  On his way back to Bukhara Badr al-Din ran into the darvish Hazrat Ganj Shukr; initially, he was disdainful of sufis, but in a confrontation Ganj Shukr won him over and he became Shukr's khalifa:                                                                                                                                          
* Died 690 h.

Yusuf Muhammad Kashmiri    []   (p. 389)
* A merchant from Kashmir, until he was overtaken by jazb:                   
* (cont.) Sufi training, went on the hajj, returned to Kashmir:                           [ / ]   
* Died in that qasbah 1111.

* Part of the Naqshbandi order (371):                 []

> Sharf Jn Makhdm adr , Takr-i Ashr, ed. Shakr Bukhr (Tehran: Soroush Press, 2001).

> Sharf Jn Makhdm adr , Tadhkr-i Ashr, ed. Shakr Bukhr (Tehran: Soroush Press, 2001), 342-343.

Edited Tehrani edition of the most important of Zia's tazkirat (according to     , the editor of the volume):              .         (p. 3).  The appendices of the edition, however, pulls biographical entries in from all of Zia's aforementioned works, as well as Zia's additions to the tazkirat   .

Akram      (p. 286-287)
* //Editor's note that [[Aini's memoirs|Aini, Yaddashtha (Tajik edition 2009)]] also have a great deal of information on this individual.//
* Takhallus: 
* Born 1271 / 1854; Died 1344 / 1925

* His reformist writings earned him the ire of the amir (286):

* Imprisoned in Khuzar until the revolution (287):                      ...      
** A conflicting report by Zia says that he was killed in Khuzar (287).

Afzal Makhdum (p. 287-288)
*   died 1334 / 1916.
* Abd al-Ahad Khan patronized a collection of courtly poets; Afzal Makhdum was one of them and he had Badr al-Din, the Qazi Kalan, to find him for him (287):                          
** Qazi Badr al-Din was Qazi Kalon from 1889-1908 and persecuted the reformists, as did his son Burhan al-Din after him who had the same position from 1913-1920 (editor's comments 381).
* Apparently Afzal wrote his own tazkirat to which Sadr Zia's own work was written in response to (editor's comments 365):    "      "                " "      
** Afzal wrote this tazkira at Abd al-Ahad's orders and Sadir Zia did not think much of it (288):                
* Zia writes that he was flawed in all of his academic pursuits and that he betrayed his teacher, Ahmad Danish (288):           (  (                   
* Served Muzaffar Khan's son   in Chorjuy; it was there that he wrote his tazkirat (289):

* Along with his brother died during Russia's conquest of Bukhara (290):

* Nadir Shah - Manghits: 37-53b

!!!           Recollections of Abu al-Faiz (and Nadir Shah) (p. 37-38b)
p. 37
* Abu al-Faiz's country was a mess and as a result Muhammad Hakim Bay Manghit managed things:                        
* Nadir Shah controls all of Turko-Persia:                     [] 
* Rizaquli crosses into Transoxiana via Termiz in 1151.  Listing the individual invaders:                [  ]          
* Battle of Qarshi is a draw:                                    
* Nadir Shah crosses:                                               []     
* Nadir crosses the Amu and moves on Bukhara, tells Abu al-Fayz that he could take the city easily if he wanted to, but really he just came to visit the Chorbakrs:                                                                   
* Nadir reconfigures power relations in Bukhara:                            
p. 37b
* (cont.):                                [
** Note that Hadi Khwaja wrote a travel log in which he meets Nadir Shah in Iraq: [[Safarnmah-i Q Hd Khwjah az Bukhr bah Irn (al-Biruni 5255/XVIII)]]; also mentioned in Zia's [[autobiography of his father|adr , ikr-i Chand Nafar-i Ulam-i Mutabbair-i Nmdr, al-Biruni 1304/IV]]
* Nadir Shah presented a gift of three thrones - one for Amla, one for himself, and one for Abu al-Fayz:                          
* Every one comes to venerate Nadir Shah:     [=  ]                                                      [ / ]           
** Note that this founding of the Muhammad Sharif madrasa is also in [[Muhammad akm Khn, Muntakhab al-Tavrkh 1842: Nadir Shah]]
* Nadir Shah as a secret Sunni:                            
* Appointing Rahim Ataliq to rule:       []

* Then Rahim's father   dies and Bukhara falls into general chaos:                                         []

p. 38
* (cont.) Pillaging a Naqshband shrine:                  []

* The Khoqand Khan turns back after reaching Miankul, prompting both Rahim and Abu al-Fayz to appeal to Nadir Shah, who sends troops to deal with the Kinagas in Shahrisabz:

p. 38b
* When Rahim Khan gets to Charjuy he hears of Nadir's death, he hurries to Bukhara and conceals the news and summons the Shaykh al-Islam to depose Abu al-Fayz:        [ ]                                         
* In 1160 Rahim Khan marches on Bukhara with an army and deposes Abu al-Fayz in favor of his son   
** Abu al-Fayz was advised to abdicate in favor of his son and go on the hajj by an informant in Rahim's camp.
** Abu al-Fayz was sent to Juybar for retirement:                         
* Nadir Shah's sons (really?) Hasan Khan and Bihbud Khan (the same ones who previously dealt with the Kinagas uprising) support Abu al-Fayz and attempt to retake Bukhara:                                                                                        
* (cont.) The approach of Qizilbash troops is what prompts Rahim to execute Abu al-Fayz Khan:                        
** Some say that Nadir and Abu al-Fayz's deaths fell on the same day:   []                 
** Ultimately, Rahim Khan drives Nadir Shah's children across the Amu Darya.

!!!                  Reign of Haydar (42b-45)
* Legitimacy comes from the line of Abu al-Fayz (42b):                
* Haydar was so pious and learned that he conducted religious tests personally (42b):                                       (p. 42b).
* Portrays the age of Haydar as a golden age (42b-43):                                             
** note his neutral take on vocal vs. silent zikr.
* After setting the stage of the early 19th century, Zia lists prominent after   in the previous sentence, starting with    , who is described in more detail in his [[biographical dictionary of the calligraphers|Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]]
* Khalifa Husayn and his descendants:                                                                    [=]                               
** note (a) that he is identified primarily as a sufi but is giving khutbas like any other alim and (b) that his responsibilities are transferring from generation to generation.
* List of prominent ulama under Haydar //mostly just names and hence only entered into the database, except the following exceptions// (43):
**             
** Not added:    
* Shaykh al-Islam under Haydar (43):                                 []                                           
** //not totally clear why Zia is discussing Hadi Khwajah and his son since they both died before the reign of Haydar//
** (cont.) Hadi Khwajah's students (43):                                
*** Inayatallah here must be referring to             ; language is not totally clear that these are Hadi's students and not his son Ataallah's, but since none of those students appear on [[Majrani's list|Marjn, Wafiyyat al-Aslf, 19th century]], must be his father's. Zia also mentions that Ataalah's son (Rahmatullah al-Sharif) became Qazi Kalan, which fits with Marjani, though Zia does not mention the name.
* (cont.) Ishan Sharif Khwajah Mavlavi (43):                                    
* Attributes the attraction of so many great ulama to Haydar's own religious stature (43):                          
* //p. 43b-44: political / military history to be revisited//
* The destruction of Marv; resuscitation of Marv when the Russians build a railroad in 1888 (44):                           []                                                                            []                        135 [= 1305]                        
* Construction and appointment of madrasa Sadr Bay (44b):                                        
* (cont.) More on Niazquli (44b-45):    []                                    
* (cont.) Abu Nasr Tughi (45):                                     
** Exiled to Ottoman lands for heresy.  His teacher, Damalla Hasan, is described in [[adr , Takr-i Ashr]].  The other teacher, Damalla Mirak Jan A'lam, is descrived in [[Vazih|Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]].
* Damalla Haji Bay Sadr Khujandi (45):                                
** Marginal note about Rafi' Khujandi (45):              1285 [ ]

!!!           Muzaffar Khan (46b-49b)
* Muzaffar came to Bukhara from Karmina in 1277, where he was presumably serving as governor (46b).
* Everyone payed tribute except the kuhistan; rebellion breaks out (46b):                          @@@@                           
* (cont.) Muzaffar's response (46b):                    @@  @@        [  ]                                                                                            [ ]

* Muzaffar goes on to conquer Uratappa and even Khoqand itself (46b):                 
** Khudayar Khan of Khoqand gets deposed in favor of Sultan Murad, but ends up with a position (46b):                             
* Two years later (after a previous two years, so probably like 1864) Muzaffar again conquers Khoqand and once again installs Khudayar Khan as ruler (46b).
* Revenge of the Kinagis in Shahrisabz.  As Muzaffar is returning from his victory over Khoqand... (46b-47):                                                             
* (cont.) Russia enters the stage (47):                                         1282                                []             []

* (cont.) And, of course, the freaking Kinagis get uppity (47):        []

> Sharf Jn Makhdm adr , Tarjuma-i Avl-i Q Abd al-Shukr

ikr-i Chand Nafar-i Ulam-i Mutabbair-i Nmdr, al-Biruni 1304/III

* Note: this is the same call number as one of the two ruznamas, the other being 2277.  I.e. physically bound in the same volume as [[Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]].
* Note: These notes are wrongly titled; "Zikr-i Chand Nafar..." is just a title of a sub-section of 1304/IV, which as a whole is marked:     

!!!            
* Family tree (98b):                 
* Moving to Bukhara in the era of Haydar (98b):                                 
** based on subsequent statements,  appears to be the name of a Turkmen tribe (see below).
* Abd al-Rasul worked as a tanner in Vabkand (98b):                                                    
* Nasrullah's Turkman blood (98b):                 []   ...
** Author comments that they often had Turkmen guests as well as guests from the tanners (98b).
* Abd al-Rasul's children:                                  
* While his grandfather's family was poor, they were nevertheless rich in faith and from the ranks of ulama (99):                         
** This status should run through the family; Abd al-Rasul hopes the same will be true of his son, sends him (Zia's father) to a maktab in their neighborhood (99):                        
* Friends of the family with high spiritual cred, who also apparently taught Shukuri in the maktab (99):                                                      
* From there Shukuri went on to study at the Kavkashan under Mulla Mirza Salih 'Alam.  Even though Shukuri had achieved great knowledge already, Sufi Khwaja was not satisfied... (99):                                               
** Admittance exam (99):      
** Mirza Salih has platonic knowledge, amongst other qualities (99):                 
** Mirza Salih always had tea ready to serve people in the madrasa (even non-students) and osh ready to share from his home, which was located not far from the madrasa (99b):                           .                            []      
** However, Mirza Salih died before Shukuri could complete his training (99b). All the great ulama of the age attended (99b):    [ ]                                         
*** Note that the Qazi Kalan is discussed in [[Vai, Tufat al-Abb fi Takirat al-b]].
*** People came from far and wide for the funeral (100).
* A new teacher in Kukaltash (100):                           
* Shukuri quickly surpassed his peers, which caused tension (100):                 
** Also, the teacher was apparently going senile with old age, which meant that Shukuri ended up teaching the classes (100):                                 
** Which caused resentment (note the implication that Mulla Abd al-Rahman is from Hisar and hence a mountain bumpkin) (100):                                                          [ \ ]      
* [revisit how this situation gets resolved - difficult prose]
* The Qazi Kalan 'Inayatullah intervenes (against custom) to get Shukuri appointed mudarris of Ghaws-i Arabl Qazi Kalan asks him why he has not taken a post at a madrasa since he is already training so many students and is stunned at the humbleness of his response (100b):                                                                   ...                                                 
** Amir Nasrullah becomes involved (100b):                                                 []        
* For his next appointment he required no patron (100b):              [] 
* Shukuri found unparalleled favor with the amir (101):        
* Shukuri gets appointed to the Mulla Iyrnazar madrasa, which is apparently very prestigious (101):                            
** Amir Nasrullah appointed him there without the prompting of the qazi kalan (101):                        
* Zia spends a lot of time praising his pop. Says that Shukuri attracted students from far and wide; commentary on prestige of madrasa vs. teacher (101):                                   
* At this point Amir Nasruallah dies and Muzaffar takes the throne (101):                             
** However, Muzaffar was taken with bad ulama (101):                                                  
*** This is the Khatlani-Tumani dispute discussed in Stephane Dudoignon, Faction struggles among the Bukharan ulama during the colonial, the revolutionary and the early Soviet periods (1826-1929): a paradigm for history writing?, in Muslim Societies: Historical and comparative aspects, ed. Sato Tsugitaka (London: RoutledgeCurzon, 2004), 62-96, which draws from the same source.
*** For instance, he appointed a Khatlani qazi kalon (101):            
* At this point Shukuri was appointed judge of Zia al-Din for one year (101b).
* In this period Sadr Zia himself was born in Zia al-Din on Friday evening 27 Ramadan, which is also where his name comes from (101b).
* After that year, Shukuri goes to Qarakul to serve as judge, during the course of which he engages in a major legal disagreement with Sadr al-Din Khatlani Qazi Kalon (102):                                                                                                   []                            
** Shukuri sends a letter back to the Amir saying that the ruling is wrong and surely there must be a mistake (102):
** In response Muzaffar sends the matter to a council of ulama, who review both sides of the dispute (102):
** Ultimately, they decide in Shukuri's favor, and Muzaffar tears up the Qazi Kalons' ruling (102b):                                           
* As a reward, Muzaffar appoints Shukuri mufti and teacher of Mulana Miskin madrasa (102b).
* Shukuri also worked as Ilchi; sent on an embassy to Khoqand 1286 (103):      
** //revisit details of his interaction with Khoqand ambassador//
* After that Shukuri is appointed ra'is of Bukhara, mudarris of Muhammad Sharif madrasa, and upgrades his crib as a result (103b):                                []    []                                                
** Improved house was necessary for hosting friends (not Turk-Tajik distinction) (103b):                        
* Shukuri moved to Tursun Khan madrasa, where he taught for the rest of his days:                                        
106b

!!!             (p. 116b-
* A biography of an ancestor of some kind (ka'bagah?; possibly an ancestor on his mother's side) (116b):        
* Was one of Hadi Khwaja's students (116b):         
** See also: [[Safarnmah-i Q Hd Khwjah az Bukhr bah Irn (al-Biruni 5255/XVIII)]]
** Hadi Khwaja was a bit of a dervish it seems (116b):           
* Meeting with Nadir Shah in Chorbakr; all Nadir wanted was to know the truth (116b-117):                                                                                                                   
** For another discussion of these events by Zia see: [[adr , Trkh-i Saln Uthmn va Nasab-i Ishn (al-Biruni 1304-II)]].  Notice that in that other text he credits primarily another individual for this victory.
** (cont.)                                                  
** Hanafi madhab solidarity (describing Mirza Umid) (117):         
* Mentions somewhat abruptly that Mirza Sharif, a famous mufti under Shah Murad and Haydar, is Mirza Umid's son (and hence Sabir's brother) (117):                             
* More on Mirza Umid's legacy (117):                                      
** Ulugh Bek and explaining the term mirza (117):                                
** But the term lost its original meaning; Mirza Umid is a descendant of Ulugh Bek (117b):                                                          
*** (117b)                                          
* Sadr Zia has copies of Sabir Jan's excellent calligraphy in his personal collection (117b).
* Sabir Jan tutored the prince - son of Amir Haydar (117b):                             
** Zia has great admiration for Husayn Khan Tura; pity he did not remain khan longer (he reigned forty days until his death?) (117b):                      
* Sabir Jan had a brother that was similar to him in almost every respect: (118):                       
** Bit of a dervish (118b):             
* Zia's maternal grandfather (118b):                          
** Grew up in the court of Amir Haydar (118b):                                        
* Once Nasrallah took the throne he sent Ubayd and Zubayd khans to the vilayat of Narzum (sp. ?) (p. 118b):                  
** Nasrallah honored Kiramatallah and asked whether he would stay in Bukhara or go with the two princes; Nasrallah was annoyed when he chose the latter, but still gave him the qaziship of that province (119):                                                                                                          
* After six months Nasruallah executed the youths and threw Kiramatallah in prison (119):                                  ...                        
* From this point Zia goes into a tail about an old dervish calling out Nasrallah on the street to answer for wrongfully imprisoning Kiramatallah
** Nasrallah's shrine visitation schedule and routine (119):               []         []                                                             [ ]                                           
** (cont.) (119b):                                                                                                                                                                       
** (119b):                                                            
** What will you say on judgment day, o' amir? Today you are a snake, but tomorrow you will be an ant (120):                                                         
** Ulama vs. amir (120):                                                          
*** (cont.) //not totally sure what this reference to Ada is// (120):                     
** All onlookers are shocked by the encounter (120):                                               
** Nasrallah's reaction - sobbing, orders a guard () to summon Kiramatallah to him (120-121b):                                      ...                                                      
** Proceeds to reward Kiramatallah greatly, including appointing him qazi of Kamat (121b):                                                                         
** //finish reading the tale from middle of p. 120b//
* Kiramatallah served as qazi of Kamat for about a year, during the tenure of which he died of tuberculosis (121):            [=   ]                                   
* Kiramatallah was an innovative calligraphist who invented his own style (121):                    
* Kiramatallah had a younger brother - Hidayatallah - who was appointed a mirza by Nasrallah then later to various qazi appointments (121):                             
* (cont.) Books written (121):                          
* Hidayatallah had a son named  , but the son died early (121).
* Kiramatallah had four sons and a daughter (121):                                        
** Haji Inayatallah (see also [[Tazkirat al-Khattatan|Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]]) - accolades at an early age (121b):                                      
*** (cont.) Career after finishing studies - went on the hajj twice, during the course of which he went to Kashgar and served Yaqub (121b):                                           
*** (cont.) Returned to Bukhara during the reign of Abd al-Ahad (121b):                                   
*** (cont.) From there appointed Qazi of Nasaf for a year, retired, went into seclusion, then died (121b):                                         []    
*** (cont.) Great feat of religious writing the Wiqaya (121b):                             
** Hikmatallah Katib
*** As also mentioned in [[Tazkirat al-Khattatan|Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]], he served as qazi in Ramitin, though here the connection to his father's position is made more explicit (121b):                
*** (cont.) Died of plague in Bukhara separately ( ) from Zia's father (121b):                       
*** Hikmatallah had a son: Mirza Ahmad Sayyid who fled with Alim Khan after the revolution (121b):                                                        
** Abd al-Aziz
*** Mudarris of Jafar Khwajah madrasa (122):   []            
*** (cont.) Death by plague on the same day as his brother (122):   1306                                
*** (cont.) His son was Abd al-Hafiz:                                
** Sadiq Makhdum - contented himself as a muezzin (122):                                        
*** Shukuri tried to use his position as Qazi Kalan to get him a better position, but he refused (122):                   \   ]   
*** Writings (//check up on these genres//):                  
*** He did not have any children.
* Zia's mother (i.e. Karamatallah's fifth child) moved with three of her brothers to Ghazian neighborhood (apparently Abd al-Aziz remained in the ancestral home), all of whom studied under Zia's father in the Ivaz Bay madrasa (122):                                                              
* Author recounts how his father invited over his mother and a marriage proposal was made.  Apparently his father's star had yet to rise at this point (122b):          
* Zia's maternal grandmother was an "Arab" (122b):                                           
** (cont.) On the legendary history of the Bukharan Arabs and the guzar Araban (122b):                                                              
* Kiramatallah evidently had multiple wives, because Zia's mother had a different mother than Inayatallah (122b):

* Opening (123):          1304                       []     
* (cont.) Plague deaths (123):

* (cont.) Zia's tenure as qazi of Khayrabad (123):         1310      
* Then to Yangi Qurghan as qazi for 15 months, where Sami was serving as ra'is at the same time (123).
** Though Zia said Sami was soon replaced by an illiterate idiot (123):                       
* In 1313 Zia became qazi of Pishkuh (Zandanay) for 17 months after sitting in Bukhara for 4 months.  Uncle Inayatallah visited during that time to  (123).
* In 1314 Zia became qazi of Khatarchi for 19 months, which was considered a promotion (123):     1314     
** Deaths of relatives at this time and a picture of the qazi's staff (123b):                          []              ...                                                
** Describing the hardship and misery (123b):           
* In 1316 Zia became qazi of    /  (p. 123b).
* In 1318 Zia became qazi of Charjuy (p. 124)
* In 1320 Zia became qazi of Karki for 2 years (124).
* In 1322 Zia became qazi of Vaghanza again (124b).
* In 1323 Zia became qazi of Kamat (124b).
** His predecessor in the qaziship was Abdallah Khwajah Sudur, who he discussed in [[Takirat al-Khan-i Mrz Muammad Sharf al-Mutakhallas bil- (al-Biruni 1304/III)]] (124b):                              
** On Abd al-Karim Shatir - illustrates the importance of patron  (125):                                                                        
** (cont.) Follows out of the ranks of elite ulama when Abd al-Shukur falls out of grace - //gives a sense of the relative importance of positions since the mudarris position was//       //against his wish of the Sudur position// (125):                                                      
** Shatir's children (125):                                                                         
*** //note (important): this text makes it seems like these were Shatir's children, but the appendix in the translated Ruznama indicates that they are Abd al-Jalil's children.//
* Friendship with Muhtaram, author of a [[poetical tazkirat|j Nimatallah, Takirat al-Shuar-i Mutaram (al-Biruni 2252 II)]], owner of a very nice horse as well as a chorbogh (125b):                                                    
** (cont.) Muhtaram arrived along with Qari Haydar Vaghanzagi, both riding donkeys (125b):                                                                           []   
*** Haydar died while qazi of Khuzar; Muhtaram died while qazi of Chiraghchi (125b):                        
* Discussing a serious earthquake, along with a long poem describing it, as well as one in Andijan (126-127).



!!!              

Akhund Damulla Shir Muhammad     (p. 153).
* These are a series of anecdotes about the Sulayman Khwajah character playing jokes on Shir Muhammad, who is exceedingly book-smart but not so street-smart.
* Lived in the time of       i.e. Shah Murad and Haydar (153).
* Appointed akhund of Kukultash (153):                      
** //notice that this particular madrasa is particularly exalted//
* Learned in all the arts (153):                 
* Tale about Shir Muhammad thinking that Euclid was an animal (153):            []       []                               []                                                      
**                                                    [ - ]     
**                                               
**                                        
* Shir Muhammad had an astonishing number of students (153b):                        []   
* Another story also attests to the extraordinary popularity of Shir Muhammad (154b):                                                                             

Abu al-Hay Khwajah Shaykh al-Islam "Qazi Kalan Shall" and his family
* So named because his lower side was paralyzed (154b):                                                      
* Abu al-Hay's son Abu Sa'id was also appointed Qazi Kalan of Samarkand (155b):                      -          []        
* Third son of Abu al-Hay Sudur's sons (Qazi Kalan Shall's grandson) died while studying (not in database) (155b):       
* Info on another son of Qazi Kalan Shall, who also immigrated to Bukhara after the Russian conquest and became a qazi (155b):                                            

Akhund Damulla Hasan (156)
* Teacher at Kukaltash under Murad and Haydar; originally from Vaghanza (156):                             
* Zia's father was one of his students (156):                            
* (cont.) Story about Akhund Damullah Hasan wearing a ridiculous amount of clothing during cold weather and getting laughed at by his students (156):
** (cont.) One of his students brings him a curious blanket from Baljuvan (156):                                             [ / ]                          []                                             
** (cont.) Hasan is late to class because he is bundling up in clothes to face the cold (156):                                                                                                       []                 [ / ]      [  ]                []  
** Hasan spent many hours puzzling over the Tajik word "kampal", and comes up with an answer (156b):                                                                                                        
** (cont.) The amirs of old had a tradition of visiting all the different madrasas when they passed by (156b):                                           
** (cont.) In this case Murad had to get his men to help carry Hasan up the stairs because his clothes were so heavy (157):                                                                                                                         []                           []                []
